BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************************\n \n\nReferences\n However, hunters and owners of hunting dogs are at high risk for transmission of brucellosis from wildlife. \n\nLittle information, including that for pathogenesis or duration of bacteremia, is available for _", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-05 00:00:00", "2011-03-24 00:00:00", "2015-01-13 00:00:00", "1986-03-24 00:00:00", "0280-05-24 00:00:00", "1183-05-10 00:00:00", "1994-03-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corazza R", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3123696", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - USA: (MT) ex WY NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3123696", "date": "2015-01-27 20:53:25", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CERVID - USA: (MONTANA) ex WYOMING NOT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 Jan 2015\nSource: Billings Gazette [edited]\nhttp://billingsgazette.com/lifestyles/recreation/genetic-data-sheds-new-light-on-brucellosis-in-montana/article_aa7f56e9-9351-5c5e-a09a-e9adeb51b5f1.html\n\n\nFor years, wildlife managers and biologists have contended that the disease brucellosis was spread to Yellowstone National Park and into Montana via wild elk and bison that had visited Wyoming's winter feedgrounds and carried the bacteria north, infecting other elk and bison.\n\nRecent research shows this is not true.\n\n'The data is suggesting very little connection between the Wyoming feedgrounds and Yellowstone and Paradise Valley elk,' said Pauline Kamath, a U.S. Geological Survey ecologist who works out of the Northern Rockies Science Center in Bozeman.\n\nFeedgrounds aren't totally scot-free, though. Kamath's research also showed that a large herd of elk that winters in the Madison Valley seems to have been infected by elk that visited a winter elk feeding ground in Idaho.\n\nKamath presented the results of her study Saturday [17 Jan 2015] at Montana State University during a brucellosis talk organized by Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks. About 50 people attended.\n\nWyoming was long blamed for Montana's problems because, since 1909, it has concentrated elk on winter feedgrounds, at 1st to keep the elk from eating ranchers' grass, and more recently to artificially sustain wildlife populations for the state's popular elk hunting industry. Last year [2014], there were more than 20 state-sponsored winter feedgrounds in western Wyoming.\n\nIt's widely accepted among scientists that brucellosis is more easily spread when animals are concentrated, such as on feedgrounds.\n\nBut Kamath's analysis of 250 tissue samples from elk, wild bison, farmed bison and cattle debunks the long-held belief that Montana's wildlife was infected by Wyoming's feedground practices.\n\nSimilar genetic research has been used to track whether a dentist infected his patients with HIV as well as to find out that severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) was transmitted to humans via an infected bat.\n\nBrucellosis can cause female ungulates to abort their 1st calves as well as infect humans with brucellosis. The most likely transmission source is when uninfected animals or people come into contact with aborted material from an infected host.\n\nAnother popularly circulated belief was that the outbreaks of brucellosis in cattle herds in the Paradise Valley, south of Livingston, were due to infected corriente cattle brought in from Mexico or Texas.\n\n'Based on the cases and isolates we have, there are no genetics from outside the (Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem) suggesting that,' Kamath said. 'It's very unlikely that something from outside is the source.'\n\nOver the last 3 years, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks has enacted measures such as hazing, fencing and lethal removal of elk to try to keep elk and cattle separated to prevent the disease from spreading to cattle. Opponents have charged that there's little evidence that elk are the source of the infections, but Kamath's research shows otherwise.\n\nBy examining the _Brucella abortus_ bacteria in tissue from infected animals, Kamath could trace the infection almost like a family tree, showing where it originally came from and where it had split off to different hosts.\n\n'It's pretty accepted that (brucellosis) was introduced into the system when they brought in dairy cattle,' Kamath said, marking the 1st time brucellosis was found in the Yellowstone, Paradise Valley areas.\n\nSeparate source animals brought brucellosis to Wyoming and Idaho, her analysis showed.\n\nYet without actually seeing a cow touch infected elk birthing material, Kamath said she couldn't say positively that elk were the source of outbreaks of brucellosis in Montana cattle. 'I can just say it was the most likely route of transmission,' based on the genetic analysis, she said.\n\nThe preponderance of evidence does point to elk as the source of outbreaks, though, said Neil Anderson, FWP lab supervisor in Bozeman.\n\n'I'm a wildlife guy, and I don't want it to come from elk,' he said. 'But it's hard to say that elk are probably not the source.'\n\nIn the 1930s the U.S. Department of Agriculture attempted to wipe out brucellosis in all livestock with an intensive eradication and vaccination program. The work was so successful that brucellosis is believed to only persist in the United States in wildlife in Montana, Wyoming and Idaho.\n\nWhat's odd is that the disease can be traced back in elk and bison in Montana and Wyoming 30 to 40 years, yet it's only in the last 7 years that cattle tested positive for brucellosis in Montana. Why that has happened is unknown. 'There's something that's driving this expansion in the system,' Kamath said.\n\nWildlife managers believe it may be higher concentrations of elk in Montana on private and public lands -- up to 2600 elk in some herds -- changes in elk movements, or simply because of increased surveillance.\n\n[Byline: Brett French]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and State animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection in 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. According to the superficial description of the research, these introductions were of different sources in Wyoming and Idaho. Unfortunately, the study has not yet been published to allow assessment of whether the conclusions posited are supported by the data.\n\nThe bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.]", "summary": "\n\nWyoming was long blamed for Montana's problems because, since 1909, it has concentrated elk on winter feedgrounds, at 1st to keep the elk from eating ranchers' grass, and more recently to artificially sustain wildlife populations for the state's popular elk hunting industry. \n\nWildlife managers believe it may be higher concentrations of elk in Montana on private and public lands -- up to 2600 elk in some herds -- changes in elk movements, or simply because of increased surveillance. \n\nOver the last 3 years, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks has enacted measures such as hazing, fencing and lethal removal of elk to try to keep elk and cattle separated to prevent the disease from spreading to cattle. \n\n\nFor years, wildlife managers and biologists have contended that the disease brucellosis was spread to Yellowstone National Park and into Montana via wild elk and bison that had visited Wyoming's winter feedgrounds and carried the bacteria north, infecting other elk and bison. Yet without actually seeing a cow touch infected elk birthing material, Kamath said she couldn't say positively that elk were the source of outbreaks of brucellosis in Montana cattle. ' \n\nWhat's odd is that the disease can be traced back in elk and bison in Montana and Wyoming 30 to 40 years, yet it's only in the last 7 years that cattle tested positive for brucellosis in Montana. Kamath's research also showed that a large herd of elk that winters in the Madison Valley seems to have been infected by elk that visited a winter elk feeding ground in Idaho. \n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term 'small ruminants', applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 'Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009' in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n'However', the authors of Ref 1 say, 'relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.'\n\n'In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.'\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2013; 32(1): 229-37.\nhttp://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/22denisov229237.pdf.\n2. Godfroid J, DeBolle X, Roop RM, O'Callaghan D, et al: The quest for a true One Health perspective of brucellosis\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2014, 33(2): 521-38\nhttp://www.oie.int/doc/ged/D14086.PDF. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/432.]", "summary": "\n\n'In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.' Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-24 00:00:00", "2001-03-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-24 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2013-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Danilovsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kalininsky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3377052", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, melitensis - UK ex Thailand: (NP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3377052", "date": "2015-05-21 12:24:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, MELITENSIS - UK ex THAILAND: (NAKOM PATHOM)\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 May 2015\nFrom: Dr Nicholas Beeching\n<Nicholas.Beeching@rlbuht.nhs.uk>\n\n\nA 51 year old UK resident presented to our clinic on 5 May 2015 with a 21-day history of daily rigors, profuse sweating attacks and high fever starting in mid-March 2015, followed by malaise, weight loss of 13 kg and intermittent fever and sweats for the next 4 weeks. This was associated with pain and swelling in his left knee, in which he had an uncomplicated total knee replacement 5 years previously for early-onset osteoarthritis following a motorcycling accident. There were no systemic abnormalities other than fever and there was an effusion in the symptomatic knee. Blood cultures yielded Gram negative coccobacilli after 3 days incubation (BioMerieux Bact/ALERT blood culture system), identified as _Brucella melitensis_ by MALDI-TOF (Bruker microflex LT), but not before 2 laboratory scientists had been exposed to open culture plates. Aspirate of cloudy fluid from the knee showed over 6000 lymphocytes and brucella organisms were cultured after 7 days' incubation. The patient has commenced a 3-month course of doxycycline and rifampin, together with parenteral gentamicin for the first 14 days. The exposed laboratory scientists were given doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 21 days as postexposure prophylaxis according to UK guidelines (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/brucella-reference-unit-bru-managing-laboratory-exposure).\n\nThe patient made frequent visits to Thailand, where he had stayed with a friend on his farm in Nakom Pathom province from 11 Dec 2014 to 8 Jan 2015. During that time he helped deliver several parturient goats and handled newly born kids and other products of conception with his bare hands. He had not consumed unpasteurized dairy products and had no contact with cattle or buffaloes. When his diagnosis was established, he informed us that a farm laborer was simultaneously being investigated in a Thai hospital for a mysterious fever. After the UK diagnosis was relayed to the physicians in Thailand, a diagnosis of brucellosis was thought likely and empiric treatment was commenced pending test results, with clinical improvement. The friend who owns the farm has now also been admitted with a similar illness, and investigations for suspected brucellosis are under way.\n\nDespite our local interest in brucellosis (1,2), this is not a diagnosis we would normally consider in a traveler returning from Thailand. As a contributing center, we reported this case within the GeoSentinel network and interrogated the GeoSentinel database, which now includes over 235 000 returning travellers (3). It includes only 82 patients with brucellosis. Only 22 from Asia: 2 cases from Thailand, 16 from South Central Asia (India 11, Iran 2, Nepal 2, Afghanistan 1) and 4 from North East Asia (China 2, Taiwan 1, 1 not specified).\n\nFoci in China, Mongolia and Central Eurasia are well recognised but the range of other countries newly affected by brucellosis continues to expand (4-6). Human infections seem to be grossly underreported compared to the patchy knowledge of its increasing incidence in livestock in South Asia (7). An outbreak of caprine and related human brucellosis in Ratchaburi Province in Thailand was reported in ProMed in 2003. The only other ProMed reports of brucellosis from this region included a boy who acquired brucellosis from raw goat's milk in Penang, Malaysia in 2010 and a German visitor who acquired brucellosis more recently in Myanmar, probably from drinking lassi. There have been sporadic case reports and 2 more detailed reviews of emerging brucellosis endemicity in Thailand over the past decade (8,9). As demonstrated by our patient, the highest risk to humans in Thailand is exposure to parturient goats (_B. melitensis_) but there is a separate risk of _B. abortus_ transmission from buffaloes. The areas of highest incidence appear to be Nakhon Si Thammarat Province and Kanchanaburi Province (8), which borders Nakom Pathom Province.\n\nClinicians should consider brucellosis as well as more commonly encountered causes of fever in returnees from Thailand and neighboring countries, such as dengue, scrub typhus, murine typhus, leptospirosis and malaria, and rarer bacterial infections such as melioidosis. A detailed risk exposure history will provide useful clues, and diagnosis of illness in travellers may aid diagnosis of unexplained illness in the country of origin.\n\nWe thank Elena Axelrod, David Hamer and Patricia Schlagenhauf for providing data from the GeoSentinel database and for helpful comments and we acknowledge our colleagues from the other 56 centres currently contributing data to the GeoSentinel network.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. The infection is also known as undulant fever, related to the occurrence of 1-3 week febrile periods separated by 1-3 days of afebrility. This occurs more likely with _B. melitensis_ (acquired from goats) as compared to _B. abortus_ (cattle) and _B. suis_ (swine).\n\nThe infection can be subclinical. Acute symptomatic brucellosis is generally manifest with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, chills, night sweats, anorexia, and an increased sense of ill health. The disease can be diagnosed serologically and/or by blood culture. The organism may grow quite slowly on primary isolation, and the clinician should make the microbiology laboratory aware of this potential diagnosis.\n\nLocalized infection may occur. Sites for localization include the skeletal system (1), heart valves (2) and urinary tract (3). Genitourinary [GU] brucellosis may present identically to GU tuberculosis. Psychiatric manifestations such as depression and anxiety are possible as late symptoms of brucellosis (4,5), so-called chronic neurobrucellosis. It remains unclear whether active brucella infection is present at that time. Overt CNS infection can, however, include meningitis and encephalitis (6,7).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. The elk are free to move in and out of the national park of Yellowstone. The elk feed at feeding grounds in the park. It is a tremendous tourist draw to see the large number of impressive animals. Some of these animals give birth to a calf at or near the feeding grounds. _Brucella abortus_, the organism responsible for the disease brucellosis, is often spread through the birthing process, fluids, and tissues. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. These same elk are free to move in and out of the park region, and thus may be spreading the disease to cattle they come into contact with in the area, thus, the article's statement of the likely source of the disease in the cow in question being elk.\n\nIn areas where a cow is found positive, the producers test their animals prior to moving them to market. The disease leads to parasites [bacteria] in the host's bloodstream, and episodes may last weeks, months or even years. It causes potentially recurrent episodes of high fever, sweating and related anemia.\n\nAt least 4 of the victims of the outbreak have been hospitalized in the neighboring city of Porto, a spokesperson from the Northern Regional Health Administration told the Expresso newspaper.\n\nLocal authorities in the Porto municipality of Baiao said the source of the brucellosis outbreak was cheese from a home-based factory, adding that the infection had been contained.\n\n'The cases of brucellosis originated from consumption of cheese produced in an artisan fashion. The place and period when they were consumed has been identified,' a local government spokesperson said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to OIE data, both _Brucella abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are present in Portugal. _B. abortus_ is related (almost) exclusively to bovines, while _B, melitensis_, generally related to small ruminants (sheep & goats), has been shown to occasionally infect cattle as well, without clinical signs but readily causing the excretion of large quantities of the bacterium in milk, becoming a serious public health hazard. This mostly happens when cattle are exposed to aborting sheep or goats.\n\nThe report does not specify the pathogen involved, nor the animal species from which the milk for the incriminated cheese production was derived. Pasteurisation of the milk prior to its processing would have prevented brucella contamination of the final product (cheese), even if sourced from infected flocks. However, certain sheep cheeses are traditionally produced from raw, un-pastuerised milk. In such cases, the cheese should undergo pasteurisation after its processing and prior to marketing.\n\nPortugal is one of the few EU member states still infected with _B. melitensis_, similar to Spain, Greece and Italy. After wrestling with the emotions over taking an animal's life and surveying the distance back to the truck, I remembered an extra task that demanded immediate attention.\n\nI searched through my pack, found a small plastic tube and filled it with blood while field dressing the elk. I capped the container, placed it inside a protective bag and secured it back inside the pack.\n\nThe vial was one of about 1500 that the Idaho Department of Fish and Game provides to elk hunters each fall, according to Dr Mark Drew, the agency's state veterinarian. The blood samples are tested to gauge the prevalence of brucellosis, an infectious bacterial disease that causes pregnant elk to abort during their middle trimester. The particular strain that affects ruminants, _Brucella abortus_, likely arrived in North America via European cattle more than a century ago, then spilled over to elk and bison. According to a 2006 report from an Idaho wildlife brucellosis work group, the US Department of Agriculture implemented a national eradication effort in 1934.\n\nSince then, federal, state, and private resources amounting to more than USD 3 billion were used to address and eventually eradicate brucellosis in livestock. One region of the United States known as the Greater Yellowstone Area, however, still harbors elk and bison infected by the disease.\n\nNot only can brucellosis affect the health of Idaho's elk herds, but its continuing presence and potential for 'spillover' back to cattle remains worrisome. Twice in the past decade the state lost its 'Class Free' status when cattle in eastern Idaho likely became infected by elk.\n\nEliminating the infection in wildlife residing in the national park and the surrounding areas of Idaho, Montana, and Wyoming appears unlikely.\n\n'If it was easy, we would have done it decades ago,' Drew said. 'Coordinating between the states, 3 federal land-management agencies, several tribes and private landowners is a challenge.' When that effort covers a large landscape for animals that roam freely and cross all those entities' boundaries, the task becomes even more difficult.\n\nDrew believes that Idaho's management seems to be working, noting that, in contrast, Montana's and Wyoming's occurrence of brucellosis infections is increasing.\n\nThe main thrust behind Idaho's efforts focuses on keeping cattle and elk separate, especially during late winter. Deep snows can concentrate wildlife and livestock at a time when pregnant elk are in their 2nd trimester and most susceptible to abortions. If the 2 species mingle at that time, the likelihood for disease transmittal rises sharply.\n\nThe emphasis on separation is coordinated by state wildlife officials and the Idaho Department of Agriculture using several tactics. Idaho prohibits any private feeding of elk inside a specific region near Yellowstone known as the Designated Surveillance Area, Drew said. In addition, fences there are constructed not only to keep elk away from haystacks, but also to force cattle to remain inside their winter feeding areas.\n\nIn order to determine the prevalence and distribution of brucellosis in elk, Fish and Game established 2 means of monitoring. The Idaho Brucellosis Management Plan mandates that elk which the state feeds more than 3 consecutive winters are trapped, bled and tested on site. Seropositive elk -- or animals that carry brucellosis antibodies but not necessarily the disease -- are removed from the area.\n\nIn addition, Fish and Game supplies hunters with blood sampling kits like the one that I carried into the Pioneer Mountains last fall and mailed back to their laboratory in Boise. These kits are distributed on an annual rotation between 3 areas that include one west, one south and one inside Idaho's portion of the Greater Yellowstone Area.\n\nDrew says 15 percent of the sampling kits are usually returned, and with about half being usable, the laboratory often yields about 200 good samples. This effort, along with the live testing of elk at feeding sites, indicates that eastern Idaho's critical area contains seropositive elk at a rate of 2 percent to 3 percent.\n\nOf the samples returned last year [2013] from the entire area west of Interstate 15, no elk tested positive, Drew said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts by the US Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and state animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection since 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nThe state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This effort, along with the live testing of elk at feeding sites, indicates that eastern Idaho's critical area contains seropositive elk at a rate of 2 percent to 3 percent. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. \n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. \n\nNot only can brucellosis affect the health of Idaho's elk herds, but its continuing presence and potential for 'spillover' back to cattle remains worrisome. \n\nThe main thrust behind Idaho's efforts focuses on keeping cattle and elk separate, especially during late winter. The blood samples are tested to gauge the prevalence of brucellosis, an infectious bacterial disease that causes pregnant elk to abort during their middle trimester. The Idaho Brucellosis Management Plan mandates that elk which the state feeds more than 3 consecutive winters are trapped, bled and tested on site. BRUCELLOSIS, CERVID - USA (03): (IDAHO) ELK\n*******************************************\n \n\nI searched through my pack, found a small plastic tube and filled it with blood while field dressing the elk. Seropositive elk -- or animals that carry brucellosis antibodies but not necessarily the disease -- are removed from the area. In addition, fences there are constructed not only to keep elk away from haystacks, but also to force cattle to remain inside their winter feeding areas. Idaho prohibits any private feeding of elk inside a specific region near Yellowstone known as the Designated Surveillance Area, Drew said. Twice in the past decade the state lost its 'Class Free' status when cattle in eastern Idaho likely became infected by elk. SUIS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 8 Oct 2014\nSource: The Land [edited]\nhttp://www.theland.com.au/news/agriculture/general/news/lls-confirms-brucellosis-in-moree-dogs/2714414.aspx\n\n\nThe North West has had a spate of serious brucellosis infections, with the Local Land Services (LLS) confirming 3 pig hunting dogs have recently tested positive for the _Brucella suis_ strain of the disease, which originates in pigs.\n\nLLS biosecurity and emergencies manager Shaun Slattery said all 3 dogs tested positive for brucellosis following suspected contact with infected feral pigs in the Moree area [northern New South Wales]. 'The dogs presented separately to private veterinarians with clinical signs suggestive of brucellosis infection, including fever, vomiting, back pain, blood in urine, lethargy, and enlarged testicles,' Dr Slattery said.\n\nDepartment of Primary Industries (DPI) pigs and poultry senior veterinary officer Amanda Lee said NSW had seen an increase in the number of dogs presenting to vets with suspected brucellosis infection.\n\n'Brucellosis is a serious infectious disease of pigs that can be passed on to other animals and people through contact with urine, blood, saliva, and reproductive materials,' Dr Lee said. 'The cases we have seen in dogs in NSW have been either as a result of direct contact with an infected feral pig or pig meat, contact with another infected dog, or as a result of the disease being passed on to a pup at birth.'\n\nThe DPI recommends that dogs infected with brucellosis be euthanased because of the potential risk to people. Anyone who is concerned that their dog may have signs of brucellosis should contact their local veterinarian to have it assessed.\n\nVeterinarians should notify Dr Lee by phone (02) 4640 6308 or email (<amanda.lee@dpi.nsw.gov.au>).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to Australia's annual OIE report for 2013, _Brucella suis_ is a notifiable disease which had been last recorded in domestic animals in 2010 and in wildlife (wild boars) in December 2012. 'Animal Health Australia (2010)' reported that _B. suis_ is confined to some populations of feral pigs in Queensland and was detected in a free-range piggery in Queensland in the last quarter of 2010. 'The _B. suis_ Accredited Herd Scheme is administered by Biosecurity Queensland on behalf of the industry and currently (2010) has 11 member herds. The scheme aims to ensure piggery freedom from _B. suis_ and to provide a secure source of disease-free breeding stock for pig producers.'\n\n_B. suis_ is a public health concern in Australia, being mainly a recreational or occupational disease of feral pig hunters, farm workers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers. According to NSW's Department of Primary Industries (2012), '80 per cent of cases occur in Queensland, with the majority of cases in men aged between 15 and 49 years. Between December 2006 and December 2011, 9 men from NSW were diagnosed with swine brucellosis following regular recreational or occupational feral pig hunting in North West NSW. All men had butchered feral pigs without wearing any protective clothing.'\n\nOrchitis is one of the predominant symptoms of _B. suis_ infection in pigs and dogs.\n\nFor further background information, please refer to Mod.TG's commentary in archive no 20140628.2571258. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ga.gov.au/image_cache/GA4073.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32617. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "The scheme aims to ensure piggery freedom from _B. suis_ and to provide a secure source of disease-free breeding stock for pig producers.'\n\n_B. suis_ is a public health concern in Australia, being mainly a recreational or occupational disease of feral pig hunters, farm workers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers. It usually begins with a high fever, which lasts for 7-10 days, but in case of absence of appropriate therapy, the temperature would keep up even for 2-3 months [so-called indolent fever - Mod.LL]. The fever is accompanied by chills, excessive sweating and general symptoms of intoxication. Later, it is joined by symptoms involving the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, nervous, and other body systems.\n\n'Frequency of cases in 2014 has not changed in comparison with 2013,' she noted. 'The highest number of cases is reported in Ganja, Imishli and Bilasuvar, and the lowest number in Baku, North and South regions (Guba, Khachmaz, Astara and Masalli). There have been no cases of death resulting from the infection in 2014 or 2013,' she said.\n\nIsmayilova stressed that human infection occurs through direct contact with animals or eating contaminated foods such as raw milk and cheese made from unpasteurized milk.\n\nIsmaylova noted that brucellosis infection is endemic in the country. 'Epidemic analysis of materials related to the main sources and routes of brucellosis transmission in our country in recent years has shown that the main source of infection is small livestock.'\n\nSuch cases have been recorded throughout the current year [2014] in Azerbaijan. The number of cases of brucellosis increases in summer and autumn.\n\n[Byline: Amina Nazarli]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis (http://www.medicinenet.com/brucellosis/article.htm) is a disease that is thought to have existed since ancient times, as it was 1st described more than 2000 years ago by the Romans and Hippocrates. It was not until 1887 that a British physician, Dr David Bruce, isolated the organism that causes brucellosis from several deceased patients from the island of Malta. This disease has had several names throughout its history, including Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Crimean fever, Bang's disease, and undulant fever (because of the relapsing nature of the fever associated with the disease).\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms.\n\nThe signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive, and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, working in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/134.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis (http://www.medicinenet.com/brucellosis/article.htm) is a disease that is thought to have existed since ancient times, as it was 1st described more than 2000 years ago by the Romans and Hippocrates. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4526332,00.html\n\n\nBrucellosis outbreak due to unpasteurized milk\n----------------------------------------------\nDue to an unusual outbreak of brucellosis in the Western Galilee, the Nahariya hospital [HaZafon (Northern District)] had to treat about 30 patients during the last 2 weeks, half of them children. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as 'Malta fever.' The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n'The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,' he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. One case, a 5-year-old girl, had to be hospitalized in the ICU to stabilize her condition.\n\nIt has been said that the current wave may continue, since the incubation period of exposed persons may take weeks and sometimes even months before clinically manifested. According to the Medical Center, throughout the course of 2013, only 10 patients had to be treated.\n\nAfter questioning by the hospital's doctors, 3 possible sources of infection have been identified.\n\nAbout 10 days ago, another cluster of brucellosis was discovered, in Jerusalem; 14 people were found infected following the consumption of unpasteurized cheese brought from the territory of the Palestinian Authority [West Bank].\n\n[Byline: Achiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most likely, all reported cases of Malta fever (the commonly used name for brucellosis in Israel) have been caused by _Brucella melitensis_, the bacteria species which is regarded endemic. There is a concerning increase of reported human cases during recent years (see further data of 2011-2013). The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. The patients were treated with antibiotics and given supportive care.\n\nDr. Bibiana Hazan, who heads the hospital's infectious diseases unit, said the disease is transmitted to people by sheep, cows, and goats that have not been immunized against it.\n\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[_Brucella abortus_ has been eradicated in Israel since the early 1980s; since then, _Brucella melitensis_ has been the only identified causative agent of brucellosis in Israel. The disease is regarded endemic, similarly to all countries in the Middle East and in many Mediterranean countries. It causes abortions in sheep and goat flocks and Malta Fever, a serious zoonosis, in humans. According to Israel's annual OIE report for 2012, 14 outbreaks were reported in sheep and goat flocks. The number of human cases was, reportedly, 183 (2.6046 per 100 000 population). Vaccination with _B. melitensis_ REV1 vaccine was applied in 144 852 sheep and 21 528 goats.\n\nThe 2013 figures are the following: 11 outbreaks in sheep and goats; 336 human cases (4.7822 per 100 000); vaccinations: sheep 148 601, goats 21 838, on the public health front, a concerning change (83 percent increase).\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Most of the human cases are encountered in southern Israel. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle; in contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle but will infect the udders followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk.\n\nMore information on the current event in the north is anticipated. Is this a cluster and from one or several locations? Is there a common source of infection (e.g. a batch of a sheep-goat dairy product)? Or, have the (rural?) patients been directly exposed to infected animals?\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\nE.Anis, A.Leventhal, I.Grotto, D.Gandacu et al (2011). The 2013 figures are the following: 11 outbreaks in sheep and goats; 336 human cases (4.7822 per 100 000); vaccinations: sheep 148 601, goats 21 838, on the public health front, a concerning change (83 percent increase). \n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle; in contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle but will infect the udders followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk. \n\nDr. Bibiana Hazan, who heads the hospital's infectious diseases unit, said the disease is transmitted to people by sheep, cows, and goats that have not been immunized against it. SUIS\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jun 2014\nSource: The Daily Examiner, NSW Department of Primary Industries report [edited]\nhttp://www.dailyexaminer.com.au/news/warning-for-dog-owners-after-infectious-disease-ou/2301232/\n\n\nThe [New South Wales (NSW) State] Department of Primary Industries (DPI) has issued a warning to dog owners, following a recent spate of serious brucellosis (_Brucella suis_) infections in dogs.\n\nDPI Senior Veterinary Officer Pigs and Poultry, Amanda Lee, said 4 dogs in NSW have recently tested positive for the _Brucella suis_ strain of the disease, which originates in pigs.\n\n'Brucellosis (_Brucella suis_) is a serious infectious disease of pigs that can be passed on to other animals and people through contact with urine, blood, saliva and reproductive materials,' Dr Lee said.\n\n'Two pig hunting dogs in north-western NSW have recently tested positive for brucellosis after suspected contact with an infected feral pig in the Moree area. Both dogs presented separately to private veterinarians with clinical signs suggestive of brucellosis infection, including fever, enlarged lymph nodes and enlarged testicles.'\n\nDPI has been assisted by Local Land Services in the investigations.\n\nDr Lee said 2 other cases highlight the risk of brucellosis being transmitted to pups at birth.\n\n'We've also confirmed that a Bull Arab cross living in Sydney [NSW], and a Great Dane cross pup in Walgett [NSW] have tested positive for this disease,' Dr Lee said. 'Neither of the dogs have had any known contact with feral pigs, and we suspect the disease may have been passed on by their mother at birth. It is a crucial reminder for people to be aware of their animal's history and to purchase or obtain pups from reputable breeders.'\n\nDPI recommends that dogs confirmed infected with brucellosis be euthanased because of the potential risk to people.\n\nDirector of Communicable Diseases Branch NSW Health Dr Vicky Sheppeard said NSW Health is in contact with the owners of the infected dogs and vets who treated the dogs.\n\n'Brucellosis in humans is a potentially fatal disease, and symptoms may include intermittent fever, sweating, lethargy, loss of appetite, headache, and back pain,' Dr Sheppeard said. 'It is essential that people who are at an increased risk of brucellosis infection, including feral pig hunters, farm workers, vets and abattoir workers, practice good personal hygiene and wear protective clothing when in close contact with potentially infected animals.'\n\nOwners who are concerned that their dog may have signs of Brucellosis should contact their local veterinarian to have it assessed. The veterinarian will notify a Local Land Services inspector or an inspector with DPI if they consider the case suspect for brucellosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a bacterial infection caused by Gram-negative coccobacillus (short rods).\n\nBrucellosis is a serious, globally distributed zoonotic disease. Humans are susceptible to infection by _Brucella suis_, _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. canis_, and can have lifelong symptoms of undulating fever, enlarged lymph nodes, malaise, and arthritis.\n\nConsumption of unpasteurized dairy products confers the highest risk for brucellosis in disease-endemic areas. However, hunters and owners of hunting dogs are at high risk for transmission of brucellosis from wildlife. Sporadic transmission of _B. canis_ from pet dogs to their owners has been reported. We caution the public about the potential for transmission to humans in contact with infected dogs and wild hogs.\n\nSmooth _Brucella_ spp. express the immunodominant O side chain on the lipopolysaccharide of their surface. Therefore, this side chain forms the antigenic basis of diagnostic tests, such as the card test. The _B. abortus_ plate antigen (BAPA) test can detect smooth species. Because _B. canis_ does not express the O side chain on its surface, serologic tests for _B. canis_ differ from tests for _B. abortus_, _B. suis_, or _B. melitensis_. Therefore, _B. suis_-infected dogs are unlikely to have positive results for _B. canis_ tests and vice versa.\n\nAlthough transmission of _B. suis_ from dogs to humans has not been reported, _B. suis_ is 2nd only to _B. melitensis_ in its pathogenicity to humans. Therefore, dogs exposed to feral hogs should be tested for _Brucella_ spp. and monitored for clinical signs, while keeping in mind that sensitivity and specificity of _B. abortus_-specific tests is unknown. If a pet is infected with _B. canis_, a long course of antimicrobial drugs and spaying or neutering to prevent breeding is advisable but might not be completely effective.\n\nBecause _B. suis_ is more pathogenic to humans than _B. canis_, and its mechanisms of pathogenesis in dogs can vary, the same recommendations might not be true for _B. suis_-infected dogs. Given the serious zoonotic implications of _B. suis_ infections, euthanasia of the affected pet may be advocated by regulatory agencies and physicians treating exposed humans.\n\nLittle information, including that for pathogenesis or duration of bacteremia, is available for _B. suis_ infections in dogs. Therefore, blood cultures might not reliably detect _B. suis_-infected dogs. For _B. canis_ infections, only animals certified free of _Brucella_ spp. by 2 consecutive serologic or blood culture tests conducted 4-6 weeks apart can be used as breeding stock in kennels. If an outbreak occurs in a kennel, all infected animals should be isolated and euthanized after showing positive test results. The premises should also be thoroughly disinfected before restocking.\n\nReferences:\n1. Seleem MN, Boyle SM, Sriranganathan N. Brucellosis: a re-emerging zoonosis. [PMC free article] [PubMed] [Cross Ref]\n6.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poultry", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Almuzara MN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nagura F", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corazza R", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2558324", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, caprine, ovine, camel - Israel: spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2558324", "date": "2014-06-22 19:26:30", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, CAPRINE, OVINE, CAMEL - ISRAEL: SPREAD\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\n[1] Current control difficulties\n[2] Past experience assessed\n[3] Human infection from camel milk\n\n******\n[1] Current control difficulties\nDate: Mon 16 Jun 2014\nFrom: Ellis Gross <ellisg@moag.gov.il> [edited]\n\n\n[In response to ProMED-mail's request for information in postings 20140513.2467609 & 20140607.2525983]:\n\nThe control of _B. melitensis_ in Israel is very complicated based on a number of reasons.\n\nCompulsive vaccination is carried on female kids and lambs between the ages of 2 to 6 months using the attenuated Rev-1 strain of _Brucella spp_. Unfortunately not all animals are vaccinated due to various issues. The vaccination prevents abortion and not infection, so some farmers wrongly believe that vaccination will render dairy products safe for human consumption even if not pasteurized.\n\nThere is a lack of a comprehensive educational policy in the country encouraging farmers to vaccinate and warning about the dangers of unpasteurized dairy products.\n\nTrade in untested breeding animals and mixing of flocks grazing is not under control.\n\nThere is no clear policy of removal of infected animals from flocks (slaughter or destruction) with indemnity payments nor is there a clear policy regarding penalties of introduction of animal into flocks without required testing and permits. Vaccination without removal of infected animals is not effective.\n\nDuring attempted epidemiological investigations, victims of the disease and flock owners often hide information regarding the source of incriminated dairy products.\n\n--\nEllis Gross,VMD, MPH\nDistrict Veterinarian\nBeersheva, Israel\n<ellisg@moag.gov.il>\n\n[Israel's veterinary brucellosis control policy and activities, as of 2010, are reviewed in Ref. 1. An appraisal of the background to the current crisis, as far as relevant to the most affected region, the Negev, has been addressed recently and is presented in item 2. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] Past experience assessed\nDate: Sat 21 Jun 2014 [accessed]\nSource: Air Water Borne Diseases 2013, 2:2 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://omicsgroup.org/journals/increasing-incidence-of-human-brucellosis-in-southern-israel-after-the-cessation-of-a-veterinarian-control-campaign-2167-7719.1000112.pdf\n\n\nRe: Ari A Shemesh & Pablo Yagupsky. Increasing Incidence of Human Brucellosis in Southern Israel after the Cessation of a Veterinarian Control Campaign\n---------------------------------------\nAbstract\n----------\nThe southern region of Israel is populated by a mostly urban Jewish majority (population: 385 200 inhabitants) and a large semi-nomadic Bedouin minority (population: 188 900) who maintain herds of sheep and goats. A retrospective study was conducted to assess the impact of the 1997 decision to discontinue a veterinarian control campaign on the epidemiology of human brucellosis in the region.\n\nDiscussion\n-------------\nBrucellosis appears to have been endemic to Middle East countries since ancient times affecting domesticated animals and humans as well. In modern times, rigorous control measures instituted by the Israel Ministry of Agriculture have eliminated brucellosis caused by _B. abortus_ among bovines, making the industrialized milk product supply safe. _Brucella melitensis_, however, continued to be endemic among sheep and goats, especially in nomadic Bedouin herds, and the veterinary control of the disease in this setting encountered serious logistic difficulties such as geographical dispersion of small herds, lack of shepherds' incentive to participate in the program, budgetary constraints, and illegal trade in infected animals. Although cessation of the eradication campaign in 1997 could have been justified by the steady decline in the endemic level of brucellosis observed countrywide, the present data clearly show that the disease was far from being brought to control in southern Israel. The results of the study demonstrate that, after a decline in the incidence of brucellosis in the early 2000's, starting in 2007, rates increased again and significantly exceeded the 1997 endemic level in 2012.\n\nThe relationship between the timing of the cessation of the veterinary control campaign and the epidemiological changes in the incidence of human disease in the Negev region is, therefore, not obvious. It is speculated that control measures did, in fact, decrease the prevalence of the zoonosis among domesticated animals because most infected sheep and goats were slaughtered and replaced by immunized animals, reducing the source of human contagion. Although the campaign was discontinued in 1997, its effect was still felt at the beginning of the following decade resulting in low attack rate of human infections. It is speculated that because the disease was not completely eradicated, brucellosis slowly built-up among animal herds, taking a few years before it spilled-over to the human population of the region. Close examination of the data demonstrate that the disease remained almost limited to Negev Bedouins who, although undergoing a rapid process of modernization and settlement in permanent towns, still keep goat and sheep herds and consume unpasteurized dairy products. The average incidence of brucellosis in the Bedouin community for the 11-year period (77.9 per 100 000 population) is appalling and ranks 2nd only to that reported among the population of neighboring Syria. These results indicate that countrywide data may overlook the incidence of a locally-endemic infection by diluting cases of disease amidst a large global denominator, and imply that the true magnitude of the problem should be assessed using specific data for the relevant population at risk.\n\nThe incidence rate of human brucellosis found in the present study can be considered only a minimal estimate. The study design did not include a small proportion of patients who could have been diagnosed in a few small clinical microbiology laboratories other than the CMLSUNC [Clinical Microbiology Laboratory of the Soroka University Medical Center, city of Beer-Sheva].\n\nIn addition, the protean clinical manifestations of human brucellosis may mimic other infectious and non-infectious conditions and, therefore, the true nature of the symptoms and signs may be easily missed. In a previous study conducted in southern Israel, isolation of _B. melitensis_ was frequently an unexpected finding in febrile Bedouin patients in whom the disease was not suspected. In a study conducted in the region, active search for the disease among relatives of 4 index patients with brucellosis resulted in the detection of an additional 12 undiagnosed cases. A similar experience was reported in Saudi Arabia, where screening of 404 family members of 55 diagnosed cases revealed an additional 53 (13.1 percent) serologically positive individuals, of which 9 were also bacteremic.\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nHuman brucellosis caused by _B. melitensis_ has reemerged as a serious public health threat to the Bedouin population of southern Israel in recent years. The Israel Ministry of Agriculture should reconsider its premature decision to terminate veterinary measures aimed to control brucellosis in domesticated animals, and implement a public education campaign to reduce human exposure to this preventable zoonotic disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For additional details, including (16) references, subscribers are referred to the full text at the source URL. As apparent from the earlier postings this year [2014] (see at 'See Also'), the situation has been deteriorating in other parts of the country as well. The situation in the Palestinian territories (West Bank) is, most likely, as concerning as the one observed in the Negev Bedouin population.\n\nAccording to the most recent available Weekly Epidemiological Report of Israel's Ministry of Health, the tendency of increased human infection has been continuing in 2014. As of 24 May 2014 (the end of the 21st week of 2014), the accumulated number of officially reported new human cases was 210, compared to a total of 120 during the same period in 2013 (75 percent increase). The total annual figures in previous years were: 2013 - 336; 2012 - 183; 2011 - 127; 2010 - 139; 2009 - 136; 2008 - 149; 2007 - 162; 2006 - 138; 2005 - 141. The current upsurge, if it continues, may supercede the record numbers of the 80's/early 90's; spill over into other populations should not be a surprise.\n\nFollowing a comment from a subscriber (referring to Saudia): 'I would be more worried about the possibility of camel-mediated transmission of brucellosis than MERS CoV,' we include the following report by Israeli authors (item 3). - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[3] Human infection from camel milk\nDate: Sat 21 Jun 2014 [accessed]\nSource: IMAJ (Israel Medical Association Journal) 2012, 14: 475-478 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.ima.org.il/FilesUpload/IMAJ/0/39/19591.pdf\n\n\nRe: S Ben Shimol, L Dukhan, I Belmaker, S Bardenstein, D Sibirsky, C Barrett & D Greenberg. Human Brucellosis Outbreak Acquired through Camel Milk Ingestion in Southern Israel.\n------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nBackground: Human brucellosis is common in southern Israel among the semi-nomadic Bedouin, a population that consumes unpasteurized dairy products. Though camel milk ingestion is a known mechanism for brucellosis acquisition, only a few reports of sporadic cases have been published in the medical literature.\n\nObjectives: To describe a local brucellosis outbreak in 15 extended Bedouin family members, following ingestion of infected camel milk.\n\nMethods: Data regarding patients' clinical manifestations, laboratory findings, treatment and outcome were collected from the hospital and the health fund clinics' computerized database. Camel's blood and milk were tested for Brucella serology and culture. Cases were defined by positive Rose Bengal test, symptoms correlating with brucellosis, and consumption of infected camel milk.\n\nResults: 15 patients were diagnosed with acute brucellosis from March to June 2011. 60 percent of cases had serum agglutination test titers of 1:160 or higher, and 4/8 (50 percent) had positive blood culture for _Brucella melitensis_. Arthralgia and fever were the most consistent clinical manifestations. Blood and milk serology and milk culture taken from the female camel were positive for _Brucella melitensis_.\n\nConclusions: The treating physicians must consider the possibility of infected camel milk ingestion as the mode of infection, both in sporadic cases and in outbreaks of brucellosis.\n\nDiscussion (excerpt)\n--------------------\nThe incidence rate of brucellosis in the Bedouin population in southern Israel was 49.4/100 000 in 2009 compared to the 1.8/100 000 nationwide incidence rate (Ministry of Health data) [later data available in item 2 above]. The high incidence rate of brucellosis in the Bedouin population could be attributed to lack of awareness regarding the nature of disease, modes of transmission and prevention methods.\n\nBetween 1998 and 2001, the local office of the Health Ministry initiated an educational community-based program aimed to increase awareness in the Bedouin population of the nature of disease, modes of transmission, and prevention methods including livestock vaccination. Evaluation of this program demonstrated a significant increase in the population's knowledge about brucellosis and its prevention methods, but there were no positive behavior changes (e.g., avoiding unpasteurized animal milk and not wearing gloves when in contact with animals).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The camel population of Israel is, reportedly, about 11 000. Most countries in the region, which maintain much larger camel populations and where camel milk has become a popular and widely distributed commodity, may probably witness significantly higher numbers of human brucellosis cases. Information from such countries will be appreciated.\n\nIsrael managed to eradicate animal diseases such as bovine tuberculosis and _B. abortus_, and to successfully control others; efforts to control _B. melitensis_ have not been, so far, successful in spite of applied efforts, as described and discussed in item 2 above and in Ref 1. The situation in other countries, particularly in the Middle east and central Asia but also in the rest of the Mediterranean basin, in the Balkans and Mexico, is similar and in some of them even worse. Israel's experience deserves to be studied and lessons drawn for all concerned.\n\nThe financial losses caused by the disease to animal owners are much lower than the devastating damage to human health; this is an obstacle in obtaining the owners' cooperation, unless control measures, including vaccination and animal identification, are free of charge and full, immediate compensations are paid when required. Only a 'one health' attitude, backed by the legal, financial and enforcement powers of national authorities would have a chance for significant achievements in the efforts to control, and -- hopefully -- eventually eradicate this long-known zoonosis from animals and consequently from humans. Some internationally accumulated lessons and guidelines may be found in refs 2 and 3.\n\nIn his preface to a recent edition of OIE's Rev Sci Tech dedicated to Brucellosis (ref 3), OIE's Director General, Bernard Vallat, wrote: 'The study of zoonotic brucellosis served as a basis for some of the great early advances in epidemiology, yet the disease remains the most common chronic bacterial infection in the world. It continues to cause important medical, veterinary, socioeconomic and conservation problems, mainly because its overall burden remains underestimated and often neglected.'\n\nReferences\n\n1. BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, CAPRINE, OVINE, CAMEL - ISRAEL: SPREAD\n**********************************************************\n [3] Human infection from camel milk\n\n******\n \n\nIsrael managed to eradicate animal diseases such as bovine tuberculosis and _B. abortus_, and to successfully control others; efforts to control _B. melitensis_ have not been, so far, successful in spite of applied efforts, as described and discussed in item 2 above and in Ref 1. \nHuman brucellosis caused by _B. melitensis_ has reemerged as a serious public health threat to the Bedouin population of southern Israel in recent years. \n\nConclusions: The treating physicians must consider the possibility of infected camel milk ingestion as the mode of infection, both in sporadic cases and in outbreaks of brucellosis. Increasing Incidence of Human Brucellosis in Southern Israel after the Cessation of a Veterinarian Control Campaign\n \n\nBetween 1998 and 2001, the local office of the Health Ministry initiated an educational community-based program aimed to increase awareness in the Bedouin population of the nature of disease, modes of transmission, and prevention methods including livestock vaccination. Brucella melitensis_, however, continued to be endemic among sheep and goats, especially in nomadic Bedouin herds, and the veterinary control of the disease in this setting encountered serious logistic difficulties such as geographical dispersion of small herds, lack of shepherds' incentive to participate in the program, budgetary constraints, and illegal trade in infected animals. The Israel Ministry of Agriculture should reconsider its premature decision to terminate veterinary measures aimed to control brucellosis in domesticated animals, and implement a public education campaign to reduce human exposure to this preventable zoonotic disease. In this update:\n\n[1] Current control difficulties\n In his preface to a recent edition of OIE's Rev Sci Tech dedicated to Brucellosis (ref 3), OIE's Director General, Bernard Vallat, wrote: 'The study of zoonotic brucellosis served as a basis for some of the great early advances in epidemiology, yet the disease remains the most common chronic bacterial infection in the world. \n\nObjectives: To describe a local brucellosis outbreak in 15 extended Bedouin family members, following ingestion of infected camel milk. Most countries in the region, which maintain much larger camel populations and where camel milk has become a popular and widely distributed commodity, may probably witness significantly higher numbers of human brucellosis cases. Evaluation of this program demonstrated a significant increase in the population's knowledge about brucellosis and its prevention methods, but there were no positive behavior changes (e.g., avoiding unpasteurized animal milk and not wearing gloves when in contact with animals). Although cessation of the eradication campaign in 1997 could have been justified by the steady decline in the endemic level of brucellosis observed countrywide, the present data clearly show that the disease was far from being brought to control in southern Israel. -------------\nBrucellosis appears to have been endemic to Middle East countries since ancient times affecting domesticated animals and humans as well. The incidence rate of brucellosis in the Bedouin population in southern Israel was 49.4/100 000 in 2009 compared to the 1.8/100 000 nationwide incidence rate (Ministry of Health data) These results indicate that countrywide data may overlook the incidence of a locally-endemic infection by diluting cases of disease amidst a large global denominator, and imply that the true magnitude of the problem should be assessed using specific data for the relevant population at risk. It is speculated that because the disease was not completely eradicated, brucellosis slowly built-up among animal herds, taking a few years before it spilled-over to the human population of the region. \n\nThere is no clear policy of removal of infected animals from flocks (slaughter or destruction) with indemnity payments nor is there a clear policy regarding penalties of introduction of animal into flocks without required testing and permits. Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://www.rosbalt.ru/federal/2014/03/28/1249953.html\n\n\nBrucellosis in sheep has been recorded in the Tula region\n---------------------------------------------------------\nBrucellosis has been revealed in a sheep breeding farm in the Belevsky district [Tula oblast]. The disease was confirmed by laboratory tests.\n\nBrucellosis is a disease transmitted from infected animals to man. Human infection occurs through direct contact with animals, through contaminated premises or by eating contaminated food -- such as raw milk and cheese made from unpasteurized milk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2 or 3) is the main causative agent of caprine and ovine brucellosis. It is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide; the disease is present in many of Russia's oblasts (led by Stavropol, Dagstan, Astrakhan and Khakasiya).\n\nClinically, the disease in animals (goats and sheep) is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses globally. All infected tissues, cultures and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. Brucellosis in cattle is generally caused by _B. abortus_.\n\nDuring 2012 (last available report), 465 human cases of brucellosis, primarily caused by _B. melitensis_, were officially reported by the Russian authorities to the OIE (0.3242 per 100 000 population).\n\nAt present, brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_ and _B. ovis_. Tula oblast is situated about 200 km (about 124 miles) south of Moscow. The last _B. melitensis_ outbreak in small ruminants was reported there in 2011; no new cases were reported during 2012 and the 1st 6 months of 2013 (last available semi-annual report).\n\nSheep and goats in Russia are vaccinated against _B. melitensis_ primarily by the Rev.1 vaccine. In about 20 percent of the vaccinations, 'Strain 19' vaccine is used. Additional information is available in Ref 1.\n\nReference:\n1. A.A. Denisov, O.D. Sclyarov, K.M. Salmakov & K.V. The event was reported in December 2013 but was only released this week. Since then, the employees have been treated and released.\n\nEarlier this week [10-12 Feb 2014], the president of the Syndicate of Food Industry Workers of Maringa (STIAM), Roberto Pino Jesus, reported the case to the Human Rights Commission of the Senate. According to the president of the union, the complaint was formalized to draw attention to the non-application of Norm 36, in force since April 2013, which dictates the rules that establish the minimum requirements for assessing, controlling, and monitoring risks existing in activities in the slaughtering and processing of meat and the meat industry.\n\nAccording to [Roberto Pino Jesus], the individual safety equipment that protects body, mouth, and eyes, for example, was not being used in the Paicandu refrigerator. It was not until 1887 that a British physician, Dr David Bruce, isolated the organism that causes brucellosis from several deceased patients from the island of Malta. This disease has had several names throughout its history, including Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Crimean fever, Bang's disease, and undulant fever (because of the relapsing nature of the fever associated with the disease).\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms.\n\nThe signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive, and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, working in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital. In this outbreak, it is not clear what symptoms the workers had or whether they were just seropositive. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJi.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This disease has had several names throughout its history, including Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Crimean fever, Bang's disease, and undulant fever (because of the relapsing nature of the fever associated with the disease). The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive, and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, working in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.
