The spread of brucellosis to humans is through consumption of unpasteurized milk, undercooked meat, or contact with secretions from infected animals. It produces abortions in animals and in humans, fever, weakness, and general pain. 'It is an extremely infectious zoonosis' warns the OIE.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following moderator comments regarding _Brucella abortus_ in bovines are taken from ProMED-mail 'Brucellosis, bison - Canada: (AB),' archive number 20110730.2294:\n\n'Brucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost exclusively by _Brucella abortus_; however, _B. suis_ or _B. melitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B. suis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically aborts only once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations appear normal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short period and develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist infection, and a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive serum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal parturition but may be delayed in about 15 per cent of cows. The incubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage of gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and uterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile. Bacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid uterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease of fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously aborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal parturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of time, in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are present in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or lick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission may occur by artificial insemination when brucella-contaminated semen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has remained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking unpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not killed by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis has been called undulating fever because of its habit of producing fever and signs that wax and wane over an extended period of time.' - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Panama can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/panama.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/9wp7. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following moderator comments regarding _Brucella abortus_ in bovines are taken from ProMED-mail 'Brucellosis, bison - Canada: (AB),' archive number 20110730.2294:\n\n'Brucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost exclusively by _Brucella abortus_; however, _B. suis_ or _B. melitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. India: (PB) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2032822", "date": "2013-11-01 01:13:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - INDIA: (PUNJAB) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Oct 2013\nSource: The Indian Express [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/brucellosis-afflicts-over-10--cattle-population-in-punjab-say-experts/1188799/\n\n\nWhile more than 10 percent of cattle in Punjab suffers from brucellosis, a disease which is contagious and causes miscarriages in animals and pregnant women, dairy farmers in Punjab are simply unaware of it, say experts.\n\n'It is a disease which causes abortions in animals during 6 to 9 months of pregnancy and if spread to humans, women get the same problem,' said Dr J P S Gill, director, School of Public Health and Zoonosis, GADVASU [Guru Angad Dev Veterinary and Animal Sciences University], talking to Newsline.\n\nNot only cattle, but also horses, sheep, goats, pigs and other animals get infected. During pregnancy the infection attacks the uterus, he said.\n\nThe 1st ever 2-day annual meeting of Department of Biotechnology, Government of India, on this disease began at GADVASU on Tuesday [29 Oct 2013].\n\nDr S R Rao, advisor, Department of Biotechnology, was present at the meeting and said that 'temperature, night chills, joint pains, bodyache are common symptoms in human beings of this disease.'\n\nDr Gill told Newsline that brucellosis is an important zoonotic disease transmitted from animals to human beings through direct contact and consumption of raw milk and milk products. 'It is still an uncontrolled serious public health problem in many developing countries, including India. In livestock, brucellosis results in reduced productivity, abortions and infertility, leading to considerable economic losses,' said Dr Gill.\n\nAsked about the measures to control it, he said that to date there is no treatment for it. 'While foreign nations slaughter animals, here it is not allowed. All we can do is to isolate animal from farm. In humans, antibiotics can only control the spread. That too only if damage has not reached beyond a level. If [it has] reached the joints, then it is irreversible,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Divya Goyal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis is usually caused by _Brucella abortus_, less frequently by _B. melitensis_, and occasionally by _B. suis_. Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand are believed to be free from _B. abortus_.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised in cattle by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis (testicular inflammation), epididymitis (inflammation of the epididymis, a tube at the back of the testicle) and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\nThough both _B. abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are known to be endemic in India (Ref), only _B. abortus_ is mentioned in India's annual reports to the OIE. The bacteria _B. melitensis and _B. suis_, both highly pathogenic for humans, are included in the list of diseases 'for which no information has been provided.'\n\nAccording to India's most recent annual report to the OIE, a total of 7 cases of bovine brucellosis, in 5 new outbreaks, have been recorded in cattle during 2012 throughout the entire country. This is an astonishingly low figure for a disease known to be endemic. The deficient surveillance, which leads to under-reporting, is particularly concerning when a zoonotic disease is at stake. In such a situation, high prevalence of human disease should not surprise.\n\nThe brucellosis-related control measures applied in India are, reportedly, limited to 'testing' and 'quarantine.' The above media report indicates that slaughter of infected animals is the only available means of control. Why preventive cattle vaccination has not been applied, remains to be clarified. Similarly, information on the situation regarding _B. melitensis_ and _B. suis_ is requested.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. This has been reportedly claimed in a report submitted by a leading diagnostic centre of the city to the Kanpur zoo authorities, giving complete description of the health status of the entire zoo staff.\n\nThe diagnostic centre had conducted medical check-up of the zoo employees and confirmed the presence of these bacteria in zoo employees. In September and October [2013], the zoo authorities had gotten their employees to undertake medical tests at a leading private diagnostic centre. The tests performed by this centre revealed that the staffers are suffering from various zoonotic diseases and need proper treatment. The decision to conduct the medical check-up for zoonotic diseases of the entire zoo staff was taken by the zoo veterinarians Dr RK Singh and Dr UC Srivastava.\n\nAccording to reliable sources, as many as 30 zoo employees are affected with leptospirosis disease (caused by bacteria _Leptospira_) alone. Some 10 zoo staffers are affected with brucellosis, including the zoo director, Kuruvilla Thomas, and zoo veterinarian RK Singh.\n\nDr Ashish Srivastava, a doctor (member) of a medical panel constituted by the Chief Medical Officer, Kanpur Nagar, on his visit to Kanpur zoo for conducting the health check-up of the zoo staff, told TOI [Times of India] that 'the zoo director and zoo veterinarian are affected with _Brucella_ bacteria but there is nothing to worry and neither is there any threat of spread of any epidemic'.\n\n'Those who stay in contact with the animals, especially at places like zoos, often suffer from zoonotic diseases. This could be termed as an occupational disease. But there is nothing to worry about. We have already examined 60 zoo employees and the remaining will be examined on Friday [15 Nov 2013]. Also, the required medicines which form the part of the treatment will be given to the zoo authorities in a day or 2,' said Dr Srivastava while talking to TOI.\n\nA panel of doctors comprising Dr Ashish Srivastava, deputy District Tuberculosis Officer Dr AP Mishra and 5 other medical staff visited Kanpur zoo on Thursday [14 Nov 2013] to conduct the health check-up of the zoo staff.\n\nThe panel of doctors had been constituted by CMO Kanpur Nagar Dr RP Yadav on the request of the Kanpur zoo administration to re-check them against zoonotic diseases and to give them proper treatment for the same.\n\nContacted, CMO Dr Yadav said, 'Those staying around wild animals, especially in places like zoos, are often exposed to these bacteria. Such risk runs in the employees of the Kanpur zoo as well. On the request of the Kanpur zoo authorities, I had constituted a team of doctors who visited zoo on Thursday [14 Nov 2013] and conducted some tests for confirmation of the diseases.'\n\nTOI also spoke to zoo director Kuruvilla Thomas. He said, 'It was a routine check up of the health of the zoo staff. The team of doctors was the part of the panel constituted by the CMO. The doctors medically examined the zoo staff for zoonotic diseases, including tuberculosis. We will treat the affected persons accordingly.'\n\nHowever, when the zoo director was asked whether he was suffering from any zoonotic disease, he refused to comment.\n\nZoo veterinarian Dr RK Singh said that the prescribed tests were performed on the zoo staff according to the All-India Service Rules. The zoo authorities also followed the guidelines of the Central Zoo Authority while conducting the health check-up of the staff, he added. However, he too declined any comment about his health.\n\n[Byline: Abhinav Malhotra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Zoos and wildlife reserves often house many species of wild mammals, birds, amphibians and reptiles. Because many zoo employees work in close contact with these wild animals, there is risk of transmission of zoonotic diseases from wild animals to humans. Zoonotic diseases that could be transmitted from wild animals in zoos include tuberculosis, rabies, anthrax, leptospirosis, listeriosis, brucellosis, tularemia, campylobacteriosis, salmonellosis, enteric _E. coli_ infections, hepatitis E, Q fever, psittacosis, influenza A, Newcastle disease, hendra virus, nipah virus, herpes B encephalitis, toxoplasmosis, cat scratch disease, SARS, malaria of nonhuman primates, hantavirus infections, ebolavirus and Marburg virus infections, and bacterial and fungal skin infections, to mention only a selection (http://www.absa.org/pdf/ZoonoticFactSheet.pdf). Some are transmitted by direct contact (including animal bites and needle stick injuries), contaminated food, water, aerosol, or bites of arthropod vectors. Some have multiple modes of transmission. A zoo employee with a contagious zoonosis may then become a source for further spread of the infection into the community.\n\nAn excellent review on this topic is: Chethan Kumar HB, Lokesha KM, Madhavaprasad CB, Shilpa VT, Karabasanavar NS and Kumar A (2013) Occupational zoonoses in zoo and wildlife veterinarians in India, Vet World 6(9): 605-613. This article reports that there are in India 198 zoos (including circuses), 102 national parks, 515 wildlife sanctuaries, 47 conservation reserves and 4 community reserves for the purpose of wildlife conservation.\n\nIt appears from the news report above that so far 60 employees at the zoo in Kanpur, India were examined for the presence of some of these zoonoses. We are not told which zoonotic diseases were surveyed and exactly how the examinations were done, perhaps by history and physical exams, serologies, skin tests (e.g., tuberculin skin test), microbiologic tests (e.g., stool cultures), or chest X-rays. Of the 60 employees examined so far, 30 have evidence, perhaps serological, of leptospirosis, and 10 have evidence, also perhaps serological, of brucellosis.\n\nWe are also not told if any of these employees were currently ill as a result of a zoonosis, nor the degree of contact the employees had with the zoo animals. For example, some of the zoo employees with evidence of leptospirosis or brucellosis may have administrative roles with very limited animal contact.\n\nTo understand the significance of this prevalence survey, however, we would also need to know if the prevalence of these diseases in zoo employees reflects their prevalence in the general community. (See: Forsyth MB, Morris AJ, Sinclair DA, Pritchard CP. Investigation of zoonotic infections among Auckland Zoo staff: 1991-2010. Zoonoses Public Health. 2012;59(8):561-7. Abstract available at: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?orig_db=PubMed&cmd=search&cmd_current=&term=Forsyth%20MB%20%E2%80%8E2012%20.) What percent of the general population in Kanpur has evidence of leptospirosis or brucellosis? Further information on the situation at the Kanpur zoo by knowledgeable individuals would be greatly appreciated.\n\nKanpur is a city of almost 2.8 million residents in Uttar Pradesh, India (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur#Geography.) A map of Indian states is accessible at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm. LEPTOSPIROSIS, BRUCELLOSIS - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH) ZOO EMPLOYEES\n*****************************************************************\n According to reliable sources, as many as 30 zoo employees are affected with leptospirosis disease (caused by bacteria _Leptospira_) alone. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://www.laprensa.hn/honduras/sanpedrosula/383320-96/story.html\n\n\nCattle ranchers in the northwestern region of Honduras are concerned about an outbreak of brucellosis and bovine tuberculosis that is affecting cattle in the country. Jorge Handal, chairman of the Cattlemen's Association (Agas, by its initials in Spanish) said that unless action is taken these [outbreaks] can turn into an epidemic that could deal a serious blow to Honduran livestock because the bacteria affect the breeding cow, which would not be able to breed again.\n\n'The livestock sector in Honduras has been given a real hit. If this [outbreak) becomes an epidemic, and we hope to God that it will not, all the cattle could be lost,' said Handal, who has called upon President Porfirio Lobo to revive a [livestock] health program to control the outbreak of the bacteria.\n\nLivestock producers attended a seminar given by Julio Paredes, a veterinarian and microbiologist from Ecuador, on how to detect positive cases of the bacteria in cattle and what measures to take. These bacteria are a problem that occurs in all countries that have livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[We do not often hear of simultaneous outbreaks of bovine tuberculosis and brucellosis, but it can happen.\n\nBovine brucellosis, caused by the bacterium _Brucella abortus_, is an economically important cause of abortions in cattle. _B. abortus_ also affects other species including bison, buffalo, and elk; some species are maintenance hosts for this organism. Infections in wildlife can hinder eradication efforts in cattle. In addition, _B. abortus_ is a human pathogen. In humans, brucellosis can be a serious, debilitating, and sometimes chronic disease that may affect a variety of organs. Most cases are the result of occupational exposure to infected animals, but infections can also occur from ingesting contaminated dairy products.\n\nIn animals, _B. abortus_ frequently causes abortion, especially in bovine, and is usually transmitted by contact with the placenta, fetus, fetal fluids, and vaginal discharges from infected animals. Animals are infectious after either abortion or full-term parturition. _B. abortus_ may also be found in the milk, urine, semen, feces, and hygroma [cystic swelling containing a serous fluid] fluids. Shedding in milk can be prolonged or lifelong, and may be intermittent. Many infected cattle become chronic carriers.\n\nUnderstanding the epidemiology of the disease, where it came from, and how it came to be in a particular herd are important aspects of controlling the disease. This investigation allows one to determine how far the disease has spread, and therefore, how to contain it.\n\n_B. abortus_ can be eradicated from a herd by test and removal procedures, or by depopulation. It is possible, using this method, to become brucellosis free.\n\nBovine tuberculosis is a chronic bacterial disease of cattle that occasionally affects other species of mammals. This disease is a significant zoonosis that can spread to humans, typically by the inhalation of aerosols or the ingestion of unpasteurized milk. In developed countries, eradication programs have reduced or eliminated tuberculosis in cattle, and human disease is now rare; however, reservoirs in wildlife can make complete eradication difficult. Bovine tuberculosis is still common in less developed countries, and severe economic losses can occur from livestock deaths, chronic disease, and trade restrictions. In some situations, this disease may also be a serious threat to endangered species.\n\nBovine tuberculosis results from infection by _Mycobacterium bovis_, a Gram positive, acid-fast bacterium in the _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ complex of the family _Mycobacteriaceae_.\n\n_M. bovis_ can be transmitted by the inhalation of aerosols, by ingestion, or through breaks in the skin. The importance of these routes varies between species. Bovine tuberculosis is usually maintained in cattle populations, but a few other species can become reservoir hosts.\n\nTuberculosis is usually a chronic debilitating disease in cattle, but it can occasionally be acute and rapidly progressive. Early infections are often asymptomatic. In countries with eradication programs, most infected cattle are identified early and symptomatic infections are uncommon. In the late stages, common symptoms include progressive emaciation, a low-grade fluctuating fever, weakness, and inappetence. Animals with pulmonary involvement usually have a moist cough that is worse in the morning, during cold weather or exercise, and may have dyspnea or tachypnea. In the terminal stages, animals may become extremely emaciated and develop acute respiratory distress.\n\nBovine tuberculosis can be controlled by test-and-slaughter or test-and-segregation methods. Affected herds are re-tested periodically to eliminate cattle that may shed the organism; the tuberculin test is generally used. Infected herds are usually quarantined, and animals that have been in contact with reactors are traced. Only test-and-slaughter techniques are guaranteed to eradicate tuberculosis from domesticated animals.\n\nWhile there is a vaccine to control brucellosis in bovines, until recently there has not been a vaccine for tuberculosis in bovines. There is a vaccine showing promise and is under development.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_abortus.pdf and http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/bovine_tuberculosis.pdf.\n\nHonduras may be found on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1G7K. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTuberculosis is usually a chronic debilitating disease in cattle, but it can occasionally be acute and rapidly progressive. People can become infected if they're exposed to a dog's birthing fluid, saliva, feces, urine, or eye or nasal fluids.\n\nState officials are encouraging anyone who suspects their dog is infected, or who has a dog that may have come from a breeder with infected dogs, to get the animal tested. Antibiotics will not cure the disease in dogs. 'Pets do not have to be euthanized, but it's important to follow the guidelines to prevent spreading the infection, including spaying or neutering, and isolation from other dogs,' State Veterinarian James Averill said in message posted this week [26 Nov 2013] on the agriculture department's website\n[http://www.michigan.gov/mdard/0,4610,7-125-1572_3628-317198--,00.html].\nIn a 2009 report, the department said canine brucellosis was 'an emerging concern in Michigan's dog breeding facilities and 'puppy mills.' ' That year, officials investigated 14 suspected cases; 5 were confirmed positive.\n\nPeople infected with brucellosis may experience fever, body aches, headaches, sweating and fatigue, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In humans, brucellosis is also known as undulant fever or Mediterranean fever, state officials said. [or Malta fever - Mod.TG]\n\nOther animals that are most commonly infected with brucellosis include sheep, cattle, goats and pigs, according to the CDC. Consuming undercooked meat or raw dairy products can lead to human infection.\n\nKristi Valentini, marketing manager for Michigan Veterinary Specialists, said it's rare to see brucellosis in dogs. 'It's so rare that the 3 internists I talked to in our Southfield and Ann Arbor hospitals have never seen a case of it in their careers,' she said. 'It's more likely to occur in large animals, like livestock, or dogs that are breeding animals.'\n\nMontcalm County case\n--------------------\nOfficials said the Montcalm County case involved an occasional dog breeder with 6 dogs, including Boston terriers, pugs, and French bulldogs. 5 of the 6 dogs tested positive for brucellosis and were euthanized. No humans were known to have fallen ill.\n\nMackinac County case\n--------------------\nThe Mackinac County case involved 2 golden retriever/Labrador mixes who were brought to Michigan from Kentucky in 2011. The dogs were littermates and had a history of back pain, state officials said. Both dogs tested positive and were euthanized.\n\nCalhoun County case\n-------------------\nIn Calhoun County, a breeder with 14 breeding dogs took 4 of them to a veterinarian for testing. One of the males tested positive and was euthanized. The other dogs were put under quarantine. No humans were known to have fallen ill.\n\nState officials offered these tips:\n- Dog owners should make sure that any dogs they are planning to use in a breeding program do not have brucellosis.\n- Breeding kennels should be on a brucellosis surveillance program.\n- People purchasing a puppy from a breeder should ask to see negative test results from the dogs that produced the litter. Anyone getting a dog from a pet shop or animal shelter should talk to their veterinarian about screening tests.\n- Newly acquired breeding dogs and dogs with a history of reproductive problems or certain eye or spine disorders should be tested.\n\n[Byline: Ann Zaniewski]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2_1t. The counties affected can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/michigan.shtml.\n\nCanine brucellosis, caused by _Brucella canis_, is an important cause of reproductive failure, particularly in kennels. This organism causes abortions, stillbirths, epididymitis [inflammation of ducts next to the testicle], orchitis [inflammation of the testicle] and sperm abnormalities in dogs. Although dogs that have been spayed or neutered do not have reproductive signs, they occasionally develop other conditions such as ocular disease and discospondylitis (inflammation of the spinal vertebrae and intervertebral discs). _B. canis_ can persist in an animal even after antibiotic treatment. In kennels, infected dogs are often euthanized to prevent them from infecting other dogs or people. Canine brucellosis is sometimes difficult to diagnose with the currently available tests.\n\nAlthough _B. canis_ is zoonotic, its importance as a cause of human illness is still unclear. Few cases have been reported in people, and most of these infections have been mild. However, human infections with _B. canis_ may be underdiagnosed. The symptoms of this disease are nonspecific, diagnostic suspicion is low among physicians, and bacterial culture is the only commonly available test for diagnosis in people.\n\n_B. canis_ occurs in the fetus, placenta, fetal fluids, and vaginal discharge after an abortion or stillbirth. It can persist in vaginal discharges for several weeks after an abortion. It is also shed in normal vaginal secretions, particularly during estrus, as well as in milk. High concentrations of _B. canis_ may be found in semen for weeks or months after infection, and intermittent shedding of smaller quantities can occur for years. _B. canis_ is also shed in urine, and low concentrations of bacteria may be excreted in saliva, nasal and ocular secretions and feces.\n\nIn dogs, _B. canis_ primarily enters the body by ingestion and through the genital, oronasal and conjunctival mucosa, but transmission through broken skin may also be possible. Most cases are thought to be acquired by venereal transmission or by contact with the fetus and fetal membranes after abortions and stillbirths. Puppies can be infected in utero, and may remain persistently infected even if they appear normal. Nursing puppies can be infected from milk, but the importance of this route is controversial. Other potential sources of infection include blood transfusions and contaminated syringes.\n\n_B. canis_ can be spread on fomites. In conditions of high humidity, low temperatures and no sunlight, _Brucella_ spp can remain viable for several months in water, aborted fetuses, feces, equipment, and clothing. _Brucella_ spp can withstand drying, particularly when organic material is present, and can survive in dust and soil. Survival is longer when the temperature is low, particularly when it is below freezing.\n\nHumans usually become infected with members of the genus _Brucella_ by ingesting organisms or via the contamination of mucous membranes and abraded skin. In case reports, _B. canis_ infections have been described after close contact with dogs, especially animals that recently aborted or gave birth, and after exposure to large amounts of the organism in laboratories (such as, contact with bacterial cultures). However, the source of the organism could not be determined in some cases.\n\nWhile documented human cases of _B. canis_ are rare, and may be underreported, immunocompromised people should be especially careful around animals known to be positive for _B. canis_.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "Source: Detroit Free Press [edited]\nhttp://www.freep.com/article/20131127/NEWS06/311270054/Canine-brucellosis-disease\n\n\nState agriculture officials said this week that they've recently investigated 3 cases [involving 8 dogs] of a bacterial disease that affects dogs and can be transmitted to humans. In general, the geographical distribution of biovar 2 has historically been in a broad range between Scandinavia and the Balkans. The prevalence in wild boars appears to be high throughout continental Europe. In recent outbreaks in Europe, wild boars have been implicated as the source of transmission of biovar 2 to outdoor reared pigs; in rare cases, such as the one recently described in Belgium (see 20120520.1139015), other domestic animals, such as bovines, may become infected.\n\nIn addition to wild boars, the European hare (_Lepus capensis_) is also considered to be a reservoir for _B. suis_ biovar 2 and has been implicated as a possible source of transmission to domestic livestock. _Brucella suis_ biovar 2 causes miliary lesions, particularly in reproductive tissues, that often become purulent. To date, biovar 2 has rarely been reported as the cause of human brucellosis. However, biovar 2 infection has been reported in 2 immuno-compromised hunters who had been extensively exposed through gutting or skinning boars or hares.\n\nThe above information is mainly derived from chapter 2.8.5 of OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, where additional information can be found; available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.08.05_PORCINE_BRUC.pdf.\n\nThe above OIE notification includes an interactive map. 'It's unfortunate. We obviously don't like finding brucellosis in our cattle, but the silver lining is that the program we've invested so much time and effort in is working,' Zaluski said. 'The infected cow was found quickly and didn't leave the DSA.'\n\nThe state will not lose its Brucellosis Class Free Status, Zaluski said, as the US Department of Agriculture's [USDA] brucellosis program is currently operating under an interim rule that de-emphasizes class status and directs states to focus on surveillance.\n\nThe cow was found in a herd of about 1000 head, which are currently quarantined and undergoing a whole-herd test. In previous brucellosis-affected herds, the rate of infection has been extremely low -- around 1 percent, Zaluski said.\n\n'Fact is, we're finding it, we're finding it early, and we're not letting infected animals make it to market,' Zaluski said. 'We've got a good program that works well for our producers and keeps infected animals from entering interstate commerce.' Governor Steve Bullock said the state has been aggressive in developing and implementing a 'practical and workable' brucellosis plan.\n\n'When brucellosis was found in 2007 for the 1st time in 22 years, it was a real wake-up call,' Bullock said. 'The livestock industry is a vital component of our economy, and as an export state, we had to reassure our trade partners that we're serious about managing brucellosis and eliminating risks to other states. 'Brucellosis risk management is a collective effort. We've got everyone involved -- the departments of Livestock and Fish, Wildlife and Parks, the state legislature, USDA-APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service], ranchers and hunters.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The ranch is located within the state's Designated Surveillance Area (DSA), a disease management area involving Beaverhead, Gallatin, Madison and Park counties, with management practices that include Official Calfhood Vaccination as required by DSA rules and a herd plan. State Veterinarian Jim Logan said in a media release it's important for the public to understand brucellosis has not been found in any livestock in our region.\n\nThe Wyoming Livestock Board, the Wyoming Game and Fish Department and Logan are working together to assess the situation and identify appropriate action.\n\nThe elk that tested positive were identified through the department's statewide brucellosis surveillance program. Through the program, hunters voluntarily submit blood samples from elk they've harvested. Game and Fish says samples are collected from hunters in the fall and early winter, and then analyzed at the department's lab through the winter.\n\nLogan said he'll be working with livestock producers in the area where the elk were found to ensure they are aware of the situation -- and he said they're moving quickly to analyze which actions should be taken. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nThe Wyoming Game and Fish Department carries out a program maintain spatial and temporal separation of bison and elk from cattle, developing habitat enhancements to reduce elk dependency on supplemental feed, implementing management strategies based on research to reduce brucellosis transmission among elk, and conducting a _B. abortus_ strain 19 ballistic elk vaccination program on feedgrounds. Mod.JG, edited]\nhttp://www.elmagallanews.cl/node/10510\n\n\nThe Agriculture and Farming Service (SAG, according to its Spanish initials) in Chile, detected the presence of some cattle with positive serology tests for _Brucella abortus_, the causative agent of bovine brucellosis, during a surveillance control performed in 3 farms on the border with Argentina, in Ultima Esperanza Province (Magellan and Chilean Antarctica region).\n\nIn the face of this situation, SAG for the Magallanes Region decreed sanitation measures in the affected farms, consisting in vaccinating and taking samples of every susceptible animal, restricting the movement of animals, and identifying and slaughtering the [affected] animals.\n\nIn addition, according to Polar radio station, samples will be taken from animals in neighboring and related farms, surveillance will be maintained in the border farms, and 100 percent of susceptible animals brought to slaughterhouses will be tested.\n\nFor his part, Mr Gerardo Otzen, Regional Director of SAG for the Magallanes Region, mentioned that 'given the importance of this disease and its economical consequences, the service has implemented emergency measures, establishing working teams dedicated primarily to investigating the route by which the disease was introduced into this region, which might have been by contact with or introduction of animals from Argentina, given that no cattle has entered the northern region of Chile during the past 10 years.'\n\n'Every effort is being made to prevent the spread of this disease. We believe that the measures implemented, such as placing the farms under quarantine and restricting the movement of animals, will allow us to rapidly recover our status of brucellosis-free region,' he added.\n\nBovine brucellosis is a communicable disease of cattle. It leads to frequent miscarriage events when the disease strikes for the 1st time. It may also lead to the production of weak offspring, causing important economical losses, and it may also become a public health problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Chile may be found at http://www.ildado.com/genimg/chile-map5.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/5u-x.\n\nBrucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost exclusively by _Brucella abortus_; however, _B. suis_ or _B. melitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B. suis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically aborts only once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations appear normal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short period and develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist infection and a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive serum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal parturition but may be delayed in about 15 percent of cows. The incubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage of gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and uterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile. Bacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid uterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease of fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously aborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal parturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of time -- in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are present in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or lick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission may occur by artificial insemination when brucella-contaminated semen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has remained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking unpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not killed by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis has been called undulating fever because of its habit of producing fever and signs that wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nFor his part, Mr Gerardo Otzen, Regional Director of SAG for the Magallanes Region, mentioned that 'given the importance of this disease and its economical consequences, the service has implemented emergency measures, establishing working teams dedicated primarily to investigating the route by which the disease was introduced into this region, which might have been by contact with or introduction of animals from Argentina, given that no cattle has entered the northern region of Chile during the past 10 years.' Weigand MD, DTMH\n BRUCELLOSIS - GERMANY (02): ex MYANMAR, ALERT\n*********************************************\n From: G Weigand [edited]\n<tropmed@web.de>\n\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yangon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Frankfurt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1492801", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, abortus - USA: (NY) ex Ecuador, cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1492801", "date": "2013-01-11 16:25:52", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, SEROTYPE ABORTUS - USA: (NEW YORK) ex ECUADOR, CHEESE\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Jan 2013\nSource: Jana Preis <jana.preis@va.gov> [edited]\n\n\nA 66-year-old veteran was admitted to our facility related to 4 weeks of fever, drenching night sweats, and a 10-pound weight loss. He was a Viet Nam veteran who was born in Ecuador, moving to the USA 40 years before. His last trip back to Ecuador was 5 years previously but does get periodic visits from relatives still living there.\n\nInitial blood cultures grew a bacillus identified as a _Brucella_, and he subsequently had 5 positive blood cultures for the organism over 4 days. Speciation of the organism was done at the New York State Department of Health and revealed to be _B. abortus_. Although he initially denied eating cheese brought from Ecuador, his daughter reported that the family had eaten cheese brought from Ecuador several times in 2012, the last time within a month of the onset of symptoms.\n\nBrucella agglutinins were subsequently positive. A transesophageal echocardiogram did not reveal valvular vegetations. He became afebrile promptly after treatment was begun with rifampin and doxycycline. All follow up blood cultures were negative. No other illnesses or serological evidence of brucellosis were found in other family members. Laboratory workers who had handled the isolate were given antimicrobial prophylaxis and are to have serological follow ups.\n\n--\nMarie Abdullah MD\nIssa Eid\nJana Preis MD\nInfectious Diseases/Microbiology\nVA New York Harbor Health Care System\nBrooklyn Campus\nBrooklyn, NY\n<jana.preis@va.gov>\n\n[The following moderator comments regarding _B. abortus_ in bovines are taken from 'Brucellosis, bison - Canada: (AB),' archive number 20110730.2294:\n\n'Brucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost exclusively by _Brucella abortus_; however, _B. suis_ or _B. melitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B. suis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically aborts only once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations appear normal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short period and develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist infection, and a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive serum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal parturition but may be delayed in about 15 per cent of cows. The incubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage of gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and uterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile. Bacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid uterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease of fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously aborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal parturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of time, in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are present in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or lick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission may occur by artificial insemination when brucella-contaminated semen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has remained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking unpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not killed by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis has been called undulating fever because of its habit of producing fever and signs that wax and wane over an extended period of time.' - Mod.LL]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1nEs.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n VA New York Harbor Health Care System\nBrooklyn Campus\nBrooklyn, NY\n<jana.preis@va.gov>\n\n Brucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease of livestock with significant economic impact. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. "date": "2013-05-06 19:45:09", "main_text": "BOVINE BRUCELLOSIS - FIJI\n*************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 2 May 2013\nSource: ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) Radio Australia [edited]\nhttp://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/radio/program/pacific-beat/fiji-officials-predict-brucellosis-outbreak-under-full-control-within-a-year/1124712\n\n\nFiji's veterinary service has been struggling to eradicate an outbreak of the cattle disease, brucellosis. But veterinary authorities say after a major effort, they expect to have the disease fully under control within the next 12 months.\n\nPresenter: Geraldine Coutts\n\nSpeaker: Dr Stephen Angus, Principal Veterinary Officer from the Department of Agriculture in Fiji\n\nAngus: First of all I'll give you a brief history of brucellosis in Fiji, there was a major campaign to eradicate brucellosis and tuberculosis in the 80s. Fiji was declared free of brucellosis on or about 1990. But unfortunately TB was never eradicated and brucellosis re-emerged in 2009. It started with an abortion storm in an area called Tailevu, which is one of the major dairying areas not far from Suva.\n\nCoutts: The link between TB and brucellosis? So, is it transmitted between people and cattle?\n\nAngus: The link, they're both zoonotic diseases affecting both animals and humans and they are of public health concern. The 2 diseases are not inextricably linked except through the dairying industry.\n\nCoutts: How contagious is it and, I guess the follow on from that, is it easily spread?\n\nAngus: Brucellosis and tuberculosis are easily spread, they're both bacterial diseases, they're both highly infectious, and if left unchecked you can get quite high morbidities.\n\nCoutts: Where exactly are the flashpoints, the points of most concern in Fiji at the moment?\n\nAngus: The concerns at the moment are that brucellosis is mainly in the dairy industry, the major dairying areas in the central region of Fiji.\n\nCoutts: Can the brucellosis itself in cattle be cured? Or if an animal gets it, does it necessarily mean it needs to be destroyed?\n\nAngus: Unfortunately that is so, there is no effective cure; once an animal is infected it generally is infected for life and unfortunately has to be destroyed.\n\nCoutts: And does that mean that if a cow in a herd gets it, the whole herd is contaminated?\n\nAngus: Absolutely not. We have had major success in the last year in cleaning out a number of herds of cattle of this infection.\n\nCoutts: The problem of not being able to contain it, how can that be explained?\n\nAngus: Hang on a second, I think someone's been misinforming you. Containing it is exactly what we've been doing in the last 12 months. Prior to that it was in an epidemic phase and the prevalence rose to approximately 3 per cent of the dairy herd in the central region. It is currently running at well under one per cent.\n\nCoutts: Well, why can't it be eradicated?\n\nAngus: It certainly can be eradicated and we are putting in major efforts to do so.\n\nCoutts: But it hasn't been because it's been evident in the country for some years now.\n\nAngus: It's been evident since 2009. As I explained there was an abortion storm and that was the re-emergence of brucellosis after an absence of nearly 20 years in Fiji.\n\nCoutts: So what happens from this point on?\n\nAngus: From this point on, we put in a major effort into controlling the infected herds. As I say we're having some considerable degree of success at the moment, and we expect to have the disease fully under control within the next 12 months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis, a zoonotic bacterial disease, is usually caused by _Brucella abortus, less frequently by _B. melitensis_, and occasionally by _B. suis_. Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Israel, Australia, and New Zealand are believed to be free from the agent.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ from abortion material, udder secretions, or from tissues removed at post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions. Additional background is available in OIE's terrestrial Manual, at http://tinyurl.com/cvby6ao.\n\nAccording to Fiji's most recent available annual report to the OIE (2011), during that year 25 new outbreaks of bovine brucellosis (_B, abortus_) were recorded, including 250 'cases' among 6129 susceptible animals of which none were destroyed, while 63 were slaughtered. 116 bovine animals were 'routine vaccinated'; 259 were 'ring vaccinated'.\n\nThe cattle population in 2011 was 44 388 head in 792 establishments.\n\nAdditional information on the current control policy addressing bovine brucellosis in Fiji will be welcomed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1Cyn.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis, a zoonotic bacterial disease, is usually caused by _Brucella abortus, less frequently by _B. melitensis_, and occasionally by _B. suis_. The results revealed 10 of the beasts had swine brucellosis and 16 had pseudorabies.\n\nRefuge biologist Rick Eastridge says that shouldn't discourage hunting the animals. But hunters should take appropriate precautions when handling their kills.\n\nThe wildlife service says hunters should wear rubber gloves and wash with soap and hot water as soon as possible after handling a feral pig carcass. Meat from feral hogs should be cooked thoroughly before being eaten.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals, and the whole ecosystem.\n\n_Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans and spillover into the domestic population can adversely impact profits. Pseudorabies is an acute, frequently fatal disease with a worldwide distribution that affects swine primarily and other domestic and wild animals incidentally. The pseudorabies virus has emerged as a significant pathogen in the USA since the 1960s, probably because of the increase in confinement swine housing or perhaps because of the emergence of more virulent strains. Pseudorabies is a reportable disease. It causes lumps and scars in the ram's testicle, which can block the flow of sperm. According to Senior District Vet Dan Salmon, many producers are unaware of the disease and the problems it can cause -- reduced fertility or infertility, lower lambing percentages, longer joining and lambing intervals, and consequent economic losses.\n\n'In the late 1990s, testing of all rams in the former Riverina RLPB district (Moulamein and Deniliquin) revealed that ovine brucellosis was present in one third of ram flocks,' he said.\n\n'There is no effective treatment for brucellosis and all producers are at risk. Infected rams spread the disease during joining through the ewe or off-season through sodomy.\n\n'Prevention is the key with this disease. Producers should only buy rams from an Ovine Brucellosis Accredited Stud and also regularly check rams.'\n\nProducers can easily check their own rams by feeling for abnormal lumps in the rams' testicles. 'This should be done twice a year, well in advance of joining and recently after the last joining. This will allow enough time for re-tests if they are needed,' Dr Salmon said.\n\n'Any lumps or bumps should be further investigated -- this involves contacting your vet who will organise blood testing. Your vet will also discuss the options available.\n\n'If you are unsure about the rams you have purchased, keep them separate from your home rams until you have them blood tested.\n\n'Also remember that rams often move freely across or through boundary fences, potentially picking up diseases and bringing them back to your property.'\n\nProducers wishing to establish a group to combat ovine brucellosis should contact their local LHPA for assistance.\n\nFurther information on ovine brucellosis, including the list of ovine brucellosis accredited flocks, is available at http://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/agriculture/livestock/sheep/health/ovine-brucellosis-scheme.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucella ovis_ produces a disease unique to sheep, in which epididymitis and orchitis impair fertility -- the principal economic effect. Occasionally, placentitis and abortion are seen, and there may be perinatal mortality. The disease was 1st described in New Zealand and Australia and has since been reported from many sheep-raising areas of the world.\n\nRams, as young as 8 weeks, have been infected experimentally by various nonvenereal routes. The disease can be transmitted among rams by direct contact. Active infection in ewes is unusual but has developed after mating with naturally infected rams. Contaminated pastures do not appear to be important in the spread of the disease. Infection frequently persists in rams, and a high percentage shed _B. ovis_ intermittently for several years.\n\nBecause not all infected rams show palpable abnormalities of scrotal tissues (and not all cases of epididymitis are due to brucellosis), the remaining rams must be examined further. Rams shedding organisms, but having no lesions, must be identified by culture of semen. Repeated examinations may be necessary to identify intermittent shedders. Microscopic examination of stained semen smears may also be helpful; fluorescent antibody examination is a highly specific diagnostic aid. Serologic tests used for eradication of disease and certification of animals include ELISA, complement fixation, hemagglutination inhibition, indirect agglutination, and gel diffusion.\n\nIncidence and spread of the disease may be reduced by regular examination of rams before the breeding season and culling of those with obvious genital abnormalities. Because susceptibility in rams increases markedly with age, it is advantageous to keep a young ram flock and isolate noninfected rams from older, possibly infected rams.\n\nImmunization of rams has been practiced extensively in New Zealand using 2 doses of killed _B. ovis_ cells in adjuvant. Because infection in ewes apparently originates almost exclusively from service by infected rams, lamb losses through infection of ewes may be controlled economically by restricting vaccination to rams.\n\nChlortetracycline and streptomycin used concurrently have affected bacteriologic cures. However, treatment is not economic except in especially valuable rams, and even if infection is eliminated, fertility may remain impaired.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110506.htm.\n\nNew South Wales, Australia may be found on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1oP3. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "Because susceptibility in rams increases markedly with age, it is advantageous to keep a young ram flock and isolate noninfected rams from older, possibly infected rams. \n\nProducers can easily check their own rams by feeling for abnormal lumps in the rams' testicles. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.erbol.com.bo/noticia.php?identificador=2147483965147\n\n\nThe director of the San Juan de Dios Hospital of Cotagaita, Marcelo Mariscal, announced on Fri 12 Oct 2012, that 5 cases of brucellosis were reported in this municipality, raising fears that the cattle in the region are infected with the bacterium.\n\n'The hospital has cared for 4-5 cases of human brucellosis. This disease is a zoonosis which is transmitted through the consumption of meat or milk products from goats or cattle,' explained the doctor.\n\nBrucellosis, also called Malta fever or undulant fever, is a bacterial disease that attacks several mammalian species including man. It also infects other mammalians among which are those which have a high economic impact such as bovines, equines, porcines, ovines, caprines, and other wildlife.\n\nMariscal said that the disease [brucellosis] is characterized by muscle pains, fever, and general malaise, and its complexity is due to the fact that the treatment is quite prolonged, hence the emphasis on a prevention campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a disease that is thought to have existed since ancient times, as it was first described more than 2000 years ago by the Romans and Hippocrates. It was not until 1887 that a British physician, Dr David Bruce, isolated the organism that causes brucellosis from several deceased patients from the island of Malta. This disease has had several names throughout its history, including Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Crimean fever, Bang's disease, and undulant fever (because of the relapsing nature of the fever associated with the disease). See http://www.medicinenet.com/brucellosis/article.htm.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms.\n\nThe signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive, and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, working in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab is vital. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3JLb.]", "summary": "This disease has had several names throughout its history, including Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Crimean fever, Bang's disease, and undulant fever (because of the relapsing nature of the fever associated with the disease). Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.eldiariodelfindelmundo.com/noticias/leer/45749/confirmaron-que-hubo-dos-nuevos-casos-de-brucelosis-canina.html\n\n\nThe Trade Union of Workers and Municipal Employees (ASOEM by its Spanish initials) of Rio Grande [department, Tierra del Fuego province] has confirmed 2 new cases of brucellosis [by _Brucella canis_] in workers of the Rio Negro Municipality. The provincial Ministry of Labor has ordered the suspension of activities in the municipal dog pound [animal shelter].\n\nASOEM director Eduardo Cabral said: 'Last week [week of 29 Oct 2012], we had confirmation of 2 new cases of brucellosis in municipal workers and are awaiting the results for other workers. We are talking of about 8 workers with brucellosis.'\n\nThe Administration and Records Secretary noted that this is an incurable disease and complained that in 2010, the union had already asked the Ministry of Labor to close the shelter and make the necessary renovations to keep the animals and the workers separate. 'There were no cases of brucellosis at that time.'\n\nOf note, the animal shelter remains closed by order from the Ministry of Labor after complaints from ASOEM.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Domestic dogs can also be affected occasionally by _B. abortus_, _B. suis_, and _B. melitensis_, and it is not clearly stated that the isolates were formally identified as _B. canis_.\n\nThe following is reproduced from Brucellosis, human, canine - USA: (NY) B. canis 20120608.1160121:\n\n_Brucella canis_ was initially recognized as an agent causing canine abortions by Carmichael in 1967 (1). Subsequently, human infections were diagnosed, primarily in laboratory workers as well as dog owners. It was subsequently clearly shown by a group from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in 1975 (2) that routine brucella agglutinin testing is not helpful for _B. canis_ infection in dogs or humans, and a more specific assay is now available (3).\n\nThe manifestations of _B. canis_ in humans can be minimal or can be an indolent bacteremia, as in this case. Complications of this infection can occur, including osteomyelitis, endocarditis, mycotic aneurysms, and granulomatous hepatitis (3).\n\n1. Carmichael LE, Bruner DW. Characteristics of a newly-recognized species of _Brucella_ responsible for infectious canine abortion. Cornell Vet 1968; 58: 579-92.\n2. Munford RS, Weaver RE, Patton C, et al. Human disease caused by _Brucella canis_. JAMA 1975; 231: 1267-9; available at http://jama.jamanetwork.com/pdfaccess.ashx?ResourceID=488710&PDFSource=13.\n3. Lucero NE, Escobar GI, Ayala SM, Jacob N. Diagnosis of human brucellosis caused by _Brucella canis_. J Med Microbiol 2005; 54(Pt 5): 457-61; available at http://jmm.sgmjournals.org/content/54/5/457.long. - Mod.LL]\n\n[This disease in people is somewhat difficult to diagnose and is underreported. Urine from infected dogs is one of the main sources of infection to people.\n\nIn dogs, _B. canis_ is mainly transmitted by contact with the fetus and fetal membranes after abortions/stillbirths or by venereal transmission. This organism primarily enters the body by ingestion and through the genital, oronasal, and conjunctival mucosa, but transmission through broken skin may also be possible. In utero infections occur. Nursing puppies can be infected from milk, but the importance of this route is controversial. Other potential sources of infection include blood transfusions and contaminated syringes.\n\nDogs often become chronically infected with _B. canis_ and can shed this organism for prolonged periods. Although some dogs clear the infection after a year (generally with treatment), others remain bacteremic for 5 years and possibly longer.\n\n_B. canis_ can also be spread on fomites. In conditions of high humidity, low temperatures, and no sunlight, _Brucella_ spp. can remain viable for several months in water, aborted fetuses, feces, equipment, and clothing. _Brucella_ species can withstand drying, particularly when organic material is present, and can survive in dust and soil. Survival is longer when the temperature is low, particularly when it is below freezing.\n\nHumans usually become infected with _Brucella_ spp. by ingesting organisms or by the contamination of mucous membranes and abraded skin. Infection with _B. canis_ seems to require close contact with infected dogs or contact with bacterial cultures. _B. canis_ is zoonotic, but the virulence of this organism for humans may be low, although it may be higher than has been reported in the past. Under-reporting of this disease may skew the reporting statistics. Under-reporting may occur because the disease is difficult to diagnose, and many physicians do not have the disease on their zoonotic radar.\n\n_B. canis_ infections in humans resemble brucellosis caused by other _Brucella_ species. Some people infected with _Brucella_ remain asymptomatic, which is one reason for the difficulty in diagnosis and the resulting subsequent under-reporting. In symptomatic cases, brucellosis is extremely variable, and the clinical signs may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, this disease begins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs such as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia, and generalized aches. Drenching sweats can occur, particularly at night. Oral lesions were reported in a child concurrently infected with _B. canis_ and cytomegalovirus and resolved with antibiotic treatment for brucellosis. Another patient with a _B. canis_ infection had fever of unknown origin.\n\nSome patients with brucellosis recover spontaneously, while others develop persistent symptoms that typically wax and wane. Occasionally seen complications include arthritis, spondylitis, chronic fatigue, and epididymo-orchitis. Neurologic signs (including personality changes, meningitis, uveitis, and optic neuritis), anemia, internal abscesses, nephritis, endocarditis, and dermatitis can also occur. Other organs and tissues can also be affected, resulting in a wide variety of syndromes. Treatment is with antibiotics; however, relapses can be seen months after the initial symptoms, even in successfully treated cases. The mortality rate is low; in untreated persons, estimates of the case fatality rate vary from less than 2 per cent to 5 per cent. Deaths are usually caused by endocarditis or meningitis.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yJb.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, CANINE - ARGENTINA: (TIERRA DEL FUEGO), BRUCELLA CANIS, SHELTER WORKERS\n*******************************************************************************************\n \n\nASOEM director Eduardo Cabral said: 'Last week [week of 29 Oct 2012], we had confirmation of 2 new cases of brucellosis in municipal workers and are awaiting the results for other workers. This finding also justifies engaging investigations to assess the respective transmission between wild and domestic animals. The strengthening of the surveillance program in wild ruminants and laboratory tests to be undertaken should help support this finding.\n\nFor the cattle, sheep and goat sector, intensive monitoring of this disease is already planned on their return from summer pastures. It will clarify the risk of contamination of farms in mountain areas.\n\nScreening cattle herds producing raw milk cheese is undertaken annually.\n\nMonitoring of clinical signs in domestic ruminants is strengthened by increased awareness of farmers and veterinarians taking measures in cases of abortion.\n\nThe support of the national platform for epidemiological surveillance in animal health has been sought. An assessment of the situation will be made with the experts involved in this monitoring in the coming days to identify any additional measures in susceptible populations, wild or domestic.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The positive case mentioned might be an animal that reacted to a serological test to detect antibodies against _Brucella abortus_. See: http://www.medicinenet.com/brucellosis/article.htm.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms.\n\nThe signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive, and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, working in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab is vital. - Mod.LL]\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1wvK.]", "summary": "\n\n\nIf the trend continues in cases of human brucellosis in the state of Jalisco from the consumption of [unpasteurized] products derived from infected cattle, it will exceed that of 2011, as reported by the holder of the Secretariat of Health Jalisco (SJS), Antonio Munoz Serrano, after which the health unit recognized 142 cases so far in 2012, of which 89 are women and 53 men, a fact that contrasts with the cases registered in 2011, which to this date had 87 cases and closed with 187. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n , he explained that 'it is not uncommon to find patients with brucellosis, especially in rural regions where dairy products such as cheese or the milk of goats carry this disease.'\n\nMunoz Serrano urged the public to avoid the consumption of foods derived from unpasteurized milk, such as those often found in flea markets, and also to buy from establishments that offer cheeses and creams of quality. Communicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a disease that is thought to have existed since ancient times, as it was 1st described more than 2000 years ago by the Romans and Hippocrates. This disease has had several names throughout its history, including Mediterranean fever, Malta fever, Crimean fever, Bang's disease, and undulant fever (because of the relapsing nature of the fever associated with the disease). The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive, and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, working in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab is vital.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-24 00:00:00", "1887-03-24 00:00:00", "2012-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1196658", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, porcine - Belgium (02): serovar 2, wild boar, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1196658", "date": "2012-07-10 21:09:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - BELGIUM (02): SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, BOVINE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nFrom: David Fretin <David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be> [edited]\n\n\nBrucella suis biovar 2 in cattle: Follow up\n-------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of Brucellosis due to _Brucella abortus_ and affecting Belgian cattle was 1st notified on 5 Mar 2012 and is currently investigated. In the context of a bulk tank milk screening aimed at controlling this outbreak, a sample from a farm near Florennes (Province of Namur) was found ELISA positive by the local 1st-line laboratory (ARSIA). Subsequent individual serum testing of all (155) lactating animals of this herd identified a single 4-year old cow (born on the farm and not pregnant) that tested positive by ELISA and sero-agglutination. This animal displayed no clinical symptom of brucellosis and was slaughtered on 23 Apr 2012.\n\nBacteriological tests were conducted at the national reference laboratory (CERVA-CODA) on lymph nodes, spleen and uterus. The lymph nodes were found negative, but colonies of a _Brucella_ sp. were isolated from both the spleen and the uterus and were unexpectedly identified as _Brucella suis biovar 2_ (_B. suis bv2_) using both biochemical and molecular typing methods. A B. suis-specific real-time PCR test (Ref 1) turned positive on DNA extracted directly from the uterus, ruling out a possible cross-contamination in the laboratory. Molecular typing of this cow isolate demonstrated a genetic profile highly related to the profile of _B. suis bv2_ strains normally retrieved from wild boars in Belgium. None of the other animals in the herd was found positive for Brucella.\n\nAuthorities have ordered a one-month hunting campaign in the surroundings of Florennes [which] started on 19 May 2012 with the aim of reducing urgently the local wild boar population while providing an opportunity to investigate _B. suis_ carriage in these animals. A key issue will be achieved by comparing the genetic profile of the cow isolate to that of the local wild boar strains, if those turn out to be carriers of _B. suis bv2_.\n\nWild boars and hares are known to be infected by _B. suis bv 2_ in many European countries. A case of cattle infection by _B. suis bv2_ probably transmitted from an infected wild hare was reported in Denmark in 1995 (Ref 2). In the present case, contaminated wild boars are the most probable source of infection. The wild boar population of the Walloon region in Belgium is known to be steadily increasing since the last 2 decades, with a concomitant risk of introducing swine brucellosis in pig farms, especially when pigs are raised outdoors. However, the way _B. suis bv2_ can be passed from wild boars to cattle as reported here remains elusive.\n\nContaminated viscera from a hunted animal or aborted material left over in a pasture are possible contamination sources. It should be reminded that harvested viscera and carcasses of wild boars shot dead by hunters represent a potential contamination risk for susceptible animals and [should] not be left over in the natural environment, especially in the vicinity of pastures or farming areas.\n\nReferences\n1. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, Neubauer H, Garin-Bastuji B, Albert D, Van Hessche M, Manart M, Godfroid J, Walravens K, Wattiau P. (2008) Brucella suis identification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol. 131:376-385.\n2. Andersen F.M. and Pedersen K.B. (1995) Brucellosis. A case of natural infection of a cow with Brucella suis biotype 2, Dan. Vet. 78:408.\n\nReported by David Fretin, Pierre Wattiau, Hein Imberechts (National Reference Laboratory for Brucellosis, CODA-CERVA, Brussels), Guy Czaplicki and Christian Quinet (ARSIA).\n\n--\nDavid Fretin\nHead of Unit 'Infectious Genitopathology in Cattle'\nOperational Direction Bacterial Diseases\nCODA-CERVA\nVeterinary & Agrochemical Research Center\nB-1180 Brussels\nBelgium\n<David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be>\n\n[The 1st-hand above update on the event, complementary to the information included in postings 20120623.1178499 and 20120520.1139015, is much appreciated.
