BRUCELLOSIS, CERVIDS - CANADA: (NUNAVUT) CARIBOU\n************************************************\n \n\nPhotos of caribou may be found at http://www.mnh.si.edu/arctic/html/caribou_reindeer.html.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-24 00:00:00", "1968-03-24 00:00:00", "1997-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Southampton Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1024159", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, human - USA (03): (MA), unpasteurized milk, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1024159", "date": "2012-01-28 17:10:25", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - USA (03): (MASSACHUSETTS), UNPASTEURIZED MILK, NOT\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2012\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2012/01/no-raw-milk-link-to-brucellosis-in-massachusetts/\n\nA Massachusetts resident who first tested positive for brucellosis has now been confirmed to not have the infection, according to an email from the assistant commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Agricultural Resources (MDAR).\n\n'While initial test results did show up positive, further, more specific and accurate testing by the CDC confirmed that the person does not have brucellosis,' Nathan L'Etoile wrote in the message forwarded by the NOFA/Massachusetts Raw Milk Network.\nAs a result, the MDAR 'will be rescinding the Cease and Desist from the sale of Raw Milk' order that had been issued in the state last week, the email stated.\n\nThe Massachusetts Department of Public Health (DPH), in an email, also confirmed that 'the patient did test negative for brucellosis. The milk and the cows also tested negative for any brucellosis bacteria. Neither DPH or DAR have any health concerns at this time.'\n\nOn 20 Jan 2012, the MDAR and the DPH issued a consumer alert for raw milk from Twin Rivers Farm in Ashley Falls, MA 'due to the possibility of raw milk being contaminated with Brucella.' That earlier news release stated, in part: 'This investigation is being conducted in response to a suspected human case, following an individual's contact with this farm. The presence of Brucella in raw milk represents a significant danger to public health.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-Mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is now apparent that the diagnosis of brucellosis in this case is incorrect due to a false positive result. It was not stated in the initial report how the diagnosis was initially made, either by serological and microbiological means. It is most likely that a commercial laboratory antibody test for brucellosis was the culprit rather than a culture report for 2 reasons. The main reason relates to the fact that every assay has some degree of false positive tests and if the assay is done in a low prevalence population, many of the positives will be false positives. Additionally, culture of brucellae usually takes, especially on primary isolation, more time than it took to become positive here.\n\nIt still may be the case that the individual's illness was related to the ingestion of the raw milk but the diagnosis is not brucellosis. - Mod. LL]\n\n[Any time there is a suspected human case of brucellosis there is traceback to the dairy that may have produced the milk or been involved in the disease. In this case the dairy is known so the animals in question would have undergone a series of testing. There are many tests used before an animal is deemed to be positive. Each test has a certain level of sensitivity and specificity associated with it. Ultimately it means that no test is perfect. When there are cases where a test appears to be positive, then one has to examine what makes a test appear to be positive. Some of the animal tests cross react with _Yersinia enterocolitica_ which the animals can harbor. This bacterium can also be transferred by dirty milking equipment or by operators with dirty hands.\n\nEach animal at the dairy will be subject to blood tests and may also be subject to milk test.\n\nMicroscopic examination of smears stained with the Stamp's modification of the Ziehl-Neelsen method can be useful for a presumptive diagnosis, particularly if the direct examination is supported by serology. Brucella species are not truly acid-fast, but they are resistant to decolorization by weak acids, and stain red against a blue background. Brucellae are coccobacilli or short rods, usually arranged singly but sometimes in pairs or small groups. This test is not definitive. Other organisms such as _Chlamydophila abortus_ and _Coxiella burnetii_ can resemble Brucella. Immunostaining is sometimes used to identify Brucella in smears.\n\nSerology can be used for a presumptive diagnosis of brucellosis, or to screen herds. Serological tests used to test individual cattle and herds include the buffered Brucella antigen tests (rose bengal test and buffered plate agglutination test), complement fixation, indirect or competitive enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) or the fluorescence polarization assay. Other serological tests include rivanol precipitation, acidified antigen procedures and the serum agglutination test (tube or microtiter test). Supplemental tests such as complement fixation or rivanol precipitation are often used to clarify the results from plate or card agglutination tests. ELISAs or the Brucella milk ring test (BRT) can be used to screen herds by detecting antibodies in milk. In vaccinated cattle, the native hapten-based gel precipitation tests (gel diffusion or radial immunodiffusion tests) are sometimes used to distinguish vaccination from infection.\n\nA brucellin allergic skin test can be used to test unvaccinated cattle for B. abortus. This test is performed by injecting the allergen intradermally into the caudal fold, the skin of the flank, or the side of the neck.\n\nA definitive diagnosis can be made if B. abortus is cultured from an animal. Brucella spp. can be isolated on a variety of plain media, or selective media such as Farrell's medium or Thayer-Martin\u2019s modified medium. Enrichment techniques can also be used. Brucella colonies usually become visible after two days growth. After four days of incubation, the colonies are round and approximately 1-2 mm in diameter with smooth margins. When the plates are viewed in daylight through a transparent medium, the colonies are translucent and a pale honey color. From above, they are convex and pearly white. Smooth (S) Brucella cultures can dissociate to rough (R) forms. These colonies are much less transparent and become more granular and dull. In crystal violet staining, rough colonies stain red and smooth colonies stain pale yellow. B. abortus can be identified to the species and biovar level by phage typing and cultural, biochemical and serological characteristics. Genetic techniques can also be used for biotyping. The vaccine strains (B. abortus strains S19 and RB51) can be distinguished from field strains by their growth characteristics and sensitivity to antibiotics and other additives.\n\nIn cattle, B. abortus causes abortions and stillbirths; abortions usually occur during the second half of gestation. Some calves are born alive but weak, and may die soon after birth. The placenta may be retained and secondary metritis can occur. Lactation may be decreased. After the first abortion, subsequent pregnancies are generally normal; however, cows may shed the organism in milk and uterine discharges. Epididymitis, seminal vesiculitis, orchitis or testicular abscesses are sometimes seen in bulls. Infertility occurs occasionally in both sexes, due to metritis or orchitis/epididymitis. Hygromas, particularly on the leg joints, are a common signs in some tropical countries. Arthritis can develop in some long-term infections. Systemic signs do not usually occur in uncomplicated infections, and deaths are rare except in the fetus or newborn. Infections in nonpregnant females are usually asymptomatic. This fact may cause an infection to be unnoticed and/or undiagnosed.\n\nLikewise, there are reasons other than infections which may cause cows to abort their calves, such as genetic defects in the calves or severe mineral imbalances. While dairies will notice them, not every abortion has a definitive diagnosis attached to it. Other diseases causing abortion or epididymitis and orchitis should be considered. In cattle, the differential diagnosis includes trichomoniasis, vibriosis, leptospirosis, listeriosis, infectious bovine rhinotracheitis and various mycoses.\n\nAnimal inoculation is rarely used to isolate B. abortus, but may be necessary if other techniques fail. Guinea pigs or mice can be used.\n\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) techniques and other genetic techniques (restriction fragment length polymorphism or Southern blotting) are available in some laboratories. Similar tests are used to diagnose B. abortus infections in species other than cattle, but each test must be validated in that species.\n\nOne might also ask if the diary workers had any illnesses. There are times when the dairy workers may be the first to have acquired brucellosis, or conversely have passed an infection to the animal.\n\nRaw milk has come under fire from people concerned about diseases, as well as those who believe it to be the most healthy. The first case of bovine tuberculosis that is transmitted to a person consuming raw will may well be undoing of the raw milk industry. While cattle are tested, a disease such as tuberculosis that develops slowly and over time may not test positive for some time. But it could have devastating consequences to the individual(s) involved.\n\nThere are numerous state and federal regulations covering milk production. However, dairy inspections are done by people. Mistakes can and do happen. Political clout can cause some inspectors or their supervisors to \u2018overlook\u2019 some infractions of regulations listed in the Pasteurized Milk Ordinance (PMO). Furthermore, every dairy wants to remain in business, and will complain to authorities including the state veterinarian, who in many cases are pseudo-politicians themselves. These authorities are often interested in keeping dairies open,  and commerce flowing, thus downgrading the importance of public health protection by overlooking regulations within the PMO.\n\nTherefore, the ultimate questions remain: how safe is raw milk? How well are regulations about public health enforced? And for those who choose commerce over public health, will they be able to live with the issue of human death on their hands when it happens on their watch? \u2013 Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1vdg.]", "summary": "Serological tests used to test individual cattle and herds include the buffered Brucella antigen tests (rose bengal test and buffered plate agglutination test), complement fixation, indirect or competitive enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) or the fluorescence polarization assay. \n\n'While initial test results did show up positive, further, more specific and accurate testing by the CDC confirmed that the person does not have brucellosis,' Nathan L'Etoile wrote in the message forwarded by the NOFA/Massachusetts Raw Milk Network. \n\nEach animal at the dairy will be subject to blood tests and may also be subject to milk test. For this reason, cattle are often slaughtered in\nbackyards without complying with basic veterinary and sanitary\nregulations, adversely affecting the epizootic situation and\nfacilitating the spread of brucellosis. Another problem is the\nuncontrolled importation of cattle from other regions of the country\ninfected with brucellosis.\n\nSpeakers offered to establish permanent and mobile veterinary\ninspection posts on the border of Dagestan with the Stavropol\nTerritory and Kalmykia which, in tandem with the law enforcement\nagencies, are expected to inspect the cattle trucks that enter the\nrepublic.\n\n[byline: Timur Abdullaev]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would be interesting to obtain information on the species of\nbrucellosis bacteria involved; these are likely to be _Brucella\nabortus_ and _B. melitensis_. He said the animal was destroyed.\n\nMiller said the ranches were open about the infection and encouraged\nthe Montana Department of Livestock to release the information about\nthe ranch. 'We had one positive animal on the ranch and we tested the\nentire herd,' Miller said. 'It's not unexpected when you're in the\ndesignated surveillance area (for brucellosis), which was created for\na reason.'\n\nLast month state veterinarian Marty Zaluski announced that a bull\nanimal on a Madison County ranch had tested positive for the disease,\nwhich can cause females [bison, cattle, elk] to abort their young.\nZaluski would not release the species of animal or the location of the\nranch other than to say it was in Madison County. He was complying\nwith a law passed by the 2011 Legislature that requires the state to\nkeep information confidential [that would] reveal specific ranchers\nfound to have an animal with the disease .\n\nThe Montana Standard challenged Zaluski to release the information,\nbut had not received a reply as of Wednesday.\n\nMiller said the Snowcrest performed 1,698 tests for brucellosis on the\nranch and the bull was the only one that came back positive. He said\nthey are confident the disease was transmitted by elk. They are\ntesting to confirm that using modern methods that can help identify\nthe source.\n\n'It's not unanticipated; the state would confirm that is an area with\na higher expectation because of elk,' he said. 'I don't think we or\nany of our neighbors are immune to further incidents of brucellosis.'\n\nLast year the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks began a\nstudy of brucellosis in Ruby Valley elk. Biologists found that 12 of\n100 cow elk captured tested positive for exposure to the disease.\n\nThe lone bull bison that tested positive does not trigger a loss of\nMontana's brucellosis-free status by the federal government, said Eric\nLiska, brucellosis program veterinarian with the Montana Department of\nLivestock. Under the rules of the designated surveillance area (for\nbrucellosis), the Snowcrest Ranch is under quarantine.\n\nThat means any livestock taken off the ranch must be hauled in a\nsealed trailer and taken directly to slaughter, Liska said. The ranch\nis barred from selling livestock to other ranches.\n\nLiska said the new rules for ranchers within the surveillance area\ngive them options to manage their herd and prevent further infections\nwithout causing the entire state to lose its brucellosis-free status.\nHe said the adjoining properties will be required to test all their\nanimals.\n\nThe Snowcrest Ranch will need 3 negative tests of all its animals to\nhave the quarantine lifted, Liska said. 'They'll be under quarantine\nuntil we're confident a release of quarantine is safe for the industry\nof our state and the industry of the United States as well,' he said.\n\n[By Nick Gevock]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nProMED-Mail Corr SB\n\n\n\n\n\n\n[Indeed Montana confirmed the animal positive in mid-November 2011\n[ProMed-mail post 20111118.3396]. Brucellosis is an infectious disease passed primarily between animals, but it can be acquired by humans through the consumption of raw milk.\n\nOfficials from the state Department of Public Health said they are investigating Twin Rivers Farm in Ashley Falls as the possible source of the infection, because the infected man purchased raw milk there. The dairy sells raw milk only at the facility, not in retail stores, and officials urged anyone who bought raw milk there to discard it. The owners of Twin Rivers Farm could not be reached for comment. Raw milk is not pasteurized, a process that heats food to kill bacteria. Health officials stressed that pasteurized milk is safe to drink.\n\nDr Alfred DeMaria, the state's top disease tracker, said the infected man, who was not identified because of patient confidentiality rules, is believed to have consumed the milk in late December 2011. But because the illness often starts with flu-like symptoms, it was difficult to pinpoint at first. 'It can percolate along with fever, fatigue, muscle aches, and with nonspecific symptoms, and can be very difficult to diagnose,' DeMaria said. 'It's an astute physician that worked it out,' he said, and alerted public health officials last night.\n\nThe man is recovering and is at home, DeMaria said, and there have been no other reported human infections. Preliminary tests to confirm the infection are expected back next week. State agriculture officials have worked hard over the past half century to reduce brucellosis infections in livestock. Dr Eugene White, an associate professor at the Cummings School of Veterinary Medicine at Tufts University, said the disease is not widely contagious among farm animals, but in areas of the world where it is common, such as South America, it can significantly hamper a herd's ability to reproduce. 'In regions of world that have this commonly, 10 to 25 per cent of cows will abort,' he said.\n\nDr Catherine Brown, the state's public health veterinarian, said the germ is not typically found in the USA, and particularly not in New England. 'We have not seen the bacteria identified in a Massachusetts animal in decades,' Brown said. If the infection is confirmed, it will have 'significant implications' for Massachusetts livestock, she said. 'We will have to figure out how the organism got here, if other livestock was exposed ,and if others are at risk,' she said.\n\nWilliam Gillmeister of the Massachusetts Department of Agricultural Resources said his agency has inspected Twin Rivers Farm and found it to be a well-run business with no history of problems. He said investigators are still trying to determine the source of the infection and are not certain that it is in the farm's raw milk, but the milk sales have been discontinued. Gillmeister said farms must obtain a permit from his department to sell raw milk. 'We regularly test the milk to make sure it is safe,' he said.\n\nThe department and health officials are advising consumers who have purchased raw milk from Twin Rivers Farm to discard it, and anyone who believes they became ill from drinking raw milk should immediately seek medical attention and notify the local board of health or the state's Food Protection Program, at 617-983-6712.\n\n[byline: Kay Lazar]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clearly stated that the milk was of bovine origin but the comments in the posting suggest that this is the case and that the isolate may be _Brucella abortus_, instead of _B. suis_ or _B. melitensis_. However, it appears that additional testing is pending. It is also not stated if, at this point, the diagnosis has been suspected by the use of serological testing of the patient or if brucellae have been isolated from the patient's blood cultures. The organism is fastidious and can be a slow grower on primary growth from the blood.\n\nCampaigns to eradicate _B. abortus_ from cattle in the USA began in 1934 and have been quite successful. A year ago, commenting on a cluster of _B. abortus_ in cattle in Starr County, Texas http://www.tahc.state.tx.us/news/pr/2011/2011Feb_BrucellosisInStarrCounty.pdf it was stated that 'Currently, the only known reservoir for bovine brucellosis is in elk and bison and is in the US Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) located in parts of Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.' ProMED-mail has posted on bovine _B. abortus_ infection in this area in recent years (see 'see also').\n\nOnce again, the specter of human infection acquired from unpasteurized milk or other dairy product has raised its head. Among the illness linked to raw milk include zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _Brucella melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, Coxiella burnetii, and _E. coli_ O157:H7. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ species, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A.\n\nOther diseases that can be related to unpasteurized milk are highlighted in these paragraphs extracted from Leedom JM. Milk and infectious diseases in humans. Clin Infect Dis 2006;43: 610-615 with the citations renumbered to be consecutive starting from 1:\n\n'In 1996 and 1998, there were 2 episodes involving rabid cows that occurred in Massachusetts (1). Milk from rabid cows can contain rabies virus, and transmission via unpasteurized milk is theoretically possible. Temperatures reached during pasteurization kill the virus. 80 persons consumed unpasteurized milk that was collected from the 2 cows, and 9 more had contact with saliva from the cows. All 89 persons received postexposure rabies prophylaxis, and no human cases of rabies eventuated. A similar report in Oklahoma of possible rabies exposure associated with the consumption of raw milk or cream from a rabid cow was circulated in 2006 (2). Tickborne encephalitis, a zoonotic arbovirus infection usually transmitted to humans by the bite of an _Ixodes persulcutus_ or _Ixodes ricinis_ tick, is endemic to Central Europe, Eastern Europe, and Russia (3). However, the virus can be found in the milk of cows and goats with tickborne encephalitis and was reported to be transmissible to humans by the consumption of unpasteurized milk (4). A case-control study failed to confirm oral transmission (5). A diarrhea syndrome (later named Brainerd diarrhea) occurred among 122 residents of Brainerd, Minnesota, during the period Dec 1983-Jul 1984 (6). It was characterized by acute onset, marked urgency, lack of systemic symptoms, failure to respond to conventional antimicrobial agents, and a long median duration of illness (median duration, 16.5 months). The syndrome was linked to consumption of raw milk from a single dairy (6). No etiologic agent was ever isolated. The outbreak of Brainerd diarrhea stopped when all of the dairy's output was diverted and pasteurized (6, MT Osterholm, personal communication). Subsequent outbreaks in Illinois and Texas were not directly associated with milk, although cattle had been in the vicinity of an Illinois well that had its water implicated as a vehicle of transmission (7). Another outbreak of Brainerd-like diarrhea, although not associated with raw milk, affected 58 (15 percent) of 394 passengers aboard a cruise ship visiting the Galapagos Islands in Ecuador (8).\n\n1. CDC. Mass treatment of humans who drank unpasteurized milk from rabid cows--Massachusetts, 1996-1998. JAMA 1999; 281: 1371-72.\n2. Rabies, bovine, human exposure - USA (OK). 2006. Available at: http://www.promedmail.org/. Accessed 26 Jul 2006.\n3. Dumpis U, Crook D, Oksi J. Tick-borne encephalitis. Clin Infect Dis 1999; 28:882-90.\n4. N Engl J Med 1993; 328: 1713-14.\n8. Mintz ED, Weber JT, Guris D, et al. An outbreak of Brainerd diarrhea among travelers to the Galapagos Islands. J Infect Dis 1998; 177:1041-15.'\n\nThe following is obtained from moderator commentis regarding _B. abortus_ in bovines (Brucellosis, bison - Canada: (AB) Archive Number: 20110730.2294):\n\n'Brucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost exclusively by _Brucella abortus_; however, _B. suis_ or _B. melitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B. suis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically aborts only once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations appear normal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short period and develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist infection and a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive serum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal parturition but may be delayed in about 15 per cent of cows. The incubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage of gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and uterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile. Bacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid uterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease of fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously aborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal parturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of time -- in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are present in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or lick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission may occur by artificial insemination when brucella-contaminated semen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has remained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking unpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not killed by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis has been called undulating fever because of its habit of producing fever and signs that wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1vdg.]", "summary": "\n\nThe department and health officials are advising consumers who have purchased raw milk from Twin Rivers Farm to discard it, and anyone who believes they became ill from drinking raw milk should immediately seek medical attention and notify the local board of health or the state's Food Protection Program, at 617-983-6712. Exposure to direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human health concern. \n\n\nA man who drank raw milk produced at a Western Massachusetts dairy farm is suspected of being infected with brucellosis, state officials said today, 20 Jan 2012, raising concerns about the emergence of a germ that has not been seen in livestock here in at least 2 decades. It has been largely\neradicated nationwide but persists in wildlife in parts of Montana,\nIdaho, and Wyoming around Yellowstone National Park.\n\nThe remainder of the unidentified Park County herd has been\nquarantined. The government also\nno longer requires that entire herds be slaughtered when infections\nare found in just a few animals.\n\nBecause of the changes, Montana can retain its brucellosis-free\ndesignation from the US Department of Agriculture despite the latest\ninfections, said agency spokeswoman Lyndsay Cole. If confirmed, it would\nbe the region's 15th infection in livestock since 2004.\n\nIntroduced by early European settlers and once widespread, brucellosis\nhas since been largely eradicated from cattle nationwide after a\ndecades-long government effort. It persists in parts of Texas and in\nwildlife in and around Yellowstone National Park.\n\nBrucellosis can cause pregnant animals to miscarry and has been blamed\nfor weight loss and other problems in cattle. It is not considered a\nsignificant threat to human health.\n\nErrol Rice with the Montana Stockgrowers Association said the\nsuspected infection in the 150-head herd demonstrated that more needs\nto be done to eliminate the disease. 'The more cases we continue to\nidentify, it makes you wonder have we really made that much progress\non mitigating the problem,' Rice said. 'The fact remains we still have\na large reservoir of the disease in a particular area of Montana that\ncontinues to affect our industry.'\n\nThousands of Yellowstone bison have been captured and sent to\nslaughter over the last decade to prevent transmissions to cattle when\nthe bison migrate to lower elevations in Montana. That has not stopped\ntransmissions from the tens of thousands of elk that roam freely\nacross the Yellowstone region.\n\nTests on elk over the last year revealed a new area of wildlife\ninfections in parts of Montana west of Yellowstone. Montana, Idaho,\nand Wyoming in recent years started requiring more stringent testing\nand vaccinations against the disease. That prompted the federal\ngovernment to stop automatically imposing trade restrictions on states\nthat have multiple infections.\n\nThe government also no longer requires that infected herds be\nslaughtered. State officials did not disclose the name of the ranch\nwhere the disease was found. The Park County infections, if confirmed,\nwould mark Montana's 4th case in recent years, including 1 in November\n[2010] on a bison ranch owned by media mogul and philanthropist Ted\nTurner.\n\nTurner's bison remain under quarantine, although testing is under way\nto lift restrictions on the animals, state officials said. Wyoming had\n2 outbreaks last year [2010] and 1 in February [2011]. Idaho's last\noutbreak was in 2009.\n\nPark County and the Park County Stockgrowers Association each have\nlawsuits pending over the management of Yellowstone's bison by the\nstate and federal governments. The\nlegislators, particularly from Mbarara District, raised fears that the\ndisease, which is transmitted from cattle to human beings, continues\nto ravage different parts of the country, and they called on\ngovernment to intervene immediately.\n\n'The disease is being transmitted from cattle to human beings through\nconsuming raw animal products. Let the ministry vaccinate our animals\nbefore it is too late,' MP for Mbarara, Ms Emma Boona, said yesterday\n[7 Sep 2011].\n\nBrucellosis is associated with the consumption of unpasteurised milk,\nghee and cheese made from the milk of infected animals that include\ncattle and goats infected with the bacteria _Brucella melitensis_.\n\nDr Francis Epatait (Ngora County) noted that the disease also causes\ninfertility and abortions among human beings. 'The effects are really\ngrave and the government should act fast,' he said.\n\nDr Medard Bitekyerezo (Mbarara Municipality) noted that so many people\nsuffering from the disease have been admitted into Mbarara hospitals\nand clinics.\n\nThe Third Deputy Prime Minister, Gen. The current situation is not an 'outbreak' but\nrather a continuing, concerning condition which is said to be\ndeteriorating.\n\nThe article mentions _B. melitensis_ as the causative agent in cattle;\nthe main cause of cattle brucellosis is _B. abortus_. In fact both _B.\nabortus_ (mainly affecting cattle) and _B.melitensis_ (mainly in\ngoats, but also affecting cattle) are reported as endemic in Uganda\nand both are zoonotic.\n\nEarlier surveillance, carried out in Mbarara -- one of Uganda's most\nimportant dairy-production areas -- mentioned herd prevalence for\nbrucellosis, in cattle, of 55.6 percent, individual-animal prevalence\nof 15.8 percent and within-herd range of 1\u00ad90 percent (Ref 1).\n\nUganda's annual reports to the OIE (2005-2010) do not include\ninformation on the number of outbreaks nor on the brucellosis\nvaccination coverage; such information, as well as updated information\nabout the current prevailing control measures and human infection data\nare requested.\n\nRef 1\nFaye Bernarda, Castel Vincenta et al (2005). Tuberculosis and\nbrucellosis prevalence survey on dairy cattle in Mbarara milk basin\n(Uganda). Source: AllAfrica [summarised, edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201109080190.html\n\n\nLegislators Issue Alert On Cattle Disease\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Ngora County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbarara District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbarara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "802816", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bison - Canada: (AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=802816", "date": "2011-07-30 18:10:32", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - CANADA: (ALBERTA)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 28 Jul 2011\nSource: Canada Views.ca [edited]\nhttp://www.canadaviews.ca/2011/07/28/disease-detected-in-wood-bison-outside-wood-buffalo-national-park/?\n\n\nFor years it has been suspected that brucellosis and bovine\ntuberculosis, introduced diseases that are common in wood bison in\nWood Buffalo National Park, also occur in bison immediately west of\nthe park. Evidence of brucellosis exposure has now been detected in 2\nbison about 20 km [12.4 miles] west of Wood Buffalo National Park.\nHunters, ranchers, Metis Settlements and First Nations in the area\nwill continue to be informed on risks of disease and future bison\nmanagement.\n\nUnder provincial legislation, wood bison east of Highway 35 and west\nof Wood Buffalo National Park can be hunted without a license, except\nin Caribou Mountains Wildland Provincial Park. Some hunters\nparticipate in disease surveillance by providing samples for testing.\nAn outfitter, provided with information and sample kits by Sustainable\nResource Development, harvested 2 adult female bison in February and\nMarch [2011] that tested positive for exposure to brucellosis. The\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency verified the results on 22 July 2011.\n\n\nThe risk of disease transmission to humans remains very low and those\nwho continue to harvest bison west of Wood Buffalo National Park are\nencouraged to contact the local Fish and Wildlife office for\ninformation on the risks associated with brucellosis and tuberculosis.\nAs a precaution:\n\n-- any bison harvested should be handled carefully with gloves and\nexamined for signs of disease, obvious lesions or other unusual\nfeatures; and\n-- if the meat is to be eaten, it must be cooked thoroughly -- smoking\nthe meat is not sufficient to kill the bacteria that cause these\ndiseases.\n\nThe Alberta government has a disease-management program to protect the\nprovince's agriculture industry and disease-free wood bison in\nnorthwestern Alberta. All free-ranging wood bison detected on private\nagricultural lands near Fort Vermilion, La Crete and within 10\nkilometres [6.2 miles] of Highway 35 will be removed. Bison\npopulations west of Wood Buffalo National Park will continue to be\nsurveyed to confirm numbers, location and whether they carry any\ndisease. This effort will continue until a long-term solution is\napplied to the bison in and around Wood Buffalo National Park.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost\nexclusively by _Brucella abortus_; however, _B. suis_ or _B.\nmelitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B.\nsuis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection\nspreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a\nherd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically aborts\nonly once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations appear\nnormal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short period\nand develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist infection\nand a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive serum\nagglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal\nparturition but may be delayed in about 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage of\ngestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and uterine\ndischarges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile. Bacteria may\nbe found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine involution, and\ninfrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid uterus. Shedding\nfrom the vagina largely disappears with the decrease of fluids\nfollowing parturition. Some infected cows that previously aborted shed\nbrucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal parturitions. Organisms\nare shed in milk for a variable length of time -- in most cattle for\nlife.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are\npresent in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and\nuterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or\nlick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by\ninfected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission\nmay occur by artificial insemination when _Brucella_ -contaminated\nsemen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited\nin the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous\nmembranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has\nremained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to\ndirect sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese\nrepresent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not\nkilled by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis\nin humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain,\nlow back pain, joint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea,\nconstipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis has been called\nundulating fever because of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\nhttp://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis.\n\n\nA map of the area within Alberta province shows where Wood Buffalo\nPark is located, in the northern portion of the province:\nhttp://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&q=map+of++canada&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&biw=958&bih=559&um=1&ie=UTF-8&hq=&hnear=0x4b0d03d337cc6ad9:0x9968b72aa2438fa5,Canada&gl=us&ei=72o0Ts61EoSssQLVm5DrCg&sa=X&oi=geocode_result&ct=image&resnum=1&ved=0CCIQ8gEwAA\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "As a precaution:\n\n-- any bison harvested should be handled carefully with gloves and\nexamined for signs of disease, obvious lesions or other unusual\nfeatures; and\n-- if the meat is to be eaten, it must be cooked thoroughly -- smoking\nthe meat is not sufficient to kill the bacteria that cause these\ndiseases. The government\nordered them sold and slaughtered to keep a disease from spreading to\nother cattle or people.\n\nOf the 38 head of cattle, 8 tested positive for bovine brucellosis.\nIt's a potentially deadly disease that took the government about 80\nyears to get rid of. It came back. This time, they weren't taking any chances.\n\nSilence fills the air on this Starr County ranch. The corrals sit\nempty, no bulls, cows, or calves. All of the rancher's livestock are\ngone, slaughtered by order of the Texas Animal Health Commission.\n\n'All the cattle, even the ones that tested negative. The explanation\nthey gave me is that since they were offspring from the other cattle\nand the bull, they had to destroy all of them,' said the Starr County rancher.\n\nThe state sent a letter to the rancher after part of their herd was\ntested for the disease in January [2011]. Veterinarians claimed\nseveral of the cows were infected with bovine brucellosis. It's the\n1st confirmed case in more than 5 years.\n\nThe rare bacterial infection causes cows to abort their fetus. It's a\nmeat livestock producer's nightmare.\n\nVeterinarian Jack Valerius says brucellosis spreads through birth\nfluids and milk.\n\n'We just don't want this to be present and begin to expand without\nknowing where it is and getting rid of it because there's been a lot\nof effort and a lot of money spent to accomplish this eradication,'\nsays Valerius.\n\nIt has caused heartaches and headaches for the rancher. 'My email\nmachine is loaded with things like that. That I should be sent to\njail. That I should be sent to prison for selling infected cattle.\nHow did I know that these cattle were infected?' says the rancher.\n\nThe rancher expects the state will pay for his cattle soon. Right\nnow, that's the least of his worries. 'I just hope that something\nlike this doesn't happen to my neighbors,' says the rancher.\n\n'Now they're in the process of testing the herds in the surrounding\nareas, approximately 1 mile [1.6 km] from where these cases were\nfound, and so far, I understand there are no positives,' says Valerius.\n\nThe rancher and his wife wanted to raise a few head of cattle. 'It's\nsomething my father had started many, many years ago, and we\ncontinued. But it's over now, and I just don't wish that for anyone\nelse,' he said.\n\nThe ranch is quarantined. Their hopes and the herd are gone.\n\nBrucellosis can also cause a disease in humans known as undulant\nfever. It proved to be deadly in the 1930s and '40s, but modern\nmedicine has made it treatable.\n\n[Byline: Polo Sandoval]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis, in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost\nexclusively by _Brucella abortus_ ; however, _B. suis_ or _B.\nmelitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B.\nsuis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection\nspreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In\na herd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically\naborts only once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations\nappear normal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short\nperiod and develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist\ninfection and a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal\nparturition but may be delayed in about 15 per cent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage\nof gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine\ninvolution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid\nuterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease\nof fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously\naborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of\ntime -- in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are\npresent in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and\nuterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or\nlick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by\ninfected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission\nmay occur by artificial insemination when _Brucella_ -contaminated\nsemen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited\nin the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous\nmembranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has\nremained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to\ndirect sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and\ncheese represent a human health concern. Many individuals believe\ndrinking unpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that\nare not killed by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer.\nBrucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats,\nheadache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal\npain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis\nhas been called undulating fever because of its habit of producing\nfever and signs that wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0ALl>. Starr County in south Texas can be\nlocated on the map at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/texas.shtml>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 14 Mar 2011\n Brucellosis in humans causes malaise, fever, chills, sweats,\nheadache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal\npain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. \n\n'We just don't want this to be present and begin to expand without\nknowing where it is and getting rid of it because there's been a lot\nof effort and a lot of money spent to accomplish this eradication,'\nsays Valerius. It causes elk, cattle, bison, and some other animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\nGovernment agencies go to great lengths to prevent transmissions from\nbison to livestock, including periodic slaughters of bison that leave\nthe park. But dealing with infected elk has proven more difficult\nsince they are more numerous and far roaming than bison.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis in the wildlife remains a thorn to most regulatory\nagencies. Indeed it is a complicated situation. Wildlife carrying the\ndisease can transmit it to domestic animals, which causes more testing\nwhen shipping domestic animals.\n\nHowever the feeding grounds for elk and bison in the winter are huge\ntourist attractions and the public is loathe to hear of the slaughter\nof these 2 great animals because of a disease they cannot see and has\nno effect on trade issues. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Montana can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/r/0wCC>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 25 Feb 2011\n However the feeding grounds for elk and bison in the winter are huge\ntourist attractions and the public is loathe to hear of the slaughter\nof these 2 great animals because of a disease they cannot see and has\nno effect on trade issues. \n\nMontana Fish, Wildlife and Parks on Friday [25 Feb 2011] released\nresults from the 1st round of a 5-year study to track the prevalence\nof the disease. Wildlife officials report that blood tests on 12 of 100 elk that were\ncaptured in southwestern Montana's Ruby Valley showed signs of\nexposure to the animal disease brucellosis. Wildlife carrying the\ndisease can transmit it to domestic animals, which causes more testing\nwhen shipping domestic animals. Government agencies go to great lengths to prevent transmissions from\nbison to livestock, including periodic slaughters of bison that leave\nthe park. \n\nLargely eradicated elsewhere in the country, brucellosis persists in\nportions of Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming surrounding Yellowstone\n Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "833726", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> PRO>Brucellosis, canine - Sweden: 1st rep, ex Poland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=833726", "date": "2011-08-24 12:25:24", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - SWEDEN: FIRST REPORT, ex POLAND\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Aug 2011\nSource: Swedish Board of Agriculture press release [in Swedish,\nmachine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.jordbruksverket.se/formedier/nyheter/nyheter2011/forstafalletavbrucellacanisisverige.5.6920cb9813122f26a5e80004739.html\n\n\n1st case of _Brucella canis_ in Sweden\n--------------------------------------\nThe dog disease _Brucella canis_ has been found for the 1st time in\nSweden. The bacterium causes abortions and infertility in dogs and\nmay, in exceptional cases, infect humans. The infected bitch was\nkilled. At present, steps have been undertaken to carry out tests and\nto try trace contact cases in order to stop the spread.\n\nThe affected animal was an American Staffordshire terrier-bitch\nimported from Poland, where it has was mated. When she aborted her\nlitter in June 2011, samples were taken to find the cause. The samples\nshowed positive results for _B. canis_ in the National Veterinary\nInstitute (SVA) and, in July 2011 at the EU reference laboratory. The\nSwedish Board of Agriculture decided that the bitch should be killed\nimmediately to prevent further spread of infection. The male suspected\nof having infected the bitch was born in Serbia and found to present\nreduced fertility, a symptom of the disease. The male is now in\nSweden.\n\nIt is important to test dogs from other countries\n-------------------------------------------------\nOne should not breed animals that are infected with _B. canis_. It is\nalways a greater risk to mate in a foreign country or import dogs,\nsays Pia Ehrenpris, veterinarian at the Board of Agriculture. We\nrecommend all owners to be careful when identifying the animals used\nfor breeding or imported. Many diseases such as leptospirosis can\noften be excluded by means of preventive testing prior to breeding or\nimportation.\n\nSexually transmitted disease\n----------------------------\nThe bacteria are spread primarily through mating, but they also occur\nthrough the transfer, for example, of aborted materials, milk, and\nurine. In exceptional cases, the bacteria can also infect humans. Sick\nanimals may particularly suffer impaired fertility but may also have\nproblems with back, eyes, and skin. Asymptomatic infections are\noccurring. Although one might try treating an infected dog, it is\nimpossible to guarantee that the dog ever becomes free of the\nbacteria.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[Initial publication of the suspected case was released by the Swedish\nBoard of Agriculture on 1 Jul 2011; see '_Brucella canis_ in Sweden'\nhttp://www.jordbruksverket.se/amnesomraden/djur/nyheteromdjur/nyheterdjur2011/brucellacanisisverige.5.695e8a9d130df3a0f5880001529.html\n(in Swedish).\n\nCanine brucellosis, caused by _B. canis_, is an important cause of\nreproductive failure in dogs, particularly in kennels and can end the\nreproductive career of a breeding animal. _B. canis_ is zoonotic,\nalthough disease appears to be rare in humans. Other _Brucella_\nspecies occasionally associated with disease in dogs include _B.\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_. Genetic and immunologic\nevidence suggests that all members of the genus _Brucella_ are closely\nrelated.\n\nDogs are the only species known to be affected by _B. canis_; however,\nantibodies to this organism have been found in other carnivores.\n\n_B. canis_ has been reported from the United States (particularly the\nsouthern states), Canada, Central and South America (including\nMexico), some European countries, Tunisia, Nigeria, Madagascar,\nMalaysia, India, Korea, Japan, and China. _B. canis_ is probably found\nthroughout most of the world; however, New Zealand and Australia\nappear to be free of this organism.\n\nIn dogs, _B. canis_ is mainly transmitted by contact with the fetus\nand fetal membranes after abortions/stillbirths, or by venereal\ntransmission. This organism can be found in vaginal discharges for 4\nto 6 weeks after an abortion. It is also shed in normal vaginal\nsecretions, particularly during estrus, as well as in milk. High\nconcentrations of _B. canis_ are found in semen for up to 2 months\nafter infection, and intermittent shedding of smaller quantities can\noccur for years. _B. canis_ is also found in urine, and low\nconcentrations of bacteria may be excreted in saliva, nasal and ocular\nsecretions, and feces.\n\nCanine brucellosis is usually introduced into a kennel in an infected\ndog or semen. This disease is controlled by sanitation and the removal\nof infected dogs. Housing in individual cages reduces the spread of\nthe organism. Repeated testing and the removal of seropositive or\nculture-positive animals, combined with quarantine and testing of\nnewly added dogs, have been used to eradicate brucellosis from some\nkennels. There is no vaccine for _B. canis_.\n\nLong-term antibiotic therapy has been used successfully to treat some\ndogs, but some animals relapse. Neutering can be used as an additional\ncontrol measure.\n\nHumans usually become infected with _Brucella_ spp. by ingesting\norganisms or by the contamination of mucous membranes and abraded\nskin. Infection with _B. canis_ seems to require close contact with\ninfected dogs or contact with bacterial cultures. The virulence of\nthis organism for humans may be low. Approximately 30 cases have been\nreported worldwide since the 1960s. However, _B. canis_ infections can\nbe difficult to diagnose in humans and may be underreported. In\nsymptomatic cases, brucellosis is extremely variable and the clinical\nsigns may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, this disease\nbegins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs\nsuch as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia, and generalized\naches.\n\n_B. canis_ is not included in the list of OIE notifiable\ndiseases/infections.\n\nFurther reading\n---------------\nCanine brucellosis: _Brucella canis_; available at\nhttp://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[Sweden and Poland can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1amu. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - SWEDEN: FIRST REPORT, ex POLAND\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[Initial publication of the suspected case was released by the Swedish\nBoard of Agriculture on 1 Jul 2011; see '_Brucella canis_ in Sweden'\n High\nconcentrations of _B. canis_ are found in semen for up to 2 months\nafter infection, and intermittent shedding of smaller quantities can\noccur for years. B. canis_ has been reported from the United States (particularly the\nsouthern states), Canada, Central and South America (including\nMexico), some European countries, Tunisia, Nigeria, Madagascar,\nMalaysia, India, Korea, Japan, and China. Typically, this disease\nbegins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs\nsuch as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia, and generalized\naches. Canine brucellosis, caused by _B. canis_, is an important cause of\nreproductive failure in dogs, particularly in kennels and can end the\nreproductive career of a breeding animal. In dogs, _B. canis_ is mainly transmitted by contact with the fetus\nand fetal membranes after abortions/stillbirths, or by venereal\ntransmission. _B. canis_ is also found in urine, and low\nconcentrations of bacteria may be excreted in saliva, nasal and ocular\nsecretions, and feces. \n\nHumans usually become infected with _Brucella_ spp. by ingesting\norganisms or by the contamination of mucous membranes and abraded\nskin. The male suspected\nof having infected the bitch was born in Serbia and found to present\nreduced fertility, a symptom of the disease. B. canis_ is probably found\nthroughout most of the world; however, New Zealand and Australia\nappear to be free of this organism. The samples\nshowed positive results for _B. canis_ in the National Veterinary\nInstitute (SVA) and, in July 2011 at the EU reference laboratory. Although one might try treating an infected dog, it is\nimpossible to guarantee that the dog ever becomes free of the\nbacteria. Other _Brucella_\nspecies occasionally associated with disease in dogs include _B.\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_. Canine brucellosis: _Brucella canis_; available at\nhttp://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf.\n- Mod. It is\nalways a greater risk to mate in a foreign country or import dogs,\nsays Pia Ehrenpris, veterinarian at the Board of Agriculture. Sick\nanimals may particularly suffer impaired fertility but may also have\nproblems with back, eyes, and skin. We\nrecommend all owners to be careful when identifying the animals used\nfor breeding or imported. Quarantine\nactivities are being conducted and an investigation is being carried out.'\nSee at <http://www.fsvps.ru/fsvps/news/2658.html?_language=en>.\n\nBrucellosis results from infection by various species of _Brucella_,\na gram-negative, facultative intracellular coccobacillus or short rod\nin the family Brucellaceae. 6 named species occur in animals: _B.\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, _B. ovis_, _B. canis_ and _B.\nneotomae_. 3 of them are zoonotic, namely _B. abortus_, _B.\nmelitensis_, and _B. suis_ biovars 1-4_; rare cases of human\ninfection by _B. canis_ have been recorded. The reservoir of _B.\nabortus_ is, generally, cattle; of _B. melitensis_, small ruminants\n(goats and sheep), and of _B. suis_, swine, with the main clinical\nmanifestation being abortion in these species. Both _B. abortus_ and\n_B. melitensis_ are reportedly present in Russia; _B. suis_ has not\nbeen recorded there since 2007. Infected animals abort, mostly during\nthe 2nd half of their gestation.\n\nIt deserves to be kept in mind, that cattle may readily be infected\nalso by _B. melitensis_, discharging the bacteria in milk, in most\ncases without suffering abortions. This phenomenon may have\nsignificant public health impact. The adult beef cow was from a ranch in Park County. State\nanimal health officials currently are investigating the case, and\nmaking plans for further testing of the cow, as well as the herd she\nwas from.\n\nAccording to assistant state veterinarian Bob Meyer, a diagnosis of\nbrucellosis in a Wyoming cow is no longer as big a threat to the\nstate's cattle industry as it used to be.\n\nIn the past, 2 herds diagnosed with brucellosis within 2 years meant\nthat state would lose Class Free status and would be subjected to more\nstringent testing requirements. On 27 Dec 2010, the United States\nDepartment of Agriculture (USDA) published an interim rule amending\nthe brucellosis regulations.\n\nMeyer explained that the new interim rule says that, 'if you have\ncases of brucellosis in your state, like we do -- and if you're\nresponding appropriately (like we are, by testing, doing epidemiology,\nmaking sure the outbreak is contained and are implementing a\nbrucellosis management plan) -- then the USDA will no longer\nautomatically downgrade your status.'\n\nAs John Clifford, chief veterinary officer for the USDA's Animal and\nPlant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), explained, 'The brucellosis\nprogram has been very successful at reducing the disease in this\ncountry ... These new regulations will help us better address the\ncurrent situation and continue to move toward our long-term goal of\ncomplete eradication.'\n\n'That's good news,' Meyers said. 'The rest of our producers aren't\nthreatened because of this outbreak. In fact,' he said, 'I'm\nresponding to the outbreak as we speak.' Meyers then returned to a\nmeeting with herd owners.\n\n[byline: MJ Clark]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The move by the USDA to not strip a state of its 'free' status is\nlikely driven by budget constraints. Buying out a herd of cattle\nbecause of a disease becomes an expensive proposition. Likewise, the\nUS is moving close to eradication of the disease in domestic animals.\n\nOne of the last and controversial strongholds of the disease is the\nwildlife feeding grounds of the Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA). The\nfeeding areas are hugely popular; they bring in tourist dollars to the\narea, which relies on tourism for much of its living. These feeding\ngrounds stir controversy among conservationist and disease-control\nauthorities. Brucellosis can be transmitted between wildlife and\ndomestic stock. Congregating the animals may assist the spread of the\ndisease among wildlife, which subsequently can spread the disease to\ndomestic stock. Because of the many factions that clash over the GYA,\nit is likely to remain the last brucellosis hot spot in the US.\n\nFor the livestock producers in the states and areas bordering the\nGYA, USDA's action is indeed good news.\n\nInterestingly, while authorities with the USDA stated that all the\nUSA had obtained a brucellosis free status in domestic stock, the\ndisease reappeared in Texas recently. Texas does not have the\nsituation of having the GYA as a neighbor as does Wyoming. But it is\nan indication that the disease may still be lurking out there\nsomewhere besides the GYA. - Mod.TG\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Wyoming is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00_b> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "\n\nMeyer explained that the new interim rule says that, 'if you have\ncases of brucellosis in your state, like we do -- and if you're\nresponding appropriately (like we are, by testing, doing epidemiology,\nmaking sure the outbreak is contained and are implementing a\nbrucellosis management plan) -- then the USDA will no longer\nautomatically downgrade your status.' Officials with the USDA's\nAnimal and Plant Health Inspection Service have been working on a new\npolicy that provides some flexibility in how outbreaks are handled, and as\na result, 'Wyoming is not in jeopardy of losing its free status as long as\nthe state is appropriately handling the cases that arise,' he said.\n\nBrucellosis can cause spontaneous abortions, infertility, decreased milk\nproduction, and weight loss in cattle, elk, bison, and other mammals. It\npersists in herds of wild elk and bison around Yellowstone National Park\nand has periodically passed to cattle in Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.\n\nLoss of a state's 'brucellosis-free' status can trigger costly restrictions\non marketing of all cattle from that state. According to the media release,\n12 heifers in Park County were tested for brucellosis this fall [2010] when\nthey were sold, a requirement under the state's brucellosis rules in that\npart of the state. 2 of the 12 were found to have been exposed to the\ndisease. One of the animals was destroyed on 10 Nov 2010, and samples from\nthe heifer were tested to determine whether it was actually infected. The\ninfection was confirmed on 24 Nov 2010.\n\nThe remaining 11 animals from the group of 12 were tested, along with 250\nherd mates, the release said. 8 of those animals were found to have been\nexposed to the disease. While a blood test from a live animal can detect\nexposure to brucellosis, the only way to confirm actual infection of an\nanimal is to destroy it.\n\nAs a result of the test results, federal officials have designated the herd\nas an 'affected herd'. The Wyoming Livestock Board has quarantined the herd\nand another 'adjacent' herd, and testing is scheduled to continue on Monday\n[29 Nov 2010] on the affected herd and adjacent herds. 'Epidemiologic\ninterviews are under way to determine the extent of this outbreak,' the\nrelease said.\n\nLate last week [week of 15 Nov 2010], Logan said officials were preparing\nto lift a quarantine of nearly a dozen cattle herds in northern Wyoming\nfollowing the earlier case detected in Park County, also believed to have\nbeen caused by contact with infected elk.\n\nThe state tested more than 3500 cattle in the county after 4 cows of one\n300-head herd were found to have the disease in October [2010]. The herd\nand 11 others nearby were quarantined while tests were done to see if the\ndisease had spread. Officials determined it had not.\n\nIn that earlier case, the one herd with the infected cows will remain under\nquarantine for about a year and undergo more testing to make sure the\ndisease is no longer present. The 4 infected cows have been slaughtered. If\nmore cases are found within the herd, that entire herd may have to be\nslaughtered.\n\nIn Wednesday's [24 Nov 2010] media release, Logan said the USDA is\npreparing to issue a new 'interim rule' regarding brucellosis, a result of\na year and a half of discussion among federal officials and state\nveterinarians in Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana. He said he met late last week\nwith USDA regional officials to discuss the implications of the 2 Park\nCounty cases and was given assurance that Wyoming's brucellosis-free status\nis not yet in jeopardy. [This is good news for Wyoming. It is also\nindicating that the USDA recognizes the challenges of dealing with this\ndisease in an area that is probably the last reservoir of the disease. It\nis a difficult situation as the American bison (buffalo) and the elk are\nhuge tourist attractions and the buffalo are considered a national herd. -\nMod.TG]\n\nLogan said the new rule 'provides the state and affected herd owners some\nflexibility in how situations are handled. The state tested thousands of cattle in 12 herds\nin the 1st case and found no additional infections.\n\nHowever, preliminary tests indicate possible brucellosis in one cow\nthat was being put up for sale in Sublette County, which is in west\ncentral Wyoming, Meyer said. More tests are being done to confirm the\ninitial findings and more will be known sometime next week [week of 6\nDec 2010], he said.\n\nThe herd in question numbers about 650 head and there are 4 or 5\nother cattle herds nearby, Meyer said.\n\nThe disease can cause spontaneous abortions, infertility, and weight\nloss in cattle, elk, bison, and other mammals. It persists in herds\nof wild elk and bison around Yellowstone National Park and has\nperiodically passed to cattle in Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.\n\nUntil recently, if the disease was found in multiple cattle herds it\nmeant costly restrictions on marketing of all Wyoming cattle to\nprevent brucellosis from spreading to other states.\n\nHowever, the US Department of Agriculture has eased its stance\nrecently on imposing statewide restrictions and has assured the state\nthat it will retain its status as being considered free of\nbrucellosis, Meyer said.\n\n'As long as we're doing a good investigation to make sure that we\nhaven't got spread into any other herds -- testing neighboring herds,\ntesting in the area, and doing a good investigation -- they said your\nstatus will stay intact, meaning we won't have a downgrade in status\nfrom USDA,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Bob Moen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis in wildlife and in the area around the Greater\nYellowstone area is a challenge for the state disease regulators. The disease can be transmitted from wildlife to cattle.\n\nLogan said reactors on blood tests do not absolutely prove that\ncattle are infected with brucellosis. However, Logan said the\nreactors were very strong indicators that the likelihood of infection is high.\n\nTissue and blood samples were collected from the 3 cows and submitted\nto the state lab for a full diagnostic evaluation. But the discovery shouldn't affect Montana's\ncoveted brucellosis-free status, which should not be in jeopardy.\n\nThe National Veterinary Services Laboratories confirmed the case\nafter a 7-year-old cow bison was singled out during routine testing,\nthe Montana Department of Livestock said. The 4600-head bison herd on\nthe ranch is quarantined, and 2 more animals are suspected of\ncarrying the disease.\n\nAnimal health officials are conducting an epidemiological\ninvestigation to determine the cause, state veterinarian Dr. Marty\nZaluski said.\n\n'In previous cases, extensive testing indicated that elk, not cattle\nor bison, were the likely source of the infections,' he said.\n\nMontana regained its brucellosis-free status last year [2009] after\ncattle in 2 separate herds tested positive for the disease within one\nyear, according to state records. Officials are hopeful the state\nwill not be stripped of its status again because of rule reviews by\nthe U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), Zaluski said.\n\n'USDA is currently reviewing its approach to brucellosis management\nnationwide,' Zaluski said. 'The proposed concept would de-emphasize\nstate status and allow brucellosis to be managed on a case-by-case basis.'\n\nLivestock officials from Montana, Idaho and Wyoming have been working\nwith the feds to come up with a solution to the long-term problem,\nDepartment of Livestock spokesman Steve Merritt said. The states are\nlooking for federal rule changes that will grant some flexibility to\nestablish, designate and change surveillance areas.\n\nA draft concept paper known as the 'White Paper' emerged from the\ndialogue, and addresses concerns in the tri-state area, but the feds\nhave not implemented any of the rule changes, Merritt said.\n\n'They're currently not operating under that concept paper,' he said\nMonday [1 Nov 2010]. 'Something did come out of those meetings, but\nnothing has been implemented yet.'\n\nMerritt said there is 'no risk' that the entire state would lose its\nstatus due to the brucellosis discovery in Turner's bison herd.\n\n'We don't expect to lose our status this time,' he said. 'USDA is\ncurrently evaluating the future direction of the brucellosis program,\nand so our understanding is that they are going to start taking this\non a case-by-case basis.'\n\nNone of the wild bison Turner recently acquired from Yellowstone Park\nare infected, Merritt said. Turner took custody of those animals,\nnumbering 86, from the park last year [2009] as part of a bison\nmanagement effort by state and federal wildlife agencies. That herd\nis housed at Turner's Green Ranch property south of Three Forks and\nis geographically separated from the domestic herd located in the\nSpanish Creek area near Gallatin Canyon.\n\n[Byline: Michael Tucker]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Montana, bison\nDate: 1 Nov 2010\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicles [edited]\n<http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/article_e17e6f96-e5ff-11df-9c0c-001cc4c03286.html>\n\n\nBrucellosis has been found in a domestic bison on the Flying D Ranch\nnear Bozeman, the Montana Department of Livestock said today [1 Nov 2010].\n\nTwo other bison at the ranch are also suspected of carrying the\ndisease. The ranch is currently quarantined.\n\nThe brucellosis-infected bison, a 7-year-old cow, was identified as a\nsuspect during routine disease testing conducted by the ranch, which\nis owned by Ted Turner. Cultures performed at the National Veterinary\nServices Laboratories in Ames, Iowa confirmed the presence of the\nagent that causes brucellosis in the suspect bison.\n\nBrucellosis-infected elk have been found on the Flying D in previous years.\n\nThe Flying D bison herd is geographically separate from the Green\nRanch, which received bison from the cooperative USDA-Montana Fish,\nWildlife and Parks quarantine facility last year [2009]. Those 86\nYellowstone Park bison remain disease-free.\n\nAfter going more than 30 years without a case of brucellosis, the\nstate lost its brucellosis-free status when the disease was found\ntwice within a 12-month period in 2007 and 2008.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is historically thought to have entered the bison\npopulation somewhere around 1920. The bison herds of the plains of\nthe US were in danger of possible extinction. The herds were\nco-mingled with cattle, and the disease was thought to have entered\nbison though this co-mingling. Nevertheless, brucellosis is similar\nin bison to that in cattle. However, bison are not believed to\ndemonstrate abortion as do domestic cattle. This may or may not be\ntrue. It might all depend upon the ability to observe and document\nthe circumstances.\n\nIt is encouraging to know the bison from the Yellowstone area remain\nfree of the disease and are not threatened by contact with the remaining herd.\n\nWhile elk are suspected as being the source, this is still a\ndisturbing disease to be found on a ranch whose management is\nregarded as very good.\n\nBrucellosis vaccine RB51 has been shown to be effective in bison.\nHowever, handling these wonderful creatures can be another challenge.\n\nWith approximately 2 million acres of personal and ranch land, Ted\nTurner is the largest individual landholder in North America. Turner\nlands are innovatively managed and work to partner economic viability\nwith ecological sustainability. All Turner ranches operate as working\nbusinesses, relying on bison and outfitting as principal enterprises.\nIn addition, Turner ranches support many progressive environmental\nprojects including water resource management, reforestation and the\nreintroduction of native species to the land.\n\nTurner Enterprises also manages over 50 000 head of bison across the\nvarious Turner ranches.\n\nThe Flying D ranch is 113 613 acres (45 977.549 hectares) and was\nacquired in 1989. The ranch supports bison ranching, elk hunting,\nwolf restoration, and cutthroat trout reintroduction.\n\nBison seem to be a politically sensitive topic, and with dwindling\nfunds for USDA to buy out diseased herds, it is understandable they\nwill take a case by case approach to find the most workable solution\nto this situation.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.tedturner.com/enterprises/ranches.asp>. - Mod.TG]\n\n******\n[3] Wyoming\nDate: 5 Nov 2010\nSource: Cattlenetwork.com [edited]\n<http://www.cattlenetwork.com/Another-Cow-Tests-Positive-For-Livestock-Disease/2010-11-05/Article_Latest_News.aspx?oid=1280139&fid=CN-LATEST_NEWS>\n\n\nOnly one more cow has initially tested positive for brucellosis, as\nthe state continues testing more than 1000 cows in the northern Wyoming area.\n\nThe new cow with the disease was from the same herd where the 1st 3\ncows tested positive for exposure to the disease in preparation for\nsale at a livestock market.\n\nState Veterinarian Jim Logan tells the Powell Tribune that he's\nencouraged that extensive testing has yielded only one more positive result.\n\n14 Meeteetse area herds are quarantined under a state order until\ntesting is complete.
