But, actually, should we\nassume that _B. abortus_ is the causative agent in this particular\ncase? Reference is made to the last case of bovine brucellosis\n(presumably due to _B. abortus_) occurring more than 5 years ago (2003\nposting in ProMED). Unfortunately, in the moderator's comments,\nreference is not made to 2 other cases of brucellosis posted by ProMED\nthat occurred in Texas a decade or so ago and that are\nepidemiologically relevant. One case was in goats (_Brucella\nmelitensis_ infection), and the other case was in a feral pig hunter\n(the Brucella species is not mentioned).\n\nMy concern is that _B. melitensis_ infection in goats in 1999/2000\nalso took place in Starr county (with a likely origin across the\nMexican border). _B. melitensis_ infection in cattle has been\ndocumented and is a major public health concern (Verger et al, 1989;\nSamaha et al, 2008).\n\nFor the brucellosis case in the feral pig hunter posted in 2009, the\nreader is referred to the Houston Chronicle, which reported Thursday\n[17 Sep 2009] that about 10 percent of Texas feral hogs test positive\nfor brucellosis bacteria: presumably _B. suis_ biovar 1.\n\nAgain, should we make such an assumption? In the south of the USA,\npopulations of feral swine are heavily infected with _B. suis_ biovar\n1 (Olsen and Tatum, 2010), and infections with _B. suis_ biovar 1 in\nhumans occur in people handling pigs, including the hunting of feral\nswine. Texas and other southeastern states report numerous cases of\nseropositive cattle, which are shown by bacterial culture to be\ninfected with _B. suis_ (Olsen and Tatum, 2010). However, it has\nrecently been shown in South Carolina that feral pigs were infected\nwith _B. abortus_ wildtype, S19 and RB51 vaccine strains besides _B.\nsuis_ biovar 1 (Stoffregen et al, 2007). I am wondering whether this\ncould be the case in feral pigs in Texas too.\n\nReferences:\n- Verger, J.M., Garinbastuji, B., Grayon, M., Mahe, A.M., 1989.\nBrucella-Melitensis Infection in Cattle in France. Annales de\nRecherches Veterinaires , 93-102.\n\n- Samaha H, Al-Rowaily M, Khoudair RM, Ashour HM. Multicenter study\nof brucellosis in Egypt. Emerg Infect Dis [serial on the Internet].\n2008 Dec [date cited]. Available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/EID/content/14/12/1916.htm>.\n\n- Olsen, S., Tatum, F., 2010. Bovine Brucellosis. Veterinary Clinics\nof North America-Food Animal Practice 26, 15-27.\n\n- Stoffregen, W.C., Olsen, S.C., Wheeler, C.J., Bricker, B.J.,\nPalmer, M.V.,Jensen, A.E., Halling, S.M., Alt, D.P., 2007. Diagnostic\ncharacterization of a feral swine herd enzootically infected with\nBrucella. J Vet Diagn Invest19, 227-237.\n\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nHead of the Section Arctic Veterinary Medicine\nDepartment of Food Safety and Infection Biology\nNorwegian School of Veterinary Science\nNorway\n<jacques.godfroid@nvh.no>\n\n[The case of bovine brucellosis in Texas was _B. abortus_. The\nindividual owning the animals sold some aged animals at a market, or\n1st point of testing. This is where it was detected. The owner had not\nsold any cattle for a long time, and, therefore, the disease in his\nherd had likely been there for a long time. The original source of the\ninformation is posted at\n<http://www.tahc.state.tx.us/news/pr/2011/2011Feb_BrucellosisInStarrCounty.pdf>.\n\nWhile this may not answer all of the epidemiology questions posed, it\ndoes provide some indication of the trace in and trace outs of the\nanimals from that herd. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 18 Mar 2011\n J Vet Diagn Invest19, 227-237.\n\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nHead of the Section Arctic Veterinary Medicine\nDepartment of Food Safety and Infection Biology\nNorwegian School of Veterinary Science\n However, it has\nrecently been shown in South Carolina that feral pigs were infected\nwith _B. abortus_ wildtype, S19 and RB51 vaccine strains besides _B.\nsuis_ biovar 1 (Stoffregen et al, 2007). (Olsen and Tatum, 2010), and infections with _B. suis_ biovar 1 in\nhumans occur in people handling pigs, including the hunting of feral\nswine. One case was in goats (_Brucella\nmelitensis_ infection), and the other case was in a feral pig hunter\n For the brucellosis case in the feral pig hunter posted in 2009, the\nreader is referred to the Houston Chronicle, which reported Thursday\n _B. melitensis_ infection in cattle has been\ndocumented and is a major public health concern (Verger et al, 1989;\nSamaha et al, 2008). Texas and other southeastern states report numerous cases of\nseropositive cattle, which are shown by bacterial culture to be\ninfected with _B. suis_ The owner had not\nsold any cattle for a long time, and, therefore, the disease in his\nherd had likely been there for a long time.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2009-09-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-24 00:00:00", "1989-03-24 00:00:00", "2010-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Garinbastuji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halling", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "C.J.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "B.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "B.J.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wheeler", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "J.M.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Olsen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "M.V.,Jensen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "A.M.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tatum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "A.E.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bricker", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ashour HM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Starr county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.C.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.M.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W.C.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "504682", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, ovine - Australia: (VI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=504682", "date": "2010-08-25 01:00:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, OVINE - AUSTRALIA: (VICTORIA)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 23 Aug 2010\nSource: Stock and Land Farm on line [edited]\n<http://sl.farmonline.com.au/news/state/livestock/sheep/20-flocks-hit-with-ovine-brucellosis/1917003.aspx>\n\n\n20 flocks hit with ovine brucellosis\n------------------------------------\nOvine brucellosis has been confirmed in 20 commercial Victorian sheep\nflocks this year [2010], sparking tracebacks to ensure infected rams\ndid not come from studs accredited as free of the disease. The\nDepartment of Primary Industries' (DPI) sheep disease project leader\nRobert Suter said he would normally only expect 2-3 reports of ovine\nbrucellosis in Victorian flocks at this time of the year.\n\nThe recent increase in confirmed reports followed drops in scanning\nor lamb marking rates of 10-20 per cent, triggering an investigation,\nhe said. He was not aware of any interstate flocks being affected or\nidentified as a source of infected rams.\n\nOvine brucellosis caused infertility in affected rams and Dr Suter\nsaid in one case an infected ram was shared among 3 flocks. The\nincreased number of reports was a concern because it came at a time\nwhen a lot of attention was being focused on flock reproductive\nperformance and rebuilding the nation's sheep flock, he said.\n\n'It is disappointing for producers when they put a lot of effort into\nbuilding a fertile ewe flock which is managed well throughout\npregnancy only to have the other part of the reproductive equation,\nthe ram, not able to do his job,' Dr Suter said. 'The only treatment\nis to cull these rams.'\n\nDr Suter said DPI was trying to identify the sources of infected rams\nto ensure they did not come from flocks accredited under the Ovine\nBrucellosis Accreditation Scheme. None of the recently reported cases\nindicated there had been any breakdown in the scheme's accreditation\nprocess, he said. 'The best protection is to buy only from ovine\nbrucellosis-free accredited ram sources and check that they can\nprovide a current accreditation certificate.\n\n'If in doubt, have your ram flock assessed by a veterinarian 2 or so\nmonths before mating, as this allows time to source replacement rams\nif necessary,' Dr Suter said.\n\n'Even if brucellosis is not present, the examination can identify\nrams of sub-optimal fertility well prior to mating.'\n\nHe said affected rams could be identified by examination of the\nscrotum and its contents by a veterinarian, who would confirm suspect\nanimals with a blood test as other conditions could mimic brucellosis\nsigns. Dr Suter said once brucellosis had been introduced into the\nram flock, it often took a long series of examinations and blood\ntests to achieve a clean flock of rams.\n\n'By this time a large proportion will have been culled,' Dr Suter said.\n\n[Byline: Terry Sim]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Finding where the disease began is the 1st step in breaking the\ncycle of transmission. Sharing rams is economical, until a disease\npassed from the ram affects the entire flock for many years, which\nmay mean sharing a ram was not so economical after all. Brucellosis\nis a major impact on any producer.\n\n_Brucella ovis_ produces a disease unique to sheep, in which\nepididymitis and orchitis impair fertility -- the principal economic\neffect. Occasionally, placentitis and abortion are seen, and there\nmay be perinatal mortality. The disease was 1st described in New\nZealand and Australia and has since been reported from many\nsheep-raising areas of the world.\n\nRams as young as 8 weeks have been infected experimentally by various\nnonvenereal routes. The disease can be transmitted among rams by\ndirect contact. Active infection in ewes is unusual but has developed\nafter mating with naturally infected rams. Contaminated pastures do\nnot appear to be important in spread of the disease. Infection\nfrequently persists in rams, and a high percentage shed _B ovis_\nintermittently for several years.\n\nBecause not all infected rams show palpable abnormalities of scrotal\ntissues (and not all cases of epididymitis are due to brucellosis),\nthe remaining rams must be examined further. Rams shedding organisms,\nbut having no lesions, must be identified by culture of semen.\nRepeated examinations may be necessary to identify intermittent\nshedders. Microscopic examination of stained semen smears may also be\nhelpful; fluorescent antibody examination is a highly specific\ndiagnostic aid. Serologic tests used for eradication of disease and\ncertification of animals include ELISA, complement fixation,\nhemagglutination inhibition, indirect agglutination, and gel diffusion.\n\nIncidence and spread of the disease may be reduced by regular\nexamination of rams before the breeding season and culling of those\nwith obvious genital abnormalities. Because susceptibility in rams\nincreases markedly with age, it is advantageous to keep a young ram\nflock and isolate noninfected rams from older, possibly infected rams.\n\nImmunization of rams has been practiced extensively in New Zealand\nusing 2 doses of killed _B ovis_ cells in adjuvant. Because infection\nin ewes apparently originates almost exclusively from service by\ninfected rams, lamb losses through infection of ewes may be\ncontrolled economically by restricting vaccination to rams.\n\nChlortetracycline and streptomycin used concurrently have effected\nbacteriologic cures. However, treatment is not economic except in\nespecially valuable rams, and even if infection is eliminated,\nfertility may remain impaired.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110506.htm> - Mod.TG]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Victoria, Australia, is\navailable at: <http://healthmap.org/r/00I2> - CopyEd.EJP]\n\n....................sb/tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Dairy farmer Kashmir Singh\nsaid a farm in Wainivesi and Waimaro district\nwould be cleaned out by the ministry officers\nbecause they had infected cattle.\n\n'We are aware that the cleaning out will be\nconducted soon but we are not aware of what these\nprocesses will include,' he said. He said the\nfarmers had been briefed on the latest results of\ntests last month. Mr Singh said they asked the\nministry officers to conduct tests on their\ncattle every 3 months so they were always sure their cattle were not infected.\n\nLast week, Colonel Smith said 7 farms which had\nbeen quarantined for brucellosis were informed of\nthe latest test results received from Australia.\nHe said the farmers concerned had been notified.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152931>\n\n\nHuman death denial\n------------------\nThere has never been any report of humans dying\nafter being infected with brucellosis in Fiji,\naccording to Ministry of Agriculture Permanent\nSecretary Colonel Mason Smith. He was reacting to\nreports made by one media organisation that some\npeople were dying due to being in contact with\nand looking after livestock infected with brucellosis.\n\n'What we know and understand that cows have been\ninfected and have died from brucellosis,' Col\nSmith said. Col Smith said one of his senior\nstaff said comments conducted in Fijian were\nmisinterpreted by the media organisation when translating it for news.\n\nEarlier last week, Col Mason Smith said 7 farms\nwhich were quarantined for brucellosis had been\ninformed of the latest test results received from\nAustralia. He said the 7 farms were still being\nquarantined but this would be reviewed after they\nreceived the results from Australia.\n\nCol Smith said the farms that were not being\nquarantined by their officers had been given 'the\ngreen light' to continue with their daily work.\nHe said this also included selling their cattle to other farms or customers.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[These articles do not say if these are dairy\ncattle, but it is strongly likely they are dairy operations.\n\nDairy cattle infected with brucellosis can\ntransmit the disease to humans through the\nconsumption of raw or unpasteurized milk.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison\nis caused almost exclusively by _Brucella\nabortus_ ; however, _B suis_ or _B melitensis_ is\noccasionally implicated in some cattle herds. B\nsuis does not appear to be contagious from cow to\ncow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many\nabortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in\nwhich disease is endemic, an infected cow\ntypically aborts only once after exposure;\nsubsequent gestations and lactations appear normal.\n\nAfter exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a\nshort period and develop agglutinins and other\nantibodies; some resist infection and a small\npercentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an\nabortion or a normal parturition but may be\ndelayed in approximately 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is\ninversely related to stage of gestation at time\nof exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\n\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during\npregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently,\nfor a prolonged time in the nongravid uterus.\nShedding from the vagina largely disappears with\nthe decrease of fluids following parturition.\nSome infected cows that previously aborted shed\nbrucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a\nvariable length of time\u0097in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of\norganisms, which are present in large numbers in\naborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine\ndischarges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed\nand water, or lick contaminated genitals of other\nanimals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls\nto susceptible cows appears to be rare.\nTransmission may occur by artificial insemination\nwhen Brucella -contaminated semen is deposited in\nthe uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in\nthe midcervix. _Brucellae_ may enter the body\nthrough mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\n_Brucellae_ have been recovered from fetuses and\nfrom manure that has remained in a cool\nenvironment for greater than 2 months. Exposure\nto direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nEfforts are directed at detection and prevention\nbecause no practical treatment is available.\nEventual eradication depends on testing and\neliminating reactors. The disease has been\neradicated from many individual herds and areas\nby this method. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression. At this time, brucellosis is suspected\nbut it is NOT detected or confirmed.\n\nThe 2 slaughtered cows were classified as reactors on serological\ntests for brucellosis, meaning their status is brucellosis-suspect.\nThe remaining serum samples from these cows (no tissue samples were\ntaken) have been sent to the World Organization for Animal Health\n(OIE) reference laboratory for brucellosis which is located in the\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) laboratory in Ottawa. Here,\nadditional laboratory investigations are being carried out on these\nsamples in order to further characterize the nature and cause of the\nserological test results obtained in the US.\n\nThe 2 herds from which the 3 suspect cows originated are quarantined\nwhile further investigations, including whole herd tests, are carried\nout in these herds. The purpose of these investigations is to\nascertain the true infection status of these herds 'and to establish\nthe absence or presence of brucellosis. An essential element of these\ninvestigations is a thorough examination of all possible routes by\nwhich these herds could have been exposed to _Brucella abortus_,\nincluding all trace-ins to these herds. Cattle removed from the herds\n(trace-outs) are being identified.\n\nThese 2 cattle herds are located very close to one another in\nsouthern BC and at a considerable distance from any known reservoirs\nof _B. abortus_ infection; and at an even greater distance from known\nreservoirs of _Brucella. suis_ infection (which could cause the\nobserved reactions). Canada has not practiced vaccination for\nbrucellosis for more than a decade; and import controls are in place\nto prevent the introduction of the disease from other countries.\n\nAlthough the last confirmed case of brucellosis in cattle in Canada\noccurred more than 20 years ago, Canada has maintained a high level\nof vigilance for this disease. Robust surveillance programs for\nbrucellosis have remained in place. These programs detect a small\nnumber of brucellosis suspect reactor cattle, not unlike these three\ncows, each year. Every finding of a suspect reactor under these\nprograms has triggered a comprehensive trace-back investigation of\nall herds associated with the reactor animal, similar to the\ninvestigations being undertaken for these three reactor cows. Since\n1989, each and every one of these investigations has confirmed the\nabsence of brucellosis infection in these herds and in Canadian\nlivestock.\n\nThe investigations into these 3 suspect reactor cows are being\nundertaken with the same diligence and thoroughness as is employed\nfor all suspect brucellosis investigations in Canada. The laboratory\ntests and field investigations that are required to definitively\nanswer the question 'has brucellosis been found in Canada?' are being\ncarried out as expeditiously as possible. I would be pleased to\nprovide an update once we have the answer.\n\n--\nMaria A. B. Given the known mechanisms of _Brucella_\ntransmission, I wonder whether or not it may be practical to put a\nlittle more emphasis on management of 'breeding' grounds (including\nmost probable 'aborting' grounds) rather than being quite so heavily\nfocused on (winter) feeding grounds. Better focus on exposure around\nthe likely worst times for exposure (aka abortions by recently\ninfected cases and normal birthing by chronically infected cases) in\nseasonal breeding reservoirs might result in useful changes to\nartificial feeding practices/regimes, better timed measures in nearby\ngrazing country to protect livestock, and also target (obviously very\ncostly) inputs more strategically for enhanced impact.\n\n--\nDavid Thomson\nSub-regional Animal Health Specialist\nSecretariat of the Pacific Community, Port Moresby\nPapua New Guinea\n<thomson.david48@gmail.com>\n\n[An interesting thought, and certainly the other side of the coin, so\nto speak, from current position. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "Better focus on exposure around\nthe likely worst times for exposure (aka abortions by recently\ninfected cases and normal birthing by chronically infected cases) in\nseasonal breeding reservoirs might result in useful changes to\nartificial feeding practices/regimes, better timed measures in nearby\ngrazing country to protect livestock, and also target (obviously very\ncostly) inputs more strategically for enhanced impact. He said preliminary\nresults could be completed by next week [week of 31 May 2010]. But\nmeanwhile, the agency continues investigating the movement of cattle\nto and from the farms in an effort to determine the origin of the\nbrucellosis.\n\nIt's not known why the disease would make a comeback after it was\nthought to have been eradicated 20 years ago. 'We worked very hard,\nprobably in the mid-1900s to the later 1900s, at eradicating\nbrucellosis from the Canadian herd and that was done through a\nslaughter and testing program,' Mr. Lehman said.\n\nPeople can contract undulant fever [brucellosis in humans] by\ndrinking unpasteurized milk from infected cows or through contact\nwith animal tissue during the slaughter process if good sanitary\nmeasures aren't used, Mr. Lehman said.\n\nSymptoms include joint and muscle pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Clearly the Canadians are doing a thorough epidemiological\ninvestigation to learn where the disease originated. They will be\ntesting the herd of origin and likely, any animals that have moved\ninto the herd or been removed from the herd (trace-ins and\ntrace-outs) in an effort to locate any nidus of infection within any\nother herds of contact.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost\nexclusively by _Brucella abortus_ ; however, _B. suis or _B.\nmelitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B.\nsuis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection\nspreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In\na herd in which the disease is endemic, an infected cow typically\naborts only once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations\nappear normal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short\nperiod and develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist\ninfection and a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal\nparturition but may be delayed in about 15 per cent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage\nof gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine\ninvolution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid\nuterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease\nof fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously\naborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of\ntime -- in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are\npresent in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and\nuterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or\nlick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by\ninfected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission\nmay occur by artificial insemination when _Brucella_ -contaminated\nsemen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited\nin the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous\nmembranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has\nremained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to\ndirect sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and\ncheese represent a human health concern. Many individuals believe\ndrinking unpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that\nare not killed by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer.\nBrucellosis in humans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes malaise,\nfever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint\npain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and\ndepression. Brucellosis has been called undulant fever because of its\nhabit of producing fever and signs that wax and wane over an extended\nperiod of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm> and\nfrom\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[British Columbia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of Canada at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d5>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 26 May 2010\n Brucellosis in humans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes malaise,\nfever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain, joint\npain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and\ndepression. The Department of\nAgriculture confirmed the re-emergence of the disease on Friday [11\nJun 2010] and in a statement Agriculture Minister Michelle Gildernew\nsaid decent farmers in the area are suffering because of the illegal\nactivities of a few individuals.\n\nThe Minister said: 'We know that we have the widespread backing of the\nfarming community in our efforts to eradicate this disease. I am\ndetermined that the illegal activities of a few self-serving\nindividuals do not undermine our efforts to eradicate brucellosis.\n'There are indications that irresponsible and even criminal practices\nare at the heart of this cluster of infection, with decent farmers\nhaving to suffer the consequences.'\n\nThis recent brucellosis outbreak has exposed the depth of the problem\nin South Armagh, particularly in the outlying area of the town of\nKeady. Since the start of 2010 8 cases of the disease have been\ndiscovered, 6 of which have been confirmed with 2 awaiting\nconfirmation. 5 herds were found to have brucellosis reactors between\nthe months of January and March, however in the last 3 weeks another 3\nherds have been highlighted with each showing multiple reactors. The\nbreakdowns in this area have so far resulted in the depopulation of\nmore than 300 cattle.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to information provided by the Department of Agriculture\nand Rural Development in the Northern Ireland Executive (devolved\ngovernment), since January 2001 annual testing for bovine brucellosis\n(BB, caused by _Brucella abortus_) was reintroduced in the Armagh,\nEnniskillen, and Newry divisional areas. He was admitted to\na private hospital after coming down with fever on 24 Apr 2010, said\nstate exco member Phee Boon Poh.\n\nHe was transferred to the Penang Hospital several days later after\nfailing to respond to the antibiotics given.\n\nAlso called Bang's disease, or undulant fever, brucellosis is a\nhighly contagious disease caused by ingestion of unsterilised milk or\nmeat from infected animals, or close contact with their secretions.\n\nIt causes flu-like symptoms, muscle pain and swollen glands, and can\nresult in complications like bone and joint lesions, encephalitis,\nmeningitis and chronic fatigue syndrome.\n\nPhee said that following the incident, the state Veterinary Services\nDepartment began conducting checks on milk suppliers.\n\n'We hope suppliers from Kulim, Kuala Ketil and Lunas will heed the\ndepartment's advice to prevent the spread of the disease,' he said.\n\nPhee said the department had so far tested 3243 serum samples of\ngoats from 11 farms in the state. '98 of the goats were culled after\nthe test results came in positive,' he said. He said the owners of\nthe culled goats were paid compensation of RM 5.60 [USD 1.65] per\nkilo.\n\nPhee advised the public to boil milk before drinking. He also urged\nthose selling mutton, including for the coming fasting month, to\nensure the meat was free from the disease.\n\n'An awareness campaign will be held on 27 Jul 2010 by the various\ngovernment departments and the municipal councils,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Manjit Kaur]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMerritt Clifton\nEditor, Animal People\nP.O. Box 960\nClinton, WA 98236\n<http://www.animalpeoplenews.org>\n<anmlpepl@whidbey.com>\n\n[Penang is an island in the Strait of Malacca off the northwestern\ncoast of West (Peninsular) Malaysia, part of the state of Pulau\nPinang. According to the Malaysian annual reports to the OIE, human\nbrucellosis has been recorded in Malaysia during 2009, though no\nquantitative data are available and no details on the bacteria\nspecies involved (in humans) given. As to the disease situation in\nanimals, it was reported that both _Brucella abortus_ and _B.\nmelitensis_ infections have been confirmed but no clinical disease\nrecorded. _B. melitensis_ was, reportedly, present during 2009 in the\nfollowing 14 states: Johor, Kedah, Kelantan, Melaka, Negeri,\nSembilan, Pahang, Perak, Perlis, Pulau Pinang, Sabah, Sarawak,\nSelangor, Terengganu. _B. suis_ seems to be absent.\n\nThe current event, involving goats, is likely to be caused by _B.\nmelitensis_. USA (04): Yellowstone", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=415679", "date": "2010-04-25 23:00:16", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CERVID - USA (04): YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 24 Apr 2010\nSource: Salt Lake Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.sltrib.com/Nation%20and%20World/ci_14952404>\n\n\nThe animal disease brucellosis is emerging in new 'hot spots' around\nYellowstone National Park, according to new research that could\ncomplicate efforts to control transmissions of the disease to cattle.\n\nFeeding grounds where food is left for elk as well as herds of bison\ninside the park have long been considered the main sources of\nbrucellosis, which causes pregnant animals to abort their young.\n\nBut Paul Cross with the U.S. Geological Survey said a 3rd source is\nnow emerging: Blood tests indicate large elk herds living far from\nthe feeding grounds have brucellosis exposure rates ranging from 10\npercent to 30 percent.\n\nThat means containing the park's bison and getting rid of the feeding\ngrounds might not be enough to stop brucellosis transmissions to\ncattle in Idaho, Montana and Wyoming.\n\nThe Yellowstone region has an estimated 100 000 elk and is the\nnation's last reservoir for the disease. Over the last decade, cattle\ninfections have appeared in all 3 states bordering the park.\n\n'It's no longer appropriate to say bison and the supplemental feed\ngrounds are the only sources of contamination,' Cross said.\n\nCross was the lead author of a USGS study published online Friday [23\nApr 2010] by the Public Library of Science. Co-authored by\nresearchers from Wyoming Game and Fish, Montana State University and\nUSGS, the study was based on more than 6000 blood tests collected\nfrom Wyoming elk between 1991 and 2009.\n\nSince the testing began, Cross said disease rates increased\ndramatically in 2 'hot spots,' north of Dubois, Wyo. and northwest of\nCody, Wyo. Both of those areas are far from the state's 23 artificial\nfeeding grounds.\n\nThe study comes on the heels of another USGS report in March 2010\nthat found brucellosis rates on the rise across the region.\nPrevalence rates increased from between 0 percent and 7 percent in\n1991-1992, to between 8 percent and 20 percent in 2006-2007.\n\nWyoming's feeding grounds were established decades ago to keep elk\nseparate from cattle in the winter. By providing elk with a\nguaranteed food source, it was hoped they would not eat hay left out\nfor cattle. But the feeding grounds also facilitated the spread of disease.\n\nMontana does not allow feeding grounds. Yet state veterinarian Marty\nZaluski said the same problems result when large elk herds congregate\non private lands off-limits to hunters. Zaluski compared the trend\nwith colds and other viruses that spread quickly through facilities\nsuch as day-care centers. 'You put any animals in close\nconcentration, you're going to exacerbate these disease issues,' he said.\n\nRepresentatives of the cattle industry -- backed by members of the\nMontana Legislature -- have pushed for the state Livestock Department\nto take more control over elk management. They argue that would be\nthe only way to stem infections that can result in severe\nrestrictions against out-of-state cattle exports. Livestock officials\nso far have declined the calls to intervene, saying elk fall under\nthe jurisdiction of Montana Fish Wildlife and Parks.\n\nIn Wyoming, wildlife managers have driven down brucellosis rates for\nelk in some areas through a pilot program to capture, test and kill\ndisease-positive animals at 3 feeding grounds. Where those efforts\nwere successful, brucellosis exposure rates have dropped as low as 5\npercent. That's versus 35 percent or more historically, said Brandon\nScurlock with Wyoming Game and Fish. Expanding the program across the\nregion would carry a steep price tag. The 5-year pilot effort cost\nUSD 1.3 million and removed 197 brucellosis-positive elk. That comes\nout to about USD 6600 per animal.\n\n[Byline: Matthew Brown]\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current price of test and removal of elk may be more than\nranchers and the general public care to pay, as it would surely\ninfluence taxes in an economy that is already suffering a load.\nHowever, the price quoted in the article sounds about right for a\ncaptive elk, except those being bred for genetics of the rack.\n\nPerhaps it is not the elk that should be behind high fences but\nrather the cattle that are at risk. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 24 Apr 2010\n Communicated by\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current price of test and removal of elk may be more than\nranchers and the general public care to pay, as it would surely\ninfluence taxes in an economy that is already suffering a load.\n Co-authored by\nresearchers from Wyoming Game and Fish, Montana State University and\nUSGS, the study was based on more than 6000 blood tests collected\nfrom Wyoming elk between 1991 and 2009. \n\nIn Wyoming, wildlife managers have driven down brucellosis rates for\nelk in some areas through a pilot program to capture, test and kill\ndisease-positive animals at 3 feeding grounds. He said\ninfected animals often abort pregnancies, and the presence of the\ndisease within livestock results in additional testing requirements\nand trade restrictions.\n\nOfficials said several cattle herds have been infected in Wyoming,\nIdaho, and Montana since 2004 and recent cases of brucellosis cattle\nare thought to have spread from elk due to the lack of contact between\nbison and cattle.\n\n'We looked at a number of hypotheses for why we may be observing these\nincreases in brucellosis,' Cross said. '2 seemed the most probable:\neither brucellosis transmission among elk is becoming more frequent as\nelk densities increase, or the diagnostic tests are cross-reacting\nwith another pathogen that is increasing in prevalence.'\n\nThe research, conducted at the USGS Northern Rocky Mountain Science\nCenter, was recently published in the journal Ecological Applications.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nBrucellosis occurs in free-ranging elk (_Cervus canadensis_) and bison\n(_Bison bison_) in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem, which includes\nportions of Idaho, Wyoming, and Montana.\n\nGeneral comments about brucellosis in cattle may be found in the\nmoderator's comments of ProMED-mail posts 20091215.4249 and\n20090117.0196.\n\nSeveral suggestions on eradicating brucellosis in the Greater\nYellowstone Ecosystem have been discussed but have not been\nimplemented. Partly, the lack of implementation is the lack of\nknowledge on the effectiveness of the methods.\n\nThe GYE remains a challenge in disease control. Part of the reason for\nthe challenge is that feeding grounds in the winter draw a remarkable\nnumber of tourists, and hence a boost to the economy. This is a\nnational park area and there has been great negative public outcry on\nthe destruction of public property (the elk) called for in some of the\nproposals.\n\nThe bison may have the disease as well, and again great negative\noutcry from the public can be heard regarding some of the proposals.\nOne other issue is the genetics in the bison herd of the GYE, some of\nthe 'original' bison herds of the foundation of the USA.\n\nControl/eradication of this disease in the GYE remains a challenge. - Mod.TG]\n\nA map of the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem can be seen at\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Greater_Yellowstone_ecosystem_map.jpg>.\nIdaho, Wyoming, and Montana can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01c2>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 30 Mar 2010\n \n\nOfficials said several cattle herds have been infected in Wyoming,\nIdaho, and Montana since 2004 and recent cases of brucellosis cattle\nare thought to have spread from elk due to the lack of contact between\nbison and cattle. \n\n'Elk-to-elk transmission of this disease may be increasing in new\nregions of the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], which remains the\nlast reservoir for brucellosis in the United States,' said Paul Cross,\na USGS disease ecologist and lead author of the study. 23(37) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=9714>\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella suis_), Latvia\n-------------------------------------\nInformation received on 15 Sep 2010 from Mr Vinets Veldre, Chief\nVeterinary Officer and General Director, Food and Veterinary Service,\nMinistry of Agriculture, Riga, Latvia\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 31 Aug 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 11 Sep 2010\nReport date 15 Sep 2010\nDate submitted to OIE 15 Sep 2010\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence February 1994\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Brucella suis\nNature of diagnosis Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Avoti, Talsi, Latvia\nDate of start of the outbreak 31 Aug 2010\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nSpecies Cattle\nSusceptible 31\nCases 0\nDeaths 0\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\n\nSpecies Swine\nSusceptible 2055\nCases 8\nDeaths 0\nDestroyed 3\nSlaughtered 0\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection;\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures: Measures applied. Quarantine; Movement control\ninside the country; Screening ; Modified stamping out; Vaccination\nprohibited; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied - Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s)\n\nLaboratory name and type: National Reference Laboratory (National laboratory)\nSpecies Swine\nTest bacteriological examination\nTest date 11 Sep 2010\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Swine\nTest complement fixation test (CFT)\nTest date 11 Sep 2010\nResult Positive\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n**\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is zoonotic disease that can have a significant negative\nimpact on reproductive capacity on farms. It mainly affects cattle,\nsheep, goats and pigs worldwide but also dogs, mice and even murine\nspecies. Infections in feral pigs, bison, elk and European hares also\ncomplicate the eradication picture and pose intermittent risks for\nzoonotic transmission.\n\nThe Center for Food Security and Public Health at Iowa State\nUniversity's College of Veterinary Medicine (see\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis.pdf>)\nsummarizes the geographic distribution as follows: _Brucella_ species\nvary in their geographic distribution. _B. abortus_ is found\nworldwide in cattle-raising regions except in Japan, Canada, some\nEuropean countries, Australia, New Zealand and Israel, where it has\nbeen eradicated. Eradication from domesticated herds is nearly\ncomplete in the U.S. _B. abortus_ persists in wildlife hosts in some\nregions, including the Greater Yellowstone Area of North America.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is particularly common in the Mediterranean. It also\noccurs in the Middle East and Central Asia, around the Arabian Gulf\nand in some countries of Central America. This organism has been\nreported from Africa and India, but it does not seem to be endemic in\nnorthern Europe, North America (except Mexico), Southeast Asia,\nAustralia or New Zealand.\n\n_B. ovis_ probably occurs in most sheep-raising regions of the world.\nIt has been reported from Australia, New Zealand, North and South\nAmerica, South Africa and many countries in Europe.\n\nIn the past, _B. suis_ was found worldwide in swine-raising regions.\nThis organism has been eradicated from domesticated pigs in the U.S.,\nCanada, many European countries and other nations. However, it\npersists in wild and/or feral swine populations in some areas,\nincluding the U.S., Europe and Queensland, Australia. In all, just less than 200 cow elk were\nslaughtered during the 5 years after they tested positive for\nexposure to brucellosis.\n\nThe program began in 2006 with testing on the Muddy Creek feedground,\nwith 171 cow elk sampled and 58 with positive exposure results. In\n2007, testing was repeated at Muddy Creek again, with 79 elk tested,\n13 of which tested positive. The pilot program expanded in 2008 to\ninclude both the Muddy Creek and Fall Creek feedgrounds. A total of\n154 elk were tested at Muddy, with 21 positive exposure tests, and\n191 elk tested at Fall Creek, with 21 positives.\n\nThe 2009 testing program was the only year that all 3 feedgrounds\nwere included. 114 elk were tested at Muddy Creek, with 8 testing\npositive for exposure. At Fall Creek, 158 cow elk were tested, with\n11 positives. At Scab Creek, 149 elk were tested, with 31 positive\nresults. The winter of 2009-10 has been relatively mild, and elk\nfeeding has not occurred at the Fall Creek feedground. Trapping at\nMuddy Creek this final year resulted in the testing of 141 elk, with\n7 testing positive for exposure. Trapping at Scab Creek also involved\n141 elk, with 27 positives.\n\nThe program, a recommendation of the Wyoming Brucellosis Coordination\nTeam, will now be subject to a reassessment by this group, involving\nboth livestock and wildlife representatives and animal health and\npublic health officials.\n\n\n[Byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Wyoming Game & Fish Department is to be congratulated. The disease is highly infectious and can cause cattle to abort.\nIdaho State veterinarian Bill Barton said all animals in the herd have been\ntested and most results are back.\n\nThe department and the industry take a brucellosis finding seriously as\nanother finding in a separate herd would cause the state to lose its\nbrucellosis-free status, wreaking havoc on cattlemen's ability to market\ntheir animals. The industry lost its brucellosis-free status in January\n2006. Aggressive action saw the state regain its status in July 2007.\n\nAlthough another animal was found to be suspect for the disease discovered\nlast week, further testing confirmed it was not infected. The 2 positive\nanimals were found in a 600 head herd based in Rigby and assembled over the\nlast couple of years, Barton said.\n\nFurther testing was needed on the 1st animal, a 15 year old cow, because it\nwas vaccinated with an older vaccine that can show a false positive with\nthe standard blood test. 'The vaccine is the best we have, but at 15 years\nof age, immunity is waning a little bit,' Barton said. The older strain 19\nvaccine has about the same efficacy as the newer RB15 vaccine, but where\nit's been used, epidemiologist must take a milk sample and culture the\ntissue for a definitive diagnosis. All animals in the herd had been\nvaccinated as required by the state, Barton said.\n\nThe 1st positive finding came as a result of another animal from the herd\ntesting suspect at slaughter. 'All animals at the slaughter plant are\ninspected with a blood test,' Barton said. If one shows up positive or\nsuspect, all animals in the herd are tested. 'We are continuing our\ninvestigation as rapidly as possible,' he said. That entails not only\ntesting the herd, which is now complete, but also tracing animals to their\nherd of origin and testing those herds. Barton has confirmed that all\nanimals that left the herd were sold to slaughter.\n\nThat's good news in regard to any possible forward infection from the herd.\nThe question now is whether the herds where the animals originated are\ninfected. Barton is more of the mind that the infection came from wild elk\nor bison that the herd came in contact with.\n\nBrucellosis is prevalent in those wild animals in the Greater Yellowstone\nArea and the herd summers in the Teton Basin. Cattlemen in the West are\nanxiously awaiting Idaho's testing results.\n\nBrucellosis is one of a handful of bovine diseases that cause concerns when\nit comes to moving cattle from state to state, said Matt Byrne, vice\npresident of the California Cattlemen's Association. California is\nbrucellosis-free and cattle producers want it to stay that way, he said.\n'Hopefully we'll find that it is a localized incident and won't have an\nimpact on California,' he said.\n\nCalifornia has had its own infectious disease troubles with tuberculosis,\nwhich has infected 8 cows in the state since January 2008, according to the\nstate's Department of Food and Agriculture. About 419 000 head of cattle\nhave been TB tested, 2 herds depopulated and more than 8000 cattle killed\nas part of an ongoing investigation, the CDFA [California Department of\nFood and Agriculture] reports. The USDA last year [2008] stripped\nCalifornia of its tuberculosis-free status, causing cattle to have to be\ntested before they leave the state.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Idaho is located close to California, as can be seen on the map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/010E>. Idaho and California have quite an exchange\nof goods from fruit to cattle, and even a migration of people between these\nstates.\n\nAccording to\n<http://www.aphis.usda.gov/animal_health/animal_dis_spec/cattle/downloads/rb51_vaccine.pdf>\nRB51 was licensed for use in 1996. So while this vaccine moved through\ntransition of being phased in while Strain 19 was being phased out, it is\nentirely possible that there is an aged cow that was vaccinated with Strain 19.\n\nStrain 19 vaccination was phased out because it created many false\npositives within the testing scheme, which was costly to producers. Now 13\nyears down the road, there are questions as to the long term efficacy of\nRB51 by some groups.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost\nexclusively by _Brucella abortus_ ; however, _B. suis or B. melitensis_ are\noccasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B. suis_ does not appear to\nbe contagious from cow to cow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many\nabortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in which the disease is\nendemic, an infected cow typically aborts only once after exposure;\nsubsequent gestations and lactations appear normal. After exposure, cattle\nbecome bacteremic for a short period and develop agglutinins and other\nantibodies; some resist infection and a small percentage of infected cows\nrecover. A positive serum agglutination test usually precedes an abortion\nor a normal parturition but may be delayed in about 15 per cent of cows.\nThe incubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage of\ngestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and uterine\ndischarges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile. Bacteria may be\nfound in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently,\nfor a prolonged time, in the non-gravid uterus. Shedding from the vagina\nlargely disappears with the decrease of fluids following parturition. Some\ninfected cows that previously aborted shed brucellae from the uterus at\nsubsequent normal parturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable\nlength of time -- in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are present in\nlarge numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine discharges.\nCattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or lick contaminated\ngenitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls to\nsusceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission may occur by artificial\ninsemination when _Brucella_ -contaminated semen is deposited in the uterus\nbut, reportedly, not when deposited in the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter\nthe body through mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has\nremained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to direct\nsunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk, and cheese\nrepresent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not killed\nby pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in humans\ncauses malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain,\njoint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and\ndepression. Brucellosis has been called undulating fever because of its\nhabit of producing fever and signs that wax and wane over an extended\nperiod of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm> and from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nA map of Idaho can be found at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:National-atlas-idaho.PNG>; its border\nwith California is at its lower (southern) edge on the left (west). - Mod.SH]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 13 Dec 2009\n Brucellosis in humans\ncauses malaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck pain, low back pain,\njoint pain, muscle pain, occasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and\ndepression. The action was taken on the\nbasis of\n\n(i) a clinical syndrome of abortion, weak calves, and increased\nretention of afterbirth in a number of herds and\n(ii) positive serology findings for brucellosis (screening by Rose\nBengal test and confirmed by CFT [complement fixation test]).\n\nThe mention of 314 'infected cattle' in recent postings refers to\nreactive sera on Rose Bengal testing, of which only 264 were confirmed\nby CFT. Reference to possible detection in the Western Division of\nViti Levu is similarly based on Rose Bengal screen testing of sera,\nnot yet confirmed by CFT.\n\nThe Fiji Ministry is in correspondence with the Australian Animal\nHealth Lab (AAHL) to confirm the presumptive diagnosis of brucellosis.\nA regulatory 'hurdle' is currently being 'negotiated' to enable\nsuspect isolates to be sent to AAHL as soon as possible. THE Fiji\nMinistry is intending to adopt _Brucella_ milk ring testing as a\nscreening tool for dairy herds. There are approximately 10 000 dairy\ncattle in the local vicinity of the affected herds in the Central\nDivision, with herd sizes ranging from 30-500. Quarantine and movement\ncontrols have been implemented.\n\nUSDA APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] is providing\nadvice on the possible application of RB51 strain vaccination.\n\n--\nIan Peebles BVSc MACVSc (Epidemiology)\nRegional Animal Health Specialist\nSecretariat of the Pacific Community\nSuva Fiji Islands\n<ianp@spc.int>\n\nThe Secretariat of the Pacific Community is a regional\ninter-governmental organisation that provides assistance to Pacific\nisland nations across social resource, public health, land resource,\nand marine resource sectors.\n\n[Strong surveillance testing and a vaccination program coupled with\nquarantines and slaughter are needed to arrest the problem and achieve\neradication of this disease.\n\nSurveillance testing consists of conducting a series of serological\ntests to detect the presence of _Brucella abortus_ antibodies in the\nanimal. On the initial official screening test, animals testing\nnegative are classified as 'negative' and are considered NOT to be\ninfected with brucellosis. Animals testing positive are classified as\n'positive,' and further testing is required to assist in a more\ndefinitive diagnosis of brucellosis. Serological screening tests for\n_Brucella abortus_ antibodies include the buffered acidified plate\nantigen (BAPA) test, which is used solely in the laboratory, while the\n'card agglutination' test, an official test, can be conducted at the\nlivestock markets or in the laboratory to classify animals as either\npositive or negative. Samples testing positive on the BAPA test are\nsubsequently subjected to the 'card agglutination' test in the\nlaboratory. If the 'card agglutination' test is used at the market,\nthen the BAPA may be used in the laboratory as the next level of\nscreening. Screen test positive samples could come from either an\nanimal infected with field _Brucella abortus_ organisms or from an\nanimal having persistent antibodies to a brucellosis vaccination,\nprovided vaccination is being used.\n\nTo determine if a screen-test positive animal is either infected with\nthe disease or if it still has antibodies caused by vaccination, the\nblood samples are subjected to official supplemental serological\ntesting. The Rivanol, the complement fixation (CF), and the particle\nconcentration fluorescent immunoassay (PCFIA) tests are official\nsupplemental serological tests used in the laboratory. The results of\nthe official supplemental testing are subsequently interpreted by a\ntrained brucellosis epidemiologist who makes the final determination\non the screen-positive animal; it is either designated as 'suspect'\nand will require further testing, or it is classified as a 'reactor'\nand must be sent to slaughter under permit to prevent the animal from\nbeing diverted back to a herd.\n\nSuspects, if they have not been slaughtered, are required to be\nre-tested in 30 to 60 days. Quarantining the suspect animal or the\nherd from which the suspect originated will be determined by the\ntrained epidemiologist. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "The results of\nthe official supplemental testing are subsequently interpreted by a\ntrained brucellosis epidemiologist who makes the final determination\non the screen-positive animal; it is either designated as 'suspect'\nand will require further testing, or it is classified as a 'reactor'\nand must be sent to slaughter under permit to prevent the animal from\nbeing diverted back to a herd. His brucellosis was traced\nto him cleaning a feral hog in March 2009. He and his son butchered\none of the many feral hogs they had shot or trapped.\n\n'People need to know that they should be cautious when they handle\nthose pigs, and always wear gloves,' he said. 'I wouldn't want what's\nhappened to me to happen to anybody.'\n\nThe man faces months of more treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by a bacterium linked to feral hogs. An estimated 2 million of\nthe wild creatures roam Texas. The Houston Chronicle reported Thursday\n[17 Sep 2009] that about 10 percent of Texas feral hogs test positive\nfor brucellosis bacteria, but the rate in eastern parts of the state\nhas been known to be higher. The disease can cause pregnant animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The CDC, earlier in 2009, reported on similar cases in the\nsoutheastern USA. As an occupation-related disease, brucellosis can\nresult from the organism from diseased animals entering through skin\nlesions or mucous membranes, or from the inhalation of contamination\ndust or aerosols.\n\nInhalation is involved with many cases associated with abattoir\nworkers (1). Contamination of skin lesions is also common in meat\npacking workers or veterinarians. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk, or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis in\nadult skeletal remains of people killed during the 1st volcanic surge\nof Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce first\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually named\nin his honor. The organism was isolated from goat's milk in 1905, also\nin Malta.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and requires high-level biosafety\ncontainment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves hydrogen\nsulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage susceptibility, and\nagglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To simplify this process,\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction technology looking at single\nnucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Robson JM, Harrison MW, Wood RN, et al: Brucellosis: re-emergence\nand changing epidemiology in Queensland. Med J Aust 1993; 159(3):\n153-8; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8336614>.\n2. Godfroid J, Cloeckaert A, Liautard JP, et al: From the discovery of\nthe Malta fever's agent to the discovery of a marine mammal reservoir,\nbrucellosis has continuously been a re-emerging zoonosis. Vet Res\n2005; 36(3): 313-26; available at\n<http://publications.edpsciences.org/10.1051/vetres:2005003>.\n3. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, et al: _Brucella suis_\nidentification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol.\n2008; 131(3-4): 376-85. In fact, current rates are\ncomparable to those of Greece, and similar to those that existed in\nthe USA during the 1930s and 1940s. See graph:\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Brucellosis-Mexico.png>\n\nThe following background data on brucellosis in Mexico are abstracted\nfrom Gideon:\n<http://www.gideononline.com/blog/2009/08/17/brucellosis-in-mexico/>\nPrimary references available on request.\n\nTime and Place:\n- Highest rates are found in Queretaro, Coahuila, Guanajuanto, Nuevo\nLeon, Chicuahua, Jalisco, Tamaulipas and Michoacan.\n- 163 fatal cases were reported during 1978 to 1982.\n- Mortality rates were 0.04 per 100 000 in 1992; 0.01 per 100 000 in 1996.\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n- 3.42 percent nationwide, ranging from 0.24 percent in Morelos, to\n13.5 percent in Mexico State (1992 publication).\n- 0.71 percent of blood donors in northeastern Mexico (2009 publication).\n- 0.24 percent of equines in Tamaulipas (_Brucella abortus_ 2006 publication).\n- 9.8 percent of goats on farms (Brucella melitensis). (Michoacan,\n2007 publication).\n\nInfecting species:\n- _Brucella melitensis_, _B. abortus_ and _B. canis_ are found in Mexico.\n- The predominant species is _B. melitensis_ (1968 to 1991).\n\nReservoirs:\n- The caprine seropositivity rate was 20.7 percent in 1947.\n- Highest rates of caprine disease are reported in Coahuila,\nChihuahua, Jalisco and Zacatecas.\n- Highest rates of bovine disease are reported in Chihuahua, Hidalgo\nand Guanajuato.\n- 11.8 percent of stray dogs in Mexico City are infected by _Brucella canis_.\n\nVehicles:\n- Most infections are acquired from unpasteurized milk, fresh cheese\nand other dairy products, primarily from goats (There are more than 9\nmillion goats in Mexico).\n- More than 35 percent of cow milk is consumed unpasteurized and more\nthan 85 percent of goat milk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nTel Aviv, Israel\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED thanks Steve Berger (and Gideon) for this information. - Mod. Reports indicate the syndrome has been\noccurring since February 2009.\n\nPreliminary analysis for brucellosis of 2429 sera collected from 9\nherds in June 2009 by Rose Bengal test identified 236 strongly\nreactive sera from 6 of the herds tested. A sub-sample of RBT\nreactive sera was subsequently analysed with the assistance of the\nQueensland Department of Primary Industries in Australia by both CFT\nand ELISA for Brucella. Serology results were 35/50 sera positive by\nCFT (titres ranging from 1/16 to 1/4096) and 48/50 sera positive by ELISA.\n\nCulture results are currently pending. Further serological analysis\nis to be conducted. Pre-emptive slaughter of reactor cattle has been\nundertaken in a number of herds.\n\nInvestigation of the source of the outbreak is ongoing. Fiji\nconducted a test and slaughter program for bovine brucellosis in the\n1980s and subsequently declared freedom from the disease in 1989.\nFiji is believed to be free from Brucella melitensis. Brucella suis\nis known to be present in some sectors of the pig population but\nrecent survey information is not available.\n\n--\nIan Peebles, BVSc MACVSc (Epidemiology)\nRegional Animal Health Specialist\nSecretariat of the Pacific Community\nSuva Fiji Islands\n<IanP@spc.int>\nThe Secretariat of the Pacific Community is a regional\ninter-governmental organisation that provides assistance to Pacific\nisland nations across social resources, public health, land resource\nand maritime resource sectors.\n\n[Ian Peebles' detailed report in response to our yesterday's RFI is\ngratefully acknowledged. Ural meat processing plants are in\nstrengthened mode. Peasants are handing over large numbers of\ninfected cattle. To process large quantity of meat, meat-packing\nplants work in the strengthened mode also, but the prices for sausage\nin shops has not decreased.\n\nIn comparison with the last [several] years, the quantity of infected\ncattle has increased repeatedly. More than 230 000 heads of cattle\nhave been examined. The greatest quantity of infected heads of cattle\nhas been revealed in Dzhangalinsky, Akzhaiksky, Dzhanibeksky\ndistricts. But, according to experts of regional territorial\ninspection of the Ministry of Agriculture, it is not an epidemic.\nSimply since this year [2009] more exact technique of revealing\nbrucellosis has begun to be applied. However conditions remain\nextremely serious. An expanded meeting devoted to brucellosis, took\nplace in regional administration. The problem of recycling of sick\ncattle became rather actual. Sanitary meat can be used after thermal\nprocessing for manufacture of sausages and canned meat. In order to\navoid the further distribution of a dangerous infection of sick cows\nit is necessary to slaughter animals, but not all peasants hurry to\ncull the animals who support them. According to Farukh Mukhanov, the\nmain expert of territorial inspection, not in all districts the work\nfor reception and sending on meat-packing plants is led at an\nappropriate level of sanitation.\n\nNevertheless, at meat-packing plants with which have been concluded\nagreements for processing of infected meat, an intense situation\nalready has developed in connection with shortage of industrial\nresources. But at such surplus of raw materials, the price for\nsausage in shops, breaking all laws of economy, remain stably high.\n\nIn total in the region for last months 9 persons have already been\ninfected by brucellosis. In Uralsk there is a real danger to catch\nthis disease, buying milk on numerous, uncontrollable spontaneous\npoints of trade or from travelling milkmen.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Difficult epidemiological and epizootic conditions connected with\nthis brucellosis outbreak have developed in a number of republics of\nCentral Asia, in particular, in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan. On 9 Jun\n2009 ProMED-RUS reported brucellosis in 30 people and 2000 cattle in\nthe Atyrausky area of Kazakhstan (archive no. 20090609.91293).\nAmong the reasons for this situation are low veterinary supervision\nover agricultural animals and the sanitary-and-hygienic control of\nthe dairy production, insufficient volume of preventive actions, in\nparticular, vaccination among the persons entering into group of\nrisk, and agricultural animals. Improvement of quality of brucellosis\ndiagnostics in the republic has led to sharp growth of detectability\nof this disease among animals and, as a consequence, to diagnosing it\nin the people who had direct contact to them. - Mod.NP]\n\n[Both _Brucella abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are reportedly present\nin Kazakhstan. The reservoir of _B. abortus_ is, generally, cattle\nand of _B. melitensis_, goats and sheep, though cross infections may\noccur. The disease\ncauses late-term abortion and infertility in cattle, while it can also\nlead to fever in humans.\n\nThe ministry's veterinarian officer, Robin Achari, says the infected\ncattle are distributed among 14 farms in North Tailevu, with one\nsuspected case in the south. Mr Achari says all sick animals have been\nquarantined and will be killed.\n\n'We're slaughtering, removing all the positive reactors from the farms\nas soon as possible. We have just managed to slaughter 32 at this\npoint in time; and the meat has been inspected and cleared, if not,\nthen discarded.'\n\nRobin Achari says the meat is safe for consumption, but people should\nstop drinking unpasteurised milk or risk infection.\n\nHowever, New Zealand's Food Safety Authority senior advisor, Kathleen\nShaw, says cooking meat should make it safe to eat, but adds it's not\ngood practice to eat products from any sick animal.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Fijivillage.com [edited]\n<http://www.fijivillage.com/?mod=story&id=070709630d0c7c94f371c2d15b239a>\n\n\nTask force formed to find origin of Brucellosis\n-----------------------------------------------\nA task force has been formed to investigate the origins of the\noutbreak of the infectious cattle disease brucellosis and map out\nplans to completely eradicate it from the country.\n\nMinistry of Primary Industry Spokesperson Joe Ulilakeba said they are\nconfident that the disease is being contained.\n\nUluilakeba said tests on cattle continue around the country and so far\nout of the 3371 cattle tested, 282 have tested positive to brucellosis\nand all confirmed cases are confined to the Wainivesi and Waimaro area.\n\nMeanwhile, Minister for Primary Industries, Joketani Cokanasiga, has\nreiterated that the meat from cattle slaughtered after being found\nwith Brucellosis is safe to eat and was thoroughly inspected by 2\nhighly qualified meat inspectors.\n\nHe stresses that nobody in Fiji eats meat raw and has suggested that\npeople get their facts right before jumping to any conclusion and\ncreating fear amongst the people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since 2005, when OIE introduced a new disease reporting system\n(WAHID/WAHIS), Fiji submitted periodical reports for 2007; no reports\nare available for the years 2005, 2006 and 2008. According to the 2007\nreport, Bovine brucellosis (a disease cause by _Brucella abortus_) was\nnot present in Fiji during 2007; the year of its last, previous\noccurrence was indicated as 'Unknown.'\n\nThough bovine brucellosis is caused by _B. abortus_, cattle can be\ninfected also by _B. melitensis_, the causal agent of ovine and\ncaprine brucellosis; no information on the status of this bacterium in\nFiji is available in WAHIS.\n\nAccording to FAO statistics (FAOSTAT) for 2007 (estimates), there are\n315 000 head of cattle in Fiji. The cow milk production in 2007 was\nestimated to be 58 000 tons. There are also 270 000 goats; this\nspecies is susceptible in particular to infection with _B.\nmelitensis_, but may be infected by _B. abortus_ as well.\n\nKnowledgeable sources are encouraged to provide updated information on\nthe animal disease situation in Fiji. In case cattle brucellosis is\nnew to Fiji, the current outbreak is expected to be officially\nnotified to the OIE.\n\nAccording to FAOSTAT (most recent data 2005, 2006) Fiji imported some\ncattle from New Zealand and Australia. _B.abortus_ was, reportedly,\nabsent in both countries since 1989.\n\nThe official name of Fiji is the Republic of the Fiji Islands. The\ncountry occupies an archipelago of about 322 islands, of which 106 are\npermanently inhabited, and 522 islets. The 2 major islands, Viti Levu\nand Vanua Levu, account for 87 percent of the population (estimated,\nJuly 2008, to be 944 720). Corr.ATS, edited]\n<http://www.24.kg/community/2009/01/22/103947.html>\n\n\n[The following is from an interview with Jalalidin Gaybulinov, the\nhead of the National Center for Quarantine and Particularly Dangerous\nInfections of MOH in Kyrgyzstan.]\n\nThere were 74.3 brucellosis cases per 100 000 population in Kyrgyzstan\nin 2008, which is slightly less than in 2007 (77.5 per 100 000). The\nmost affected regions were Jalal-Abad, Talasskoe, Norinskoe [Naryn],\nand Issik Kulsoe, with incidence far exceeding [the national average].\n\nEpidemiologists from [the national] center for quarantine and\nparticularly dangerous infections conducted consultations and carried\nout seminars for the affected population. Additionally, patients'\nco-payments for treatment have been decreased to the minimum\naccording to the program of governmental guarantees.\n\nThe morbidity among humans is directly associated with the morbidity\namong farm animals. There were 5127 brucellosis cases in cattle and\n3509 cases in smaller livestock in 2008. Currently, farm animals are\nnot documented, and there is uncontrolled traffic of animals both\ncross-border and inter-province. Infected animals stay in private\nyards for months, thus spreading infection to humans and other\nanimals. Another reason for high brucellosis incidence in farm animals\nis incomplete vaccine coverage.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The numbers provided in this article tell about incidence and not\nprevalence, which may be several times higher. Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.regnum.ru/news/1151240.html>\n\n\nBrucellosis found in cattle in the Chuvash Republic for the 1st time in 40\nyears\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nFor the 1st time in 40 years, brucellosis has been revealed in cattle and\nin small ruminants in Chuvashia. Infected animals have been detected in the\nagricultural enterprises 'Bakhcha,' Krasnoarmeysky district and\n'Turunovskiy,' Cheboksary district.\n\nAll cattle and small ruminants in the 2 facilities, over 200, have been\neliminated: 51 cattle and one horse (conditionally healthy animal, which\ndid not show positive tests for brucellosis) have been slaughtered at the\n'OAO Vurnarsky meat plant', while others have been recycled in the SUE\n'Tsivilsky vetsanutilzavod' plant. Note that the positive reactions to\nbrucellosis were detected in 40 sheep and 2 cows.\n\nBrucellosis in animals was recorded in March [2009], after a check-up in\nFebruary by experts of the Russian Federal Service for Veterinary and\nPhytosanitary Surveillance (Rosselkhoznadzor). It was revealed that on 25\nDec 2008, 150 [infected?] sheep for breeding were transported with an\ninvalid veterinary certificate from the agricultural production plant\n'Bakhcha' to 'Turunovskiy.' The veterinary certificate was 'backdated,'\navoiding the prescribed quarantine period at the location of origin, which\ninvolves diagnostic tests. In this connection, 149 sheep out of the 150\ntransported were put in quarantine, sampled, and positive brucellosis\nreactors discovered. Chuvashia had been regarded free of brucellosis for\nseveral decades and the 'Turunovskiy' plant did not keep sheep before;\ntherefore, other routes of disease introduction could be regarded improbable.\n\nAs to the way the disease penetrated the 'Bakhcha' enterprise, [the\nepidemiological investigation] revealed that sheep were introduced in 2005\nfrom 7 facilities in the Astrakhan, Yaroslavl, and Ivanovo regions with\nsevere violations of requirements of normative legal certificates of the\nRussian Federation in the field of veterinary science.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In view of the available information, particularly the involvement of\nsheep, it may be assumed that the pathogen involved is _Brucella\nmelitensis_. Laboratory confirmation is anticipated, preferably with\ninformation on the serovar (there are 3 _B. melitensis_ serovars). The\nsevere zoonotic nature of _B. melitensis_ calls for caution in handling of\nthe infected animals and premises. Other domestic animals, including dogs,\nshould be tested as well; the pathogen mainly infects sheep and goats, but\noccasionally also cattle, camels, and dogs, and rarely horses and pigs.\nInfections in sheep and goats can spill over into wild ruminants.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is\nconsidered the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational\nexposure is seen in farmers, their family members, laboratory workers,\nveterinarians, and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Aborted\nfoeti and vaginal secretions are particularly rich in infective material.\nBrucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections.\nPeople who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by\ningesting unpasteurized dairy products.\n\nThe application of recycling of the culled cattle is interesting; it is\nindicative of allowing the utilisation of cattle-derived meat and bone meal\nin Russia. For which purposes?\n\nChuvashia is an autonomous republic of western Russia in the Volga River\nvalley; for its location, see the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_Russia_-_Chuvash_Republic_(2008-03).svg>.\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Russia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00a1>.\n\nFurther reading\n---------------\n1.
