A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. This according to the Dublin SPCA\n[Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals] and the Ulster SPCA.\n\nThe 2 organisations have reported that the puppy farm in question is\nhome to a staggering 700 breeding bitches and there are currently up\nto 300 puppies on the premises.\n\nThe farm's owner has refused to sign an undertaking not to move the\ndogs off-site before an official inspection can take place to\ninvestigate the extent of the problem.\n\nSomeone from the farm told the Irish Times that the 2 animal welfare\nagencies were involved in acts of 'intimidation' against the establishment.\n\nCanine brucellosis is transmissible to humans and can cause liver\ndamage and arthritis.\n\n'We got accurate information on Friday [2 May 2009] that this man was\nintending moving and selling these dogs and we acted on it,'\naccording to Jimmy Cahill, chief executive of the DSPCA. 'The guards\nwere very helpful but the owners refused to let us see the dogs or\nany of the carcasses [see comment below. - Mod.AS]. If there is an\noutbreak of canine brucellosis it could have a devastating impact on\nthe greyhound industry,' he added.\n\nBrucellosis in humans is a potentially life-threatening disease and\nis difficult to treat. There are several varieties of brucellosis,\nall caused by bacteria of the genus _Brucella_, the most notable\nbeing _B. abortus_ [affecting mainly cattle. - Mod.AS] and _B.\nmelitensis_ [affecting mainly goats and sheep. - Mod.AS], and _B.\ncanis_ which infects dogs and other canids.\n\nAll are widely spread around the world. The most severe infections\nare thought to be associated with _B. melitensis_, which primarily\ninfects goats, sheep, and camels in the Mediterranean, Asia, Latin\nAmerica, parts of Africa, and some southern European countries.\nHumans can catch _B. canis_ through contact with the body fluids of\ninfected dogs, especially semen, urine, and vaginal fluids.\n\nDogs can be infected with brucellosis without showing any signs or\nsymptoms, and infection can only be diagnosed with specific blood tests.\n\nThe typical symptoms of the type of brucellosis contracted from dogs\nare: fever that comes and goes, loss of appetite, fatigue, weakness,\nmalaise, sore joints, low back pain, spine pain, headache,\ndepression, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhoea, vomiting,\nweakness, dizziness, unsteadiness of gait, and urinary retention.\nHeart and lung complications can occur.\n\nA Department of Agriculture veterinary source told the Times that an\noutbreak of canine brucellosis would be 'extremely unusual.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Canine brucellosis, caused by _Brucella canis_, is an important\ncause of reproductive failure, particularly in kennels and can end\nthe reproductive career of a breeding animal. _B. canis_ is zoonotic,\nalthough disease appears to be rare in humans. Other _Brucella_\nspecies occasionally associated with disease in dogs include _B.\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_. Genetic and immunologic\nevidence suggests that all members of the genus _Brucella_ are closely related.\n\nDogs are the only species known to be affected by _B. canis_;\nhowever, antibodies to this organism have been found in other carnivores.\n\n_B. canis_ has been reported from the United States (particularly the\nsouthern states), Canada, Central and South America (including\nMexico), some European countries, Tunisia, Nigeria, Madagascar,\nMalaysia, India, Korea, Japan, and China. _B. canis_ is probably\nfound throughout most of the world; however, New Zealand and\nAustralia appear to be free of this organism.\n\nIn dogs, _B. canis_ is mainly transmitted by contact with the fetus\nand fetal membranes after abortions/stillbirths, or by venereal\ntransmission. This organism can be found in vaginal discharges for 4\nto 6 weeks after an abortion. It is also shed in normal vaginal\nsecretions, particularly during estrus, as well as in milk. High\nconcentrations of _B. canis_ are found in semen for up to 2 months\nafter infection, and intermittent shedding of smaller quantities can\noccur for years. _B. canis_ is also found in urine, and low\nconcentrations of bacteria may be excreted in saliva, nasal and\nocular secretions, and feces.\n\nCanine brucellosis is usually introduced into a kennel in an infected\ndog or semen. This disease is controlled by sanitation and the\nremoval of infected dogs. Housing in individual cages reduces the\nspread of the organism. Repeated testing and the removal of\nseropositive or culture-positive animals, combined with quarantine\nand testing of newly added dogs, have been used to eradicate\nbrucellosis from some kennels. There is no vaccine for _B. canis_.\n\nLong-term antibiotic therapy has been used successfully to treat some\ndogs, but some animals relapse. Neutering can be used as an\nadditional control measure.\n\nHumans usually become infected with _Brucella_ spp. by ingesting\norganisms or by the contamination of mucous membranes and abraded\nskin. Infection with _B. canis_ seems to require close contact with\ninfected dogs or contact with bacterial cultures. The virulence of\nthis organism for humans may be low. Approximately 30 cases have been\nreported worldwide since the 1960s. However, _B. canis_ infections\ncan be difficult to diagnose in humans and may be underreported. In\nsymptomatic cases, brucellosis is extremely variable and the clinical\nsigns may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, this disease\nbegins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs\nsuch as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia, and generalized aches.\n\nMortality in dogs, due to _B. canis_, is highly unusual. The\nmentioning of 'carcasses' on the kennel's premises is in need of\nclarification, and a laboratory confirmation of the exceptionally\nextensive outbreak reported above is anticipated.\n\nFurther reading\n---------------\nCanine brucellosis: _Brucella canis_; available at\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Ireland is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bn>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\n \n\nThe typical symptoms of the type of brucellosis contracted from dogs\nare: fever that comes and goes, loss of appetite, fatigue, weakness,\nmalaise, sore joints, low back pain, spine pain, headache,\ndepression, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhoea, vomiting,\nweakness, dizziness, unsteadiness of gait, and urinary retention. USA: (MT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=146595", "date": "2009-01-17 13:00:43", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MONTANA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 17 Jan 2009\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\n<http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/articles/2009/01/15/news/000elk.txt>\n\n\nElk in the cross hairs\n----------------------\nMontana wildlife officials killed 2 radio-collared cow elk near Gardiner\nthat had tested positive for exposure to brucellosis, a bacterial disease\nthat can cause pregnant cattle, bison and elk to abort calves.\n\nThe rest of the elk herd, which tested negative, will be allowed to\ncontinue grazing in the Paradise Valley and south-central portions of\nYellowstone National Park, where they spend most of the spring, summer and\nfall, Ron Aasheim, spokesman for the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife\nand Parks (FWP), said on Wednesday [14 Jan 2009]. So far, only wildlife\nnear Yellowstone have tested positive for brucellosis, Aasheim said. 'We\nhave not found brucellosis anywhere else,' he said.\n\nOfficials have known for years that elk carry the disease and can transmit\nit to cattle and bison. But after finding it in 2 different cattle herds\nduring the past year [2008], causing Montana to lose its brucellosis-free\nstatus, state wildlife experts have ramped up efforts to track the disease.\n\nSince 1981, FWP has tested nearly 7000 elk for brucellosis, mostly north\nand west of Yellowstone Park. But this year, after the National Veterinary\nService said elk were the likely culprits infecting cattle, FWP expanded\nefforts to collect blood samples from hunter-harvested elk in south western\nMontana. And the agency is working toward implementing better tracking\nsystems, Aasheim said, 'collaring another bunch of elk as we speak.'\n\nExisting tests show that up to 5 per cent of the elk grazing in and near\nthe park have been exposed to brucellosis. Fewer than half of those\ninfected are capable of passing it on, said state veterinarian Marty\nZaluski. But cattle ranchers, nervous about the disease, are asking the\nstate to increase elk-monitoring efforts, said Errol Rice, executive vice\npresident of the Montana Stockgrowers Association.\n\nBy better understanding the disease, the FWP aims to limit cattle-wildlife\ninteractions during late-winter and spring months when the potential for\ntransmission is highest, rather than targeting brucellosis-positive elk for\nremoval, Aasheim said. And although brucellosis may be more visible now\nwith increased testing, the threat to Montana cattle likely has not\nincreased, Aasheim said. 'I don't think the threat is any greater than it's\never been,' Aasheim said.\n\nWhile it's no surprise the disease popped up this week, Rice said ranchers\nneed to be vigilant and lobby the state to fund wildlife testing, to help\nensure cattle herds stay healthy. 'Just hunters alone are not going to be\nable to give adequate numbers,' Rice said. 'We can always do more.'\n\nOn Monday, the Montana Board of Livestock approved an 'action plan' to\nlimit transmission of the disease among cattle, requiring cattle in a\n7-county area considered high risk be tested, largely based on exposure to\nelk and bison. And Zaluski said the state's various efforts to halt the\ndisease are paying off. 'We've made a fair amount of progress in a short\namount of time,' Zaluski said. 'But we still have a way to go.'\n\nThe 2 elk killed on Tuesday were tested last spring [2008] and found to be\ncarrying the disease, but Montana wildlife officials waited until the\nanimals left the park before putting them down.\n\n[byline: Jessica Mayrer]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The disease is caused by a group of bacteria known scientifically as the\ngenus _Brucella_. 3 species of _Brucella_ cause the most concern: _B.\nabortus_, principally affecting cattle, bison, and cervids; _B. suis_,\nprincipally affecting swine and reindeer but also cattle and bison; and _B.\nmelitensis_, principally affecting goats but not present in the United\nStates. In the Greater Yellowstone Area, the bacterium of concern is _B.\nabortus_. In cattle and bison, the disease currently localizes in the\nreproductive tract discharges.\n\nThere is no effective way to detect infected animals by their appearance.\nThe most obvious signs in pregnant animals are abortion or birth of weak\ncalves. Milk production may be reduced from changes in the normal lactation\nperiod caused by abortions and delayed conceptions. Not all infected cows\nabort, but those that do usually abort between the 5th and 7th month of\npregnancy. Infected cows usually abort once, but a percentage will abort\nduring additional pregnancies, and calves born from later pregnancies may\nbe weak and unhealthy. Even though their calves may appear healthy,\ninfected cows continue to harbor and discharge infectious organisms and\nshould be regarded as dangerous sources of the disease. Other signs of\nbrucellosis include an apparent lowering of fertility with poor conception\nrates, retained afterbirths with resulting uterine infections, and\n(occasionally) enlarged, arthritic joints. organs and/or the udder.\nBacteria are shed in milk or via the aborted fetus, afterbirth, or other\nreproductive tract discharges.\n\nThe incubation period of brucellosis in cattle, bison, and other animals is\nquite variable ranging from about 2 weeks to 1 year and even longer in\ncertain instances. When abortion is the 1st sign observed, the minimum\nincubation period is about 30 days. Some animals abort before developing a\npositive reaction to the diagnostic test. Other infected animals may never\nabort.\n\nGenerally, infected animals that do not abort develop a positive reaction\nto the diagnostic test within 30 to 60 days after infection, although some\nmay not develop a positive reaction for several months to more than a year.\n\nRepeated attempts to develop a cure for brucellosis in animals have failed.\nOccasionally, animals may recover after a period of time. More commonly,\nhowever, only the signs disappear and the animals remain diseased. Such\nanimals are dangerous sources of infection for other animals with which\nthey associate.\n\nBrucellosis is commonly transmitted to susceptible animals by direct\ncontact with infected animals or with an environment that has been\ncontaminated with discharges from infected animals. Aborted fetuses,\nplacental membranes or fluids, and other vaginal discharges present after\nan infected animal has aborted or calved are all highly contaminated with\ninfectious brucella organisms. Cows may lick those materials or the genital\narea of other cows or ingest the disease-causing organisms with\ncontaminated food or water. Despite occasional exceptions, the general rule\nis that brucellosis is carried from one herd to another by an infected or\nexposed animal. This mode of transmission occurs when a herd owner buys\nreplacement cattle or bison that are infected or have been exposed to\ninfection prior to purchase. The disease may also be spread when wild\nanimals or animals from an affected herd mingle with brucellosis-free herds.\n\nThe presence of brucellosis in free-ranging bison and elk in Yellowstone\nNational Park and Grand Teton National Park threatens the brucellosis\nstatus of the surrounding states and the health of their livestock herds,\nwhich are free of the disease. Reintroduction of the disease into a\nbrucellosis-free state could have a serious economic impact on domestic\nlivestock markets and potentially threaten export markets. The US\nDepartment of Agriculture's (USDA) Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService (APHIS) is working cooperatively with other State and Federal\nagencies toward containing the spread of brucellosis from bison to domestic\nlivestock and eliminating the disease from the Yellowstone and Teton herds\nwhile maintaining viable free-roaming bison herds in the parks.\n\nThis comment has been extracted from\n<http://www.aphis.usda.gov/lpa/pubs/fsheet_faq_notice/faq_ahbrucellosis.html>\n- Mod.TG\n\nA map showing the State of Montana may be viewed at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/montana.html> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "The US\nDepartment of Agriculture's (USDA) Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService (APHIS) is working cooperatively with other State and Federal\nagencies toward containing the spread of brucellosis from bison to domestic\nlivestock and eliminating the disease from the Yellowstone and Teton herds\nwhile maintaining viable free-roaming bison herds in the parks. The government of Kyrgyzstan is well aware of the\nbrucellosis situation in animals and humans and is treating this as an\nurgent national issue.\n\nA national control program for brucellosis has been set in motion with\nmulti-donor assistance from the World Bank, the Swiss Development\nCooperation (SDC), the EU, the Swedish International Development Agency,\nand others. Kyrgyzstan is recognized as a country having one of the highest\nrates of brucellosis in animals and humans. Naryn has been the focus for\nmuch of the surveys and initial pilot work. Based on the results of the\ninitial survey work, the Government has instituted a national vaccination\nprogram in 2008 to control the disease at source in the livestock\npopulation. This has been combined with a public awareness campaign to\nimprove personal hygiene and prevent human exposure through direct contact\n(that is, during lambing, care after animals) or consumption of\ncontaminated food products.\n\nIt is likely that the 10 per cent incidence of brucellosis reported in\nhumans in the province of Naryn, and refuted by the Ministry of Health,\nactually refers to a 10 per cent Rose Bengal test [RBT] seroprevalence\nfound in small ruminants in a recent randomized survey of animals in 13\nvillages in Ak-Talaa, a district in Naryn. A seroprevalence of 1.7 per cent\nwas found in cattle. The final seroprevalence will depend on results of\nindirect ELISAs [enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay] on all RBT reactors.\n\nBrucellosis in humans in Naryn province during 11 months of 2-8 [?2008]\nappeared to be 151.3 per 100 000 population [from] recently conducted\n[studies] in the high risk area of Naryn [that is, the incidence of\nbrucellosis in Naryn is actually about 0.15 per cent instead of 10 per cent\nindicated in the ProMED-mail report]; the incidence of brucellosis in\nhumans has been stabilized and is reduced.\n\nThe Government of Kyrgyzstan takes this situation very seriously, is\ncommitted to a long term strategy for reducing the incidence of brucellosis\nin animals and humans, and has moved to a risk-based approach. This\nincludes high-coverage vaccination of small ruminants, control programs for\ncattle, awareness campaigns, and public involvement at the village level.\nIn fact, the brucellosis program has evolved from donor supported projects\nfor community and village health and also bird flu control and is an\nimportant part of the comprehensive approach to 'One Health'. This effort\nis coordinated through the deputy prime minister and with uniquely close\ncooperation between the MAWRPI [Ministry of Agriculture, Water Resources\nand Processing Industry] and the Ministry of Health for the control of\nzoonotic diseases. The program is also consistent with the Government's\nvery close collaboration with the OIE [World Organisation for Animal\nHealth] in upgrading its veterinary services to meet international\nstandards in accordance with its WTO [World Trade Organisation] commitments.\n\nIt should also be recognized that this work is being carried out during a\nvery difficult period of fiscal crisis and with considerable limitations on\nthe national budget and resources.\n\nNurlan Dyusheev\nFirst Deputy Director General of the State Veterinary Department\nMAWRPI [Ministry Agriculture, Water Resources and Processing Industry]\nKyrgyz Republic\nJalalidin Gaibulin\nDirector of the Centre of Quarantine and Dangerous Infection\nMoH [Ministry of Health]\nKyrgyz Republic\n\n--\nJoldoshbek Kasymbekov\nChief of the Information and Communication Unit\nState Veterinary Department (SVD)\n(MAWRPI)\nKyrgyz Republic\n<joldoshbekk@yahoo.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Nurlan Dyusheev, first deputy director general of the\nState Veterinary Department and Jalalidin Gaibulin, director of the Centre\nof Quarantine and Dangerous Infection of the Ministry of Health, Kyrgyz\nRepublic, for their clarification of the situation in Kyrgyzstan and\nexplanation of data presented in ProMED-mail posting archive 20090102.0010.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "Kyrgyz Republic\n<joldoshbekk@yahoo.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Nurlan Dyusheev, first deputy director general of the\nState Veterinary Department and Jalalidin Gaibulin, director of the Centre\nof Quarantine and Dangerous Infection of the Ministry of Health, Kyrgyz\nRepublic, for their clarification of the situation in Kyrgyzstan and\nexplanation of data presented in ProMED-mail posting archive 20090102.0010. Outbreaks of human brucellosis in\nRussia likely occur as a result of consumption of raw milk or milk\nproducts from infected animals, and occupational exposure to infected\nanimals' tissues or secretions among farmers, veterinarians, and meat\nindustry workers.\n\nProMED-mail Russian Mod.NP attributed the ongoing problem to\n'violations of veterinary-sanitary rules, such as: import of animals\nwithout veterinary assessment, lack of quarantine measures for\nimported animals, or limited veterinary control over the levels of\nvaccine coverage (see ProMED-mail post Brucellosis, livestock, human\n- Azerbaijan, Russia 20080518.1658).\n\n--\nMatthew Levinson\nProMED-mail Bacterial Disease Moderator (Mod.ML)\nProfessor of Public Health\nDrexel University School of Public Health\nAdjunct Professor of Medicine, Formerly Chief, Division of Infectious Diseases\nDrexel University College of Medicine\nPhiladelphia, Pennsylvania, USA\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "NP attributed the ongoing problem to\n'violations of veterinary-sanitary rules, such as: import of animals\nwithout veterinary assessment, lack of quarantine measures for\nimported animals, or limited veterinary control over the levels of\nvaccine coverage (see ProMED-mail post Brucellosis, livestock, human\n- Azerbaijan, Russia 20080518.1658). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 3 Jan 2009\n Outbreaks of human brucellosis in\nRussia likely occur as a result of consumption of raw milk or milk\nproducts from infected animals, and occupational exposure to infected\nanimals' tissues or secretions among farmers, veterinarians, and meat\nindustry workers.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "141452", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Kyrgyzstan: (NA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=141452", "date": "2009-01-02 16:00:41", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - KYRGYZSTAN: (NARYN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 29 Dec 2008\nSource: FarmingUK [edited]\n<http://www.farminguk.com/news/Kyrgzstan-Brucellosis-epidemic-in-cattle-and-humans.9548.asp>\n\n\n[An] epidemic of brucellosis in Kyrgyzstan has affected 2000 humans.\nThe Red Cross and the World Health Organization (WHO) are at a loss\nknowing what to do as the hospitals fill up and nothing is being done\nto prevent the spread of the disease.\n\nThe small former Soviet nation of Kyrgyzstan that gained independence\nin 1991 is showing in the Naryn region, a 10 percent incidence of\nbrucellosis in the human population according to the WHO. Brucellosis\nin humans causes loss of weight, followed by a slow agonizing death\nand abortion in women.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 10 percent incidence of brucellosis in Naryn reported in the\nnews release above has been denied by the Ministry of Health Care of\nKyrgyzstan. The director of the Republican Center of quarantine and\ndangerous infections, J Gaibulin, told the correspondent from the\nKabar Agency that 404 cases [about 15 cases per 10 000 population] of\nbrucellosis were registered this year [2008] in Naryn oblast and 444\ncases last year [2007] (see\n<http://74.125.47.132/search?q=cache:C1drXd-t5BgJ:www.timesca.com/index.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D193838%26Itemid%3D7+WHO+brucellosis+naryn&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=1&gl=us>).\n\nBrucellosis in humans is a zoonotic infection caused mainly by one of\n3 species of _Brucella_, namely B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B.\nabortus_. Brucellosis is transmitted to humans either by direct\ncontact with tissues of infected animals or their\npost-partum/post-abortion secretions, or by the ingestion of\ncontaminated, unpasteurized food products, mainly dairy products.\nDirect person-to-person transmission from an infected mother to infant\ncan occur by means of breast-feeding. Sexual transmission has also\nbeen reported. _B. melitensis_, which causes the most severe\ninfections in humans, is maintained in small ruminants (sheep and\ngoats), though cases in cattle and buffalo may occur sporadically. _B.\nabortus_ is maintained mainly in large bovines (cattle and buffalo).\nThe _Brucella_ species that are causing brucellosis in Kyrgyzstan are\nnot given in the news release.\n\nBrucellosis in humans causes fever, sweating, weakness, headaches,\ndepression, and muscle and joint pains, the duration of the which can\nvary from a few weeks to many months or even years. Mortality is low\n(less than 2 percent), and is usually associated with endocarditis.\nFocal complications include sacroiliitis, endocarditis,\nepididymoorchitis, and meningitis. Diagnosis is based on isolation of\nthe organism and/or serology.\n\nBrucellosis in humans can be prevented by eradication of brucellosis\nin animals and by pasteurization of milk. Brucellosis control\nprograms in animals involve test-and-slaughter, and/or vaccination.\n\n_Brucella_ can also be used as a bioweapon, in which the\nmicroorganism is delivered as an aerosol. An outbreak following\naerosolization would be initially difficult to detect because the\nearliest indications of infection are non-specific flu-like symptoms.\n\nThe current situation with brucellosis in Kyrgyzstan is likely a\ncontinuation of a prior outbreak that was noted in ProMED-mail post\narchive number 20060924.2725. In this post, Dr Steve Berger said\nthat: '[Kyrgyzstan] may have the highest rate of brucellosis in the\nworld. Annual rates exceed those of adjacent countries and even\ntraditional 'hot-spots' in southern Europe. See:\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Brucellosis-Kyrg.jpg>.'\n\nThe rates of brucellosis for Kyrgyzstan [extracted by Mod.LL] ranged\nfrom 15 to 24 cases per 10 000 in the 1990's and rose to 50 in 2003\nand 43 in 2004.\n\nAccording to another prior ProMED-mail post, archive number\n20060923.2715 that concerned brucellosis in Kyrgyzstan, Mod.NP noted,\n'...hygienic standards are frequently not observed in the sale of meat\nand dairy products. The population quite often does not hand over\nsick animals to veterinarians for slaughter.' Also see\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=20842>.\n\nKyrgyzstan is a mountainous, landlocked Central Asian country, west\nof China, that is divided into 2 administratively independent cities\n(Bishkek, the capital, and Osh) and 7 provinces (oblasts), one of\nwhich is Naryn. The provincial capital of Naryn is about 350 km (218\nmi) from Bishkek and 200 km (124 mi) from the Chinese border. The\ntown of Naryn has a population of about 50 000 (there are about 260\n000 inhabitants in the whole of the Naryn oblast) and is separated\nfrom the rest of Kyrgyzstan by mountain ranges\n(see <http://www.advantour.com/kyrgyzstan/naryn.htm> and\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naryn>).\nSheep, raised on the extensive steppe and alpine pastures, are the\nmainstay of the economy.\n\nFor maps of Kyrgyzstan see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/commonwealth/kyrgyzstan_pol_05.jpg>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=1527590&v=41.433,75.967,6>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "The director of the Republican Center of quarantine and\ndangerous infections, J Gaibulin, told the correspondent from the\nKabar Agency that 404 cases [about 15 cases per 10 000 population] of\nbrucellosis were registered this year [2008] in Naryn oblast and 444\ncases last year [2007] (see\n<http://74.125.47.132/search?q=cache:C1drXd-t5BgJ:www.timesca.com/index.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D193838%26Itemid%3D7+WHO+brucellosis+naryn&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=1&gl=us>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 29 Dec 2008\n The\ntown of Naryn has a population of about 50 000 (there are about 260\n000 inhabitants in the whole of the Naryn oblast) and is separated\nfrom the rest of Kyrgyzstan by mountain ranges\n(see <http://www.advantour.com/kyrgyzstan/naryn.htm> and\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naryn>). Brucellosis is transmitted to humans either by direct\ncontact with tissues of infected animals or their\npost-partum/post-abortion secretions, or by the ingestion of\ncontaminated, unpasteurized food products, mainly dairy products. For maps of Kyrgyzstan see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/commonwealth/kyrgyzstan_pol_05.jpg>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=1527590&v=41.433,75.967,6>. \n\nBrucellosis in humans causes fever, sweating, weakness, headaches,\ndepression, and muscle and joint pains, the duration of the which can\nvary from a few weeks to many months or even years. \n\nBrucellosis in humans is a zoonotic infection caused mainly by one of\n3 species of _Brucella_, namely B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B.\nabortus_. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 10 percent incidence of brucellosis in Naryn reported in the\nnews release above has been denied by the Ministry of Health Care of\nKyrgyzstan. The current situation with brucellosis in Kyrgyzstan is likely a\ncontinuation of a prior outbreak that was noted in ProMED-mail post\narchive number 20060924.2725. _B. melitensis_, which causes the most severe\ninfections in humans, is maintained in small ruminants (sheep and\ngoats), though cases in cattle and buffalo may occur sporadically. The small former Soviet nation of Kyrgyzstan that gained independence\nin 1991 is showing in the Naryn region, a 10 percent incidence of\nbrucellosis in the human population according to the WHO. Brucellosis\nin humans causes loss of weight, followed by a slow agonizing death\nand abortion in women. LL] ranged\nfrom 15 to 24 cases per 10 000 in the 1990's and rose to 50 in 2003\nand 43 in 2004. \n\nKyrgyzstan is a mountainous, landlocked Central Asian country, west\nof China, that is divided into 2 administratively independent cities\n The Red Cross and the World Health Organization (WHO) are at a loss\nknowing what to do as the hospitals fill up and nothing is being done\nto prevent the spread of the disease.\n\n In this post, Dr Steve Berger said\nthat: '[Kyrgyzstan] may have the highest rate of brucellosis in the\nworld.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1990-03-24 00:00:00", "1991-03-24 00:00:00", "2003-03-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Naryn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "218364", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=218364", "date": "2009-06-12 21:00:09", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, SWINE HUNTERS - USA: (SOUTH CAROLINA, PENNSYLVANIA) EX FLORIDA\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 11 Jun 2009\nSource: MMWR 12 Jun 2009; 58: 618-621 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5822a3.htm>\n\n\nHistorically, brucellosis from _Brucella suis_ infection occurred\namong workers in swine slaughterhouses. In 1972, the USA Department\nof Agriculture National Brucellosis Eradication Program was expanded\nto cover swine herds. Subsequent elimination of brucellosis in\ncommercial swine resulted in a decrease in _B. suis_-associated\nillness in humans. Currently, swine-associated brucellosis in humans\nin the USA is predominantly associated with exposure to infected\nferal swine (i.e., wild boar or wild hogs), that is, swine that have\nlived any part of their lives as free-roaming animals.\n\nIn May and July 2008, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC) was contacted by the state health departments in South Carolina\nand Pennsylvania regarding 2 cases of brucellosis possibly linked to\nferal swine hunts. Both state health departments contacted the state\nhealth department in Florida, where the hunts took place. The\nsubsequent investigation, conducted jointly by the 3 state health\ndepartments and the CDC, determined that the 2 patients had confirmed\nbrucellosis from _B. suis_ infection and the brother of 1 patient had\nprobable brucellosis. All 3 exposures were associated with feral\nswine hunting, and at least 2 patients did not have symptoms until\n4-6 months after exposure (Table [for table, see original URL -\nMod.LL]). The findings from this investigation suggest that\nclinicians treating patients with unexplained febrile illness should\nconsider brucellosis in the differential diagnosis and obtain a\nthorough history of travel (e.g., to enzootic areas), food\nconsumption, occupation, and recreational activities, including feral\nswine hunting. Cross-agency collaboration by state health departments\nand agriculture agencies is needed on brucellosis investigations to\nreduce the risk for illness through contact with infected animals.\n\nCase Reports\n------------\nPatient A. On 7 May 2008, a man aged 67 years from South Carolina\n(patient A) was referred by his private physician to a local\nemergency department after 1 week of fever (cyclic daily range: 99.2\ndegrees - 102.5 degrees F [37.3 degrees C - 39.2 degrees C]),\nmalaise, anorexia, painful swollen left knee, and headaches. Patient\nA had a left total knee arthroplasty in 2004 and uneventful treatment\nin 2005 for septic arthritis in the same knee. Before onset of\nsymptoms for his acute illness, patient A reported that he felt well\nexcept for an unintended 13 pound weight loss over a 16 week period\nand night sweats that began the day before he sought treatment. In\nthe emergency department, blood and synovial fluid were obtained for\nculture, and the patient was empirically treated with intravenous\nnafcillin for septic arthritis.\n\nThen, 2 days later, on 9 May 2009, the man was referred to a hospital\nwith chills, persistent fever, continuing left knee arthralgia, and\nedema. He was admitted with a diagnosis of left knee infection and\nsepsis and treated initially with vancomyin. Knee aspirate cell count\nresults were 16 700 white blood cells/cubic mm (normal: greater than\n150) and 1322 red blood cells/cubic mm (normal: greater than 1).\nSpecimens of blood and a knee aspirate were collected for culture.\nInitial microbiologic examination indicated _Corynebacterium\nurealyticum_. Upon infectious disease consultation, the patient was\nstarted on doxycycline and naprosyn; on 11 May 2009, he developed\nepididymo-orchitis and was changed to levofloxacin and daptomycin on\n12 May 2009 for a 6 week course. _Brucella spp._ subsequently were\nidentified from isolates from the blood and synovial specimens\ncollected from patient A on 7 May 2009. Isolates were sent to the\nSouth Carolina state public health laboratory and CDC for\nconfirmatory testing. On 29 May 2009, _B. suis_ biovar 1 was identified.\n\nThe epidemiologic investigation revealed that patient A had hunted\nferal swine in southwestern and south central Florida with 2\ncompanions during 23 - 29 Dec 2007. All participated in field\ndressing and butchering 8 or 9 feral swine at 2 locations. While\nfield dressing one of the swine, patient A cut his hand with a knife.\nNo personal protective equipment was worn during the field dressing\nand butchering. The meat was brought back to South Carolina, stored\nin a freezer, and boiled before being consumed by patient A over\nseveral months. No one else prepared or ate the meat, and no meat was\ncollected for testing. No other risk factors for brucellosis were identified.\n\nBecause patient A's hunting companions were well, serologic testing\nfor brucellosis was not performed. Patient A recovered with no\npermanent knee joint damage after antimicrobial therapy with\nlevofloxacin and daptomycin for 6 weeks.\n\nPatient B. On 14 Jul 2008, a previously healthy man aged 37 years\nfrom Pennsylvania (patient B) went to a local emergency department\nafter 1 week of morning fevers, chills, myalgia, shortness of breath,\nand night sweats. He also reported an unintended 30 pound weight loss\nover a 1 month period, beginning 3 weeks before illness onset. A\nblood chemistry profile was within normal limits with the exception\nof glucose of 121 mg/dL (normal: 74 - 100). A blood specimen for\nculture was obtained.\n\nClinical impression was acute viral syndrome; patient B was\ndischarged with instructions to use an albuterol metered-dose inhaler\n3 times daily for 1 - 2 days for his shortness of breath and to\nfollow up with his private physician in 2-3 days. On 23 Jul 2009, the\nPennsylvania state public health laboratory received patient B's\nblood specimen from the local hospital and isolated and identified\n_B. suis_ using Laboratory Response Network standardized biochemical\ntests and polymerase chain reaction.\n\nEpidemiologic investigation revealed that, on 29 Dec 2007, patient B\nhad hunted feral swine in Florida with his brother (patient C), a\nFlorida resident. Both men participated in field dressing and\nbutchering 4 feral swine. No personal protective equipment was worn\nduring these procedures, and no other risk factors for brucellosis\nwere identified. Patient B brought the meat back to Pennsylvania and\nstored it in a freezer. The meat was prepared and consumed by patient\nB and his family members over a 7 month period. According to patient\nB, the meat was cooked adequately (i.e., to an internal temperature\nof 160 degrees F [71.1 degrees C]).\n\nThe CDC received 3 _B. suis_ isolates for confirmation and further\nmolecular characterization. One isolate was from the blood of patient\nB, and the other 2 were recovered from frozen sausage and tenderloin\nof a feral swine from the 29 Dec 2009 hunt. All 3 _B. suis_ isolates\nwere analyzed at the CDC by molecular genotyping assay, using\nmultiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis. The assay\nindicated that the 2 meat isolates had identical signatures at all of\nthe 15 genomic markers, and the patient B isolate matched the meat\nisolates at all but 1 of 15 markers, suggesting that the 3 isolates\nwere linked.\n\nPatient B reported that his wife and children were not ill; however,\nhis brother (patient C) had experienced similar symptoms in April\n2008. Although asymptomatic, initial serologic testing for\nbrucellosis was performed on all household family members, and no\nantibody elevation was noted. Patient B recovered after 6 weeks of\ntreatment with rifampin and doxycycline.\n\nPatient C. In August 2008, the Pennsylvania state health department\nreported the association between patient B's infection and feral\nswine hunting to the Florida state health department, which, on 21\nAug 2008, contacted patient C (patient B's brother who had\naccompanied him on feral swine hunts). At the time, neither patient C\nnor his family members reported experiencing symptoms of brucellosis.\nHowever, patient C recalled feeling ill in April 2008 with night\nsweats and shortness of breath. He did not seek treatment because he\nattributed his symptoms to a recent scorpion sting.\n\nOther than feral swine hunting, no other brucellosis risk factors\nwere identified for patient C. He reported that all the meat he\nreceived from the December 2007 feral swine hunts was either smoked,\nroasted, or barbequed and was consumed at one family cookout. On 12\nSep 2008, a serum specimen from patient C was tested at CDC for\nanti-Brucella antibodies using the Brucella microagglutination test.\nThe resulting immunoglobulin G titer of 1:640 met the case definition\nfor probable brucellosis.\n\nBecause patient C's family was well, serologic testing for\nbrucellosis was not performed. Treatment was recommended for patient\nC, but he was lost to follow-up.\n\nEditorial Note:\n---------------\nBrucellosis is a bacterial zoonotic infection usually caused by\n_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, or rarely _B. canis_.\nHumans are infected through occupational or recreational exposure to\ninfected animals, inhalation of infectious aerosols, laboratory\nexposure (1), consumption of contaminated unpasteurized dairy\nproducts, or consumption of inadequately cooked contaminated meat.\nThe average incubation period for brucellosis is 2-10 weeks but, as\nseen in this report, can range to 6 months. Symptoms can be\nnonspecific and influenza-like: intermittent fever, chills, malaise,\ndiaphoresis, arthralgia, myalgia, headache, anorexia, and fatigue\n(2,3). Because of its nonspecific clinical syndrome, _B. suis_\ninfection likely is underreported. Clinicians should inquire about\ntravel, food consumption, occupation, and recreational activities\n(including feral swine hunting) of patients with nonspecific\ninfluenza-like symptoms with intermittent fever.\n\nPatient A likely was infected through the hand wound he acquired\nwhile field dressing feral swine. The investigations suggest that\npatient B and patient C also were infected during the field dressing\nor butchering process because family members consumed the meat and\nwere not affected clinically. Clinicians should order brucellosis\ntesting for persons who are symptomatic and have a history of feral\nswine hunting. Duration and type of therapy is dependent upon\nmultiple factors such as health status or age of patient and the\nmanifestation of disease. Untreated brucellosis can last from several\nweeks to several years. Chronic untreated brucellosis can lead to\nabscesses in the liver, spleen, heart valves, brain, or bone;\nosteoarticular complications; and, in rare cases, death (2,3).\n\nHuman brucellosis is a nationally notifiable disease in all 50\nstates, New York City, the District of Columbia, and all USA\nterritories except Puerto Rico. In 2007, 131 brucellosis cases were\nreported in the United States (Figure [for figure, see original URL -\nMod.LL]). States with the highest numbers of reported cases were\nCalifornia (33), Texas (25), and Florida (10) (4).\n\nFeral swine have been reported in 35 states (J. Corn, PhD, personal\ncommunication, Southeastern Cooperative Wildlife Disease Study,\n2009). The national feral swine population is estimated at\napproximately 4-5 million, with the largest populations in Texas (1.5\nmillion), California, Florida, and Hawaii. Serologic surveys have\ndetected endemic feral swine infection with _B. suis_ in 10 states\n(Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Louisiana,\nMississippi, Missouri, South Carolina, and Texas) (5-9). Feral swine\nhunting is allowed in most states with feral swine presence, and most\nstates require some form of license to hunt feral swine. Out-of-state\nhunters, as in this report, often bring swine meat back to their home states.\n\nEfforts to prevent _B. suis_ infection should focus on education of\nhunters and partnerships between state and local public health,\nwildlife, and agricultural agencies, and sportsmen's associations.\nEducational materials for feral swine hunters should include\nrecommendations for safe field dressing, butchering, and cooking (9).\nAll human brucellosis cases should be investigated jointly by state\nhealth departments and agriculture agencies to determine the sources\nof infection and prevent further illness in humans.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Laboratory-acquired brucellosis--Indiana and Minnesota,\n2006. MMWR 2008;57: 39-42.\n2. Glynn MK, Lynn TV. Brucellosis: J Am Vet Med Assoc 2008;233: 900-908.\n3. Mikolich DJ, Boyce JM: Brucella species [Chapter 223]. In:\nMandell, Douglas, and Bennett's principles and practice of infectious\ndiseases. 6th ed. Gresham CS, Gresham CA, Duffy MJ, et al: Increased prevalence of\nBrucella suis and pseudorabies virus antibodies in adults of an\nisolated feral swine population in coastal South Carolina. J Wildl\nDis 2002;38: 653-656.\n6. Stoffregen WC, Olsen SC, Wheeler CJ, et al: Diagnostic\ncharacterization of a feral swine herd enzootically infected with\nBrucella. J Vet Diagn Invest 2007;19: 227-237.\n7. van der Leek ML, Becker HN, Humphrey P, et al: Prevalence of\nBrucella sp. antibodies in feral swine in Florida. J Wildl Dis\n1993;29: 410-415.\n8. Zygmont SM, Nettles VF, Shotts EB, et al: Brucellosis in wild\nswine: a serologic and bacteriologic survey in the southeastern\nUnited States and Hawaii. J Am Vet Med Assoc 1982;181: 1285-1287.\n9. Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, US Department of\nAgriculture. Feral/wild pigs: potential problems for farmers and\nhunters. Agriculture information bulletin no. 799. Washington, DC: US\nDepartment of Agriculture; 2005. Available at\n<http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/wildlife_damage/content/printable_version/feral%20pigs.pdf>.\n\n[Byline: Giurgiutiu D, Banis C, Hunt E, et al.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As an occupation-related disease, infection can result from the\norganism from diseased animals through skin lesions or mucous\nmembranes or from the inhalation of contamination dust or aerosols.\nInhalation is involved with many cases associated with abbatoir\nworkers (1). Contamination of skin lesions is also common in meat\npacking wokers or veterinarians. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis\nin adult skeletal remians of people killed during the 1st volcanic\nsurge of Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce 1st\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually\nnamed in his honor. The organism, also in Malta, was isolated from\ngoat's milk in 1905.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and required high-level\nbiosafety containment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves\nhydrogen sulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage\nsusceptibility and agglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To\nsimplify this process, real-time polymerase chain reaction technology\nlooking at single nucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\n1. Isolates were sent to the\nSouth Carolina state public health laboratory and CDC for\nconfirmatory testing. All 3 _B. suis_ isolates\nwere analyzed at the CDC by molecular genotyping assay, using\nmultiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis. From the discovery\nof the Malta fever's agent to the discovery of a marine mammal\nreservoid, brucellosis has continuously been a re-emerging zoonosis. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves\nhydrogen sulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage\nsusceptibility and agglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To\nsimplify this process, real-time polymerase chain reaction technology\nlooking at single nucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies"], Data for the other Bosnian entity,\nRepublika Srpska, was not immediately available, but brucellosis has\nbeen seen as a growing problem there as well.\n\nWith more than 30 infections per 100 000 residents, Bosnia's\nFederation entity has seen the greatest share of brucellosis\ninfections than any other European country, Puvacic said.\n\nBrucellosis is carried by domestic and wild animals and can spread to\nhumans who work with animals or eat meat which was not properly\ncooked.\n\nIn addition to hundreds of registered human cases, tens of thousands\nof cases of brucellosis have been registered among domestic animals\nin Bosnia over the past few years.\n\nBosnia is especially susceptible to this and other infectious\ndiseases transmitted by animals because of the weak capacity of its\nhealth and veterinary services, but also because of a complex\nadministrative setup which prevents cooperation among different\nsectors and administrative units. As a result, many infected humans\nand animals are diagnosed late. Farmers often have to wait for weeks,\neven months for the culling of infected domestic animals, which are\nthen sometimes inappropriately disposed of.\n\nIn humans, brucellosis induces inconstant fevers, sweating, weakness,\nanemia, headaches, depression and muscular and bodily pain but is\nusually not fatal. It is treatable with antibiotics, although it can\ntake weeks, even months to recover.\n\nIn October 2008, the World Bank announced the launch of a new project\naimed at improving the country's technical and administrative\ncapacity to fight infectious diseases, including bird flu.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak of brucellosis in Bosnia and Herzegovina was\npreviously noted in ProMED post Brucellosis - Bosnia & Herzegovina\n20080523.1696. This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was 'irresponsible' and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - URUGUAY: (ARTIGAS)\n****************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. \n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "113657", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV), serovar 2", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=113657", "date": "2008-09-23 12:00:35", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - GERMANY: (MECKLENBURG-WESTERN POMERANIA), SEROVAR 2\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 22 Sep 2008\nFrom: Thomas Mettenleiter <Thomas.Mettenleiter@fli.bund.de>\n\n\nResponsible veterinary authorities imposed restrictions on a farm\nafter positive serological results in outdoor farmed pigs. The sera\nwere collected during a voluntary monitoring for this disease.\n\nFurther serological and bacteriological examinations confirmed the\ndiagnosis of brucellosis. Bacteriological differentiation performed\nat the National Reference Laboratory at the\nFriedrich-Loeffler-Institut identified the agent as _Brucella suis_\nbiovar 2. The pigs in question were culled and removed in agreement\nwith sanitary regulations.\n\n_Brucella suis_ biovar 2 is the cause of porcine brucellosis in\nCentral Europe. In contrast to _Brucella suis_ biovar 1 and biovar 3,\nbiovar 2 is assumed to be pathogenic for humans only under certain\ncircumstances, i.e. long-term immunosuppressive treatment.\nNevertheless, sanitary regulations as outlined in the German animal\ndisease legislation also apply to pigs infected with _Brucella suis_ biovar 2.\n\nBiovar 2 of _Brucella suis_ is present in wild boars and hares in\nGermany as shown by a serological survey (Melzer et al., 2006).\nVarious isolations of this agent in the last few years from both\nanimal species confirmed this finding.\n\nHow the pathogen was introduced into the farm has not been elucidated\nso far. The local state veterinarian acknowledged that this outdoor\nfarm operates according to the rules. Three brucellosis outbreaks\nhave been notified up to now in Germany in 2008. All were registered\nin Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania. Germany is officially free of\nbrucellosis in cattle, sheep and goats.\n\n--\nProf. Dr. rer. nat. habil. Dr. med. vet. h.c. Thomas C. Mettenleiter\nPraesident und Professor\nFriedrich-Loeffler-Institut\n17493 Greifswald-Insel Riems\nGermany\n<Thomas.Mettenleiter@fli.bund.de>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 22 Sep 2008\nFrom: Godfroid Jacques <jacques.godfroid@veths.no>\n\n\nRe: Brucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV) 20080918.2927\n-----------------------------------------------\nI would like to make the following comment in relation to the\nmoderator's statement, 'Since _B. suis_ is pathogenic to humans, the\nstatement 'there is no danger to humans' is in need of clarification\nor reconsideration.'\n\nYes, brucellosis is a zoonosis, but this does not mean that all\n_Brucella_ species or all biovars within a given _Brucella_ species\nare pathogens for humans. Indeed, the species _Brucella ovis_,\n_Brucella neotomea_ and _Brucella microti_ are not regarded as human\npathogens, and within the _Brucella suis_ species, _B. suis_ biovar 2\nhas been reported to infect humans only in very rare instances, for\nexample, if they are immuno-compromised. Recent data suggest that\nwithin the marine mammal brucellae, some isolates are true human\npathogens, whereas others are not able to infect human macrophage\ncell lines and thus are very unlikely to be human pathogens.\n\nIn the particular case of Germany, _Brucella suis_ biovar 2\ninfections in wild boars have been known for decades and were\nextensively described in the former DDR (Dedek et al., 1986). The\nstatement: 'The Veterinary authorities consider that the most likely\nroute of transmission was by wildlife, especially wild boar.\nTherefore, free-range animals are particularly affected by the\ndisease' strongly suggests that _B. suis_ biovar 2 is involved in\nthis outbreak, and, hence, reference made to 'data on the disease in\nhumans are derived from Mod.LL's commentary in ProMED-mail posting\n20040401.0883' is out of the context of this particular case.\n\nSo, to summarize, my point is that such a case should be used to\nhighlight that all _Brucella_ species are not equally pathogenic for\nhumans. By not doing so, we miss a golden opportunity to inform, and,\nmore importantly, we may mislead ProMED-mail readers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nHead of the Section Arctic Veterinary Medicine\nDepartment of Food Safety and Infection Biology\nNorwegian School of Veterinary Science\nStakkevollveien 23\n9010 Troms\nNorway\n<jacques.godfroid@veths.no>\n\n[The original article in the official regional website of\nMecklenburg/Western Pomerania included the statement 'there is no\ndanger to humans' (in German: 'Gefahr fur Menschen bestehe nicht').\nThe comprehensive response of Prof Godfroid, a world authority on\nbrucellosis, to our call for clarification is indeed eye-opening and\nmuch appreciated.\n\nSee also the following: 'The pathogenicity for humans of _B. suis_\nbiovars 1, 3 and 4 is well established, whereas _B. suis_ biovar 2\nseems to be less pathogenic. Indeed, although hunters and pig farmers\nhave repeatedly experienced infectious contact with _B. suis_ biovar\n2 (found in wild boar and outdoor-rearing pigs in Europe), isolation\nof _B. suis_ biovar 2 from human samples have only been seldom\nreported.' The news was published by the paper 'Schweriner\nVolkszeitung' (Sat 13 Sep 2008).\n\nHow the disease got onto the farm with locations in Bickhusen and\nNostorf is not known. There is no danger to humans [see commentary].\nThe disease was detected during routine checks in early August\n[2008]. 400 breeding pigs were immediately killed and removed, the\nremaining 4400 pigs were kept until reaching the minimum weight of 15\nkg (33 lb) and were then slaughtered and processed.\n\nDifferent variants of brucellosis affect cattle, pigs, or sheep.\nAccording to the Friedrich-Loeffler-Institute, 5 outbreaks of\nbrucellosis have been detected, thus far during 2008, on livestock\nfarms in Germany.\n\nThe Veterinary authorities consider that the most likely route of\ntransmission was by wildlife -- especially wild boar. Therefore,\nfree-range animals are particularly affected by the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<http://www.cvlonghorns.de>\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to Germany's report covering January-June 2008, the last\nyear of brucellosis occurrence in cattle, sheep/goats, and pigs was,\nrespectively, as follows: _Brucella abortus_ (bovine brucellosis)\n2004; _B. melitensis_ (ovine/caprine brucellosis) 2006; and _B. suis_\n(porcine brucellosis) 2006. All 3 OIE (World Organisation for Animal\nhealth)-listed zoonotic pathogens are reportable in Germany.\n\nThe main clinical manifestation of brucellosis in animals is abortion.\n\nThe following data on the disease in humans are derived from Mod.\nLL's commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20040401.0883:\n\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _B. melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing\nthe most severe and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling\ncomplications. A prolonged course of illness, which may be associated\nwith suppurative destructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_\n(from feral or commercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_\n(from cattle, buffalo, and camels) is associated with\nmild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is rarely associated with\ncomplications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that is\nindistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.\n\nMecklenburg-Vorpommern, translated as Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania,\nis a state in northern Germany, comprising 2 parts, Mecklenburg and\nVorpommern. See map at\n<http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:Deutschland_Lage_von_Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.svg>.\nLudwigslust is a district in the said state; see map at\n<http://www.answers.com/topic/mecklenburg-wp-lwl-png-1>.\n\nThe significant infection rate of wild boars in Mecklenburg-Western\nPomerania was demonstrated by a large-scale survey. A total of 763\nsera of wild boars were tested, of which 22 percent reacted to\nbrucellosis. The authors (see reference below) concluded that the\nhigh seroprevalence of brucellosis (as well as of tularemia) in wild\nboars indicated that natural foci of these zoonoses were present in\nwildlife in Germany. They also stated that 'the impact of\ntransmission of zoonotic pathogens from wildlife to livestock is\nunknown.' The current outbreak may shed some light on this aspect of\nwildlife infection.\n\nReference\n---------\nAl Dahouk S, Noeckler K, Tomaso H, et al (2005): Seroprevalence of\nbrucellosis, tularemia, and yersiniosis in wild boars (_Sus scrofa_)\nfrom north-eastern Germany. Eradicated elsewhere in the country, the disease\npersists in Yellowstone's bison, elk, and other wildlife and is\noccasionally transmitted to cattle.\n\nState Veterinarian Marty Zaluski said Montana must wait until May\n2009 to request reinstatement of its disease-free status. That's a\nyear after brucellosis was most recently found in a cow from a ranch\nnear Pray. An earlier infection on a ranch in Bridger in May 2007 was\nMontana's 1st since 1985.\n\nFederal DNA testing points to wildlife as the source of the Pray\ninfection. Since no bison are found in that area, Zaluski has said\nelk are the most likely culprit.\n\nThe testing of cattle is expected to cost ranchers in the state's\nbillion-dollar cattle industry an estimated USD 6 million to USD 12\nmillion. It will be required of export cattle that are capable of\nbreeding and over 18 months of age, at a cost of USD 7.50 to USD 12 per head.\n\nA small number of cattle, including those being sent directly to\nslaughter, will be exempt from testing.\n\nTo regain its disease-free status from the US Department of\nAgriculture (USDA), state officials plan to expand cattle\nvaccinations and find ways to keep cattle from interacting with wildlife.\n\n'Everyone knew this was coming,' Zaluski said. 'No one is happy about\nlosing our brucellosis-free status, but we're optimistic that, by\nworking together, we can develop practical approaches that reduce the\nrisks of transmitting the disease.'\n\nMeanwhile, Wyoming also is at risk of losing its disease-free status\nafter an infection was discovered in June [2008] on a ranch near Daniel.\n\nOfficials from both states have complained that federal regulations\nfor the disease are too rigid, and fail to account for the unique\nsituation of brucellosis in Yellowstone's wildlife.\n\nBut in announcing Montana's loss of disease-free status, the\nDepartment of Agriculture contended the potential economic toll would\nbe far greater -- an estimated USD 80 million annually -- if the\ndisease spread to other states.\n\n[Byline: Matthew Brown]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nPray is located in Park County, south of Livingston in south central\nMontana. BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (08): (MONTANA), LOSS OF STATUS\n*********************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1985-03-24 00:00:00", "2009-05-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2007-05-24 00:00:00", "2021-06-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Park County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daniel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "103047", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, canine - USA: (MI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=103047", "date": "2008-08-14 16:00:29", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - USA: (MICHIGAN)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2008\nSource: Michigan Department of Agriculture (official release) [edited]\n<http://www.michigan.gov/mda/0,1607,7-125-48096-198184--,00.html>\n\n\nThe Michigan Department of Agriculture (MDA) received confirmation of\ncanine brucellosis (CB) in 5 Michigan breeding kennels that sold\nsmall, mixed breed, and pure bred dogs in Michigan. The Missaukee,\nOsceola, Wexford, and Van Buren county kennels have been quarantined\nand MDA is in the process of notifying purchasers.\n\nCanine brucellosis is a contagious bacterial disease that causes\nabortions, death of puppies shortly after birth, and chronic health\nproblems in older dogs. Canine brucellosis is a reportable disease\nand an emerging concern in dog breeding facilities and 'puppy mills'\nin Michigan. There is no vaccine for the disease and no long-term\ncure. Antibiotics will control the infection and spaying dogs will\nminimize the risk of transmission to almost zero.\n\nCB is considered a zoonotic disease, even though the risk of actual\nhuman infection from a pet is very low. Although people can get CB\nfrom infected pets, transmission is very rare. It is mostly\ntransmitted through handling birthing tissues from an infected dog,\nalthough it can be transmitted in water and food dishes, in urine,\nand in feces. Even though most dog infections generally do not result\nin human illness, people with weakened immune systems are more\nsusceptible and should not handle dogs known to be infected with\ncanine brucellosis. There is also a higher risk to people working in\ninfected kennels.\n\nMDA has limited information that CB might be present in other canine\npopulations. An individual in Macomb County adopted a rescued dog\nfrom an animal shelter. The recently spayed female dog had signs of\nillness and the owner brought it to her veterinarian. The dog was\ntested and found positive for CB. The veterinarian treated the dog\nwith a course of antibiotics. The dog is home and is not considered\ninfectious.\n\nTo limit the potential spread of infection, the state veterinarian\nstrongly recommends pet shops purchasing puppies for resale require\nthe kennel of origin to provide evidence that all animals are tested\nnegative for brucellosis. This includes puppies from kennels in other\nstates.\n\nThe state veterinarian also recommends sexually intact dogs from\nunknown backgrounds, adopted or rescued from animal shelters, be\nscreened for canine brucellosis. Note that state law requires adopted\ndogs and cats to be spayed and neutered by the new owners, so we have\na public health safeguard.\n\nMDA actions to contain canine brucellosis:\n1. The breeding kennels have been quarantined and depopulated at the\nowner's expense, or are on a test-and-remove program. With\ntest-and-remove, the kennel remains quarantined, with no sales\nallowed, until there is no infection.\n2. When possible, people who purchased or traded dogs from these\nkennels have been contacted. We are contacting families in the\nvicinities of infected breeding kennels as some neighbors' dogs were\nallowed to breed at the kennels. Unfortunately, some of the kennel\noperators do not have complete records, so the following additional\nsteps will be taken.\n3. We are asking veterinarians statewide to be on heightened alert\nfor CB in small, mixed breed, and pure bred small dogs from shelters.\nThe Michigan Veterinary Medical Association (MVMA) is assisting MDA\nby contacting practicing veterinarians. Veterinarians and their staff\nexposed to the blood, or placentas, of infected dogs are at risk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nwith thanks to ProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett for sending in a\npress report on the outbreak.\n\n[There appears to be some evidence that the origin of the canine\nbrucellosis in Michigan may have been imported from a kennel in the\nneighboring state of Indiana. Even though most dog infections generally do not result\nin human illness, people with weakened immune systems are more\nsusceptible and should not handle dogs known to be infected with\ncanine brucellosis. It is mostly\ntransmitted through handling birthing tissues from an infected dog,\nalthough it can be transmitted in water and food dishes, in urine,\nand in feces. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nwith thanks to ProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett for sending in a\npress report on the outbreak. \n\nThe state veterinarian also recommends sexually intact dogs from\nunknown backgrounds, adopted or rescued from animal shelters, be\nscreened for canine brucellosis. The Michigan Department of Agriculture (MDA) received confirmation of\ncanine brucellosis (CB) in 5 Michigan breeding kennels that sold\nsmall, mixed breed, and pure bred dogs in Michigan. We are contacting families in the\nvicinities of infected breeding kennels as some neighbors' dogs were\nallowed to breed at the kennels. Canine brucellosis is a contagious bacterial disease that causes\nabortions, death of puppies shortly after birth, and chronic health\nproblems in older dogs. Canine brucellosis is a reportable disease\nand an emerging concern in dog breeding facilities and 'puppy mills'\nin Michigan. Note that state law requires adopted\ndogs and cats to be spayed and neutered by the new owners, so we have\na public health safeguard. [There appears to be some evidence that the origin of the canine\nbrucellosis in Michigan may have been imported from a kennel in the\nneighboring state of Indiana. That\nwould mean additional testing requirements for Wyoming cattle before\nthey're sold or transported across the state line.\n\nBut ranchers throughout western Wyoming must already submit cattle to\nadditional testing because they're in a brucellosis surveillance area.\n\n'We have to test in order to sell breeding livestock,' said a\nDaniel-area rancher. 'We are not the same as the rest of the state.\nWe are currently under restriction, and we don't have the same rights\nas everybody else in the state.'\n\nState Veterinarian Walt Cook has asked the federal government to\nextend its slaughter deadline until later this fall [2008], when the\n11 other herds that have had contact with the infected herd can be\ntested. The USDA [US Department of Agriculture] rejected Cook's\ninitial request for an extension, and he has appealed that decision.\n\nAnother Daniel-area rancher, said by refusing to extend the deadline\nfor the rancher to make his decision, the federal government is\npressuring the rancher to slaughter his breeding cattle.\n\n'They're trying to force him. They're trying to make it so bad he'll\nhave to slaughter,' [he] said. 'The guy's worked on those cows for\nyears. It's a high-altitude herd. These cattle have been acclimated\nto this area. So why should he have to start all over again? He's\nchoosing between 2 evils.'\n\nLivestock officials point out the rancher could preserve some of that\nbreeding effort through 'test and slaughter' - testing his cattle and\nkilling only those that test positive.\n\nThe program would take at least one year to complete. In the\nmeantime, Wyoming would lose its brucellosis-free status.\n\nThe state will also lose its status if another Wyoming herd tests\npositive for brucellosis within 2 years.\n\n[A] Wheatland cattle rancher, said he would support the rancher if he\ndecided not to slaughter his breeding cattle, even though that would\nadd a burden to his own operation.\n\n'It's a genetic base he's been working on for generations of cattle.\nHe's been selecting and raising his cattle according to what he sees\nas most fit for his environment and the customer,' [the cattle\nrancher] said. 'If he were to depopulate, he'd liquidate that genetic\nbase that he's been building for years. I understand very much his reluctance.'\n\n[The cattle rancher] said he believes the USDA's Animal and Plant\nHealth Inspection Service [APHIS] has given the rancher an\nunwarranted ultimatum by holding fast to its 29 Aug [2008] slaughter deadline.\n\n'Brucellosis isn't like foot-and-mouth or other highly contagious\ndiseases,' [he] said. 'When it has been quarantined, there isn't any\ndanger to public health, or the health of the national cattle herd.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Wyoming, in the western United States, can be located\non the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\n\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area includes Montana, Wyoming, and Idaho; it\ncan be seen on the map at <http://gorp.away.com/gifs/states/wy/m_gryel2.gif>.\n\nThe article makes good points in that the disease is contagious\nbetween animals, but certainly not in the same rapid fashion as\nfoot-and-mouth disease (FMD). Even in the FMD outbreak in the UK in\n2001 the aspect of valuable genetics of animals was an issue.\n\nGiven the genetics of the animals and the disease not having the same\nspread capacity as FMD, and the fact that Wyoming is already under\nsurveillance, it would seem prudent on the part of USDA to allow a\nlittle more time for consideration on the issue. After all, this is\nlikely many years of work and it being the only herd, it is not\npresently urgent to depopulate.\n\nIt is gratifying to see fellow producers encouraging more time and\nunderstanding that the best way for this owner may not be\ndepopulation and their support of him.\n\nIt is understandable that USDA would like to eliminate this domestic\nnidus of infection, but until the Greater Yellowstone Area is free of\nthe disease, situations like this may offer perhaps even next year.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison is caused almost\nexclusively by _Brucella abortus_ ; however, _B. suis or B.\nmelitensis_ are occasionally implicated in some cattle herds. _B.\nsuis_ does not appear to be contagious from cow to cow. Infection\nspreads rapidly and causes many abortions in unvaccinated cattle. In\na herd in which disease is endemic, an infected cow typically aborts\nonly once after exposure; subsequent gestations and lactations appear\nnormal. After exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a short period\nand develop agglutinins and other antibodies; some resist infection\nand a small percentage of infected cows recover. A positive serum\nagglutination test usually precedes an abortion or a normal\nparturition but may be delayed in about 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is inversely related to stage\nof gestation at time of exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during pregnancy, uterine\ninvolution, and infrequently, for a prolonged time, in the non-gravid\nuterus. Shedding from the vagina largely disappears with the decrease\nof fluids following parturition. Some infected cows that previously\naborted shed brucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a variable length of\ntime -- in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of organisms, which are\npresent in large numbers in aborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and\nuterine discharges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed and water, or\nlick contaminated genitals of other animals. Venereal transmission by\ninfected bulls to susceptible cows appears to be rare. Transmission\nmay occur by artificial insemination when _Brucella_ -contaminated\nsemen is deposited in the uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited\nin the mid-cervix. Brucellae may enter the body through mucous\nmembranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\nBrucellae have been recovered from fetuses and from manure that has\nremained in a cool environment for more than 2 months. Exposure to\ndirect sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk, unpasteurized milk and cheese\nrepresent a human health concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health. Diseases that are not\nkilled by pasteurization represent a risk to the consumer.\nBrucellosis in humans is not a pleasant disease.\n\nSigns and symptoms in people include malaise, fever, chills, sweats,\nheadache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal\npain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. Brucellosis\nhas been called undulating fever because of its habit of producing\nfever and signs that wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm> and from\n<http://www.merckveterinarymanual.com>. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2008\n \n\nSigns and symptoms in people include malaise, fever, chills, sweats,\nheadache, neck pain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, weight loss, abdominal\npain, weakness, irritability, insomnia, and depression. \n\nState Veterinarian Walt Cook has asked the federal government to\nextend its slaughter deadline until later this fall [2008], when the\n11 other herds that have had contact with the infected herd can be\ntested.
