The remaining 250 or so Angus cattle will be tested next\nweek, Logan said. Once the entire herd is tested, the state will\nbegin testing surrounding herds belonging to other ranchers.\n\nWhile the state has confirmed the presence of brucellosis, the\nfederal government was still conducting tests to make the\nconfirmation official.\n\nWyoming is in danger of losing its brucellosis-free status if the\ndisease is found in another herd or if the Daniel rancher declines to\nslaughter his entire herd.\n\nSchwartz said it's 'fairly high,' but not alarming to have 15 cattle\nin the herd test positive for brucellosis. 'It's really a fairly\nclean herd but we do have more than just the 2 that were initially\nfound,' he said.\n\nHe noted that wild elk herds commonly have 30 percent infection rates\nand some bison herds have had up to 70 percent infection rates.\n\nThe cattle from the Daniel area herd have been quarantined.\n\nSchwartz said the latest case of brucellosis infection has ranchers\nin western Wyoming concerned. 'We've now had\n2 cases of the disease in 2 years, and no contact with bison in\neither case. It supports our conclusion that elk were the source in\nboth cases.'\n\nZaluski said the information is a 'crucial' piece of evidence that\nshould pave the way for future efforts to manage the risk of\nbrucellosis transmission from wildlife to cattle.\n\n'The evidence supports the concept of interspecies transmission and\nshows that brucellosis must be a consideration in elk management in\nthe Greater Yellowstone area,' Zaluski said.\n\nThe Montana Board of Livestock (BOL) at its 22 Jul 2008 meeting\npassed a motion directing Zaluski and the Department of Livestock\n(DOL) to establish a task force that can evaluate the problem and\ndevelop potential solutions.\n\nThe motion reads, 'Since there is compelling evidence that\nbrucellosis can be transmitted to cattle from wildlife, the BOL\ndirects the DOL to work with Fish, Wildlife and Parks to jointly set\nup a task force that includes both livestock producers and sportsmen\nto help design both short- and long-term wildlife disease management\npolicies.'\n\n'A task force with a strong mission statement to keep it focused will\nbe an immensely valuable tool,' Zaluski said.\n\nBrucellosis is a bacterial disease that causes pregnant cows to\nabort, and also causes decreased milk production, weight loss,\ninfertility and lameness. A zoonotic disease, it can be passed to\nhumans through unpasteurized dairy products and contact with birthing\nfluids from an infected animal.\n\nMontana had been brucellosis-free since 1985, but the disease was\ndiscovered in a Bridger cattle herd in May of 2007. That outbreak was\ntraced to a herd in Emigrant, located just north of Yellowstone\nNational Park. This year's case, which was identified in late May\n2008 and confirmed on 9 Jun 2008 was the 2nd found in Montana within\nthe last 12 months; as such, it is expected that USDA will revoke\nMontana's Brucellosis Class Free status. Brucellosis was also found\nthis summer in Wyoming. [See comment below].\n\nFingerprinting, or genotyping, is a way to determine the genetic\nmakeup of an organism or a group of organisms. The process used in\nMontana's brucellosis investigation is called variable number tandem\nrepeat (VNTR), which is especially useful in genetic and biological\nresearch, forensic crime investigations, paternity suits, and to\nstudy genetic diversity and breeding patterns of wild or domestic animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Genotyping has been proving useful with TB in Michigan, so it is\nonly natural that the same technology should be helpful in the\nbrucellosis cases in those areas affected by the disease in the\nGreater Yellowstone Area. - Mod.TG\n\nThis report is a big disappointment, since on 1 Feb 2008 the US\nDepartment of Agriculture announced that for the first time in the\n74-year history of the brucellosis program, all 50 states, Puerto\nRico, and the Virgin Islands have simultaneously achieved class-free\nstatus in cattle <http://www.avma.org/onlnews/javma/mar08/080315f.asp>\n\nPicture of cattle in the Bridger (WY) valley:\n<http://farm1.static.flickr.com/157/423175717_1908bbad96.jpg?v=0>\nPicture of bull elk:\n<http://www.hickerphoto.com/data/media/40/elk_bull_sc11.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - Montana's brucellosis investigation is called variable number tandem\nrepeat (VNTR), which is especially useful in genetic and biological\nresearch, forensic crime investigations, paternity suits, and to\nstudy genetic diversity and breeding patterns of wild or domestic animals.\n\n--\n According to the report issued by the National Veterinary Services\nLaboratories (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa, 'Genotyping results ... indicate\nthat the _Brucella abortus_ strain recovered from the adult cow in\nMontana appears to be similar to strains recovered from bison and elk\nin the Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA).' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org ---------------------------------------------------------\nFingerprinting tests, or genotyping, from the brucellosis-infected\ncow found in Paradise Valley earlier this year (2008) have identified\nelk as the most likely source of the disease. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Genotyping has been proving useful with TB in Michigan, so it is\nonly natural that the same technology should be helpful in the\nbrucellosis cases in those areas affected by the disease in the\nGreater Yellowstone Area. This year's case, which was identified in late May\n2008 and confirmed on 9 Jun 2008 was the 2nd found in Montana within\nthe last 12 months; as such, it is expected that USDA will revoke\nMontana's Brucellosis Class Free status. \n\n'The genetic analysis is consistent with other epidemiological\ninformation that suggests the transmission of brucellosis from elk to\ncattle,' said Dr. Martin Zaluski, state veterinarian. \n\n'The evidence supports the concept of interspecies transmission and\nshows that brucellosis must be a consideration in elk management in\nthe Greater Yellowstone area,' Zaluski said. \n\nBrucellosis is a bacterial disease that causes pregnant cows to\nabort, and also causes decreased milk production, weight loss,\ninfertility and lameness.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-05-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1985-03-24 00:00:00", "2008-02-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "VNTR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Puerto \n Rico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Virgin Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "86408", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=86408", "date": "2008-06-11 04:00:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA: (MONTANA)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Jun 2008\nSource: New West Bozeman [edited]\n<http://www.newwest.net/city/article/sick_cow_costs_montana_its_brucellosis_free_status/C396/L396/>\n\n\nSick cow costs Montana its brucellosis-free status\n--------------------------------------------------\nA sick cow near Yellowstone National Park has Montana governor Brian\nSchweitzer and cattlemen calling for measures to protect stock and\nranchers. The disease is brucellosis. The cow was in Paradise Valley. In\nMay 2008, it tested positive for the disease that causes cows to abort. The\ncase will cause Montana to lose its federal designation as brucellosis-free.\n\n'The big unknown is what will be the impact on the marketplace here in\nMontana,' said Dennis McDonald, former president of the Montana Cattlemen's\nAssociation. 'None of us know for sure. It'll be a financial burden. It's a\nquestion to what extent.'\n\nWhat it means is that all of Montana's livestock producers will now be\nrequired to test bulls and cows, unspayed and 18 months old or older a\nmonth before interstate shipment. Montana cattle ranchers who want to ship\nor move their stock will have to prove to the US Department of Agriculture\n(USDA) that the animals do not have _Brucella abortus_ bacterium, the\ncausative agent of the disease.\n\n'It's an enormous amount of work,' McDonald said. Montana veterinarian\nMarty Zaluski said the loss of brucellosis-free status is particularly\nfrustrating given efforts by livestock producers and the industry to\nmitigate risks and increase disease surveillance.\n\n'Producers in the Paradise Valley have been involved and diligent, and they\nhave taken it upon themselves to be proactive in regard to managing the\nrisk of brucellosis transmission,' Zaluski said. 'In this particular case,\nthe owner did everything right. The cow had been vaccinated twice and was\npart of a herd management plan.'\n\nOfficials will test to track the cause of the disease in the Paradise\nValley animal. The last case was linked to elk, Zaluski said.\n\nAbout a year ago, the disease was discovered in a Bridger cattle herd. Two\nherds, totaling 585 animals were killed to limit the spread of the disease.\nTo keep its brucellosis-free status from the USDA, the state would have had\nto have no cases until July 2009. Previously, Montana livestock had been\nfree of the disease since 1985.\n\nThe soonest the state can apply to regain class free status is a year from\nthe date the last positive animal was killed, which will be 27 May next\nyear [2009].\n\nAll other animals in the herd where the sick cow was found have tested\nnegative for brucellosis. Herds with links to the herd where the infected\ncow was found will be placed under quarantine unless, or until, they are\nwhole-herd tested. McDonald of the Cattlemen's Association said the 2nd\ncase does not come as a surprise. 'I'm only surprised it took as long as it\ndid,' he said. 'It's obvious that park wildlife is a reservoir of brucellosis.'\n\nMcDonald said the National Park Service has not made any significant\nefforts to curb the spread of the disease, which he was careful not to\nblame on bison. McDonald advocated for vaccination 'We need funds for more\nresearch into a better vaccine. We need a plan to vaccinate wildlife in a\nmanner that's least destructive to their lives and ecosystems,' McDonald said.\n\nPlus, he said, the area near Yellowstone National Park needs to be treated\ndifferently than the rest of the state. Gov Schweitzer agreed. Montana\nneeds 'split-state' status, he said, so cattle ranchers across the state\nwon't be affected by cases near Yellowstone.\n\nSchweitzer has been advocating for a different brucellosis management\nstrategy near the park since taking office. He called for a small, separate\nmanagement zone -- termed 'split-state status' by USDA -- for the area\nimmediately surrounding the park. Only about 5 per cent of the state's\ncattle would have been affected by the USDA action.\n\n'Let's not play the blame-game,' McDonald said. 'Let's roll up our sleeves\nand figure out the next step.'\n\n[byline: Robert Struckman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[For cattle owners this becomes an economic burden. Testing of cattle\nshipped from Montana can add up in dollars and time. The state will\ncertainly be diligent in their testing and in tracing animals. This is\nconfirmation from the WSVL that the herd is infected with\nbrucellosis. Official confirmation is pending culture results from\nthe National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa.\n\nBlood from these cows initially tested positive at a sale barn. The\nblood was sent on to WSVL where testing confirmed the reaction seen\nat the sale barn. However, since false positive blood tests can\noccur, the cows were sent to the lab where they were necropsied and cultured.\n\nWith culture, tissues are tested for the actual bacteria. In this\ncase, the bacterium was cultured from tissues from both cows.\n\nThe Wyoming Livestock Board and USDA (US Department of Agriculture)\nAnimal & Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) plans to test the\nremainder of the cattle herd this week to discover if additional\ncattle may be infected. Once that is complete they will test\nneighboring cattle herds and complete investigations in an attempt to\ndiscover the source of the infection and determine if the infection has spread.\n\nIf the herd is not depopulated, the state may lose its\nbrucellosis-free status granted by APHIS, the Wyoming Livestock Board\nsaid, noting that the producer may choose to undergo a repeated\ntesting and removal program. Loss of this status would result in\ntesting requirements for all cattle in the state when they are sold\nor move out of state.\n\n[Byline: Tim Lundeen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The state may loose its 'brucellosis-free' status even if the herd\nis depopulated. A state is allowed 2 cases over a 2-year period.\nAnimals moving into the herd (trace-ins) and animals moving out of\nthe herd (trace-outs) have likely not been completed, then it is\ndifficult to determine if there are other cases. Also it is possible\nthat there could be cases coming into the state within the next 2 years.\n\nThe state is likely to institute rules reflecting the change in the\nrisk to the state and require a negative brucellosis test within a\ncertain number of days before coming into the state.\n\nIt is standard to depopulate the index herd to decrease the immediate\nloss of a state's 'free' status. Should the owner elect to refuse to\ndepopulate, the state will immediately loose its 'free-state' status.\n\nThis case represents a risk to the state. Likewise, the proximity to\nthe Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) increases the risk to the state.\nGYA has brucellosis in some subset of its elk and bison. There has\nbeen a committee that for several years has been established to\nexamine methods of eradicating the disease without jeopardizing the\nanimal populations within the national park.\n\nBrucellosis can transmit to human beings through unpasteurized milk\nas well as through exposure to birth fluids. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Wyoming, in the western United States, can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 17 Jun 2008\n \n\nIf the herd is not depopulated, the state may lose its\nbrucellosis-free status granted by APHIS, the Wyoming Livestock Board\nsaid, noting that the producer may choose to undergo a repeated\ntesting and removal program. \n\nThe state is likely to institute rules reflecting the change in the\nrisk to the state and require a negative brucellosis test within a\ncertain number of days before coming into the state. Human\nbrucellosis represents a professional hazard, being acquired via\ningestion, inhalation in laboratories or abattoirs, conjunctiva and\nskin trauma contamination with infected animal tissues and products\n(1,2). Symptoms can appear as acute or insidious onset, after 5 to 60\ndays and last for days, months and occasionally as long as a year.\nRelapses can also occur. Treatment is effective with antibiotics.\nUntreated brucellosis can lead to death (case-fatality ratio around 2\npercent), usually by heart complications.\n\nEpidemiological situation in Greece\n-----------------------------------\nBetween 2000 and 2007, the mean yearly incidence rate of brucellosis\nin Greece was 2.9/100 000 population. The annual incidence rate shows\na decreasing tendency: 5 in 2000, 3.7 in 2001, 3 in 2002, 2.2 in\n2003, 2.1 in 2004, 3.1 in 2005, 2.6 in 2006, and 1.38 in 2007. The\ndata indicate that the disease mainly affects rural areas of the\nmainland, all cases either engaged in a high-risk occupation\n(shepherds, workers in animal husbandry, vets) or sharing\nunpasteurized milk or dairy products with friends and relatives (3-5).\n\nStrict regulation in Greece only permits the circulation in the\nmarket of licensed producers' fully processed milk and its products\n(either pasteurized or cheese matured for at least 3 months before\nconsumption) and Human Public Health and Veterinary Public Health\nauthorities in all prefectures of the country ensure implementation\nby performing regular inspections in all restaurants, hotels,\ncatering establishments and other settings. During the summer months,\nthe Ministry of Health and Social Solidarity (MHSS) reinforces more\nfrequent inspections for the prevention of all foodborne diseases,\nincluding brucellosis.\n\nThe majority of islands, including Thassos of Kavala mainland\nPrefecture, are free from human cases and herds are considered\nbrucellosis-free, with serology conducted sporadically that prove\nthis. The Ministry of Rural Development and Food (MRDF), regularly\nprovides these results to the Hellenic Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention (HCDCP) and the MHSS, both of which it collaborates with\nclosely. All animals are tested before importation to the islands, so\nno brucellosis vaccination is conducted thereafter. On the other\nhand, in mainland Greece the brucellosis control program includes\nvaccination of herds and regular testing for brucellosis.\n\nOutbreak in Thassos\n-------------------\nNo cases of human brucellosis were reported in Thassos in 2007 or\nduring the 1st quarter of 2008, until early May 2008, when a\nconsiderable number of cases were notified to the Department of\nEpidemiologic Surveillance and Intervention, of the HCDCP MHSS (Table\n1 [for tables, see original URL - Mod.LL]). The onset of symptoms of\nthe 1st case was 1 Apr 2008. As of 17 Jun 2008, 55 human cases have\nbeen reported: 53 had consumed unpasteurized milk and/or dairy\nproducts (Figure 1 [for figures, see original URL - Mod.LL]): 8 had a\nhigh-risk profession (6 herd owners and 2 butchers), and 9 had had\nsystematic contact with sheep and/or goats. A total of 50 cases and 5\ncases were permanent residents of Thassos and Kavala respectively,\nthe age ranging from 8 to 88 years old, with a median of 46 years,\nsparing only 0-4 years old (Figure 2); 26 cases were male, 29 female.\n\nLaboratory results\n------------------\nAll cases reported tested positive for brucellosis (Standard\nAgglutination Test), except for 1 patient who met the clinical and\nepidemiological criteria while the laboratory result was pending when\nreported. 8 were asymptomatic while testing positive, 6 of whom\nreported consumption of non-pasteurized milk/dairy products, and 2\nreported their husbands' illness and high-risk profession.\n\nThere is a widespread custom among local residents of Thassos of\nconsuming unpasteurized milk and its products around Easter-time in\ntheir households. This does not affect tourists from Greece or abroad\nvisiting the island.\n\nControl measures\n----------------\nThere is a a standard procedure of close cooperation between the\nHuman Public Health (HPH) and Veterinary Public Health (VPH)\nofficials at the local level in the Prefectures of Greece, under the\nconstant supervision of the Unit for Zoonoses and Foodborne Diseases,\nof the HCDCP-MHSS, and the Ministry of Rural Development and Food.\nMore specifically, once the HPH is informed by physicians of the\nNational Health System (general practicioners, internists,\npediatricians) of a single human brucellosis case, they define the\nanimals or flock linked in any way with the patient and immediately\nprovide this information to the Veterinary Public Health office so\nthat brucellosis serology and/or testing of milk and its products are\nconducted in the veterinary reference laboratories. If indicated, the\nherd immediately undergoes all measures indicated by the brucellosis\neradication and control programme operating in Greece. A spontaneous\nsharing of all data has been established across the country among\nlocal HPH, VPH authorities, HCDCP, and the General Veterinary\nDirectorate, MRDF.\n\nSoon after the 1st human case was notified early in May 2008 in\nThassos, the above spontaneous usual procedures resulted in positive\nherd serologies. The HPH officials, being aware of the local habit,\ndistributed advice to all health authorities, and to all residents,\ndoor to door, suggesting the destruction of any improperly processed\nmilk products in households.\n\nCurrently, the slaughter of seropositive animals and vaccination has\nbeen applied to all herds of the island, which is the control program\nalready operating across mainland Greece (6), and this will continue\nuntil the island is again free of brucellosis.\n\nCoordinated HPH and VPH inspections in all restaurants, groceries,\nhotels, and other settings proved that only licensed products were\ncirculated in the market. A rapid telephone survey with a structured\nquestionnaire was conducted by the Unit for Zoonoses and Foodborne\nDiseases, HCDCP, and all interviewed cases confirmed that these\nhousehold products were not offered to any tourist in any setting.\n\nWork on a case control study has been initiated and is scheduled to\ntake place shortly.\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nBrucellosis is a disease of public health priority in Greece. The HPH\nand VPH authorities (7) at the central and local levels have a close\ncollaboration and integration, aiming at the target of eradicating\nthe disease which, judging by both reported cases and comments from\nleading hospitals? microbiologists, is thought to be in decline\nregarding annual incidence in the country. According to the\ninformation we have on this outbreak at the time of writing, it is\nunlikely that any tourists were exposed to brucellosis on Thassos. In\naddition, the public health measures applied after this local\noutbreak ensure that there is no future risk for tourists visiting the island.\n\n1. Young EJ: Brucella species. In: Mandell GL, Bennet JE, Dolin R,\neditors. Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases.\nPhiladelphia: Churchill Livingstone; 2001, pg. 2386-2393.\n2. Voss A, Nulens E: Prevention and control of laboratory-acquired\ninfections. In: Murray PR, Baron EJ, Jorgensen JH, et al, editors.\nManual of Clinical Microbiology. Washington, D.C.: ASM PRESS; 2003, pg.109-120.\n3. Pappas G, Papadimitriou P, Akritidis N, Christou L, Tsianos EV:\nThe new global map of human brucellosis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2006;6: 91-99.\n4. Turkmani A, Ioannidis A, Christidou A, et al: In vitro\nsusceptibilities of _Brucella melitensis_ isolates to eleven\nantibiotics. Ann Clin Microbiol Antimicrob. 2006;5: 24.\n5. Zerva L, Bourantas K, Mitka S, Kansouzidou A, Legakis NJ: Serum\nis the preferred clinical specimen for diagnosis of human brucellosis\nby PCR. J Clin Microbiol 2001; 39: 1661-1664.\n6. European Commission 2002: Final report of a mission carried out\nin Greece from 23 to 27 September 2002. In order to evaluate the\nprogress of the bovine brucellosis eradication programme. DG(SANCO)/8629/2002.\n7. Vorou R, Mellou K, Dougas G, et al: Selection of zoonoses of\npriority in the Episouth Countries. Available from:\n<http://www.episouth.org/outputs/wp8/WP8Report_Public_area_FINALE_REV_9-4-08.pdf>\n\n[Byline: Vorou R, Gkolfinopoulou K, Dougas G, et al.\nHellenic Center for Disease Control and Prevention,\nMinistry of Health and Social Solidarity,\nAthens, Greece]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is considered a Category B bioterrorism agent, which is,\nin nature, acquired as a zoonotic infection by humans. Its\nmanifestations are protean, including undulant fever, with positive\nblood and/or bone marrow cultures, and it is a cause of localized\ndisease in many organ systems including skeletal, urinary tract,\ncentral nervous system, liver, heart, and lung. With a caprine and\novine source, the organism here is probably _B. meletensis_.\n\nThe location of Thassos in the northern aspect of the Aegean Sea can\nbe found on a map at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/greece.pdf>. - Mod.LL]\n\n[_B. melitensis_ is maintained mainly within small ruminants (sheep\nand goats), though cases in cattle and buffaloes may occur sporadically.\n\nEfforts to eradicate _B. melitensis_ from the European countries\naffected (Portugal, Spain, France, Italy, and Greece) have been under\nway -- with EU support -- for a long period; though total eradication\nhas not been achieved yet, advances in three of them have been\nencouraging. The continued, significant animal infection in Greece is\na cause for concern.\n\nAccording to the reports of Greece to the OIE, 171 outbreaks of\nB.melitensis in sheep and goats have been recorded during 2006 and 54\nduring 2007. The above described outbreak in humans is a cause for\nconcern regarding the rate of eradication achieved; moreover, it is\nindicative of surveillance deficiencies.\n\nEU's Food and Veterinary Office Programme of Audits and Inspections\nfor 2008 includes a planned inspection of the Greek system, covering\nalso its Tuberculosis and Brucellosis Eradication Control . A\nsimilar inspection is planned for Portugal. Reports will be awaited\nwith interest.- Mod. The\ndata indicate that the disease mainly affects rural areas of the\nmainland, all cases either engaged in a high-risk occupation\n(shepherds, workers in animal husbandry, vets) or sharing\nunpasteurized milk or dairy products with friends and relatives (3-5). Human\nbrucellosis represents a professional hazard, being acquired via\ningestion, inhalation in laboratories or abattoirs, conjunctiva and\nskin trauma contamination with infected animal tissues and products\n(1,2). Its\nmanifestations are protean, including undulant fever, with positive\nblood and/or bone marrow cultures, and it is a cause of localized\ndisease in many organ systems including skeletal, urinary tract,\ncentral nervous system, liver, heart, and lung. The HPH\nand VPH authorities (7) at the central and local levels have a close\ncollaboration and integration, aiming at the target of eradicating\nthe disease which, judging by both reported cases and comments from\nleading hospitals? The majority of islands, including Thassos of Kavala mainland\nPrefecture, are free from human cases and herds are considered\nbrucellosis-free, with serology conducted sporadically that prove\nthis. All cases reported tested positive for brucellosis (Standard\nAgglutination Test), except for 1 patient who met the clinical and\nepidemiological criteria while the laboratory result was pending when\nreported. Currently, the slaughter of seropositive animals and vaccination has\nbeen applied to all herds of the island, which is the control program\nalready operating across mainland Greece (6), and this will continue\nuntil the island is again free of brucellosis. A total of 50 cases and 5\ncases were permanent residents of Thassos and Kavala respectively,\nthe age ranging from 8 to 88 years old, with a median of 46 years,\nsparing only 0-4 years old Source: Eurosurveillance, Volume 13, Issue 25 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18910>\n\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis resulting in reproductive failure in wild\nand domestic animals and febrile disease and occasionally severe\ninfections of the central nervous system and endocarditis in humans. The HPH officials, being aware of the local habit,\ndistributed advice to all health authorities, and to all residents,\ndoor to door, suggesting the destruction of any improperly processed\nmilk products in households. \n\nEfforts to eradicate _B. melitensis_ from the European countries\naffected (Portugal, Spain, France, Italy, and Greece) have been under\nway -- with EU support -- for a long period; though total eradication\nhas not been achieved yet, Hellenic Center for Disease Control and Prevention,\nMinistry of Health and Social Solidarity,\nAthens, Greece]\n\n--\n During the summer months,\nthe Ministry of Health and Social Solidarity (MHSS) reinforces more\nfrequent inspections for the prevention of all foodborne diseases,\nincluding brucellosis. In animals and humans alike, it is found worldwide, including\nsoutheastern Europe, the Mediterranean basin (Portugal, Spain,\nsouthern France, Italy, Greece, Turkey, northern Africa), parts of\nMexico, Central and Latin America, Asia, and Africa (1). A spontaneous\nsharing of all data has been established across the country among\nlocal HPH, VPH authorities, HCDCP, and the General Veterinary\nDirectorate, MRDF. The Ministry of Rural Development and Food (MRDF), regularly\nprovides these results to the Hellenic Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention (HCDCP) and the MHSS, both of which it collaborates with\nclosely. As of 17 Jun 2008, 55 human cases have\nbeen reported: 53 had consumed unpasteurized milk and/or dairy\nproducts (Figure 1 [for figures, see original URL - Mod. \n\nEU's Food and Veterinary Office Programme of Audits and Inspections\nfor 2008 includes a planned inspection of the Greek system, covering\nalso its Tuberculosis and Brucellosis Eradication Control . 8 were asymptomatic while testing positive, 6 of whom\nreported consumption of non-pasteurized milk/dairy products, and 2\nreported their husbands' illness and high-risk profession. On the other\nhand, in mainland Greece the brucellosis control program includes\nvaccination of herds and regular testing for brucellosis. \n\nThere is a widespread custom among local residents of Thassos of\nconsuming unpasteurized milk and its products around Easter-time in\ntheir households. \n\nCoordinated HPH and VPH inspections in all restaurants, groceries,\nhotels, and other settings proved that only licensed products were\ncirculated in the market. The annual incidence rate shows\na decreasing tendency: 5 in 2000, 3.7 in 2001, 3 in 2002, 2.2 in\n2003, 2.1 in 2004, 3.1 in 2005, 2.6 in 2006, and 1.38 in 2007. If indicated, the\nherd immediately undergoes all measures indicated by the brucellosis\neradication and control programme operating in Greece. LL]): 8 had a\nhigh-risk profession (6 herd owners and 2 butchers), and 9 had had\nsystematic contact with sheep and/or goats. Soon after the 1st human case was notified early in May 2008 in\nThassos, the above spontaneous usual procedures resulted in positive\nherd serologies. In\naddition, the public health measures applied after this local\noutbreak ensure that there is no future risk for tourists visiting the island. Conclusions\n-----------\nBrucellosis is a disease of public health priority in Greece. According to the\ninformation we have on this outbreak at the time of writing, it is\nunlikely that any tourists were exposed to brucellosis on Thassos. 'The case is not exceptional and the situation\nis under control; no room for hysteria and panic,' said the Odintsovo\nDistrict's chief veterinary officer, Vladimir Motoshin, in an interview.\n\nAs explained by Motoshin, in December 2007, a farmer introduced 100 sheep\nfrom the Volgograd region without the prescribed permits and in violation\nof all veterinary rules.\n\nOn 29 Feb 2008, the Odintsovo veterinary office was informed on the strange\nbehavior [see commentary] of animals on the Kozlov farm. The Head district\nveterinarian visited the site on the same day and issued an official order\nto put the farm and the village Solmanovo under quarantine.\n\nA police post was established on the location. Out of 82 tested animals, 25\nwere found brucellosis positive. Prior to the established diagnosis, 18\nsheep were gone. The owner said that they had been consumed by the family,\nstating that they were not sold in Moscow.\n\nCurrently, the Kozlov family members and all neighbors are being examined.\nThe Prosecutor's office has been informed about the case, since the farmer\nhad managed to transport animals across nearly half of Russia without\nproper documentations. passing through tens of police posts. As the farmer\nexplains, he successfully offered bribes in every road post.\n\nAfter the final analysis, the unaffected sheep will be sent to an abattoir\nand slaughtered for meat, while the infected sheep sent to a rendering plant.\n\nVladimir Mitoshin underlined once more that there is no danger to animals\nor humans as of today.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It may be assumed that the sheep, originating in the Volgograd region\n(about 1000 km south of Moscow; map at\n<http://www.geographicguide.net/europe/maps-europe/maps/russia-map.jpg>)\nwere found (or suspected?) to be infected by _Brucella melitensis_, a\nzoonotic bacterium known to be endemic in the southern parts of Russia. The\nevent illustrates the complexity of controlling animal diseases in the huge\nRussian territory.\n\nThe reported 'strange behavior' of the sheep on the farm needs\nclarification. The only clinical manifestation of brucellosis in sheep is\nabortion; could this be the meaning of 'strange behavior'?! The control of\n_B. melitensis_ can be carried out, on top of quarantine measures, by the\n'test and slaughter' policy, or by preventive vaccination, which should be\ncombined with animal identification. For the procedures and biologicals\napplied, refer to chapter CHAPTER 2.4.2. in OIE's Manual of Diagnostic\nTests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, available at\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/A_00069.htm>. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 12 Mar 2008\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It may be assumed that the sheep, originating in the Volgograd region\n(about 1000 km south of Moscow; map at\n<http://www.geographicguide.net/europe/maps-europe/maps/russia-map.jpg>)\nwere found (or suspected?) to be infected by _Brucella melitensis_, a\nzoonotic bacterium known to be endemic in the southern parts of Russia. The\ndisease can cause cows to abort, deliver weak calves, or produce less milk.\nCattle brucellosis is a zoonotic disease (can be spread from animals to\nman) that caused significant human disease incidence until the eradication\nprogram reduced the incidence of the disease in cattle, and, sanitary\npractices and pasteurization procedures for milk were implemented to reduce\ntransmission to humans. All other states in the United States are\nclassified brucellosis-free, some for more than 25 years.\n\n'Texas was the last state to achieve the 'free' status. We have more herds\nand more cattle than any other state -- 14 million at last count. We also\nhad more brucellosis infection to fight. In 1959, when Texas officially\njoined the national eradication program, we had more than 20 000 of the\ncountry's 100 000 infected herds,' said Dr Bob Hillman, Texas' state\nveterinarian and head of the Texas Animal Health Commission (TAHC), the\nstate's livestock and poultry health regulatory agency. 'This victory for\nthe cattle industry did not come easily or without hardship,' said Dr\nHillman. 'For many cattle producers in the early days of the program, it\nmeant losing a herd with only salvage value payment, or having the herd\nunder quarantine and being unable to sell animals for long periods of time.\nSome producers' herds became re-infected. In recent years, infected herds\nwere purchased from owners and depopulated whenever possible, to quickly\nwipe out infection.'\n\nDr Hillman credited the 2006 Brucellosis Eradication Working Group with\nre-evaluating all aspects of the Texas brucellosis program, in preparation\nfor the USDA review, which was conducted in summer 2007. The group was\ncomprised of about 25 cattle industry members. 'I also want to thank TAHC\nand USDA staff for their long days of testing cattle, consulting with\nproducers, keeping detailed test records, and handling tense situations\nwhen herds had to be quarantined. The efforts by the industry, the TAHC and\nUSDA have brought us to a great place -- disease eradication.\n\n'Now we must ensure that the disease is not reintroduced, or if it is\nlingering undetected, we must find the infection and eradicate it quickly.\nIf 2 infected herds are detected within the next 2 years, we could lose\nthis hard-earned, well-deserved status, so we must do everything to protect\nthe health of our herds,' said Dr Hillman.\n\n'To this end, we must continue testing our cattle at the first-point of\nconcentration and change of ownership for the next couple of years,' said\nDr Hillman. 'This procedure is part of the national brucellosis program\nstandard and was included in the program as a means of assuring that states\nthat have just acquired free-status could identify infected herds should\nthe disease have been left undetected in a herd or is re-introduced into a\nstate. Additionally, brucellosis slaughter surveillance will continue for\nmany years to come to assure that the disease is completely eradicated from\ncattle herds in Texas and other states of the United States.'\n\n'Decades of hard work are now paying off with this incredible\naccomplishment. I commend the cattle industry of the state and the Texas\nAnimal Health Commission for working together to establish Texas as cattle\nbrucellosis-free,' Texas agriculture commissioner Todd Staples said.\n\n'Texas ranks first in the nation in the number of cattle and calves and the\nindustry is a USD 16 billion business for the Texas economy. This new\nstatus will positively improve the industry and help our dedicated cattle\nproducers,' commissioner Staples said.\n\n'Hearing the words 'cattle brucellosis-free' is music to the industry's\nears,' said Mr Ernie Morales, chairman of the Texas Animal Health\nCommission (TAHC). 'While in the short term we will have to continue\ntesting our cattle, there is a tremendous benefit for cattle producers to\nbe able to market their cattle as cattle from a brucellosis-free state.\nThis status designation will provide cattle producers and trading partners\nadditional assurance that Texas cattle do not pose a disease risk.'\n\n'This tremendous achievement could not have been accomplished without the\ncombined efforts of state and federal agencies and industry,' said Bruce\nKnight, under secretary for USDA's marketing and regulatory programs\nmission area. The interim rule declaring Texas as brucellosis free was\npublished in the 1 Feb 2008 Federal Register and became effective upon\npublication.\n\n'We must now focus our efforts on eradicating brucellosis from the\nfree-ranging elk and bison populations in the Greater Yellowstone Area in\norder to protect our national cattle herd against future outbreaks of this\ndisease,' said Under Secretary Knight. He said the presence of brucellosis\nin free-ranging bison and elk in Yellowstone National Park and Grand Teton\nNational Park still threatens cattle health in surrounding states.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nCarla Everett\n<ceverett@tahc.state.tx.us>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 1 Feb 2008\nSource: North Texas e-News [edited]\n<http://www.ntxe-news.com/artman/publish/article_43544.shtml>\n\n\nAgriculture Commissioner Todd Staples has received notice from the US\nDepartment of Agriculture that Texas has been declared brucellosis-free.\nThis news means for the first time in the 74-year history of the\nbrucellosis program, all 50 states, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands\nhave simultaneously achieved Class Free status.\n\n'Today is a landmark day for the nation's number one cattle state. Decades\nof hard work are now paying off with this incredible accomplishment. I\ncommend the Texas cattle industry and the Texas Animal Health Commission\nfor working together to establish Texas as brucellosis-free,' commissioner\nStaples said.\n\nFor nearly 5 decades, Texas cattle producers have battled brucellosis, a\nbacterial disease that poses no threat to food safety, but can cause\ndecreased milk production, weight loss, infertility, loss of young, and\nlameness in cattle. There is no known treatment for brucellosis, and\ndepopulation of infected and exposed animals is the only effective means of\ndisease containment and eradication.\n\nThere are 14 million head of cattle in Texas, more than half of the state's\npeople population and cattle production is the number one agriculture\ncommodity in Texas in terms of cash receipts. Bottom line, the cattle\nindustry is big business in Texas.\n\n'The Texas cattle industry is a USD 16 billion business for the Texas\neconomy. This new brucellosis-free status will positively improve the\nindustry and help our dedicated cattle producers,' commissioner Staples said.\n\nThis is historic news but the work is not over. Brucellosis-free status is\nbased on a state finding no known brucellosis in cattle for 12 months. A\nstate's status can change if brucellosis is found in more than one herd of\ncattle in a brucellosis-free state within a 2-year period.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a major accomplishment for Texas. The Italian government has set up an emergency commission to\ntry and stop the spread of the disease, which affects milk production.\n\nThe plains of Campania, around Naples, are home to large buffalo\nherds. As much as 30 percent of the herd which live in the shadow of\nMount Vesuvius are reported to be infected. The area is the exalted\nhome of mozzarella di bufala: not only an essential part of the\nItalian diet, but one of Italy's most important exports.\n\nBut the Neapolitan farmers who make this famous milky cheese are\nfacing a crisis. In the next 2 months, the Italian government will\nstart the slaughter of 32 000 buffalo, infected with Brucellosis -- a\ncontagious bacterial disease that in livestock leads to abortion,\ninfertility and reduced milk production.\n\nIt can be transmitted through food to humans, causing severe\nintermittent fever -- though the milk which produces the cheese is\nperfectly safe when it is pasteurised.\n\nBrucellosis has been present in the herd for 10 years. But the\nItalian papers say the local vets who are supposed to test and put\ndown infected animals have been intimidated by the local mafia -- the\nCamorra -- who also control some of the farms. Consequently, it is\nreported, the disease has been allowed to spread to almost 30 percent\nof the herd.\n\nCaserta, one of 2 key mozzarella-producing areas, is the worst\naffected. In the coming weeks, armed police will accompany government\nvets to help with the cull. They say every infected animal destroyed\nwill be burnt -- and it is estimated the cost to the Italian\ngovernment will be 66m euros (USD 97m; BP 49m).\n\n[Byline: Christian Fraser]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis, a disease affecting mainly cattle and buffaloes,\nis a highly contagious disease caused by _Brucella abortus_. Its\ndominant feature is late-term abortion and infertility in cattle. The\ndisease is also a serious zoonosis, causing undulant fever in humans.\n_B. abortus_ is transmitted to humans mainly in the following 2\nroutes: by direct contact with affected animals or their\npost-partum/post-abortion secretions, or by the ingestion of\ncontaminated, unpasteurised food products, mainly dairy products.\n\nBrucellosis is an OIE and EU listed, notifiable disease. In Italy,\nthe following control measures are officially applied: screening,\nsurveillance, movement control, zoning and stamping out. Vaccination\nis prohibited.\n\nAccording to the most recent (2006) available data on the OIE WAHID\ninterface, the number of new Italian outbreaks during 2006 was, for\nthe whole country, 3357 -- of which 387 were in Campania. The other\naffected regions were Abruzzo, Basilicata, Calabria, Lazio, Molise,\nPuglia, Sicilia, Valle D'aosta and Marche.\n\nCattle and buffaloes can also be infected by _B. melitensis_, a\nbacterium mainly infecting goats and sheep and the causative agent of\nMalta Fever in humans. It is probable that cross infection into\nbovines occur in Italy as well, since _B. melitensis_ is endemic in\nthe south of the country: during 2006, 4374 new outbreaks were\nreported from the 5 heaviest infected regions, of which 383 were in\nCampania. The other regions were Basilicata (61), Calabria (663),\nPuglia ( 372) and Sicilia (2895).\n\nThe requirement to destroy infected animals while refraining from\nvaccination is prescribed by EU regulations. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jan 2008\n \n_B. abortus_ is transmitted to humans mainly in the following 2\nroutes: by direct contact with affected animals or their\npost-partum/post-abortion secretions, or by the ingestion of\ncontaminated, unpasteurised food products, mainly dairy products. A decision was made to\ncull ill animals.\nThe spokesman for the State Veterinary Service at the Azerbaijan\nAgriculture Ministry, Yolchu Khanveli, told the APA that importation of\nbeef from Georgia to Azerbaijan is not expected to be banned. Khanveli said\nthat brucellosis has also been observed among cattle in Azerbaijan and\nemphasised that, if beef is imported from any country, it is put under\nquarantine for 40 days and examined. If any disease is revealed,\nimportation of beef will be banned.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[The manifestations of the disease in the human cases here are not stated\nnor is the species of brucella involved. These bacteria are primarily passed among animals and\ncause them to miscarry.\nHumans become infected by coming into contact with animals or animal\nproducts that are contaminated with these bacteria. In humans,\nbrucellosis can cause a range of symptoms that are similar to the flu\nand may include fever, sweats, headaches, back pains, and physical\nweakness. Severe infections of the central nervous system or lining\nof the heart may occur. Brucellosis can also cause long-lasting or\nchronic symptoms that include recurrent fevers, joint pain, and fatigue.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is not 'the 1st time in 60 years that an outbreak of the\ndangerous disease was detected in Bulgaria.' On 12 Jun 2006, the\nBulgarian authorities officially reported to the OIE an outbreak of\nbrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_) in goats in the village Smoljan,\nprovince Zlatograd, southern Bulgaria. The reason for notification\nwas 'reoccurrence of a listed disease;' the given date of previous\noccurrence was 1941. All 4 'susceptible and infected' goats were\ndestroyed. The source of infection was, reportedly, 'contact with\ninfected animal(s) at grazing/watering;' this may point at the\npossible presence of infection in additional animals in Bulgaria. For\nthe official immediate notification, including map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=5406>.\nDuring 2007, 2 additional outbreaks in animals have been recorded in\nsouthern Bulgaria, one in August in the village of Valche pole, the\n2nd one (probably in contact with the previous one), in September, in\nHarmanli, where -- according to a published statement of the\nveterinary services -- 36 goats out of a herd of 70 had tested\npositive for the infection. This high infection rate may indicate\nthat the introduction of the pathogen had taken place several months\nearlier. The current newswire reports the destruction of the entire flock.\nThe outbreak in Valche pole was discovered following a clinical case\nof brucellosis ('Malta fever') in a woman; the media reported that 'a\nnational veterinary service statement said 19 animals had been\ninfected in the village of Valche pole, where the 65-year-old woman\nfell ill with the disease.'\nThe current newswire says that the infection (apparently in Valche\npole) came from goats stolen from a Greek village and illegally\ntransported to Bulgaria. No date of introduction (which may have\noccurred a considerable time prior to disease detection) nor results\nof serological tests in local, in-contact livestock are disclosed.\nThe role of humans as sentinels for animal infection is cause for\nconcern; the disease may have gained ground since its reoccurrence in\nBulgaria, officially reported in 2006.\nThe Bulgarian authorities may contemplate a systematic serological\nsurveillance in small ruminants to assess the real situation within\nits southern territories and, in case disease has already gained some\nground, to consider a 'test and slaughter' policy while this is still\nfeasible, namely during the initial phase of the outbreak and before\nit spreads to northern territories. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "The Bulgarian authorities may contemplate a systematic serological\nsurveillance in small ruminants to assess the real situation within\nits southern territories and, in case disease has already gained some\nground, to consider a 'test and slaughter' policy while this is still\nfeasible, namely during the initial phase of the outbreak and before\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The outbreak in Valche pole was discovered following a clinical case\nof brucellosis ('Malta fever') in a woman; the media reported that 'a\nnational veterinary service statement said 19 animals had been\ninfected in the village of Valche pole, where the 65-year-old woman\nfell ill with the disease.' This high infection rate may indicate\nthat the introduction of the pathogen had taken place several months\nearlier.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-24 00:00:00", "1941-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2006-06-12 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-08-24 00:00:00", "2007-08-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Valche", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Harmanly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zlatograd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smoljan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209666", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, animals - China", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209666", "date": "2007-12-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, ANIMALS - CHINA\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 5 Dec 2007\nSource: Shuangyashan News [trans.DS, edited]\n<http://shuangyashan.northeast.cn/system/2007/12/05/051073992.shtml>\n\nThe Ministry of Health said on 4 Dec 2007 that human brucellosis\ncontinues to increase in China and case numbers in Heilongjiang are\nparticularly high. The Ministry of Health has asked all locales to\nstrengthen prevention work.\nStatistics from the Ministry of Health show that China's prevention\nand control of human brucellosis is in serious circumstances, and\noccurrence in cow and sheep producing regions is a grave [concern]. A\ntrend has emerged in which the disease is spreading from herding and\nsemi-herding regions to farming regions and even urban areas. Other\nthan Chongqing, Guizhou, and Hainan, all provinces and\ncentrally-administered municipalities have reported human\nbrucellosis. The top 10 provinces and autonomous regions by number of\ncases are Inner Mongolia, Heilongjiang, Shanxi, Hebei, Shaanxi,\nJilin, Liaoning, Xinjiang, Henan, and Shandong, which together\naccount for 98.15 percent of reported cases nationally. By the end of\nSeptember 2007, there were a total of 18 116 brucellosis cases in\n2007 nationally, an increase of 2.6 percent over 2006's 17 644 cases.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Dan Silver\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Brucellosis is considered to be a Category B bioterrorism agent\nwhich is, in nature, acquired as a zoonotic infection by humans. Its\nmanifestations are protean, including undulant fever, with positive\nblood and/or bone marrow cultures, and it is a cause of localized\ndisease in many organ systems including skeletal, urinary tract,\ncentral nervous system, liver, cardiac and lung. The reader is\nreferred to Young EJ. Human brucellosis. Rev Infect Dis 1983; 5:\n821-39 for a review of these manifestations.\nThe following is part of a narrative from ProMED-mail 'Brucellosis -\nChina 20041222.3371' written by Mod.AS:\n'A detailed review, 'Epidemiology and control of brucellosis in\nChina,' was published in December 2002 by Shang Deqiu, Xiao Donglou\nand Yin Jiming (Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology, Chinese\nAcademy of Preventive Medicine, Beijing) in Veterinary Microbiology\n90, 1-4, pp 165-182. Based on the analysis of 3425 _Brucella_ strains\nisolated from humans and animals in 21 provinces, the data revealed\n73.79 per cent infected with _B. melitensis_, 13.64 per cent infected\nwith _B. abortus_, 5.78 per cent infected with _B. suis_, 0.05 per\ncent infected with _B. ovis_ (which is generally not regarded as\nzoonotic!), and 6.70 per cent infected with atypical _Brucella_\nstrains. For the entire country, _B. melitensis_ was the predominant\nstrain associated with outbreaks, but there were some differences\nfrom province to province, for example _B. suis_ in Guangxi and _B.\nabortus_ in Sichuan were the predominant strains isolated. In most of\nthe epidemics, the predominant strain was _B. melitensis_, with\neither _B. abortus_ and/or _B. suis_.'\nA map of China showing the provinces can be found at\n<http://www.travel.com.hk/map/newmap/engmap/web/china.gif>.\nHeilongjiang province is found in the extreme northeastern part of\nthe country. - Mod.LL]\n[Brucellosis in man is acquired in 2 ways: occupational disease,\naffecting mainly those in direct contact with infected animals\n(particularly during parturition or following abortions), and the\nfood-borne disease route, affecting consumers of unpasteurised milk\nand dairy products originating from infected animals. While in\nherding, semi-herding and animal-farming regions, both routes\nprevail, in urban regions the predominant route of infection is the\nfood-borne one. The latter can be reduced or prevented by proper\npasteurisation of the (cow, sheep and goat) milk. Preventing\nbrucellosis in rural population requires controlling, preferably\neradicating the disease in the animal populations involved, applied\non a regional or rather national levels. Brucellosis control\nprogrammes are costly, laborious and of long duration; they require\nthe full cooperation of the animal breeders, and usually would\ninclude 2 main activities: test-and-slaughter, and/or vaccinations.\nThere are several kinds of brucellosis animal vaccines, targetting\nthe different species. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Based on the analysis of 3425 _Brucella_ strains\nisolated from humans and animals in 21 provinces, the data revealed\n73.79 per cent infected with _B. melitensis_, 13.64 per cent infected\nwith _B. abortus_, 5.78 per cent infected with _B. suis_, 0.05 per\ncent infected with _B. ovis_ (which is generally not regarded as\nzoonotic!), and 6.70 per cent infected with atypical _Brucella_\nstrains. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Brucellosis in man is acquired in 2 ways: occupational disease,\naffecting mainly those in direct contact with infected animals\n(particularly during parturition or following abortions), and the\nfood-borne disease route, affecting consumers of unpasteurised milk\nand dairy products originating from infected animals. Its\nmanifestations are protean, including undulant fever, with positive\nblood and/or bone marrow cultures, and it is a cause of localized\ndisease in many organ systems including skeletal, urinary tract,\ncentral nervous system, liver, cardiac and lung. AS:\n'A detailed review, 'Epidemiology and control of brucellosis in\nChina,' was published in December 2002 by Shang Deqiu, Xiao Donglou\nand Yin Jiming (Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology, Chinese\n While in\nherding, semi-herding and animal-farming regions, both routes\nprevail, in urban regions the predominant route of infection is the\nfood-borne one. By the end of\nSeptember 2007, there were a total of 18 116 brucellosis cases in\n2007 nationally, an increase of 2.6 percent over 2006's 17 644 cases.\n For the entire country, _B. melitensis_ was the predominant\nstrain associated with outbreaks, but there were some differences\nfrom province to province, for example _B. suis_ in Guangxi and _B.\nabortus_ in Sichuan were the predominant strains isolated. Brucellosis control\nprogrammes are costly, laborious and of long duration; they require\nthe full cooperation of the animal breeders, and usually would\ninclude 2 main activities: test-and-slaughter, and/or vaccinations. The top 10 provinces and autonomous regions by number of\ncases are Inner Mongolia, Heilongjiang, Shanxi, Hebei, Shaanxi,\nJilin, Liaoning, Xinjiang, Henan, and Shandong, which together\naccount for 98.15 percent of reported cases nationally. Preventing\nbrucellosis in rural population requires controlling, preferably\neradicating the disease in the animal populations involved, applied\non a regional or rather national levels.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-09-24 00:00:00", "2006-03-24 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2002-12-24 00:00:00", "1983-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2007-12-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Shanxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liaoning", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sichuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Henan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Heilongjiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chongqing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hebei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hainan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shaanxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jilin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Xinjiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guizhou", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "50025", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, lab workers, 2006 - USA: (IN, MN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=50025", "date": "2008-01-17 19:00:14", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, LAB WORKERS, 2006 - USA: (INDIANA, MINNESOTA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jan 2008\nSource: Morbid Mortal Week Rep 2008;57: 39-42 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5702a3.htm>\n\n\nLaboratory-acquired brucellosis - Indiana and Minnesota, 2006\n-----------------------------------------------\nIn November 2006, 2 cases of brucellosis in microbiologists at 2\nclinical laboratories were reported to state health departments in\nIndiana and Minnesota. The Minnesota Department of Health (MDH)\ncontacted CDC regarding this suspected multistate cluster of\nlaboratory-acquired brucellosis. MDH and the Indiana State Department\nof Health (ISDH) asked CDC to conduct further testing on _Brucella_\nisolates suspected of causing the infections and to provide\nrecommendations for appropriate response by the laboratories. This\nreport summarizes the investigation conducted jointly by MDH, ISDH,\nand CDC, provides guidance on safe laboratory handling of _Brucella\nspp._, and makes recommendations for responding to _Brucella_\nlaboratory exposures. The results of that investigation determined\nthat 146 workers at the 2 laboratories had been exposed to and that,\nalthough 2 _Brucella_ isolates had been handled by both laboratories,\ninfections in the 2 microbiologists were caused by 2 unrelated\nisolates. Because _Brucella spp._ pose a risk for aerosol-transmitted\ninfection, CDC recommended risk assessment for all Brucella-exposed\nlaboratory workers, postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for those at high\nrisk, surveillance for symptoms of disease, and serologic follow-up\nwith workers. The events in Indiana and Minnesota emphasize the\nimportance of adhering to recommended biosafety practices, timely\nsharing of information regarding laboratory exposures, and rapid\nimplementation of response protocols.\n\nCase Reports\n-------------\nIndiana: On 28 Sep 2006, a microbiologist aged 47 years\n(microbiologist A) who worked at a clinical laboratory had onset of\nhigh fever, sweating, malaise, anorexia, headache, and hip pain.\nInitially, her symptoms were not severe; she did not seek medical\ntreatment until 3 weeks later, after her symptoms had progressively\nworsened. The microbiologist was hospitalized on 22 Oct 2006 and\nrecovered fully with treatment. On 26 Oct 2006, an unidentified blood\nculture isolate from microbiologist A (isolate A) was submitted for\nidentification to a Minnesota clinical laboratory and determined to\nbe _Brucella spp._; both MDH and IDSH were notified of the finding.\nEpidemiologic investigation later revealed that, on 17 Jul 2006,\nmicrobiologist A had subcultured on an open laboratory bench an\nunidentified isolate (isolate C) from a referring laboratory. Isolate\nC subsequently was forwarded for identification to the same Minnesota\nclinical laboratory and identified as _Brucella spp_.\n\nMinnesota: On 25 Oct 2006, a microbiologist aged 61 years\n(microbiologist B), who worked at the same Minnesota clinical\nlaboratory that received microbiologist A's isolate, had onset of\nlow-grade fever, fatigue, and night sweats. She was hospitalized and\nrecovered with treatment. On 9 Nov 2006, the Minnesota laboratory\nidentified a blood culture isolate from microbiologist B (isolate B)\nas _Brucella spp._ and notified MDH. The subsequent investigation\ndetermined that microbiologist B had not handled isolate A from\nmicrobiologist A. However, previously she had handled on an open\nbench 2 unidentified isolates subsequently identified as _Brucella\nspp_. Her 1st exposure had occurred on 21 Jul 2006 while she was\nhandling isolate C, which had been forwarded from the Indiana\nclinical laboratory. The 2nd exposure had occurred on 8 Aug 2006\nduring testing of an isolate from a Texas referring clinical\nlaboratory (isolate D).\n\nInvestigation and Response\n--------------------------\nThe investigation revealed that all potentially implicated specimens\nor isolates had been manipulated on an open bench, the routine\npractice for handling unidentified isolates in these laboratories. No\nspills or aerosol-generating procedures had occurred. Neither\nlaboratory had formal protocols for 1) notification and follow-up of\nstaff members who worked with isolates identified as _Brucella spp._\nor 2) notification of laboratories that forwarded isolates later\nidentified as _Brucella spp_.\n\nBrucella-exposed workers (any person present in the microbiology\nlaboratory from the time the culture was first manipulated until all\nculture isolates were destroyed or removed from the laboratory) from\neach laboratory were identified, and their exposures were classified\nas either high risk or low risk.\n\nA high-risk exposure was defined as 1) having direct personal\nexposure (e.g., sniffing bacteriologic cultures; direct skin contact;\npipetting by mouth; inoculation; or spraying into the eyes, nose, or\nmouth), 2) performing work on an open bench (i.e., outside of\nbiosafety level 3 containment equipment) with an open culture plate\ncontaining a _Brucella_ isolate or being in close proximity to such\nwork (e.g., across an open bench top or within 5 feet), or 3)\npresence in the laboratory during any procedure conducted on a\n_Brucella_ isolate that might result in generation of aerosolized\norganisms and inhalational exposure (e.g., vortexing or catalase\ntesting). A low-risk exposure was defined as being present in the\nlaboratory during an exposure but not meeting the definition for a\nhigh-risk exposure.\n\nIn Indiana, 105 staff members were exposed; 15 of those exposures\nwere classified as high risk, including the exposure of\nmicrobiologist A. In Minnesota, 41 staff members were exposed; 13 of\nthose exposures were classified as high risk, including the exposure\nof microbiologist B. All staff members classified with high-risk\nexposure, other than the 2 microbiologists who received antimicrobial\ntherapy, were advised to receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).\n\nTo determine the source of the _Brucella_ infections, CDC compared\nblood culture isolates from the microbiologists with the isolates\nthey handled, using multiple-locus variable number tandem repeats\nanalysis at 21 genomic regions. All isolates were identified as\n_Brucella melitensis_ biovar 3. Matching of 16 genomic amplicons\nsuggested that isolate C was the source of infection for\nmicrobiologist A, the Indiana microbiologist. Matching of 17 genomic\namplicons suggested that isolate D was the source of infection for\nmicrobiologist B, the Minnesota microbiologist.\n\nSerial serum samples from the 105 exposed Indiana laboratory staff\nmembers, excluding microbiologist A, were tested at CDC for\nanti-_Brucella_ antibodies, using the Brucella microagglutination\ntest (BMAT); the Minnesota laboratory conducted voluntary serial BMAT\ntesting for 11 exposed laboratory staff members. No additional\ninfections were detected in either group.\n\n[Reported by: Griffith J, Sullivan M, Howell J, et al]\n\nEditorial Note\n--------------\nBrucellosis is a bacterial zoonotic infection usually caused by\n_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, or less commonly by\n_B. canis_. Humans usually are infected by occupational exposure to\ninfected animals, consumption of unpasteurized dairy products from\ninfected animals, or inhalation of infectious aerosols. The average\nincubation period for brucellosis is 2-10 weeks but ranges from a few\ndays to 6 months. Symptoms include intermittent fever, chills,\nmalaise, sweating, joint and lower back pain, headache, anorexia, and\nfatigue (1). Untreated brucellosis can last from several weeks to\nseveral years. Chronic untreated brucellosis can lead to abscesses in\nthe liver, spleen, heart valves, brain, or bone; osteoarticular\ncomplications; and, in rare cases, death. A definitive diagnosis\nrequires that bacteria be cultured from clinical specimens. A\npresumptive diagnosis requires demonstrating high or rising titers of\nspecific antibodies in the serum (1).\n\nSince 1986, fewer than 150 cases of brucellosis have been reported\nannually in the USA (2; CDC, unpublished data, 2007). However,\nbrucellosis is among the most commonly reported laboratory-acquired\nbacterial infections (3). In a review of laboratory-associated\ninfections during 1979-1999, _Brucella spp._ accounted for\napproximately 8 percent of all laboratory infections, 16 percent of\nbacterial infections, and 4 percent of deaths (4). Infections have\noccurred from sniffing culture plates, spilling blood-culture\nbottles, mucocutaneous exposure to sprays of organism-containing\nsuspensions, aerosol generation from ruptured centrifuge tubes, or\nroutine laboratory work with _Brucella_ cultures outside of\nbiological safety cabinets (5-9).\n\nBiosafety level 3 (BSL-3) practices, containment equipment, and\nfacilities are recommended for all manipulations of _Brucella_\ncultures (Box 1, for boxes, see original URL. - Mod.LL) (10). Because\nunidentified isolates are commonly manipulated on an open bench,\ninadvertent exposure can occur when _Brucella_ unexpectedly grows in\na culture. A formal notification and response protocol must be used\nafter identification of _Brucella spp_. Timely identification,\nnotification, and appropriate follow-up of potentially exposed\nworkers, in combination with worker training to maximize awareness\nand observance of appropriate safety practices, can prevent\nunnecessary illness and hospitalization from brucellosis. Exposures\ncan be minimized by clinicians and forwarding laboratories clearly\nidentifying specimens they suspect to be _Brucella_.\n\nOnce _Brucella_ has been identified (or is highly suspected),\nclinical laboratories should notify the state health department and\nsend the isolate to the state public health laboratory or nearest\nLaboratory Reference Network laboratory for confirmation and species\nidentification. When _Brucella_ is confirmed, the state public health\nlaboratory should notify all other laboratories that handled the\nspecimen, and exposure to workers should be assessed at the\nsubmitting laboratory and other laboratories involved.\n\nClassification of exposures as high risk or low risk by practitioners\nof occupational health, infection control, or public health\ndetermines PEP recommendations. PEP is recommended for persons with\nhigh-risk exposure (Box 2, for boxes, see original URL, but primarily\ndoxcycline and rifampin for 3 weeks. - Mod.LL). Serologic follow-up\nfor exposed persons using quantitative assays (e.g., BMAT) should be\nperformed at the time of exposure and at weeks 2, 4, 6, and 24 after\nexposure. Active, regular (e.g., weekly) surveillance for symptoms\nconsistent with brucellosis should be conducted for all exposed\nlaboratory workers for 6 months after exposure. PEP and monitoring\ndiffer for persons exposed to _B. abortus_ RB51, an attenuated\nveterinary vaccine strain that is less commonly associated with human\nillness, is rifampin resistant in vitro, and does not elicit a\nmeasurable serologic response using available tests. Laboratory\nworkers who might have been exposed to _Brucella_ and who have\nunexplained febrile illness consistent with brucellosis should be\nreferred to health-care providers for evaluation. Evaluation should\ninclude blood culture and anti-_Brucella_ antibody serologic testing,\nand treatment for brucellosis should be initiated when compatible\nillness is confirmed.\n\n_Brucella spp._ are dangerous infectious bacteria listed among CDC's\ncategory B bioterrorism agents. CDC and the Animal and Plant Health\nInspection Service (APHIS) regulate the transfer, possession, or use\nof such agents in the USA. New isolations, laboratory exposures, and\nother incidents associated with the intentional or unintentional\nrelease of _B. abortus_ (excluding RB51), _B. melitensis_, or _B.\nsuis_ must be reported as soon as possible to either CDC or APHIS.\nPersons seeking assistance in identifying _Brucella spp._ or\nserologic monitoring of exposed persons should contact their state\nhealth departments or the CDC Bacterial Zoonoses Branch at telephone,\n404-639-1711.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Young EJ: Brucella species. In: Mandell GL, Bennett JE, Dolin R,\neds. Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's Principles and practice of\ninfectious diseases. 6th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier Inc; 2005: 2669-74.\n2. CDC: Summary of notifiable diseases - United States, 2002. MMWR 2004;51(53).\n3. Pike RM: Laboratory-associated infections: summary and analysis of\n3921 cases. Health Lab Sci 1976;13: 105-14.\n4. Harding AL, Byers KB: Epidemiology of laboratory-associated\ninfections. In: Fleming DO, Hunt DL, eds. Biological safety:\nprinciples and practices. 3rd ed. Washington DC: ASM Press;2000: 35-56.\n5. Al-Aska AK, Chagla AH: Laboratory-acquired brucellosis. J Hosp\nInfect 1989;14: 69-71.\n6. Fiori PL, Mastrandrea S, Rappelli P, Cappuccinelli P: Brucella\nabortus infection acquired in microbiology laboratories. J Clin\nMicrobiol 2000;38: 2005--2006.\n7. The service said in a statement that 36 goats out of a\nherd of 70 had tested positive for the infection in the southern town\nof Harmanli.\nThe infection in Harmanli spread from a 1st outbreak in August 2007\nin the nearby village of Valche pole, where dozens of goats and sheep\nwere found to be infected after a woman fell ill with\nbrucellosis-like symptoms. Later, 3 other people also tested positive\nfor the disease, which is often difficult to diagnose as its initial\nsymptoms, which include weakness, fever, sweating, headaches, and\njoint pains, resemble influenza.\nHumans can contract brucellosis from contact with sick sheep and\ngoats or by consuming infected meat, milk, or cheese. The disease,\nwhich is very rare in Bulgaria, can be fatal for humans but cannot be\ntransferred from one person to another.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is not clearly stated whether the goatherd 'testing positive' was\nby bacteriologic or serologic means.\nBrucellosis is considered a Category B bioterrorism agent, which is,\nin nature, acquired as a zoonotic infection by humans. Recent outbreaks in Idaho and Wyoming\nhave cost livestock producers there millions of dollars. Montana is\nnow on probation for 2 years and will lose its brucellosis-free\nstatus if any further cases turn up during that time.
