BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA) (03)\n****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-05-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "16329", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, Q fever, lab workers - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=16329", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. 'Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,' he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n'We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,' he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. Then the rancher is\nleft with 2 choices; one is bad, the other awful.\nEarly Monday, Jim and Sandy Morgan, who had 7 cows from their ranch\nsouth of Bridger test positive for brucellosis in May 2007, picked\nthe bad choice.\nSandy Morgan and her mother, Connie Malcolm of Emigrant, stoically\nworked the corrals, helping 5 Montana Department of Livestock brand\ninspectors sort, herd and load the cows -- cattle from her\ngrandfather's genetic lines -- into double-decker cattle trucks to be\nhauled to slaughter in South Dakota.\n'It's devastating,' Sandy Morgan said. 'You're OK as long as you\npretend they're going to summer grass.'\nThe awful choice would have been for the Morgans to refuse the USD\n423 000 federal livestock officials offered for their nearly 600\ncows, bulls and calves. Then the entire state of Montana would lose\nits brucellosis-free status and producers would have to spend\nmillions to vaccinate and test cattle before shipping.\nBrucellosis causes domestic cows to abort their calves. It is also\nfound in elk and bison. The feds have an unbendable rule: Once\nbrucellosis is found in a herd, that herd must be slaughtered.\nActing State Veterinarian Jeanne Rankin said she is breathing freer\nfor now. 'It's a difficult decision, and nobody is happy,' Rankin\nsaid. 'We need to protect the 2.4 million cattle in Montana and the\nlivelihood of these other ranchers.'\nYet Montana remains under a brucellosis cloud. If one more cow tests\npositive in the next 2 years, the state will lose its brucellosis-free\nstatus.\nUnder the midday sun Monday [16 Jul 2007], the thermometer stuck at\n103 F outside; 6 cattle trucks were lined up to ship the 284 cows and\n16 bulls from Morgan's herd to Cimpl Packing in Yankton, South Dakota.\nThe 284 calves from the herd will be shipped today [17 Jul 2007]\nfrom the ranch to Modesto, California, where they will be made into\nveal. Rankin said the calves needed to go to another facility because\nthey weigh less and need different equipment at the packing plant than\nadult cattle. Starting at 7 am Monday [16 Jul 2007], the calves were\nweighed, and the numbered tag on each cow and bull was marked off on\nthe official federal list to make sure no animal was missing.\nBy 11 a.m., Sandy and Jim and the state officials were herding the\nconfused cows up the cattle chute into the trailer of the 1st truck.\nThe 1st 6 were cows that had tested positive for brucellosis, bearing\na big 'B' brand on the left side of their necks. The 7th positive cow\nwas euthanized in Iowa in May 2007. The rest of the herd tested\nnegative, but they may have been exposed to the highly contagious\ndisease.\nAfter crunching the numbers, the Morgans decided not to keep the\ncalves and fatten them for fall shipping. After the calves were\nweighed Monday [16 Jul 2007], Jim and his wife's father, Bruce\nMalcolm, watched an online video auction where similar weight calves\nwere selling for USD 1.45 a pound. The federal Animal and Plant Health\nInspection Service, a division of the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture, offered the Morgans 85 cents a pound. 'So\nwe're USD 56 000 short just on our calves,' he said.\nDr. Ray Randall of Bridger Veterinary Clinic said the Morgan's calves\nwouldn't have brought top price because they may have been exposed to\nbrucellosis. He said the Morgans may have a financial argument to\nmake, but the alternative of rejecting the buyout was unacceptable.\n'If other ranchers had had to go through all the testing, they would\nbe mad at the state and mad at the feds and mad at the Morgans,' he\nsaid. 'There'd be a lot of plain mad.'\nJim Morgan called Dr. Lennis Knight, an APHIS vet in Helena, Monday\n[16 Jul 2007] about the price difference on the calves, and he said\nKnight promised to try to help. Knight did not return telephone calls\nMonday [16 Jul 2007].\nRankin said it is the cattle industry's turn now. 'We appreciate the\nsacrifice of the Morgans and the Hergenriders, and we want the\nindustry to step up to the plate to restock their cattle, if\nnecessary,' she said. Karen Hergenrider of Belfry grazed some cattle\nwith the Morgan herd and also was bought out by APHIS.\nSince the Morgan herd was tested on 16 May 2007, the state has tested\nmore than 2700 head of cattle, mainly in the Bridger and Emigrant\nareas. Herds that contacted the Morgan cattle will be retested this\nfall.\n[Byline: Jan Falstad <jfalstad@billingsgazette.com>]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Montana in the western United States may be viewed at:\n<http://www.census.gov/geo/www/us_regdiv.pdf>.\nYellowstone National Park is located mostly in the state of Wyoming,\nbut also extends into Montana and Idaho.\nAlthough Montana has done the epidemiology of tracing for this herd,\nthe possible loss of their coveted free state status remains at risk\nfor the next 2 years. Assoc.Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.regnum.ru/news/840747.html>\n\nThe Ministry of emergency situations in the Dzhidinskiy district of\nthe republic of Buryatia is applying control measures following the\nidentification of ovine brucellosis.\nAccording to the directorate of Rosselhoznadzor [Federal Agency for\nVeterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance. - Assoc.Mod.NP], the 1st\ncase of infection in animals was been registered in April 2007.\nVictor Smolin, deputy head of the directorate of Rosselhoznadzor,\ninformed that 132 brucellosis seropositive sheep have been detected.\nNo human cases have been reported.\nThe infection affected 4 collective farms in the villages Gegetuj and\nMaliy Naryn. Over 1900 animals have been transported to a sanitary\nslaughterhouse at a meat packing plant. The sanitary processing\ncontinues today [8 June 2007]. Surveillance\nactivities are to be continued.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Buryatia (or the Buryat Republic), a member of the Russian\nFederation, is situated in SE Siberian Russia, north of Mongolia,\nextending between Lake Baikal and the Yablonovy mountains. Livestock\nraising is one of the main economic activities of the 1.1 million\nstrong multi-ethnic population. See map at\n<http://firntravel.ru/i/buryatia.1.gif>.\nMost probably, the causal disease agent is _Brucella melitensis_, the\nbacterium causing Malta fever (undulant fever) in humans. _B.\nmelitensis_ is prevalent in most Mediterranean countries where large\nnumbers of flocks of sheep and goats are infected, and also in\ndeveloping countries of Southwest Asia, central Asia, parts of Latin\nAmerica, and Africa, where it constitutes a serious human health\nhazard.\nControl of the disease needs an extended effort, combining the animal\nand public health authorities. 'Test and slaughter' method in small\nruminants may be applied but it is costly and difficult to perform if\ninfection is widespread. Most affected countries apply vaccinations\nof the susceptible animals, which should be combined with\nidentification of the vaccinated animals. Selective culling might be\napplied in tandem. The human infection rate may be reduced by the\npasteurization of dairy products and application of other prevention\nand hygienic measures, particularly among the rural population. If\nthe slaughter of infected animals is permitted or imposed, special\nmeasures should be taken to protect the personnel of the\nslaughterhouse.\nFor further reading and background, see\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/brucellosi-ov.html>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "_B.\nmelitensis_ is prevalent in most Mediterranean countries where large\nnumbers of flocks of sheep and goats are infected, and also in\ndeveloping countries of Southwest Asia, central Asia, parts of Latin\nAmerica, and Africa, where it constitutes a serious human health\nhazard. Some of the\nwoman's animals tested positive for a contagious animal disease last\nmonth [May 2007].\nNot far from cages upon cages of cooped-up canines, an old sign reads\n'Three Mountain Dog Rescue.' Hutton\nsays that's all baseless. 'They get the shots every year,' she said.\nSome people say it's a puppy mill. 'We do a little bit of breeding,\nbut no, it's not a puppy mill,' she said.\nThere is a quarantine filed by health officials. The order says 'no\nanimals' may enter or leave. Hutton claims the quarantine doesn't apply to horses.\n'Just the dogs are under the quarantine order,' she said. She says that way she can make sure the dogs and cats\ngo to responsible owners.\n[Byline: Paul Aker]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley\n[_Brucella canis_ is the bacterial organism that primarily causes\nbrucellosis in canines. It is a gram negative intracellular\nbacterium. Other species, _B. abortus_ and _B. suis_ have, on\noccasion, been known to infect canines.\nReproductive failure is the most prevalent clinical sign. Females may\nhave embryonic death and resorption about 20 days post mating or may\nhave abortions about 45-55 days of gestation. Consequently, the\ncomplaint is most often a failure to conceive. The male may share in\nthe cause of this apparent failure as well.\nMales may have epididymitis in one or both testes and/or infertility.\nTesticular atrophy and a moist scrotal dermatitis may be present. The\nsemen of infected males has a large number of abnormal sperm, or no\nsperm at all.\nLoss of libido, lethargy, and generalized lymph node enlargement may\nbe noticed in both genders. Premature aging has been noted in both\ngenders when infected.\nDiagnosis can be difficult. Culture from the blood, lymph nodes,\nmarrow, urine, milk, vaginal discharges or semen is the only\ndefinitive diagnosis.\nExperimentally, the organism was seen in 100 percent of the dogs at 2\nmonths post infection, and the bacteremia [bacteria in the\nbloodstream] lasted 6-12 months. The organism was recovered in 100\npercent of the males and 30 percent of the females in tissues (lymph\nnode, spleen) when they were abacteremic.\nSummary of diagnosis: Use the RSAT, 2ME-RSAT [see original reference\nbelow for explanations] to screen and identify all negative animals.\nUse the AGID cell wall antigen test to confirm the disease. Culture is\nthe only definitive diagnosis and is the best diagnostic test in the\n1st 2 months of the disease; however, dogs become abacteremic after\n27-64 months. Treatment can be difficult and expensive, especially in\nthe case of kennel animals. The urine of infected male dogs may tend\nto concentrate the organism such that cleaning up urine may present a\nrisk to immune compromised individuals (cancer patients or HIV or\nother causes of immune suppression).\nThis report doesn't specifically indicate that the quarantine was for\nbrucellosis, but it is perhaps implied. If the quarantine was for\nbrucellosis, then selling animals not only violates the quarantine but\nmay place some people at risk of the disease. It may also represent a\nrisk of spreading the disease to other animals. This report does not\ntell us the method used to diagnose the dogs. Clearly, from the\ndiscussion presented above, an accurate diagnosis is important. Horses\nmay also get brucellosis, although the mechanism is different, and\ngenerally horses do not get _Brucella canis_.\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\n<http://www.vetmed.lsu.edu/eiltslotus/theriogenology-5361/bruci.htm>.\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\nprosecutor says he plans to look into this and if he finds the\nquarantine has been violated, he'll seek a civil court order enforcing\nthe quarantine. This report doesn't specifically indicate that the quarantine was for\nbrucellosis, but it is perhaps implied.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-05-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WASHINGTON STATE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hutton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lewis County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "12841", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=12841", "date": "2007-06-11 23:00:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA) (02)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 10 Jun 2007\nSource: The Prairie Star [edited]\n<http://www.theprairiestar.com/articles/2007/06/10/ag_news/opinion/oped02.txt>\n\nMy colleagues and I in the Montana Department of Livestock, along\nwith other officials in both state and federal agencies, are now\nengaged in one of the most intensive disease investigations in recent\nMontana history.\nThe tremendous help and cooperation we've been receiving from ranch\nfamilies around the state, and from others involved in Montana's\nlivestock industries, has been critically important and is most\nappreciated.\nBrucellosis was detected in Montana cattle on 18 May 2007,\nthreatening our state's brucellosis-free status. While brucellosis\nposes only a minute risk to human health, the economic costs could\nseverely curtail Montana's premiere beef cattle industry. In\naddition, under federal rules, once brucellosis is detected, an\nexhaustive investigation that confirms no other cases of diseased\nlivestock must be completed within 60 days for the state to retain\nits disease-free status, which was hard won in 1985.\nBrucellosis usually causes late-term abortions in cattle, bison and\nelk. Rarely will an infected cow carry a calf past 5 to 7 months, but\nsometimes a live, but weak calf is born. The bacteria, _Brucella\nabortus_, thrives in un-pasteurized milk, afterbirth and other\nreproductive tract discharges, including aborted fetuses. The\ninfection also spreads through reproductive discharges of fluids and\nmaterials.\nResearch documents the spread of brucellosis from wildlife to\ndomestic cattle when 2 or more species share rangelands, especially\nduring the spring birthing season.\n_Brucella abortus_ can lead to undulant fever in humans, an incurable\nand severely debilitating condition. Once a serious problem (and\nstill a problem in epidemic proportions around the world), this risk\nin the U.S. has been virtually eliminated. It is the reason behind\nthe nation's eradication effort, which began in the 1930s. Today,\npasteurized milk and properly-cooked meat are risk-free.\nMontana Department of Public Health and Human Services statistics\nindicate that between 1960 and 1985, when Montana acquired its\nbrucellosis-free status, there were 28 cases of human undulant fever\ndiagnosed in Montana. In the past 20 years since becoming Brucellosis\nclass-free, only 4 Montanans have contracted the disease.\nOver the past several weeks, the Montana Department of Livestock and\nthe Veterinary Services Division of the USDA Animal and Plant Health\nInspection Service (USDA:APHIS:VS) worked in close cooperation to\ntest the Bridger herd, where brucellosis was discovered.\nOur state Diagnostic Laboratory in Bozeman has done extraordinary\nwork, at times generating accurate test results in as short a\nturn-around as several hours. To confirm brucellosis, a veterinarian\nmust draw a blood sample and send it to the Diagnostic Laboratory in\nBozeman. Usually, results are available within a week.\nNow we are engaged in an effort to trace all breeding stock that has\ncome in contact with the Bridger herd through sales, purchases or\ncommingled grazing over the past 2 years. We are determined to\ncomplete this process within 60 days counting from the day the 1st\npositive test result arrived (18 May 2007), and we are hoping to find\nno more sign of the disease.\nMeanwhile, all cattle from the Bridger herd are quarantined and will\nsoon be slaughtered and the owners compensated through a livestock\nappraisal process paid for by USDA:APHS:VS. Individual cows, heifers\nand bulls from a 2nd herd owned by the extended family have been\ntested, and all results revealed no disease. This herd will be\nretested in 30 days and again in 120 days to complete the\ninvestigation from the birth herd of the original index cow. Montana\nmust remain clean from brucellosis for 2 years after discovering the\n1st positive herd for the state to retain our brucellosis-free\nstatus. If testing confirms brucellosis in a 2nd herd of Montana\ncattle, the state will drop from brucellosis-free status to Class A\nstatus.\nBefore they can be exported, 18-month and older heifers, cows and\nbulls from a Class A state must demonstrate negative results (no\nbrucellosis) from blood tests within the 30-day period before\nshipping. Already, North Dakota has restricted imports of Montana\nbreeding stock, requiring a health certificate, individual\nidentification and a negative brucellosis test within 30 days of\nimportation. This testing requirement does not apply to steers or\nspayed heifers. Cattle grazing bordering counties will be evaluated\non a case-by-case basis.\nMontana's 1.4 million beef cattle comprise the 7th largest herd in\nthe nation. Montana leads the U.S. in quality seedstock, the breeding\nheifers, cows and bulls that are shipped nationwide and overseas.\nWhile comparatively small, Montana's domestic bison (19 000 in 2002)\nand dairy cattle (28 000 cows and heifers) enterprises also\ncontribute significantly to our state's largest economic driver. If\nMontana were to lose its brucellosis-free status, all 18-month-old\nand older reproductive cattle shipped out of state would be tested\nfor brucellosis within 30 days of transport, costing Montana\nproducers an estimated USD 5 million to USD 15 million annually. All\nMontana cattle exports would need to test negative for the disease\nover the course of the investigation. That investigation could last\nfrom one to several years before the state regains its\nbrucellosis-free status.\nCattle producers can vaccinate against brucellosis when livestock are\n4 to 10 months old.\nMany, if not most, Montana producers voluntarily protect their stock\nfrom this economically devastating disease, but the vaccine is only\n60 percent to 85 percent effective. That is better than no\nprotection, but not a guarantee.\nThe urgency of our ongoing investigation is a great inconvenience for\nlivestock owners and their animals.\nThe process requires a lot of extra work from everyone involved. We\nare grateful for all the cooperation and help we're receiving from\nproducers in this trying time. One way or another, science will\ndetermine the outcome of this process.\n[Byline: Dr. Jeanne Rankin, Montana's Acting State Veterinarian]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The state of Montana has approximately 5 more weeks to finish\ntrace-ins (animals being brought into the herd) and trace-outs\n(animals leaving the herd) and its epidemiology report to the USDA,\nAPHIS. And 3 other dogs could also test positive in the coming\nweeks. They were found on the property of a woman who rescues and breeds\ndogs. About 110 dogs were found on the property; many of them living in\nfilthy conditions. Officials are advising anyone who has obtained a dog\nfrom the woman to have it checked out by a vet.\n_Brucella canis_ is a particular strain of brucellosis that infects dogs.\nThe disease is not easily transmitted to humans and is relatively mild,\nwith the exception of individuals with immune compromising conditions\n(patients with cancer, HIV infection, or transplants) and young children.\nIn dogs, the disease is transmitted during breeding causing females to\nabort and males to develop long term chronic infections.\nTreatment in dogs is not very effective and the recommended management to\nprevent the spread to other dogs is euthanasia of infected dogs.\nBrucellosis is transmitted by contact or by contaminated food, water, and\nexcrement. Health officials are trying to stop to the transmission of this\ndog disease to the other dogs on the property and prevent it from spreading\nto other dogs in the county.\nAnyone who received a dog from this woman along Hwy 508 near Mary's Corner,\nHwy 12 at the Ethel Market area or from a parking lot in any of the\nbusinesses at Exit 79 in Chehalis since mid February is advised to take it\nto a veterinarian or an animal shelter. Health officials say, do not dump\nthe dog along the road or out in the country. People who are concerned\nabout exposure can consult with Lewis County Public Health Department at\n360-740-1222.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n[_B canis_ is a cause of abortion in kenneled dogs. Dogs are the definitive\nhost of this organism, and natural infections in other animals are rare.\nInfection has caused a reduction of 75 per cent in the number of pups\nweaned in some breeding kennels. The disease disseminates rapidly among\nclosely confined dogs, especially at time of breeding or when abortions\noccur. Transmission occurs via ingestion of contaminated materials or\nvenereal routes. Both sexes appear to be equally susceptible. Transmission\nof brucellosis from dogs to humans occurs but appears to be very rare.\nPrimary signs are abortion during the last trimester of pregnancy without\npremonitory signs, stillbirths, and conception failures. Prolonged vaginal\ndischarge usually follows abortion. Abortions may occur during subsequent\npregnancies. Infected dogs may develop generalized lymphadenitis and\nfrequently epididymitis, periorchitis, and prostatitis. Spondylitis and\nuveitis are occasional complications. Bacteremia is frequent and persists\nfor about 18 months after exposure. Fever is not characteristic.\nDiagnosis is based on isolation and identification of the causative agent\nor by serology. The organisms can usually be readily isolated from vaginal\nexudate, aborted pups, blood, milk, or semen of infected dogs. The most\nwidely used serologic test is an agglutination test by a tube or slide\nmethod. Nonspecific agglutination reactions occur in some dogs from which\nbrucella has not been isolated. To eliminate nonspecific antibodies, the\nserum is treated with 2-mercaptoethanol and retested. An agar gel\nimmunodiffusion test performed in some laboratories is quite specific.\nAttempts at immunization have not been successful. Control is based on\nelimination or isolation of infected dogs identified by positive cultural\nor serologic tests. Incidence of infection is much lower in kennels where\ndogs are caged individually. Longterm therapy, eg, with a combination of\nstreptomycin or gentamicin and tetracycline, has been successful in many\ncases. Neutering of infected dogs is sometimes an alternative to euthanasia.\nThe brucella agent is often found concentrated in an infected dogs urine.\nCleaning of urine by immune suppressed individuals may put them at risk for\nthe disease.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/112200.htm> - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Anyone who received a dog from this woman along Hwy 508 near Mary's Corner,\nHwy 12 at the Ethel Market area or from a parking lot in any of the\nbusinesses at Exit 79 in Chehalis since mid February is advised to take it\nto a veterinarian or an animal shelter. People who are concerned\nabout exposure can consult with Lewis County Public Health Department at\n360-740-1222.\n --\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n Health officials are trying to stop to the transmission of this\ndog disease to the other dogs on the property and prevent it from spreading\nto other dogs in the county. The disease disseminates rapidly among\nclosely confined dogs, especially at time of breeding or when abortions\noccur. Control is based on\nelimination or isolation of infected dogs identified by positive cultural\nor serologic tests. The disease is not easily transmitted to humans and is relatively mild,\nwith the exception of individuals with immune compromising conditions\n(patients with cancer, HIV infection, or transplants) and young children. The most\nwidely used serologic test is an agglutination test by a tube or slide\nmethod. Source: KING5.com [edited]\n<http://www.king5.com/localnews/stories/NW_050407WABbruscellacanisTP.3912df5f.html>\n\nBrucellosis (dog disease)\n Longterm therapy, eg, with a combination of\nstreptomycin or gentamicin and tetracycline, has been successful in many\ncases. Treatment in dogs is not very effective and the recommended management to\nprevent the spread to other dogs is euthanasia of infected dogs. BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE \ufffd USA (WASHINGTON)\n**************************************\n In dogs, the disease is transmitted during breeding causing females to\nabort and males to develop long term chronic infections. The organisms can usually be readily isolated from vaginal\nexudate, aborted pups, blood, milk, or semen of infected dogs. Lewis County [WA] health officials say 15 dogs have now tested positive for\n_Brucella canis_. Infected dogs may develop generalized lymphadenitis and\nfrequently epididymitis, periorchitis, and prostatitis. Some conservation\ngroups blamed the jump on the supplemental\nfeeding, which biologists say congregates\nanimals, increasing the spread of the disease.\nIn this year's [2007] study, wildlife officials\ntested 39 samples for the _Brucella_ bacteria,\nfinding it in 2 animals. Researchers also\nattached Global Positioning System and VHF radio\ncollars, and vaginal implant transmitters to 41\nfemale elk. The transmitters are designed to\ndetect when and where a pregnant female elk\naborts her fetus. Blood from 2 of the 41 elk\nfroze in the syringe, making it unusable for\nbrucellosis testing.\nStudies of brucellosis rates in Buffalo Valley\nfrom 1987 to 2005 showed disease in 2.7 percent\nof the animals. After emergency feeding last\nyear, brucellosis rates jumped to about 20\npercent.\nOfficials say the jump likely is not caused by\nthe emergency feeding but rather resulted from\ndifferences in testing methods. The 1987 to 2005\ndata is derived from hunter samples submitted\nduring the fall, while the Wyoming Game and Fish\nDepartment used helicopters to capture elk in the\nwinter during the past 2 years [2005, 2006].\nIn a statement, Game and Fish wildlife\nveterinarian Dr. Terry Kreeger said it was\n'highly unlikely'\ufffd last year's [2006] 20 percent\ndisease rate was caused by any management action.\n'Successive years of data must be collected and\nstudies repeated before accurate conclusions can\nbe made,' he said.\nHank Edwards, a wildlife disease specialist with\nGame and Fish, said biologists aren't sure why\nthe rate was 20 percent last year [2006] only to\nfall again this year [2007].\n'I wish we had a good explanation for it, but we\ndon't have a good handle on that herd unit,' he\nsaid. 'Are we sampling the same elk? What\ndifference does snow play?'\n'This disease is one of those things, just when\nyou think you've got a good handle on it, it\nthrows it back in your face. This is not a closed\nsystem. There's elk moving in and out ... unlike\na research project where we can bleed everybody.'\nEdwards said he wasn't sure if the data from the\nmost recent survey are statistically significant.\n[Byline: Cory Hatch]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Brucellosis is caused by the bacteria _Brucella\nabortus_ in elk. The disease is best known for it\nability to induce abortions, although stillborn\nand weak calves are other possible effects. It\nis difficult to find in these wild animals\nbecause the herds are so dynamic that disease\nstatistics are not static. The differences in the\npercentages of disease suggests hunting vs.\ncapture plays a large role in the statistical\nvariation of the numbers. Group feeding or\nemergency feeding congregates the animals, which\nprovides conditions suitable for easy\ndissemination, but that may not necessarily be\nthe whole story to brucellosis in elk. These\ntheories, management issues, and debates about\nbrucellosis -- especially in the Greater\nYellowstone Area -- are likely to continue for\nsome years or until we have advanced\ntechnologically to detect and eradicate this\nelusive disease in wildlife.\nEtter and Drew published 'Brucellosis in Elk of\nEastern Idaho' in the Journal of Wildlife\nDiseases, 42(2), 2006, pp. 271-278. Chile (Osorno): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6412", "date": "2007-01-08 00:00:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - CHILE (OSORNO): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 8 Jan 2007\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Mercopress [edited]\n<http://www.mercopress.com/vernoticia.do?id=9596&formato=HTML>\n\nOutbreak of brucellosis in southern Chile\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of bovine brucellosis has been confirmed in the Chilean\nprovince of Osorno, according to the Minister of Agriculture, Alvaro Rojas.\nMeasures to isolate the outbreak in the rural area of Osorno have\nbeen taken, and 'we're talking with farmers about the complications\nto rural activities which this entails,' Rojas is quoted by an Osorno\ndaily, adding that since 'we have an open alert system,' the\nreappearance of the outbreak was rapidly detected.'\nHowever, Chile's Agriculture and Livestock Service, SAG, responsible\nfor animal and plant's health, admitted that the exact location of\noutbreaks has yet to be determined.\nLuis Paredes, from SAG's Livestock department, said that the\noutbreaks come as a 'great surprise,' since 'Osorno has been the\nregion which has most advanced in the matter, and no outbreaks had\nbeen reported for a very long time.'\n'We believe we are facing isolated cases, but it's a call of\nattention to remind us we must be alert at all times,' added Paredes.\nVeterinary surgeon Francisco Lanuza recalled that immunization of\nheifers is essential to avoid outbreak of the disease and must be\ndone when calves are 5 to 8 months old.\nBrucellosis is an infectious disease caused by the bacteria of the\ngenus _Brucella_. These bacteria are primarily passed among animals,\nand they cause disease in many different vertebrates. Various\n_Brucella_ species affect sheep, goats, cattle, deer, elk, pigs,\ndogs, and several other animals. Humans become infected by coming in\ncontact with animals or animal products that are contaminated with\nthese bacteria.\nIn livestock, the bacteria attacks mainly cattle of reproductive age,\ncausing abortions. An infected animal can rapidly spread the disease,\nparticularly in areas of high density or concentration, such as dairy farms.\nIn humans, brucellosis can cause a range of symptoms that are similar\nto the flu, and may include fever, sweats, headaches, back pains, and\nphysical weakness.\nOsorno is 900 km south of Santiago and north of Puerto Montt.\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[A map of the region may be found at\n<http://travel.yahoo.com/p-map-482514-map_of_osorno-i>.\nIt is interesting to note the reference to an 'open alert system'\nrapidly detecting the disease. What exactly is meant by an 'open\nalert system' remains in question. Also, they know the region but not\nthe exact location. Perhaps this is a slaughter report that tested\npositive, or perhaps it is an export. There seem to be many\nepidemiological questions left unanswered. - Mod.TG]\n[More information on this outbreak from knowledgeable sources would\nbe appreciated. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Measures to isolate the outbreak in the rural area of Osorno have\nbeen taken, and 'we're talking with farmers about the complications\nto rural activities which this entails,' Rojas is quoted by an Osorno\ndaily, adding that since 'we have an open alert system,' the\nreappearance of the outbreak was rapidly detected.' However, Chile's Agriculture and Livestock Service, SAG, responsible\nfor animal and plant's health, admitted that the exact location of\noutbreaks has yet to be determined. Various\n_Brucella_ species affect sheep, goats, cattle, deer, elk, pigs,\ndogs, and several other animals. We believe we are facing isolated cases, but it's a call of\nattention to remind us we must be alert at all times,' added Paredes.\n Source: Mercopress [edited]\n<http://www.mercopress.com/vernoticia.do?id=9596&formato=HTML>\n\nOutbreak of brucellosis in southern Chile\n BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - CHILE (OSORNO): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-01-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Puerto Montt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10508", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10508", "date": "2007-05-22 12:00:02", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 19 May 2007\nSource: Billings Gazette [edited]\n<http://www.billingsgazette.net/articles/2007/05/19/news/state/20-brucellosis.txt>\n\nSeven Montana cows have tested positive for brucellosis, and if at\nleast 2 cows from a separate herd near Emigrant test positive next\nweek, Montana will lose its brucellosis-free status.\nThat means Montana ranchers would have to pay to test all adult\ncattle being shipped out of state until Montana can regain its\nbrucellosis-free status.\nGov. Brian Schweitzer said he expects the 2nd set of test results as\nearly as Tuesday [22 May 2007]. 'There is a process you go through --\nrounding up cattle, drawing blood, testing it., and then it's either\n'Whew!' or 'Oh, my God,' ' Schweitzer said.\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture's (DOA) Animal and Plant Health\nInspection Service (APHIS) is in charge of controlling the disease.\nAPHIS rules say that a state loses its brucellosis-free status when\nat least 2 cows from 2 herds test positive within 12 months.\nOn 1 May 2007, 51 Angus cows bound for Iowa were tested for\nbrucellosis in Baker. Because Montana is a brucellosis-free state,\nthe cows wouldn't normally be tested, but because the cows were going\nto be surrogate mothers, the tests were conducted. On 4 May 2007, the\nMontana State Lab in Bozeman found that one cow had tested positive\nfor brucellosis. That cow was euthanized and tissue cultures were\nre-tested at the National Veterinary Services lab in Ames, Iowa,\nwhich conducts the testing for APHIS. The infected cow was traced\nback to a herd of 301 cows in Bridger, and that herd was quarantined\nafter 6 more cows tested positive for brucellosis. The cattle came\nfrom a ranch near Emigrant, Schweitzer said. A 2nd herd in the\nParadise Valley is being tested now.\nTo prevent the spread of [the disease] from bison to area cattle,\nofficials from the Montana Department of Livestock have hazed\nwandering Yellowstone National Park bison back into the park. Last\nyear [2006], more than 1000 bison that ranged onto private lands in\nMontana were captured, and most were sent to slaughter. However, the\ngovernor said information he has received indicates that bison aren't\nto blame. 'It seems almost impossible this was a direct transmission\nfrom Yellowstone bison to cattle. It could have been it came from\nelk,' Schweitzer said. 'Or it could have been someone shipping cattle\ninto Montana from some infected herd in Texas or Mexico.' Jeremy\nSeidlitz, executive director of the Montana Cattlemen's Association,\nexpressed concern but said he feels helpless for now. 'I really don't\nthink there is anything we can do but watch and hope,' Seidlitz said.\n'Losing the brucellosis-free status is very expensive in terms of\nmoney and time.'\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease in ruminant animals that can\ncause fetuses to abort. It is considered one of the most serious\nlivestock diseases, primarily affecting cattle, swine, bison, and\nelk.] Ranchers, veterinarians, and workers in slaughterhouses are\nmost at risk for the human strain, called undulant fever.\nMontana has been brucellosis-free since June 1985. Wyoming found\nbrucellosis in its cattle in 2004, and regained its brucellosis-free\nstatus last September, [2006]. Currently, Idaho and Texas are the\nonly states without a brucellosis-free rating.\nTesting costs from USD 5 to USD 10 per animal, depending on whether\nthe tests are conducted at the ranch or elsewhere, said Ray Randall,\nwho owns Bridger Veterinary Service. 'It's a significant problem,' he\nsaid. 'The last time I remember having a brucellosis-positive herd\nwas in the '70s.' Randall said he hasn't taken any blood tests for\nbrucellosis yet.\nEven if the 2nd herd tests free of the disease, the 301 cows\nquarantined near Bridger must be slaughtered, according to APHIS\nrules. There is no immediate financial help for the owner. Indemnity\nfunds exist for ranchers who lose livestock to wolves, but not this\ndisease, Seidlitz said, adding that he has never heard of brucellosis\ninsurance.\nSchweitzer said the bad news is reason to adopt his plan to test all\ncattle within a ring around Yellowstone National Park. He has\nproposed to APHIS that Montana be allowed to mark off an area of 60\nto 70 miles (approx. 97-113 km) around Yellowstone National Park and\nrequire that all the cattle moving in and out of the zone be tested.\nIf the disease shows up, only that zone would lose its\nbrucellosis-free status, not the whole state. 'We would have caught\nit at its source,' the governor said. 'Now we're in a position where\npeople long removed from Yellowstone Basin are being painted with the\nsame brush.'\nMeanwhile, APHIS spokeswoman, Teresa Howes, in Fort Collins,\nColorado, said tracing back and testing cattle is a long process, one\nthat's just starting in Montana. 'The good news is that this was\nfound and it didn't go on to infect the national herd,' she said.\n'Now we're doing the investigation to make sure no other herds are infected.'\n[Byline: Jan Falstad]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[Animal caretakers, including veterinarians, are especially\nsusceptible to brucellosis from infected animals. Generally, when the\nanimal requires assistance during the birthing process, the person\nproviding the assistance is most at risk of exposure to the causative\nbacterium _Brucella abortus_. This agent can be passed to humans\nthrough unpasteurized or raw milk as well.\nBrucellosis is commonly transmitted to susceptible animals by direct\ncontact with infected animals or with an environment that has been\ncontaminated with discharges from infected animals. Aborted fetuses,\nplacental membranes or fluids, and other vaginal discharges present\nafter an infected animal has aborted or calved are all highly\ncontaminated with infectious brucella organisms.\nCattle, bison, and cervids are susceptible to _B. abortus_; other\n_Brucella_ species affect other animals. The animals experience a\nloss of production (including abortion of the fetus), a drop in milk\nproduction, weight loss, infertility, and lameness. Although the\nanimal may abort the 1st fetus, the animal may successfully carry a\nfetus to term during the next pregnancy. Offspring may be born weak\nor dead, without actual abortion.\nThe brucellosis eradication program in place for about 50 years has\nalmost eliminated the disease. Currently, only Texas and Idaho are\nclassified as Class A states, meaning they have a herd infection rate\nof less than 0.1 percent. All other states are classified as\nbrucellosis-free. - Mod.TG]\n[The state of Montana (MT) in the western United States may be\nlocated on the map at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/unitedstates.html>. Yellowstone\nNational Park is located mostly in the state of Wyoming (WY), but it\nextends into Montana (MT) and Idaho (ID). - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Billings Gazette [edited]\n<http://www.billingsgazette.net/articles/2007/05/19/news/state/20-brucellosis.txt>\n\nSeven Montana cows have tested positive for brucellosis, and if at\nleast 2 cows from a separate herd near Emigrant test positive next\nweek, Montana will lose its brucellosis-free status.\n Aborted fetuses,\nplacental membranes or fluids, and other vaginal discharges present\nafter an infected animal has aborted or calved are all highly\ncontaminated with infectious brucella organisms.\n [Byline: Jan Falstad]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n A cow that reacted positively to a brucellosis test through the\nMarket Cattle Inspection Program under the Cooperative State-Federal\nBrucellosis Eradication Program was traced to the Swan Valley ranch. Idaho,\nwhich has had brucellosis-free status since 1991,\nsays it may challenge the federal move. Lifting\nthe status would force ranchers to test female\nand un-castrated male cattle over 18 months old\nbefore selling them across state lines, according\nto minimum testing guidelines.\nIn addition, cattle herds in eastern Idaho that\nhave contact with wild elk in the winter also may\nhave to be tested for the disease. Elk, along\nwith bison, are major carriers of brucellosis in\nthe area near Yellowstone National Park.\n'We will continue our vigilance, and we will ask\ncattle owners to do the same,' said state\nAgriculture Director Pat Takasugi.\nThe infection can lead to spontaneous abortions,\ninfertility, decreased milk production and weight\nloss in cattle. It is rarely transmitted to\nhumans.\nMore than 50 cattle were slaughtered in eastern\nIdaho, after veterinarians confirmed brucellosis\ninfections at a Swan Valley beef ranch in early\nOctober [2005]. A 2nd case was discovered in an\nArco feedlot.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Brucellosis is an economic drain to the\nproducers if their animals harbor the disease. One has to\nre-emphasize that positive serological titers is either indicative of\na smooth _Brucella spp._ infection (one cannot make any inference as\nto whether _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ is involved\nunless the most likely source of infection is identified) or/and _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infection.\nClinical symptoms help in classifying the case as probable or\nconfirmed brucellosis, according to the CDC case definition. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere 'at the end of the world.'\n1. Yes, _B. melitensis_ is responsible for the majority of human infections\nand is primarily food borne. Primary hosts for _B. melitensis_ are sheep\nand goats. _B. abortus_ infection is generally sporadic and occurs in\npeople who work with cattle or pigs, respectively. It is also valid that\nthe general public generally acquires the infection including _B. abortus_\nthrough the ingestion of unpasteurized milk and milk products. Our traveler\nconsumed milk and sheep milk cheese on the streets in Istanbul. I agree\nwith the professor that the cheese as the source of disease is unlikely,\nbut unpasteurized milk and brucellosis exist in Turkey, both _melitensis_\nand _abortus_.\n2. Clinical symptoms are generally not specific for brucellosis. The\npossibility of brucellosis should be considered in any fever of unknown\norigin in patients who recently traveled in endemic areas. Turkey is an\nendemic area, and our traveler visited there. The patient developed the\nflu-like symptoms of headache, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, malaise,\nfatigue, fever and weight loss. The fever showed diurnal variation and came\nand went over time.\n3. In the laboratory, we found positive inflammatory indexes. In the blood,\nleucopenia with lymphocytosis were found, and liver function tests were\nabnormal. Hepatosplenomegaly was found by ultrasound. Lymphadenopathy was\nfound as well. No other infectious or non-infectious etiology of hepatitis\nwas found.\n4. Serologically, high titers for brucellosis were found, and antibodies\nagainst _Y. enterocolitica_ were lower. It is debatable whether infection\nwith _Y. enterocolitica_ was present, but brucellosis was definite. When we\nhave diagnosed extraintestinal yersiniosis in patients in previous years,\nbrucellosis titers have always been non-reactive.\nSources:\n1. She was living in Turkey during January\nuntil the beginning of February 2005 in an Istanbul hotel. There, she\nconsumed milk in her coffee and sheep milk cheeses, probably both\nun-pasteurized, on Istanbul streets. The patient developed fatigue,\nheadache, malaise, arthralgias, myalgias and fever beginning in April 2005.\nThe patient was treated with a variety of antimicrobial agents in different\nmedical facilities without therapeutic effect until our department\ndiagnosed acute brucellosis (_B.abortus_) in combination with the\nextraintestinal form of yersiniosis (_Y. enterocolitica_).\nThese diagnoses were made by laboratory serological examinations where\nantibodies against brucellosis (in several blood samples) were in the 1000s\nand antibodies, including antigen O:9, against _Y. enterocolitica_ were\nalso found.\nWe used the combination of 2 antibiotics for her treatment, and the patient\nis now healthy. The antibody titers have also decreased after treatment.\n--\nVladimir Strakrle MD\nBrno, Czech Republic\n<strakrle@e-globals.net>\n[ProMED would like to thank Dr. Strakrle for this firsthand report of\nimported brucellosis. Whether the tourist had a co-infection with\nyersiniosis, however, is unclear.\nThe serodiagnosis of acute or recent infections with _Brucella abortus_ and\n_Yersinia enterocolitica_ O:9 together is problematic because many of the\ncommonly used serological tests demonstrate cross-reactivity (1, 2), both\nin animals and humans. It appears that the serological titers against _B.\nabortus_ were higher in this case, and since neither pathogen was\napparently isolated, the antibody test for _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is\nlikely to be a cross-reaction.\nThis cross-reactivity is caused by an epitope (A) on the smooth-type\nlipopolysaccharide (S-LPS). Although a variety of Gram negative bacilli may\ncontain this epitope, only _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is a significant cause\nof cross-reaction (3).\nThe exact serological tests were not given, however, and some serologies\ncan distinguish the 2 pathogens. As examples, a Western Blot assay to assay\nantibody against the outer membrane protein of _Brucella_ (4) and using\nmonoclonal antibodies directed against different S-LPS epitopes (5) can\nidentify _Brucella_, and a _Yersinia_ outer protein assay (6) can identify\n_Yersinia_ O:9.\n1. Huvell B: Serological cross-reactions between different _Brucella_\nspecies and _Yersinia enterocolitica_. Acta Vet Scand 1972; 13:472-83.\n2. Chart H, Okubadejo OA, Rowe B: The serological relationship between\n_Escherichia coli_ O157 and _Yersinia enterocolitica_ O9 using sera from\npatients with brucellosis. Epidemiol Infect. 1992; 108:77-85.\n3. Munoz PM, Marin CM, Monreal D, et al: Efficacy of several serological\ntests and antigens for diagnosis of bovine brucellosis in the presence of\nfalse-positive serological results due to _Yersinia enterocolitica_ O:9.\nClin Diagn Lab Immunol 2005; 12:141-51.\n4. Corrente M, Desario C, Greco G, et al: Development of a western blotting\nassay to discriminate _Brucella_ spp. and _Yersinia enterocolitica_ O:9\ninfections in sheep. New Microbiol 2004; 27:155-61.\n5. Kittleberger R, Bundesen PG, Cloeckaert A, et al: Serological\ncross-reactivity between _Brucella abortus_ and _Yersinia enterocolitica_\nO:9IV. In contrast,\nGreece is moderately (or even more) infected with _B. melitensis_ (68\noutbreaks in 2003) as well as with _B. abortus_ (221 outbreaks in 2003).\n_B. melitensis_ is the species that is generally regarded as more\npathogenic to humans. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The diagnostic criteria used for brucellosis here is not stated. About 2000 goats will be culled today at the country's\nbiggest goat farm, in Kanchanaburi province, to prevent the spread of the\ninfectious disease brucellosis, a senior Livestock Development Department\nofficial said on 6 Sep 2005.\nSamart Jaralyanon, provincial chief for livestock development, said the\nculling at Mahboonkrong Dairy Goats Co was ordered by the department's\ndirector-general. It will be the 1st time animals are culled in such large\nnumbers, he said. The transport of all of the farm's products, such as live\ngoats, dairy products and meat, were also banned under the same order.\nSamart said goat dairy products already available on the market were safe\nto eat, because the bacteria were killed by pasteurization. Dr Pakdi\nBhotisiri, secretary-general of the Food and Drug Administration, confirmed\nthat goat dairy products already on the market were not contaminated.\nSamart said more than 700 goats had been killed at the farm since the\ninfectious bacterial disease was first discovered in Mar 2005. The farm was\ndeclared an epidemic control zone last Thu, 1 Sep 2005. Humans can be\ninfected through direct contact with secretions of infected goats.\nSamart said the farm also raised goats for meat, even though it was\nregistered as a dairy farm. He said only goats raised for meat would be\nculled, because there were no reports of infection among the farm's 2500\ndairy goats. The director-general of the Livestock Development Department\nwill inspect the farm today with an adviser to the agriculture minister.\nThe farm's manager also invited journalists to visit at the same time.\n12 men and 7 women who worked at the farm have so far been infected with\nthe disease. Dr Surapong Tanthanasri-sakul, head of public health for the\nprovince, said a special center was set up at Phra Piya Hospital to care\nfor those infected. He said the disease could be cured with a 6 week\nregimen of antimicrobial agents.\nDr Thawat Suntrajarn, director-general of the Disease Control Department,\nsaid it was not necessary for infected humans to be quarantined, because\nthere were no reports of human-to-human transmission. A special team of\ndoctors was sent to the farm to find out how the workers had become infected.\n[byline: Pennapa Hongthong and Duangkamol Sajirawattakul]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Caprine brucellosis is usually caused by _B. melitensis_, which is a\nsignificant human zoonotic disease. In 2003, ProMED-mail posted a previous\noutbreak of brucellosis in humans and goats in Thailand. Of note, Laurence\nGleeson from Australia's Animal Health Laboratory commented: 'This is an\nimportant report, as _Brucella melitensis_ has not been previously reported\nfrom Thailand, and in fact Southeast Asia is considered free from the\ndisease (OIE Manual of Standards, 2000).\n'Although an epidemic of brucellosis due to _B. abortus_ would not be\nexpected in goats, especially in the absence of some concurrent abortion\noutbreak in cattle, clearly a definitive identification of the causative\n_Brucella sp_ is required to clarify the situation.\n'If this is a true introduction of an exotic agent into Thailand, then it\nwas most likely introduced by animal movement from an endemic area. Goats\nmove into some parts of Thailand from Myanmar (a single outbreak of caprine\nbrucellosis was reported in 1998 and 1999; OIE 'Handistatus'), but of more\nconcern would be if the animals came from further west, where other serious\ndiseases of goats are endemic, e.g., peste des petits ruminants and goat\nand sheep pox.\n'As goats can also be carriers of FMD, there is potential for such animal\nmovement to shift strains from South Asia to South East Asia. This incident\nis a marker for an important background event that hopefully will be\nunravelled by the epidemiological and laboratory investigations conducted\nby the Department of Livestock Development, Thailand.'\nBrucellosis is another zoonotic infection that can be spread not only by\ndirect contact with the animal carrier but also by the ingestion of\nunpasteurized dairy products such as milk and cheese. The infection is also\nknown as undulant fever, related to the occurrence of 1-3 week febrile\nperiods separated by 1-3 days of afebrility. This occurs more likely with\n_B. melitensis_ (acquired from goats) as compared to _B. abortus_ (cattle)\nand _B. suis_ (swine).\nThe infection can be subclinical. Acute symptomatic brucellosis is\ngenerally manifest with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, chills, night\nsweats, anorexia, and an increased sense of ill health. The disease can be\ndiagnosed serologically and/or by blood culture. The organism may grow\nquite slowly on primary isolation, and the clinician should make the\nmicrobiology laboratory aware of this potential diagnosis. Localized\ninfection may occur. Sites for localization include the skeletal system\n(1), heart valves (2) and urinary tract (3). GU brucellosis may present\nidentically to GU tuberculosis. Psychiatric manifestations such as\ndepression and anxiety are possible as late symptoms of brucellosis (4,5),\nso-called chronic neurobrucellosis. It remains unclear whether active\nbrucella infection is present at that time. Overt CNS infection can,\nhowever, include meningitis and encephalitis (6,7).\n1. Samples from\nreactors are undergoing cultural examination.\nVeterinary advice was that 4 of the reactors should be culled.\nSlaughter of the 4, with compensation, has now been carried out and\nfurther testing will be done on lymph nodes to check for _Brucella_.\nSampling of the remaining reactors, who are in isolation, has taken\nplace and the blood and milk samples are under investigation.\nDefra is also tracing any movements off the farm in recent months.\nHowever, it is understood that the farm has been relatively\nself-contained with few movements off the farm apart from to\nslaughter. Testing has been undertaken on 2 premises under the same\nmanagement. There have been no abortions reported from the farm and\nno other clinical evidence that Brucellosis has been identified.\n_Brucella_ cultures are relatively slow-growing, and results may not\nbe available for at least 2 weeks. There is a possibility that the\ninitial test results could be due to a cross-reaction to the test\nrather than infection.\nNotes for editors\n----------------\n1. Brucellosis of cattle is caused by infection with the bacterium\n_Brucella abortus_, which can also cause a disease of humans known as\nundulant fever. In cattle, it causes abortion or premature calving of\nrecently infected animals; the foetus, placenta and uterine fluid\ncontain large quantities of _Brucella abortus_ bacteria, which can\naffect other cattle coming into contact with an infected animal\naround the time of calving. The organism continues to be excreted in\nthe milk; in the past humans were frequently infected through\ndrinking unpasteurised milk.\n2. The last case of Brucellosis was in 2004 in Cornwall. Details of\nthe last press release dated 20 Jul 2004 can be found at:\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2004/040720d.htm>.\n3. If slaughter is required, animals will be slaughtered under the\nBrucellosis (England) Order 2000. Compensation is payable for\nslaughter of reactors under the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis (England\nand Wales) Compensation (Amendment) Order 1998 [NB the parent Order\nis the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis (England and Wales - Compensation\nOrder 1978]. The maximum payable is calculated monthly based on the\naverage market price and for Mar 2005 is GBP 591 [USD 1105].\n4. Article 10 of the Brucellosis (England) Order 2000 requires all\ncattle farmers to report abortions and premature calving to the local\nAnimal Health office. Similar legislation is in place for Scotland\nand Wales. Details of the disease [caused by infection with]\n_Brucella abortus_ can be found on the Defra website at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2005//animalh/diseases/notifiable/disease/brucellosis.htm>.\n5. A fact sheet for farmers, detailing what they should do in an\noutbreak is also available on the Defra website at:\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2005//animalh/diseases/notifiable/disease/brucellosis.htm>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu, 24 Mar 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Scotsman, 24 Mar 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.scotsman.com/latest.cfm?id=4305270>\n\nCows Culled Amid Fears of Disease Outbreak\n-------------------\n4 cows have been culled at a farm amid concerns of a potential\noutbreak of brucellosis, it was revealed today.\nThe department for environment food and rural affairs (Defra) said it\nhad also imposed movement restrictions on the Derbyshire dairy after\n23 animals failed tests for the contagious disease, which causes\npremature abortions in cattle and can cause a fever in humans.\nThe 4 slaughtered cows showed stronger reactions to the routine blood\nand milk tests than the rest of the herd, said a Defra spokesman.\nThe department was keen to stress more checks were needed to confirm\nthat the cattle were infected with the _Brucella_ bacteria because\ninitial results could show a cross-reaction to the test itself.\n_Brucella_ can cause a disease in humans called undulant fever, but\nthis has only been contracted in the past, said the spokesman, by\ndrinking unpasteurised milk.\nCattle develop the disease when coming into contact with an infected\ncow's placenta or aborted foetus.\nDefra said it was too early in the tests process to identify the farm involved.\n'At this stage it's only the initial test that shows this and it\ncould be a cross-reaction, so we won't normally give out any further\ndetails until the further tests confirm or negate the problem,' the\nspokesman said.\nIt is understood that the farm has been relatively self-contained in\nrecent days, with few movements off the site apart from [cattle being\ntaken] to slaughter. The dangerous disease was\nintroduced by 25 infected sheep which were moved into the district in\nJune, 2004 from the Orenburg region.\nThe regional veterinary service has serologically identified 15\nbrucellosis-positive sheep.\nThe movement of the sheep was carried out without the permission of\nthe district state veterinary service, and the animals did not go\nthrough the prescribed quarantine period. Consequently, the sheep\nwere resold, reaching 6 farms in 3 villages: Babka, Shabury and\nSolomaty. All infected sheep and their contacts will be destroyed,\nwithout further use of meat, skins or offal. Disinfection and\nderatization [yes, it does mean getting rid of rats - PG] is planned for\nthe infected premises. People who had contact with the infected\nanimals will be put under medical follow-up and tested serologically.\nThose engaged with animal vaccination will be protected by\nvaccination, reports 'New region'.\nAccording to physicians, the brucellosis bacteria, extremely\ndangerous to humans, may be spread by aerosol. Earlier, the territory\nof the Perm area was considered relatively safe in relation to\nbrucellosis infection in animals. In other regions of the country,\nbetween 400 and 700 human patients are diagnosed annually. The\ndisease causes severe clinical signs, often becoming chronic,\nresulting in physical disability.\nAmong the recommended preventive measures are thorough cooking of\nmeat and precautions when handling suspect animals and their products\n[thermal treatment of milk and milk products is of prime importance,\nnot to be neglected. - Mod.AS]. Personnel involved with suspect\nanimals should be vaccinated.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This information probably relates to _Brucella melitensis_, which is\nendemic in several parts of the Russian Federation. Cattle,\nsheep, goats, pigs, and camels can transmit the disease. WHO officials said\nbrucellosis is accompanied by fever, generalized aches and pains, fatigue,\nand depression.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella sp._ are Category B bioterrorism zoonotic agents. Of the 3 major\nspecies, _abortus_ is found in cattle, _melitensis_ in goats and _suis_ in\nswine. In this area of the world, the caprine species is most common.\nSymptoms of brucellosis are protean in nature, and none are specific enough\nto make the diagnosis. Symptoms include fever, which is intermittent in 60\nper cent of patients with acute and chronic conditions, undulant in 60 per\ncent of patients with subacute brucellosis, and can be associated with a\nrelative bradycardia. Fever of unknown origin is not an uncommon initial\ndiagnosis for patients in areas of low endemicity.\nConstitutional symptoms include anorexia, asthenia, fatigue, weakness, and\nmalaise.\nBone and joint symptoms include arthralgias; low back pain; spine and joint\npain; and, rarely, joint swelling. Symptoms were present on presentation in\nas many as 55 per cent of patients.\nRespiratory complaints of cough and dyspnea are present in as many as 19\nper cent of cases, but these complaints rarely are associated with active\npulmonary involvement. Pleuritic chest pain can be observed in patients\nwith underlying empyema.\nNeuropsychiatric symptoms are frequent despite the rare involvement of the\nnervous system. Headache, depression, and fatigue are the most frequently\nreported complaints.\nGastrointestinal complaints, present in 51 per cent of patients, include\nabdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, and vomiting.\nNeurologic symptoms can include weakness, dizziness, unsteadiness of gait,\nand urinary retention. Complaints associated with cranial nerve dysfunction\ncan be present in those with chronic CNS involvement. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Symptoms include fever, which is intermittent in 60\nper cent of patients with acute and chronic conditions, undulant in 60 per\ncent of patients with subacute brucellosis, and can be associated with a\nrelative bradycardia. \nWorld Health Organization information said brucellosis is transmitted from\nanimals to humans through contaminated and untreated milk and milk products\nor by direct contact with infected animals and animal carcasses. The woman was\ninfected in Mainland China.\nA human case of brucellosis\n----------------------------\nIn late Oct 2004, CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch (PHLSB)\nconfirmed a case of human brucellosis. The patient was a 34-year-old\nhousewife, who suffered from recurrent headache and fever since mid Sep\n2004. She was admitted to a hospital on 7 Oct 2004 because of pyrexia of\nunknown origin without other focal symptoms or signs. Blood tests were\ngrossly normal except for liver derangement (ALT 280). Blood culture\nyielded slow-growing Gram-negative coccobacilli, which was later identified\nas _Brucella_ species in PHLSB, with species identification result\npending. 'The situation is stark.'\nBrucellosis is an infectious disease caused by bacteria of the genus\n_Brucella_. These bacteria are spread primarily among animals, including\nsheep, goats, cattle, deer, pigs and dogs. Humans become infected by coming\nin contact with animals, or animal products, that are contaminated with\nthese bacteria.\nIn humans, brucellosis can cause a range of symptoms similar to influenza\nand may include fever, headache, back pain, and physical weakness. Severe\ninfections of the central nervous systems or lining of the heart may occur.\nBrucellosis can also cause long-lasting or chronic symptoms that include\nrecurrent fever, joint pain, and fatigue.\nThe Ministry of Health noted that it has issued a notice, together with the\nMinistry of Agriculture, ordering local health and agricultural departments\nto take rigorous quarantine and disinfecting measures, and, to conduct\nstrict animal culls on sick livestock to halt the spread of the disease.\nThe 2 ministries asked local agencies to improve health education to raise\npeople's awareness of the disease, the Ministry of Health said. Meanwhile,\nthe Ministry of Health said the 2 ministries also asked local agencies to\nenforce efforts in disease monitoring.\n'The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Agriculture will readjust and\nincrease the key national monitoring posts according to the development of\nthe epidemic,' the Ministry of Health said.\nLocal health institutions were asked to cooperate with agricultural\ndepartments closely, and to report disease information immediately, the\nHealth Ministry said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is given regarding the manifestations of brucellosis in the\ncases or how the diagnosis was made, by culture, by serology, or just\nempirically.\nBrucellosis is considered to be a Category B bioterrorism agent which is,\nin nature, acquired as a zoonotic infection by humans. Its manifestations\nare protean, including undulant fever, with positive blood and/or bone\nmarrow cultures, and it is a cause of localized disease in many organ\nsystems including skeletal, urinary tract, central nervous system, liver,\ncardiac and lung. The reader is referred to Young EJ. Human brucellosis.\nRev Infect Dis 1983;5:821-839 for a review of these manifestations. - Mod.LL]\n[China's (annual) reports to the OIE related to the brucellosis situation\nthere are available only for 1999 (_B. suis_ and _B. abortus_ 'present', no\n_B. melitensis_ reported) and 2002. The latter report says 'no cases.'\nHowever, a recent detailed review, 'Epidemiology and control of brucellosis\nin China,' was published in December 2002 by Shang Deqiu, Xiao Donglou and\nYin Jiming (Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology, Chinese Academy of\nPreventive Medicine, Beijing) in Veterinary Microbiology 90, 1-4, pp\n165-182. Based on the analysis of 3425 _Brucella_ strains isolated from\nhumans and animals in 21 provinces, the data revealed 73.79 percent\ninfected with _B. melitensis_, 13.64 percent infected with _B. abortus_,\n5.78 percent infected with _B. suis_, 0.05 percent infected with _B. ovis_\n(which is generally not regarded as zoonotic!), and 6.70 percent infected\nwith atypical _Brucella_ strains. For the entire country, _B. melitensis_\nwas the predominant strain associated with outbreaks, but there were some\ndifferences from province to province, for example _B. suis_ in Guangxi and\n_B. abortus_ in Sichuan were the predominant strains isolated. They say that feedgrounds help spread the disease from\nelk to livestock.\nA 19-member task force, appointed by Gov. Dave Freudenthal, is studying the\nfeedground issue, and, could recommend changes later in 2004.\nElk have been known to overrun cattle pasture near feedgrounds. But, the feedground, which provided the animals with hay and\nalfalfa, was designed for just 300 elk. The elk began spilling over into\nneighboring pastures, damaging fences and consuming haystacks and crops.\nFear said it got so bad that on some mornings, elk outnumbered cattle 3 to\n1. 'It was a mess,' he said.\nBrucellosis was discovered in cattle in the Boulder area in November\n[2003]. There's the drought that's occurring,\nand now, we have a brucellosis outbreak,' said Cathy Purves, acting\ndirector of the Wyoming Wildlife Federation.
