The team will supplement and\nsupport the existing local epidemiological investigation team that has been\nworking on the outbreak since it was first disclosed in March 2004.\nDefra today announced the lifting of the final movement restrictions on\nneighbouring holdings in Cornwall after the last tests on a batch of cows\nin the south east of the county were found to be negative.\nThe premises of origin of the reactor bull -- suspected as the source of\nthe outbreak -- have been tested, with negative results.\nThe specialist group will liaise closely with the State Veterinary Service\nand will look at the history of the herd breakdown, the full tracing\nresults and imports.\nDr Reynolds said it was vital that no stone was left unturned in attempting\nto find the source of the outbreak following the 1st confirmed case of\nbrucellosis in England since 1993.\n'While we are delighted to be able to remove the movement restrictions\nimposed on neighbouring holdings, the backward and forward tracings of\nanimals that left the infected herd have not revealed the source of the\noutbreak. The small epidemiological team will look at the brucellosis\ntesting history of the infected herd, the relationship between cows, bulls,\nand youngstock, cattle movements on and off over the past 2 years, any\nknown unrecorded cattle movements, the herd's breeding programme, and any\nunusual mixing of livestock.\n'We are also continuing to look at imports of stock into Devon and Cornwall\nover the past 3 years,' she added.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In ProMED-mail's initial posting on the brucellosis outbreak in Cornwall\n(20040319.0761), DEFRA informed the detection of 5 'reactors' in a 35-cow\nherd, near Liskeard; it further stated: '[the herd] has been under\nrestriction since unexplained abortions were reported in the herd earlier\nin March 2004. Further serological results are expected from the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, Weybridge, very shortly. The 5 reactors will be culled\nand if the laboratory culture results are positive, the whole herd will be\nslaughtered'.\nSince the news release above does not include information on the mentioned\nlaboratory culture results, ProMED-mail contacted DEFRA for clarifications.\nThe following information has been immediately received from Dr Alick\nSimmons, Head of Veterinary Endemic Diseases and Zoonoses Division, Animal\nHealth and Welfare Directorate General, DEFRA:\n'The whole herd was slaughtered on the strength of a _Brucella abortus_\nbiovar 1 isolate from one of the aborting cows. 3 other cows aborted with\nculture positive vaginal swabs or foetal stomach contents. Culture results\nare awaited from the remainder of the slaughtered animals including the bull.\nThe confusion might arise from the fact that we slaughtered the 4 cows and\na bull as reactors before we confirmed infection. That is quite normal and\nin accordance with practice: we slaughter some 30 CFT and ELISA reactors\nper year, which after slaughter turn out to be false-positive,\nculture-negative reactors.\nThe bull in question was traced back to its herd of origin and that herd\nwas restricted and tested. During 2002, 452 outbreaks (in animals, mostly goats)\nhave been reported. Tourists to this part of the world should be aware of\nthe risks associated with the consumption of (unpasteurized) dairy\nproducts. -Mod.AS]\n[This infection, a bacterial zoonosis, is classified among the category B\nbiowarfare agents. Natural transmission to humans occurs after\noccupational exposure or through ingestion of contaminated food\nproducts. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries.\nEach species of Brucella has a specific animal reservoir in which chronic\ndisease is present. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid.\nThis localization allows for efficient spread to farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and consumers.\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that\nis indistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries. Among the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid. Aborted fetuses,\nplacental membranes or fluids, and other vaginal discharges present after\nan infected animal has aborted or calved are all highly contaminated with\ninfectious brucella organisms.\nCattle, bison, and cervids are susceptible to _B. abortus_. Other\n_Brucella_ species affect other animals. The animals experience a loss of\nproduction (including abortion of the fetus), a drop in milk production,\nweight loss, infertility, and lameness. This information has not been made public due to an attempt of a\ncheese producer, in Wadi el-Arayesh, to conceal the incident.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella melitensis_, the causative agent of brucellosis in sheep and\ngoats, and, of Malta fever in humans, is endemic throughout all countries\nin the Mediterranean basin. Now, the samples have been\ntested and it's time to find out who stays, who dies, and who gets a shot\nof vaccine.\nRick Wallen, a Yellowstone wildlife biologist, emerged from a trailer with\na clipboard and climbed onto the grated walkways overlooking the holding\npens and chutes. As 2 bison moved into the chute below, a crew member\ncalled out the 4-digit number on the sticker affixed to the bison's hides.\nWallen checked his clipboard and found both tested positive for exposure to\nbrucellosis. 'Ship,' he said.\nThe news was relayed by hand signals -- an unmistakable thumbs down -- and\nthe bison were herded toward a pen where they would be sent to slaughter\nthe next morning.\nNext up was a yearling bison skittering wide-eyed through the chute.\n'Keep,' Wallen announced after checking his notes.\nThe bison, soon clamped into a narrow passageway, was the first that day to\nget a syringe full of RB51, a vaccine designed to protect animals from\nbrucellosis.\nThroughout the afternoon, bison were sorted, some were vaccinated, and\nabout half that tested negative were slated for slaughter. At times the\ncapture facility, where several of the animals had red gouges from tussles\nwith their pen-mates, seemed more like a domestic cattle operation than a\nplace for Yellowstone's iconic wild bison.\nThe Stephens Creek bison pen, tucked behind a locked gate and down a gravel\nroad, has been a busy place the last 2 months. So far in 2004, 464 of\nYellowstone's estimated 4200 bison have been captured. Of those, 264 have\nbeen taken to slaughter, and 198 are being held until food conditions\nimprove in Yellowstone.\nThe activity -- hazing and capturing bison that might leave Yellowstone --\nis nothing new. What's new is a push to vaccinate some of the bison that\nare captured. [Some readers may not be familiar with this type of 'hazing,'\nwhich means driving the animals from horseback. - CopyEd.PG]\nState and federal officials believe that the vaccinations can reduce the\nrisk of transmitting brucellosis from the park's bison to cattle outside\nthe boundaries.\nAt the beginning of 2004, Yellowstone officials began giving shots to bison\ncalves and yearlings that had already tested negative for exposure to\nbrucellosis. About 111 have received the vaccine so far.\nThe vaccination program is expected to continue into 2005 at the north end\nof the park. Also, Montana Department of Livestock officials are preparing\nto conduct a study about whether a similar program should be started for\nbison that leave Yellowstone's western boundary.\nThe effectiveness of the vaccination on bison, though, is unclear. In one\ncontrolled test, RB51 was able to help 60 percent of vaccinated calves fend\noff _Brucella_ bacteria. Elsewhere, though, the success rate isn't as good.\n'So far there is no consensus on efficacy. Some indications of protection\nhave been found in some studies; others have failed to find any\nprotection,' said a 2002 paper on RB51 bison vaccine written by 2\nscientists from the U.S. Geological Survey and the U.S. Department of\nAgriculture.\nYellowstone officials in the mid-1960s tried a version of the capture,\ntest, slaughter and/or vaccinate program but soon scrapped it.\n'These efforts were reviewed by park management and determined to be\nineffective and 'never-ending,' ' according to background information in\nthe current Interagency Bison Management Plan.\nWallen said RB51 is a better option than a predecessor, known as Strain 19,\nbut uncertainties about RB51 remain.\nPark officials put ear tags on the vaccinated bison this year and will test\ntheir exposure to brucellosis if the bison are captured again. That's the\nbest plan so far, Wallen said, but technological advances could improve the\nprogram.\n'There are a lot of different things happening in the world of vaccines,\nsome very promising studies using DNA,' Wallen said.\nThe Department of Livestock also wants to study how a vaccination program\nmight work on the west side of Yellowstone, where bison often wander out\nduring the winter.\n'The goal is to increase overall herd immunity and try to prevent infection\nwithin the herd,' said Karen Cooper, a Department of Livestock spokeswoman,\nadding that the state and federal plan is aimed at protecting cattle from\nbrucellosis while maintaining a wild bison herd.\nBut Ted Fellman with the Buffalo Field Campaign, a group fighting against\nthe bison hazing and capturing program, said the vaccination program is a\nshort-sighted way to deal with a 'problem that doesn't exist.'\n'By vaccinating them and holding them in captivity and ear-tagging them --\nit's turning the wildlife of Yellowstone into livestock,' Fellman said.\n'It's appalling that the Park Service would treat them that way.'\nIt probably was cattle that first spread brucellosis to Yellowstone's bison.\nCows came to the park with people who lived and worked at Yellowstone. At\nBuffalo Ranch in the Lamar Valley, bison probably came in contact with\ninfectious aborted material left behind by cattle, according to Mary\nMeagher, a former Park Service scientist who researched the origins of the\ndisease in Yellowstone.\nBrucellosis was first diagnosed in the Yellowstone bison in 1917.\n'It pretty well comes back to the Buffalo Ranch,' said Meagher, who retired\nin 1997.\nOver the years, the bison population fluctuated, but concerns over\nbrucellosis remained. Nearby ranchers were especially worried that the\ncontagious disease, which can cause abortions and other problems, would\ninfect cattle herds outside Yellowstone.\nIn Montana, livestock officials remain concerned that the bison could cause\nthe loss of the state's brucellosis-free status, which would mean increased\nmeasures and costs for shipping cattle across state lines.\nA plan approved in 2000 by Montana and federal agencies, including the Park\nService, allows bison that leave the park -- or, on the north end, appear\nto be headed for the border -- to be hazed, captured, tested, and sometimes\nsent to slaughter.\nLast year, 231 were killed after being captured on Yellowstone's northern\nend. More than 1000 were sent to slaughter in the winter of 1996-97.\nEarlier in the winter of 2003-2004, park officials estimated there were a\nrecord 4200 bison in Yellowstone. But in mid-February 2004, the fluffy snow\non the park's northern range became packed and hard. That makes it more\ndifficult for bison to get to the food below, so they migrate north in\nsearch of lower elevations and more to eat.\nOver the course of several weeks, hundreds of bison were taken to the\nStephens Creek facility. About half tested negative for exposure to\nbrucellosis and will be held in a pasture until later this spring.\nWhile much of the focus is on the bison captured on the northern end,\nWallen said it's easy to forget about the other thousands of bison in\nYellowstone's interior.\n'Even though we handled some 460 animals, there are still over 3500 that we\nhaven't touched on the landscape. That's twice what was there 20 years\nago,' Wallen said.\nEventually, the vaccination program could lead to a more hands-off approach\nto bison, or at least an expansion of their range, Wallen said.\n'We're trying to develop a program so that the (Montana) state veterinarian\nhas a greater confidence that there'll be no exposure risk to livestock\nhe's charged to protect,' Wallen said.\nFor now, though, the vaccinated animals aren't given a free pass to wander\noutside Yellowstone and the prospect of claiming that there's no risk of\nbison transmitting the disease to cattle is slim.\n'It's not zero right now,' Wallen said. 'It may never be zero.'\nBy the numbers:\nThe winter of 2003-04 has been a busy one for crews trying to keep bison\nfrom leaving the northern end of Yellowstone National Park. A look at the\nnumbers so far this year:\n464 captured at the Stephens Creek pen and pasture -- 264 sent to slaughter\n198 being held for release later this spring\n1 bison died in captivity\n1 bull bison shot\n111 or 113 calves and yearlings vaccinated\n4200 estimated in Yellowstone at the beginning of the winter\n[Byline: Mike Stark]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A look at the\nnumbers so far this year:\n464 captured at the Stephens Creek pen and pasture -- 264 sent to slaughter\n198 being held for release later this spring\n1 bison died in captivity\n1 bull bison shot\n111 or 113 calves and yearlings vaccinated\n4200 estimated in Yellowstone at the beginning of the winter\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Some indications of protection\nhave been found in some studies; others have failed to find any\nprotection,' said a 2002 paper on RB51 bison vaccine written by 2\nscientists from the U.S. Geological Survey and the U.S. Department of\nAgriculture. Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 18 Mar 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Scotsman, 18 Mar 2004 [edited]\n<http://news.scotsman.com/latest.cfm?id=2666325>\n\nFarms' Movements Restricted Amid Brucellosis Fears\n-----------------------------------------------------\nMovement restrictions have been placed on 8 neighbouring farms after\nan outbreak of a 'serious' cattle disease, it was announced today.\nPreliminary tests have shown that 6 animals from a 38-strong beef\nsuckler herd, near Liskeard, Cornwall, may have brucellosis, which\ncauses abortions in cattle.\nThe Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs [DEFRA]\ndescribed the move as 'precautionary'.\nBrucellosis is caused by infection with the bacterium _Brucella\nabortus_, but it can also cause a disease of humans known as undulant\nfever.\nDefra said while the disease was 'serious, it is not nearly as\nserious as foot and mouth disease,' which crippled the industry 3\nyears ago.\n[Byline: Helen William]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu, 18 Mar 2004\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Defra News Release, 18 Mar 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/news/2004/040318b.htm>\n\nDefra Confirms Brucellosis on Farm in Cornwall;\nMovement Restrictions on 7 Neighbouring Farms\n---------------------------------------------------\nDefra has imposed movement restrictions on 7 neighbouring livestock\nholdings in South East Cornwall following an outbreak of brucellosis\nin a beef suckler herd.\nPreliminary test results have shown that 5 animals in the single herd\nhave the notifiable disease, which causes abortions in cattle. The\n35-cow herd, near Liskeard, has been under restriction since\nunexplained abortions were reported in the herd earlier in March 2004.\nFurther serological results are expected from the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, Weybridge, very shortly. The 5 reactors will be\nculled and if the laboratory culture results are positive, the whole\nherd will be slaughtered.\nState Veterinary Service vets are currently undertaking forward\ntracings of animals that have left the suckler unit, although\nevidence so far suggests that the overwhelming majority of animals\nhave gone to slaughter.\nFarmers are reminded of their statutory requirement to notify\nabortions in cattle immediately to Defra.\nThe neighbouring herds have been placed under movement restrictions\nwhile blood tests take place. Milk tests from neighbouring dairy\nfarms show no evidence that the disease is currently present.\nWildlife can spread disease by moving infected afterbirth to\nneighbouring farms, but it is normally spread by cattle-to-cattle\ncontact. While the disease is economically serious, it does not carry\nthe same implications as Foot and Mouth Disease. The Food Standards\nAgency advise that whilst it is possible to catch the disease by\ndrinking infected unpasteurised milk or dairy products, this rarely\nhappens in the UK and the risk is very small. The risk from meat\nproducts is even smaller.\nChief Veterinary Officer Jim Scudamore said that Great Britain has\nofficial brucella-free status. There were 2 cases during 2003 in\nScotland which were linked with imported consignments from the\nRepublic of Ireland.\nMr Scudamore said it was vital for all livestock farmers,\nparticularly in Cornwall, to report all abortions in cattle to their\nlocal Animal Health Divisional Office. Further investigations into\nthe source of the outbreak are continuing.\nNotes for editors\n1. Brucellosis of cattle is caused by infection with the bacterium\n_Brucella abortus_, which can also cause a disease of humans known as\nundulant fever. This used to be a major problem for farmers and vets.\nA full question-and-answer brief is available from the Health\nProtection Agency\n(<http://www.hpa.org.uk/infections/topics_az/zoonoses/brucellosis/menu.htm>).\nIn cattle, it causes abortion or premature calving of recently\ninfected animals; the foetus, placenta and uterine fluid contain\nlarge quantities of _Brucella abortus_ bacteria, which can affect\nother cattle coming into contact with an infected animal around the\ntime of calving. The organism continues to be excreted in the milk;\nin the past humans were frequently infected through drinking\nunpasteurised milk.\n2. Great Britain gained formal recognition as a region of the\nEuropean Union with Official Brucellosis-Free Status in 1991. OBF\nstatus is not necessarily compromised by occasional outbreaks [see\ncomment].\n3. Animals will be slaughtered under the Animal Health Act 1981. On\nthe farm, there are 35 cows and 96 other cattle (including bulls and\nyoung stock). All susceptible animals on the farm will be slaughtered\nfollowing veterinary assessment.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella abortus_ had not been isolated from any premises in Great\nBritain since October 1993 until its confirmation on 4 premises in\nScotland during early 2003. An additional, unrelated case was\nidentified later (2 Dec 2003) in a Scottish beef herd when\npost-import blood testing was undertaken on a heifer imported from\nthe Republic of Ireland.\n<http://www.scotland.gov.uk/pages/news/2003/12/SEEN721a.aspx>\nAccording to article 2.3.1.2. of OIE's terrestrial animal health\ncode, a Country or zone shall satisfy the following requirements to\nqualify free from bovine brucellosis:\n1) bovine brucellosis or any suspicion thereof is notifiable;\n2) the entire cattle population is under official veterinary control\nand it has been ascertained that the rate of brucellosis infection\ndoes not exceed 0.2 percent of the cattle herds in the country or\nzone under consideration;\n3) the serological tests for bovine brucellosis are periodically\nconducted in each herd, with or without the ring test;\n4) no animal has been vaccinated against bovine brucellosis for at\nleast the past 3 years;\n5) all reactors are slaughtered;\n6) animals introduced into a free country or zone shall only come\nfrom herds officially free from bovine brucellosis or from herds free\nfrom bovine brucellosis. This condition may be waived for animals\nwhich have not been vaccinated and which, prior to entry into the\nherd, were isolated and were subjected to the serological tests for\nbovine brucellosis with negative results on 2 occasions, with an\ninterval of 30 days between each test. These tests are not considered\nvalid in female animals which have calved during the past 14 days.\nIn a country where all herds of cattle have qualified as officially\nfree from bovine brucellosis and where no reactor has been found for\nthe past 5 years, the system for further control may be decided by\nthe country concerned. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "According to article 2.3.1.2. of OIE's terrestrial animal health\ncode, a Country or zone shall satisfy the following requirements to\nqualify free from bovine brucellosis:\n1) bovine brucellosis or any suspicion thereof is notifiable;\n2) the entire cattle population is under official veterinary control\nand it has been ascertained that the rate of brucellosis infection\ndoes not exceed 0.2 percent of the cattle herds in the country or\nzone under consideration;\n3) the serological tests for bovine brucellosis are periodically\nconducted in each herd, with or without the ring test;\n4) no animal has been vaccinated against bovine brucellosis for at\nleast the past 3 years;\n5) all reactors are slaughtered;\n6) animals introduced into a free country or zone shall only come\nfrom herds officially free from bovine brucellosis or from herds free\nfrom bovine brucellosis. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. In Spain, the disease\ncurrently affects goats and sheep -- bovines are usually free of the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Following is the historical series of the reportable diseases section of\nthe Spanish National Epidemiology Center, regarding the incidence of human\nbrucellosis in Andalusia: 1997 (589), 1998 (476), 1999 (691), 2000 (498),\n2001 (441), and 2002 (428). About 900 cattle at 10 farms were slaughtered at that time.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Brucellosis is endemic in Korea; 110 outbreaks have been reported\nduring 2002, the last year for which Brucellosis data are available\non the OIE web-site. The cattle have\nbeen replaced through federal support.\nSince the purging of the contaminated ranch -- more than 3000 head of\ncattle, close to 80 percent -- it is expected that the southern part of the\nstate will be free of both diseases by September 2003.\nJesus Osuna Carrasco, president of the Mazatlan Breeders' Association, was\ninformed that the owner has received a federal subsidy for each animal\nsacrificed, so that he may keep the ranch and the breeders may continue\nworking.\nThe most affected communities in Mazatlan are El Quelite, El Habla, and\nEscamillas, where the main dairy and beef farms are located. Breeders in\nthis area have expressed their concern because the daily requirement for\nsupplying the local markets is at least 100 000 liters of milk.\nOsuna stated that several months ago it was made public that approximately\n1000 head of cattle were contaminated, but that due to the lack of\nresources and support, little had been done to combat the problem,\nresulting in the propagation of the disease and the increasing desperation\nof the breeders.\nOsuna added that because of the region's humid climate, it is common for\nbovine tuberculosis to increase during the rainy season. He further\nexplained that tuberculosis is a fatal disease for cattle and that the\naffected animals must be sacrificed in order to avoid contagion. Signs in\nthe animals include cough and high fever.\nThe contaminated meat is apt for human consumption, since cooking it at\nhigh temperatures destroys the bacteria. Nonetheless, veterinarians at the\nmunicipal slaughterhouse are ensuring that no contaminated animals are\nslaughtered and their meat and byproducts sold.\n90 head of cattle are sacrificed daily at the municipal slaughterhouse, and\ntheir products are inspected to ensure that they are fit for human\nconsumption. Osuna stated that the 2500 head of infected cattle were culled\nat the municipal slaughterhouse.\nJorge Guillermo Felix, president of the Sinaloa Breeders' Union, stated\nthat the state and federal governments have created a fund to control the\nproblem and to provide support to the breeders from now until the end of 2003.\nFelix announced that, for the time being, there are no quarantined ranches\nin the region, but that the possibility of imposing quarantine measures at\nany moment has not been discarded. He called on society and the owners of\ncattle ranches not to be alarmed, since there are medical personnel at the\nslaughterhouses examining every animal and ensuring that there is no risk\nfor humans.\nFelix assured the breeders that support would be provided, but that it is\nimportant that they collaborate in the effort to produce healthy cattle,\nwhich will open the doors to exports of feeder cattle to the United States.\nHe further stated that there is also no risk regarding the consumption of\nmilk, because most of it is sold to pasteurizing plants where the absence\nof contamination is ensured. [Brucellosis can be passed through\nunpasteurized milk. The statement says that most of it is sold to\npasteurizing plants. 'Most' is not 'all.' \u00ad Mod.TG]\nFinally, Felix explained that the cattle have a metallic ring used for\ncontrol and for identification, so that if an animal becomes ill, it is\npossible to determine its provenance immediately.\n[Byline: Yovana Gaxiola Aldana]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Bovine tuberculosis is a chronic bacterial disease caused by the\nacid-fast, slow-growing rod-shaped _Mycobacterium bovis_; transmission to\nhumans constitutes a public health problem.\n[Bovine] tuberculosis (TB) can produce internal lesions in animals.\n[Bovine] TB can be spread within a herd when an infected animal coughs,\nreleasing bacteria-laden mucus onto feed that is consumed, or into the air\nthat is inhaled by nearby cows.\nAerosol exposure to _M. bovis_ is considered to be the most frequent route\nof infection of cattle, but infection by ingestion of contaminated material\nalso occurs. Characteristic tuberculous lesions occur most frequently in\nthe lungs and the retropharyngeal, bronchial, and mediastinal lymph nodes.\nLesions can also be found in the mesenteric lymph nodes, liver, spleen, on\nserous membranes, and in other organs. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 5 Aug 2003 11:29:41 +0100\n Osuna stated that several months ago it was made public that approximately\n1000 head of cattle were contaminated, but that due to the lack of\nresources and support, little had been done to combat the problem,\nresulting in the propagation of the disease and the increasing desperation\nof the breeders. Finally, Felix explained that the cattle have a metallic ring used for\ncontrol and for identification, so that if an animal becomes ill, it is\npossible to determine its provenance immediately.\n [Byline: Yovana Gaxiola Aldana]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Since the purging of the contaminated ranch -- more than 3000 head of\ncattle, close to 80 percent -- it is expected that the southern part of the\nstate will be free of both diseases by September 2003. Brucellosis has been spreading in\nthe western province since early September 2003. The bacteria are usually\npassed among animals such as goats and cattle. Humans can be infected\nthrough contact with the animals or by consuming their contaminated products.\nLocal veterinarian Manaschai Watanakul said infected animals would suffer\nmiscarriages, while infected humans would suffer flu symptoms such as high\ntemperature, headache, pain in the joints, and loss of weight.\nHe said livestock officials found 256 infected goats on 10 farms in Suan\nPhung district. The animals were killed and buried on Monday and their\nowners compensated. Thousands of goats are raised in Ratchaburi, mostly in\nSuan Phung and Muang districts, and Ban Kha sub-district.\nDr Jaruthas Narischart, Ratchaburi public health chief, said the infection\nwas confirmed in 2 patients while 40 others were under observation. The\ndisease can be fatal if complications are not adequately treated.\nBlood samples from over 3000 goats in Ratchaburi had been sent to\nlaboratories in Bangkok for tests, he said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Caprine brucellosis is usually _B. melitensis_, which is a significant\nhuman zoonotic disease and can carry case fatality rates of around 30\npercent. One of its more unpleasant aspects is its capacity to induce\nflorid psychotic periods in humans during convalescence. It was a major\nsource of illness among the Allies during the World War II fighting in\nItaly. This is not a disease to regard lightly.\nChecking the OIE statistics, Thailand has not reported this B-class disease\nin its goats. However, they have reported sporadic _B. abortus_ outbreaks\nin cattle in 2001, 1997, and 1996. Various caprine vaccines are available,\nand a new 'RB' vaccine for melitensis is in development and has been\nundergoing field trials in Argentina. When it will be available elsewhere I\nam unsure, but it looks to be as successful as the RB51 vaccine. - Mod.MHJ]\n[Brucellosis is another zoonotic infection that can be spread not only by\ndirect contact with the animal carrier but also by the ingestion of\nunpasteurized dairy products such as milk and cheese. The infection is\nalso known as undulant fever, related to the occurrence of 1-3 week febrile\nperiods separated by 1-3 days of afebrility. This occurs more likely with\n_B. melitensis_ (acquired from goats) as compared to _B. abortus_ (cattle)\nand _B. suis_ (swine).\nThe infection can be subclinical. Acute symptomatic brucellosis is\ngenerally manifest with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, chills, night\nsweats, anorexia, and an increased sense of ill health. The disease can be\ndiagnosed serologically and/or by blood culture. The organism may grow\nquite slowly on primary isolation, and the clinician should make the\nmicrobiology laboratory aware of this potential diagnosis. Localized\ninfection may occur. Sites for localization include the skeletal system\n(1), heart valves (2) and urinary tract (3). GU brucellosis may present\nidentically to GU tuberculosis.\nAs noted by Moderator MHJ, psychiatric manifestations such as depression\nand anxiety are possible as late symptoms of brucellosis (4,5), so-called\nchronic neurobrucellosis. It remains unclear whether active brucella\ninfection is present at that time. Overt CNS infection can, however,\ninclude meningitis and encephalitis (6,7).\n1. Mousa ARM, Muhtaseb SA, Almudallal DS, et al,. Osteoarticular\ncomplications of brucellosis: a study of 169 cases. Rev Infect Dis\n1987;9:531-43.\n2. Al-Kasab S, Al-Fagih MR, Al-Yousef S, et al. Brucella infective\nendocarditis. J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 1988;95:862-67.\n3. Kelalis PP, Greene LF, Weed LA. Brucellosis of the urogenital tract: a\nmimic of tuberculosis. J Urol 1962;88:347-53.\n4. Lulu AR, Araj GF, Khateeb MI, et al: Human brucellosis in Kuwait: a\nprospective study of 400 cases. Q J Med 1988;66:39-54.\n5. Annesley PT. Schizophreniform psychosis with chronic brucellosis. Brit J\nPsych 1968;114:353-54.\n6. Mousa ARM, Koshy TS, Araj GF, et al. Brucella meninigitis: presentation,\ndiagnosis and treatment. Q J Med 1986;60:873-85.\n7. Fineham RW, Sahs AL, Joynt RJ. Protean manifestations of nervous system\nbrucellosis. over 6300 in 1988; 5958 in 1992; 2699 in\n1995; 3362 in 1996; 3387 in 1997; 3502 in 1998; 2669 in 1999; 2129 in 2000;\n2826 in 2001; 2802 in 2002.\n163 fatal cases were reported during 1978 to 1982. Mortality rates were\n0.04/100 000 in 1992; 0.01/100 000 in 1996 .\nThe caprine seropositivity rate was 20.7 percent in 1947.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to OIE's data on Bovine brucellosis, Mexico reported during\nrecent years the following numbers of outbreaks: 1997 (5225), 1998 (5152),\n1999 (3932), 2000 (4582), 2001 (5304). The numbers of outbreaks of Caprine\nand Ovine Brucellosis (excluding _B. ovis_), which might be significantly\nrelated to human brucellosis, were the following: 1997 (552), 1998 (521),\n1999 (2147), 2000 (1550), 2001 (1301). Pending confirmation of\nfunding, a brucellosis control programme in high risk districts will be\ninitiated in 2003 by FAO in Tajikistan and monitored by the Government\nveterinary and public health units in order to reduce the disease incidence\nin animals and humans.\n\nAn epidemiologically sound and agreed control programme is needed if the\nincidence of brucellosis in animals and humans is to be effectively reduced.\nNot all districts can be covered; therefore the number of districts addressed\nin such a programme must be determined by known brucellosis prevalence.\n\nDetermining which districts are at highest risk is therefore the objective of\nthe current Brucellosis Survey. Texas and Missouri are the only\nstates in the nation not free from this bacterial disease.\n'We are closing in on the last infected herds in Texas, and after months of\nnot finding infection, we were hopeful we might have finally eradicated the\ndisease,' commented Dr. Max Coats, deputy director for Animal Health\nPrograms at the Texas Animal Health Commission (TAHC). 'With more than 153\n000 cattle herds in Texas, finding the last infected herds is like looking\nfor the proverbial 'needle in the haystack.' We still may find a few more\ninfected herds in Texas before we join the ranks of the other\nbrucellosis-free states in this national disease eradication program.'\n'Twice now, we've gone longer than a year without finding a\nbrucellosis-infected herd in Texas,' said Dr. Coats. 'The first time was\nfrom July 2000 through December 2001, but soon after, we detected and\ndepopulated 4 infected herds in Montgomery, Rusk, Henderson, and Colorado\nCounties. Then, after a lull of more than a year, we detected the latest\ninfected herd, in Henderson County, through our routine testing of adult\nbreeding cattle being sold at livestock markets. We're in the process of\ntesting neighboring herds and tracing cattle movement into and out of the\nHenderson County herd to determine if infection has spread.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[With such a large number of herds in the state, such disappointments are\n-- unfortunately -- to be expected. According to the local Sunday Mail newspaper, the\nCypriot government is forced to slaughter the animals, as at least 25 per\ncent of the herd have been found to carry brucella.\nOver the past 3 to 4 years, cases of brucellosis have been on the rise in\nthe island. State vets attributed the worsening situation to uncontrollable\nlivestock trading between Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot farmers. They\nsaid many of the traders were transporting animals from one area to another\nwithout first receiving veterinary services approval or a clean bill of\nhealth for the animals, an illegal practice.\nBrucellosis causes abortion in cattle and livestock. In Texas, the\noverwhelming majority (in the 1990s, upwards of 90 per cent) of human\nbrucellosis cases (30 to 50 annually) resulted from the consumption of\nunpasteurized goat-milk cheese made in Mexico [undoubtedly - Mod.LL] from\nthe milk of _Brucella melitensis_-infected goats. And of course, humans can\nbe infected by handling recently aborted animals, fetuses, and afterbirths;\nfarmers and vets are at particular risk of this.\nOut of interest, if 25 per cent of the national herd is seropositive, will\nkilling 4000 cattle make that much impact? As stated above,\nmilk products can, if not adequately pasteurized, transmit the infection to\nman. In this regard, _B. melitensis_ may be spread more readily by the oral\nroute, as it is less effectively killed by low gastric pH (1).\nMeat from infected animals is rarely the vehicle for infection to man, as\nit is usually cooked and has only a low organism burden (2). A low risk,\nhowever, is not no risk.\nBrucellosis is an occupational disease of farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and microbiology laboratory staff through direct or\nindirect contact with the animals or their secretions via abrasions or cuts\nin the skin or via the conjunctiva.\n1. UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203403", "date": "2003-02-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - UK\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 21 Feb 2003\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSubject: The Glasgow Herald, UK, 21 Feb 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/archive/21-2-19103-0-41-27.html>\n\nFresh blow for farming industry with outbreak of brucellosis\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe farming industry faced another major problem yesterday after bovine\nbrucellosis was confirmed in a Scottish herd for the first time in 30 years.\nBrucellosis, a highly contagious bacterial disease which can be transferred\nto humans, was discovered in 2 imported cattle from the Republic of Ireland\nat a farm in Forfar. If unchecked, the infection can cut a herd's\nproductivity, causing heifers to abort and trigger undulant fever, a\nchronic debilitating disease in humans.\nThe British mainland was believed to have eradicated the disease, with the\nlast case in Scotland reported in the 1970s.\nThe disease at Forfar was identified following the abortion of a cattle\nfoetus. The animals had been under restriction since 11 Feb 2003, and\nsurveillance and testing will continue to ensure that the outbreak has been\neradicated.\nThe farm at the centre of the scare is a mixed beef and sheep enterprise\nwhich does not sell milk. Any risk to humans is through direct contact with\nthe aborted animal.\nFarmers were advised to exercise great care in planning the purchase of\nlivestock when re-stocking herds and were reminded by the Scottish\nExecutive that by law, they must report all bovine abortions and premature\ncalvings to the local Animal Health Office.\nA statement said: 'Contact with infected discharges provides the route of\ninfection through beef cattle. The only humans at possible risk are those\nin direct contact with livestock who are well aware of the known\noccupational hazards. Symptoms can include recurrent or chronic fever.\nThere is no risk from pasteurised milk, cooked meat, or contact with\npasteurised animal products. The local public health department has been\ninformed.'\nIn England, the Department for the Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs,\nsaid last night that 3 other animals at a farm near Middlesbrough were to\nbe culled because they came from a Northern Irish herd which had been shown\nto have brucellosis.\nThe announcement by Jim Scudamore, the chief veterinary officer, will\nconcern farmers still struggling to recover from the outbreak of\nfoot-and-mouth disease and BSE.\n[Byline: Stephen Stewart]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Bovine brucellosis is usually caused by _Brucella abortus_, less\nfrequently by _B. melitensis_, and rarely by _B. suis_. It is manifested by\nabortion, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in\nmilk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion\nmaterial, udder secretions, or tissues removed at post-mortem.\nAlternatively, specific cell-mediated or serological responses to Brucella\nantigens can be demonstrated. All Brucella species are pathogenic for humans.\nThe only organism involved in outbreaks of Bovine Brucellosis in Northern\nEurope is _B. abortus_; Southern European countries are affected by _B.\nmelitensis_ as well. The last outbreak of Bovine Brucellosis was recorded\nin the UK in 1993. In 1997, 13 cattle were compulsorily slaughtered as\nreactors to serological tests, and a further 3 animals as contacts -- but\nno infection with _Brucella sp._ was detected in laboratory investigations\nin any of these cattle.\nThe Republic of Ireland has a high incidence of bovine Brucellosis, though\nsome decrease has been observed in recent years. During the 4 years\n1998-2001, the number of outbreaks there was 1081, 875, 659, and 553,\nrespectively. As reported to the OIE, 24 233 head were compulsorily\nslaughtered in infected farms during 2001.\n<http://www.oie.int/hs2/sit_pays_mald_pl.asp?c_pays=89&c_mald=33>\nIt remains to note the exact origin of the animals imported to Scotland\nfrom Ireland and which -- if any -- certification accompanied them.\nAccording to the provisions of OIE's International Animal Health Code, a\ncountry may be regarded as free of Bovine Brucellosis if its entire cattle\npopulation is under official veterinary control, it has been ascertained\nthat the rate of brucellosis infection does not exceed 0.2 percent of the\ncattle herds, vaccination is not allowed, and prescribed surveillance is\noperational. The current reported outbreak does not change UK's status as a\nBrucellosis-free country, hopefully to remain so thanks to the adopted\ncontrol and eradication steps.\nVaccination of cattle against _B. abortus_ is prohibited in all EU member\ncountries.\nData on the infectivity of _B. abortus_ in animal products have been\nincluded in the moderator's comments to posting 20020905.5234. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "According to the provisions of OIE's International Animal Health Code, a\ncountry may be regarded as free of Bovine Brucellosis if its entire cattle\npopulation is under official veterinary control, it has been ascertained\nthat the rate of brucellosis infection does not exceed 0.2 percent of the\ncattle herds, vaccination is not allowed, and prescribed surveillance is\noperational. Foster, K.L. Jahans, R.J. Reid, H.M. Ross\nABSTRACT\nBrucella organisms which differed from the recognised species of the genus,\nwere isolated from nine seals, eight cetaceans and one otter. A method is\ndescribed for the isolation of Brucella species from sea mammals and the\nfirst isolations of Brucella species are recorded from an Atlantic\nwhite-sided dolphin (Lagenorhynchus acutus), two striped dolphins (Stenella\ncoeruleoalba), a hooded seal (Cystophora cristata), a grey seal (Halichoerus\ngrypus) and a European otter (Lutra lutra). There were differences in the\nculture media required for the primary isolation of the organisms and in\ntheir dependency on carbon dioxide. Subcutaneous lesions, when present,\nalways yielded a confluent growth. The organisms were isolated from seven\nof 14 spleen samples and also from the mammary glands, uterus, testes and\nblood and the mandibular, gastric, iliac, sub-lumbar and colorectal lymph\nnodes.\n(9 Refs.)\n---\nPete Blathwayt\npeteb@easynet.co.uk\n......................................................................mhj\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This is the first\ntime we face this problem.\nThis is a community of 17 families (approximately 40 adults and 50\nchildren) that live in a condominium in northern Santiago, Chile. A month\nago, 2 dogs in one household became sick and [were] taken to the\nveterinarian. After a few lab tests and physical examination they\ndiagnosed brucellosis, as serological tests for _Brucella canis_ were\npositive. The veterinary recommendation, which actually was followed, was\nto sacrifice the dogs.\nFurther testing of 16 dogs living in the community showed 10 of them\npositive for _Brucella canis_. There have been no cases of adults or\nchildren presenting with symptoms that could suggest brucellosis; however\nthere is a big concern among families about children contracting the\ndisease considering the close contact they usually have with them.\nWe would appreciate input on how to manage this problem, estimation of risk\nfor humans, need of serological testing for humans contacts, advice on what\nto do (treatment, evaluation, follow up) with serologically positive but\nasymptomatic dogs and recommendations for further investigation of the\noutbreak.\n[It is very important to distinguish the genus and species causing human\nbrucellosis to evaluate the risk. Human infections due to _Brucella\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ (originating with farm animals) can\nbe severe and require strict measures for control. Although I must admit I\nam not up to date on this subject, some time ago cases of _B. canis_ in\nhumans were rare, only 15 cases (8 of them originating in the laboratory)\nbetween discovery of the organism in 1966 and 1979, when LE Carmichael\nwrote his section in Jim Steele's CRC Handbook of the Zoonoses. More\nimportantly _B. canis_ caused a mild human disease which is easily\ntreatable with tetracycline. The disease was originally reported in kennel\ndogs and control consisted of removing infected animals from the kennel.\nInfected individuals can be identified with serological and bacteriological\ntests. More definitive comments from anyone who has substantial experience\nin such situations would be appreciated.\nIt appears that the condominium dog population may be large enough to\nsupport ongoing transmission. I wonder if the condominium housing pattern\nallowed a large enough population of dogs to live in close proximity and\ntherefore provide _B. canis_ with a new environment to exploit. - Mod.PC]\n--\nPablo Agustin Vial\nAssociate Professor\nUniversidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine\nand Center for Medical Research.\n......................................pc/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
